ceviche - looked more like guacamole than what i've had of ceviche but it still tasted really good. they give you 7 whole shrimps and was loaded w/ fresh avocados.  Oh and they also give you tortilla chips so you can eat it w/ the ceviche.

mixed basket & chips: fish, coconut shrimp, oysters w/ sweet potato fries. Everything was fresh and were lightly battered which i like. The fish was cooked perfectly for deep fried fish. Normally at other places, i get this heavily battered fish where the meat doesn't flake off, it's just one hard and dry piece of fish. here it was still soft and flaky. The coconut shrimp was delicious in taste, i only wish it was bigger shrimp. The oyster was pretty good. The sweet potato fries was really good too - perfectly crisp and lightly salted. 

service was great! we had told them beforehand that we were going to  share the appetizer and the mixed basket. They divided the basket for us which made it easier for us to eat since we now have our own basket of food. And instead of giving us 3 oysters total.. we got 4 (2 for each of us). And we each have our own plate of cole slaw and fries! 


yes, i'd come back here again. And it's walking distance from california academy of sciences - perfect place to grab lunch during your visit at CAS or dinner after you visit the CAS
author: Cherie T.

description:
For the 2nd time, our friends tried to take us to a restaurant in the neighborhood  and it was closed.  So, we ended up by chance at Pacific Catch.  Our waiter was horribly slow.  It took him forever to take our orders.  We were all speculating that he was a laid off from a previous job as he didn't seem to have a handle on things.  Hubby even witnessed a younger waitress go up and punch in her orders while our waiter was still prodding along with his order on the computer.

The signature miso is to be avoided, $2.95.  We liked the Cabo Calamari which was fried and spicy, $8.95.  My fried oyster basket, $13.95 was too oily and the oysters were not firm.  Hubby and BFF's hubby had the Ahi 3 ways, $17.95, which they both liked.  Portions are filling and BFF's hubby tried the Mochi Fondue.  It was mochi balls filled with ice cream (you can buy these at Safeway nowadays), cut into quarters and served with a ramekin of hot chocolate dipping sauce.  It was OK, $5.95.  The other odd thing the waiter did was he gave BFF & her hubby their iced teas and an additional glass of ice for "refills".  In the end, the ice all melted into water and he had to go get them a fresh glass of iced tea with fresh ice.  Go figure.
author: Ry T.

description:
Today was the fourth time I've eaten here in the past couple of years. It really brought home how jaded we become in San Francisco with so many good places to eat - and especially in that neighborhood.

A friend from Mendocino was here to see the Musee d'Orsay exhibit at the De Young. We came here for lunch and she loved the food, the menu, the staff, the location, the neighborhood. Well duh, I'm just accustomed to it and my waist shows it! 

The French-fried sweet potatoes are the best anywhere and I eat them all over town. Sparse amounts of sea salt added after cooking adds to their appeal. The thin cut, crispness, and everything about them are good. I ordered fish & chips which felt appropriate somehow for a Saturday. The fish is the best I've had outside Oldham, England - cooked perfectly, flaky, and the batter crisped to perfection with no trace of uncooked batter inside. Bubba likes!

Pacific Catch is a consistently good restaurant set amidst a sea of great places to eat. It's location is an added bonus  that allows an alternative to the museum cafeteria and warrants being a destination on its own.
author: Larry R.

description:
This is the TGIFridays/Bennigans/AppleBee's of San Francisco! Perfect atmosphere if you have 3 children who want to bang chopsticks on the table for 1 hour! Perhaps you have a kid who wants to throw french fries on the ground? Or maybe your children just love to be kids, singing, yelling, running around a restaurant? Well, THIS is the place for YOU! 

Every staff member we encountered was great. No complaints. 

Everything on the menu sounded sooo good! The food and the presentation were both a huge letdown. They serve some of their dishes in a paper lined metal basket. The sweet potato fries were soggy, but our waiter kindly and quickly brought us a fresh order. The $19 miso cod was bleh. The ahi poke was the saltiest dish ever.

The place is HUGE and loud. Not a good place for a date night. This felt like a good hang out joint for 16 year olds, and 4 year olds. 

Sorry!
author: Amy J.

description:
Ok I need to update my review
Sweet potato fries - definitely worth it.. 

Sushi - pretty gross.. AND yes i know this isnt a sushi place so what was I thinking.. I am now telling myself. What were you thinking!

note to self.. fries - yes.. sushi - never!

Takeout service was pretty lame. My bag was waiting in the kitchen forever.. I watched it, thankfully my blood sugar wasn't low!
author: Monica S.

description:
This place is fine. Would I go out of my way to come here again? Probably not.
     Although very clean, the decor reminded me of what I'd expect at Applebee's. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it screamed restaurant chain.
     The food itself wasn't bad. The crispy baja fish tacos were quite tasty. THe fish wasn't particularly flavorful, but it was cooked well. The crispy shrimp tacos were also delicious. The cabbage, salsa, and jalapeno tartar all tasted fresh and added both taste and texture.
     The ono taco wasn't as good. The fish was well seasoned, but it was dried out. It makes me wonder if the other dishes were good because it was battered and deep fried. (its always the case)
     I would probably like this place more if it was more affordable. Getting mediocre food and paying more than you would expect makes me think elsewhere when I'm hungry for lunch.
author: Siao W.

description:
This place is very Yummy! I usually don't like raw fish but the Hawaiian Poke is wonderful! Weather you get it in a salad or a sushi roll it is very good with great flavor! 

I used to come here since this was the only place way back when that had sweet potato fries. Since everyone has them now it isn't as fun however I must say this is the best place still compared to everywhere I have tried them! 

The island tacos are very tasty as well! Not very big but still great. But the reason why i love it here is for the JAPANESE WASABI RICE BOWLS! (wakame salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, cucumber, ginger, sesame seeds, shredded nori & soy-wasabi sauce). I was here about two months ago and I see they changed and added some new rice bowls but I haven't tried them yet. These are very filling and you will for sure have something to take home with you for later if that is what you are looking for. 

Also if you likes sweets you cant leave this place without trying their Fried Dulce de Leche "Spring Rolls" (vanilla ice cream & caramel sauce). OMG TO DIE FOR! It is not a huge dessert and since it tastes so great it is NOT FOR SHARING! lol 

Definitely a good place to eat...
author: Michelle B.

description: Absolutely love their Japanese Wasabi Bowl!!! Everytime I pass by here on my way home on the 71 I debate getting off and eating one. Edamame is also excellent and nice strong cocktails too. Service has been pretty good all the times I've been.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
I was introduced to this place a couple of years ago when we attended a graduation celebration here. Since then I haven't had a chance to make it back here until recently and I'm so glad I did. 

After running B2B, we were trying to decide where to eat and since I've been talking about wanting to go back here for I don't know how long, the rest of my group decided to accomodate my request. 

We got there right at 11am when it opened which was perfect since we were able to find parking in the small lot next to the restaurant for customers and we were seated in a nice table next to the window where we could see peopel walkby in their costumes.

For lunch we had:
- Ahi tuna poke (starter) served with wonton chips- super fresh and just as tasty as I remember. I could probably eat a whole serving of this myself
- Sushi grade ahi salad- seared ahi, avocado, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds with soy-wasabi vinaigrette- delicious and fresh it was a perfect meal after a run
- Cabo shrimp taco- crispy shrimp with pico de gallo, avocado, jalapeño tartar & lime crema- huge shrimp, lightly battered and super tasty. 
- Monthly special: Some fish that starts with an e that I can't remember, but it had some spice rub on it, served with some green sauce, sweet potato fries and grilled zucchini, peppers and corn.
- Dessert: Mochi fondue- came with 3 type of mochi- chocolate, vanilla and coffee with a warm fudge in the middle- yummy!! 

Everything was fantastic. If I lived in SF or if my office was remotely close to this restaurant,  I would probably be here a lot more. Service was also super friendly and I appreciate our server for putting up with my endless requests for tea (it was freezing outside!). What can I say, I love this place and am looking forward to coming back to try more dishes from their menu.
author: Nadia L.

description: Just left pacific catches happy hour, and couldn't have been more pleased. The bartender Grayson made all the difference, his perfectly made whiskey sour made my evening. I have been to pacific catch many times and their appetizing food keeps me coming back. Tonight's service stood out though, thanks to Grayson's outstanding attentiveness. I often order whiskey sour but this one was perfectly balanced and I must say it was the best I've tasted. Thank you, Grayson for an enjoyable experience, keep up the excellence. Did I mention that it only cost me $4.50 :P  love it!!
author: Sylvia R.

description:
Oh, Pacific Catch....I've loved you for so long. The only problem is that I never order anything new. But I guess that's the definition of comfort food, right?

This was my first visit to this location.  The seared ahi wasabi bowl is my meal of choice...and always stellar. Today I paid careful attention to the menu because I'm trying to pay careful attention to my figure...(I know - the wasabi sauce has got to be really bad for me somehow) and discovered that not only could I substitute the white rice for brown rice, but I could also substitute half of THAT for lettuce. Bonus! I can eat the whole thing and not be the complete pig I want to be. And let me tell you, I'm not a brown rice fan, but this stuff was delicious. Anyway, the bad news was the fish. When getting the seared ahi on top, I'm used to maybe part of a piece or two being a little too fibrousy-chewy. Unfortunately, this time, Only a piece or two was NOT too yucky to eat. Believe me, I didn't leave behind much of anything else, so when I let the server know that was the case (pretty obvious since all the fish was leftover), he deducted $4 off the tab. And believe me, I let him know he didn't really have to do that. But that's good service right there and saved them a star. But you know I can't give you 5 stars when your name is Pacific Catch, and the catch in my bowl can't be eaten, right?

There is no question - I will be back either to this location or the Chestnut St. one. I know they'll figure it out and not do that to me again....right?
author: Laurie H.

description: Service was excellent, but a bit of a wait because so few seats at table and bar.  Hawaiian Teriyaki rice bowl was very good and would order again.
author: Gerald H.

description:
Have been coming here many times over the past 2 years. Generally consistent food and service, and great for meeting up with people. 

Nice to have a menu that crosses multiple cuisines and tends to satisfy most tastes. M-F, there is also a nice happy hour, which is also offered 10pm to closing.

Recent highlights include the Peruvian Ceviche - super delicious! And,  the Let's Get Saucy roll (spicy salmon and albacore).  

Definitely a place to go back again! and again!
author: MandS R.

description: Great food, decent price. Go after a trip to Golden Gate Park or for dinner with friends. Can get very busy so check ahead of time if you can get a table!
author: Steve L.

description:
Came here after Fan Fest for some non-ballpark food.  We'd never been to the Chestnut location, and this is just too close to home to pass up.  It was crab season, so there was a slew of extra crab items on the menu.  I had the crab melt, and it was something kind of awesome.  Well, I actually split it with my sister, who had the crab chowder (bisque? well soup something).  Either way, we both agreed that the crab melt was SO much superior than the soup!  Her friend from England had the fish and chips.  She said they were "ok."  Sandra got shrimp tacos.  I think she also liked the crab melt better!  

Sweet potato fries and ceviche were both pretty good, too.  The order of ceviche was kind of small.  Probably should stick to the Mission for ceviche!  

We'd probably walk over here again, but only during crab season!
author: ROB L.

description:
I've been avoiding this place since it took over the old coffee shop (the first I ever went to in SF), until I found discount gift cards at Costco (2 $50 gc for $75 total.

It's kind of like a pan-Asian version of Cheesecake factory (or maybe a sushi-ish version of PF Changs?) . Lot's of white people, which is not really a commentary as much as it was an observation. Standardized seafood with an Asian twist, cooked to a perfectly executed corporate formula.  I'm not saying it's bad or that I'm even above it -- I enjoy food like this from time to time.
author: Sabine S.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in SF. 

The best meal I've had here is the Cedar Plank Salmon slathered in a blackberry chutney. Mmm... Amazing. It comes with a grilled corn on the cob, and potato fingerlings which I can only assume were seasoned with marsala. (This is a special and is only available during certain times of the year.)

The best dessert I've had here is the Dulce de Leche Spring Roll. It's one of my all-time favorites. However it can be a bit rich and is best split between two people.

 Several other dishes I highly suggest:

-Thai Coconut Shrimp (amazing starter)
-Salmon Sandwich
-Firecracker Salmon Roll

They usually offer a few exotic beers, and if you're looking for a drink that packs a punch go with the Pacific Catch Mai Tai, if you drink more than one I suggest you catch a cab.

The only downfall here is that the service can become a bit hectic. They seem to be understaffed at times, but during a weekday afternoon there's never a problem. 

Eat on,
James
author: James B.

description:
We stopped in one Sunday night early evening to try this place out. 

If you've ever been to this location, you know parking is insane in this hood so we tried the Pacific Catch parking lot. All spots were full in the lot (except for the "handicapped" spot) so we pulled over on the side of the lot and waited for a few minutes, hoping to get lucky.

A few moments later, a large Lexus SUV rolled in with the license ------- and backed into the handicapped spot. We thought "well, at least someone deserving got the spot" but there were no HC placards noticeable. 

Out jumped an older couple, and their small children. As were looking over in there direction, a 50ish blonde woman came over from the SUV and looked at our car.

"Is there a problem" she said, in a defiant snotty tone.

"I guess not as long as you are handicapped" I said.

"We're the owners", she snorted, her botox straining to fill out her forehead, then she stormed off.

Now if I owned this particular location, I would be a little nicer to a possible customer. What a b*tch.

We got a parking spot and went in anyway. The food was mediocre. However, our server whose name was "Lara" was bright, pleasant and fast - for her the place gets one star. Otherwise, ZERO.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note: I was contacted by Pacific Catch after this review was posted and I was told that the person misrepresented themselves as the owner, and Pacific Catch also apologized. Ok, back to 3 stars for Pacific Catch thanks to a professional contact person.
author: Zig Z.

description: Great Poke. We went here on a double date and it was a perfect place a little nicer than your average casual dinning. My BF is a picky eater and he found something he could enjoy while the rest of us had interesting and slightly unusual dishes. We were most impressed with the coffee, you get your own little French press with 3 cups.
author: Molly M.

description:
Wonderful food that I'll call "elegant casual." 

The chips were a tad too spicy but the fish was plump and juicy, lightly fried just right.  The Vietnamese-style shrimp sandwich was fantastic, and the sesame-coleslaw sides balanced in flavor and texture.  The service was friendly, not overbearing, and attentive (mind you, we were here during lunch hour not dinner hour), and the ambiance of the space light and refreshing.  

We had not been there since its coffee-shop days, and regret we procrastinated too long before returning!
author: Jim W.

description: Here we are....Friday night, traffic is horrendous and we are hungry as hell...went for a walk in a park and decided to stop in for a drink and poke. As always, everything is fresh, service is wonderful and and kids enjoyed themselves. Highly recommend brown rice bawl with either fish or chicken, sunrise roll and Hawaiian poke. Yum!
author: Abe L.

description:
The thought of Pan-Asian or Asian Fusion anything kind of scares me...especially since one should NEVER go to the Marina hungry for Korean food. But the rice bowls at Pacific Catch were surprisingly tasty and split-able! Good if you're looking for a quick dinner with a friend.

The real reason I'm a fan: The Dulce de Leche "Spring Rolls". 

Wtf? Why are they called spring rolls? Ugh, besides the Asian Fusion BS, the taste of this dessert is amazing! Friend dulce de leche with vanilla ice cream & caramel sauce is the reason I'll be returning!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I'm not quite sure if I enjoyed Pacific Catch simply because I had just returned to the US after being abroad for a year and I was looking at the American world through rose-colored glasses...or if it really is a great place. 

My boyfriend took me here for happy hour and I was delighted to have the Hawaiian Poke since I've been craving something fresh and you can't get any fresher than raw fish done right. It was the perfect intro to Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences, which is walking distance from the restaurant.
author: Myra A.

description:
I've been to Pacific Catch many times before and this was my second bad experience. The first time I had the Tropical Shrimp Tacos, they didn't sit well with me. The shrimps didn't taste fresh at all!!!! 
This second time. I didn't make a reservation, so we had to wait about 30 min (which wasn't bad at all). I usually make one on OpenTable.com but this was a last min trip. 

We were seated and it took forever for out waitress to come to our table.  We didn't order Alcohol (although their mojitos are good). But it took her forever to get our drinks. We started off with Calamari, and it was tasty, I've had better, but it wasn't gross. 

My friend and I both got tacos. First it took about 45 min to get our food from the time we ordered it. Not only that, she came back to ask us what we had ordered. Which makes me think she didn't put it in or just forgot. When we got our food, it looked BLAH. I had the Shrimp Spicy Tacos, and there were nasty. Tasteless and the cabbage, wasn't fresh. I could barely eat one. 
Our waitress walked by and saw that we weren't eating our food but didn't ask us anything. Finally we just asked for the check. She asked us if we wanted boxes and we said no. At this point we were so annoyed complaining wasn't even worth it. But she got her manager and our food was comped. She asked us if we wanted anything else, but knowing it'd take another 45 min it wasn't worth it.
author: Irma R.

description:
I used to grub at the Marina location once a month, but since they established the Sunset location, I was ecstatic as there is parking lot, more spacious, and no long lines.  

The highlights are the Wasabi Brown Rice Bowls (Usually get the Hawaiian Poke), the Fish Tacos (whatever is the special fish of the day), and the Sweet Potato Fries. The dipping sauces are such a great complement. 

Ambiance is definitely more airy than the Marina joint and the decor has a contemporary feel. 

Prices are reasonable for its generous portions. 

Staff is always friendly and don't make you wait to long to place an order, ask for stuff, or get you the bill. 

Can't wait for my next trip here...
author: Dee T.

description: I love this place.... But I way prefer the Peruvian ceviche with whitefish over scallops... The spicy pacific martini is amazing !!!! The bartender Liz recommended it and I'm soooo glad she did.  I love to come here for happy hour!
author: Julie B.

description:
I was the first to arrive for a birthday party of 13, 15 minutes before the reservation. Upon checking in, the hostess took my box of a dozen cupcakes back for me without me having to ask. 

We had calamari, California rolls and fried shrimp rolls for appetizers. All were really tasty. I can't even remember the last time I've had a California roll with real crab. When you order the calamari, watch out for the slices of fried lemon! 

Dinner went smoothly without any mixed up orders. The birthday girl's grandmother ordered salmon cakes and wasn't very happy with her order, but everyone else seemed satisfied. I had the Mixed Catch Basket ($13.95)- it's a lot of food. In order of preference, 1. fish 2. oysters 3. coconut shrimp. The sweet potato fries were abundant, too. 

Later, they served the cupcakes on plates with spoons to everyone and it was really nice.

I think if I were to come here again, I'd order calamari and a side of sweet potato fries for dinner.

PS- They have disposable chopsticks here, and if you use a pair for appetizers, the waiter will take them away with your plate, and you have to open a new pair of chopsticks for your entree. Am I the only one who thinks this is super wasteful? I don't mean to go all Avatar on you (I haven't even seen it), but think of the trees!
author: Amy D.

description: I haven't been a fan for a while now. So I decided to give it a second chance.... It passed! The bar is the place to sit tho..... Great service ! food was ok..... drinks were great tho.
author: Ray C.

description: After visiting my cousin at UCSF Medical Hospital, we took a nice walk down a few blocks and came across this place.  Food was good.  Service was ay ok.
author: Kat N.

description:
So I've been wanting to try this place since I always pass by it.  Finally my boyfriend's sister was having her going away party here (she was moving to Paris).  So they basically ordered a bunch of happy hour foods and had tables all set up with all the foods near the bar.  Smart idea, and very nice of them to accommodate for us.  

Their specialty drinks are quite delicious, I attempted to try all of them that day and that didn't turn out well =X.  Their poke salad was delicious, but I recommend eating it when you get it.  We had a couple orders of it, so it was just sitting out there ... on our table ... in the sun ... and well, if you don't get the picture, i ended up a bit sick that night.  Their rolls are good as well, but a bit americanized if you ask me.

The place has a great feel to it.  The bartenders, I loved ... and their staff was good as well.

The next time I came back after that was during happy hour which was pretty great.  We got a couple rolls, edemame, etc -- all fantastic.  Something I didn't get to try though were their fries, darnnit!  Next time, next time ...
author: Pia V.

description:
I've been here three times in the past 13 months.  The first two times were last summer, 2010, with the most recent being yesterday.  The first two times, I became infatuated with their Japanese Wasabi 'Asian Bowl' with Hawaiian Poke.  Ordered sushi rice both times over brown rice and loved the combination of flavors with the added zing of the wasabi.  The bowl seems a little on the pricey side until you get it and it's huge and filling.  Forgot to mention to start out with the sweet potato fries, which are probably the best I've ever had.   

My only gripe about this place came yesterday, when my party was among the handful of tables here but had to wait to be seated, wait to make our orders, and on top of that, the waiter messed up on everything.  I think he was trying to be cool and memorize our order (not too hard because we only ordered three things), but my bowl came out with brown rice instead of sushi rice, and halfway through the meal we figured out we wouldn't be getting our sweet potato fries.  I'm guessing the manager came out and took over our table because of the multiple errors and comped our fries.

All in all, whether it was the poor service or just my overdue, over-hyped expectation, my bowl was not as great as last year.  Sad to say, this experience ruined this place a little for me which is too bad because the place is a nice place to eat.  Also, my silverware was dirty and that's unacceptable when you're charging $40+ for lunch.
author: Kuishinbo E.

description:
So I've spent most of my college and all of my post college time in The City frequenting establishments in the 9th and Irving area.  I took my kid brother to Fireside for his first (legal) beer, tasted Indian food for the first time at Naan-n-Curry when I was but a wee sophomore at SF State, and fell in love with BJ's on the Bayou (and subsequently had my still beating heart ripped from my chest when it closed down).

In my opinion this is the highest concentration of great and diverse food anywhere in the city (yeah, I know the Mission gives it a run for its money, but I don't like stepping in dog and hobo shit on my way to dinner, so quit being a smartass).  The only problem with the area (ya know, besides parking) is that once I get down here I'm like a kid in a candy shop with only a buck; I have so many great things to choose from and it's hard to decide which is going to win.  

Well, by way of finally getting to a review, my first trip to Pacific Catch just made my decision of where to go when I'm in the area that much harder.  

I came by for their happy hour at the bar.  The drink deals were solid (like 3.50 for draft) and the bar food (in this case, delicious, delicious coconut shrimp) were discounted, as well.  I'll admit that I wasn't terribly in love with the beer selection (I'm not much for IPA's and this bar favors them, so bully for you if you're into hoppy beer), but their whiskey and scotch selection was very impressive (great range of tastes, flavors, and countries from what I could see) and they weren't slouches in the gin department (ya know, if you're like me and you sometimes want to drink something that tastes vaguely antiseptic).

I was also really liking the decoration and flow of the place: clean and sleek.  The service was solid, I experienced two bartenders and both left positive impressions.

The pricing was consistent with what I'd expect from it (it doesn't look or act like a greasy spoon, so it wasn't cheap like a greasy spoon).

All in all, I expect to find myself back here soon.  Nicely done.
author: Matt R.

description:
This place is awesome... i love going to the Marina to eat.  This place is a gem.  I haven't had everything on the menu...but if anything I will definately go back for the Fried Oysters and the sweet potato fries.YUM... 
And the people are nice too..
author: Jamie B.

description:
This is going to piss of John T., I know it.

I don't really like this place.  I thought, when I first went there, that it was a dos coyotes (http://www.yelp.com/biz/dos-coyotes-sacramento) of seafood. I got a deece sando, mahi or whatever fish bullshit, and some sweet potato fries.  Those were damn good, but so is bacon every time you eat it.  

Beyond that, fuck it.  Location speaks for itself: it's designed to capture tourists from the science museums that want seafood because they're in San Francisco...  when does that EVER lead you in the right direction?  In-N-Out, that's where.  But besides that, this place is low on the list.  Tried the martinis during happy hour.  4 dollars or something real cheap, but it's shitty booze, and the better shit is ~$3 more than it should be.

AND THEY RAN OUT OF FISH AND CHIPS AT OUTSIDE LANDS AT 5PM.
author: Michael P.

description:
This review is for the BAR area ONLY.

We stopped in for a bloody mary after an afternoon in the park.  There were hardly any other customers and a bunch of open tables so we had ourselves a seat.  The servers and the bartender pretty much ignored us so my boyfriend walked up to the bar and ordered for us after waiting for about 10 mins.  There were two sorta d-bag looking dudes that the bartender and server were doting on and literally walked right past us as if we were not there.  Plus, the bloody mary's had too much wasabi in them.  

Boo.
author: Nat O.

description:
The family suggested this place for lunch, so we came here after finding some hard-earned street parking down several blocks away. Parking meters and their wretched quarter-gulping system... damn you! That's one thing that I hate, not enjoying a meal because you're worried if you're parking meter will run out of time. 

I'm a big seafood fan, especially fish or shrimp, so I had a tough time choosing what to eat. I finally settled on the shrimp and salmon tacos, which comes with a side of sweet potato fries. I thought everything tasted okay, fresh, crispy and not-soggy fries. Everyone else in the party seemed to enjoy their fish entrees. 

The problem is, living down in SoCal, there's a restaurant called California Fish Grill that's very similar to this place. Decent quality food, a plethora of choices, and a wide variety. Not quite the "Asian-fusion" vibe or waiter service, but comparable. The major difference is that Cali Fish Grill is very inexpensive compared to Pacific Catch. 

Our bill at Pacific Catch including tip was over $80, which I thought was very overpriced. Then again, there was nothing to complain about with the food. Perusing the reviews, it seems like Happy Hour is where it's at for the best deals. With all the other seafood choices in SF, I don't think I'd be returning again.
author: Dru C.

description: Overdue review. This is one of my favorite spots!  The space is comfortable and the staff members are always so nice, especially to my toddler! The food is always fresh and consistent. Came here last with a party of 9 (3 kids under 4 yrs old).  It was busy dinner time on Sunday and for whatever reason, the wait for entrees was unusually long. The manager and waitress came by often to check on us and apologize for the long wait. I think they were worried about the kids. But, it's so comfortable there it was not an issue. They gave the kids chalk and chalkboards to play with too. Once we got our entrees they kept checking on us and then didnt charge us for our desserts to make up for the wait.  Love the rice bowls and tacos. Love coming here early on Fridays for dinner. I'll keep coming back!
author: Amy H.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants. They have very high quality fish, an attentive wait staff who remember me, and interesting choices in food.

My particular favorite is the Pan-Asian bowl, with Ahi tuna (the poke is also good), with half rice and half salad. Healthy, tasty, and affordable (as seafood goes). I also love their fish and chips.
author: Rio S.

description:
Came here for happy hour right after thursday nightlife. It seemed this place was understaffed as only 2 waiters and a busboy was serving the entire restaurant and took them at least 10 mins to get our tables cleaned and ready from the previous customers. When we were finally seated, we ordered sweet potato fries, calamari, lets get saucy sushi roll, and coconut shrimp. 

The calamari was decent and came with a wasabi/horseradish sauce and a sweet, sour, and spicy sauce. This was probably the best appetizer dish on the happy hour menu. The sweet potatoe fries were nothing special but a little soggy and less crispy then I expected. The lets get saucy roll was very tasty and I would recommend it.  The coconut shrimp was nothing special but if you like shrimp its decent enough to warrant a order. I also got the Kona Longboard Lager which  was light and slightly more flavorful then bud or coors.

Overall its a decent place for happy hour, especially after nightlife since its a 5 min walk; although the service was subpar due to understaffing. I might come back here again but probably just for happy hour as the rest of the menu is quite expensive and I hear its also smalled portioned.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Sometimes I just want some fish. Not make some fish, but have fish that someone else made for me (preferably by a chef) without going to a fancy restaurant and paying a lot for it because i'm really at a steak restaurant with 2 Michelin stars and they just happen to have fish. It's affordable and not smelly gross fish like they have at Applebees. 

Also you get a choice of sweet potato fries or regular fries or other stuff. I've never been to a place where sweet potato fries is an option, usually you have to pay extra and you get a giant basket that's meant for 4 people to share. This makes me happy. Everything is good, service is great, and well priced. Never had a bad meal here.
author: Catface G.

description:
I go to the 9th Ave location for lunch, usually on Tuesdays when they have the Ahi salad on special. It is perfectly prepared, very reasonably priced and the meal includes a drink-out the door under $20 in San Francisco is rare.  
Also excellent is the California crab salad.  Waiters are friendly and attentive, service is efficient.
author: Chris B.

description: The fish selection is pretty limited and it gets really loud when it's busy.  I usually come here for their seared ahi-tuna salad over rice.  What I like about their dishes is that they always gives you lots of vegetables and more rice than is fashionable these days.  It's hard to finish the entire bowl, especially if you include all that rice.  What is disappointing is their other dishes that are Asian-based, such as their Salmon Teriyaki, fall below the standards of your average Japanese restaurant in the city.  Still, I give this restaurant credit for giving decent sized portions of fresh vegetables with most of their orders.  Their vegetables are fresh, and usually cooked firm.
author: Robert C.

description:
Reunited at last. The last time I had good sweet potato fries was back in LA at Father's Office.  Coming here was a must once I knew we were going to the Academy Arts & Sciences Nightlife.  For $12 bucks, you can get a savory BBQ Salmon Sandwich with a generous helping of orange goodness.  To top it off, the two extra sauces (sweet spicy & wasabi aioli) makes everything that much better.  Although I haven't tried their tacos, but judging from the silence at the table I figured it was DAMN good.

I'll be back soon to try their bowls.  I don't think you can go wrong at this restaurant, it's definitely a "CATCH". =)
author: Alexander H.

description: This place was pretty spectacular and I would definitely go again. I got the fish and chips and I appreciated that they had three different options for fries- regular, spicy, and sweet potato. My boyfriend got the fish tacos and those were great too!
author: Blake Y.

description: The menu is geared a bit towards the hipsters. There really isn't enough of a selection of standards, lots of wasabi and trendy stuff. That keeps it from being a four. It's kind of a seafood chipotle to me. Three stars plus, no way is it the five star place I've seen in these postings.  It is good though, I would come back .
author: dave d.

description: Back when I was living in San Francisco, this was my favorite restaurant. It's a seafood restaurant, but it also has an Asian Fusion feel to the menu. From grilled fish, to Asian rice bowls and fish and chips, you really can't do wrong here. My personal favorite thing is there California Grill Style with the fish of the day, and the lemon confit. It's to die for, and always satisfies me. Another bonus is their sushi here is delicious, and always fresh. Quick tip: if you're going on the weekend, make a reservation!
author: Leah N.

description:
Pacific Catch has totally redeemed itself. I was there with a friend the other night at the Marin restaurant and they have added a bar which looks fabulous and really breaks up the room in a good way. The wait staff was really spot-on energetic and helpful. 
Of course the food was perfect, I usually order the poke salad bowl and my friend had a sushi roll plate that was divine. Loved everything. 
The edamame is still a little bland, but oh well. Just waited for my salad and had a glass of wine. 
Didn't try the calamari like we usually do, but who needs deep fried with a salad ?

Great changes and upgrades. Love it!
Thanks Pacific Catch and thanks management for all the attention to comments. 
Nice to know someone is listening.
author: Lanie D.

description: Poke salad was an excellent main course. One of the best entree salads in recent memory. Dressing was slightly sweet and complimented the mixed greens. The kids loved their chicken soft tacos and terriakki salmon bowl. Service was slightly slow but the place was moderately busy. Staff was friendly.
author: Michael G.

description: I love Pacific Catch especially the pacific steak tacos... mmm yummy. Great service and very accommodating.
author: Audra H.

description:
Pan-Asian Rice Bowls...Pan-Asian Rice Bowls! Woo Hoo!

My boyfriend came to visit San Francisco, and had a taste for some fish. Since it was pouring raining, and we were visiting Golden Gate Park, we decided to go to Pacific Catch, because it was close. However, we weren't dissapointed. 

I had the Japanese Wasabi with seared ahi! *rubs tummy*   He had something with salmon...I believe it was a sandwich, and those french fries were good. 

Our waitress was cool and I liked how she was able to recommend some wine for dinner. This place is alright with me!
author: Lauren H.

description:
I like this place but I like the one in court madera better.

Sushi rolls are the best here or their fresh catch of the day!

Calamari is done right here and the sauce is really awesome.

Food gets pricey here and the place is so large it sometimes feels a bit stagnant with all the room and if it's not that busy

Staff is nice and by now recognizes me.  

I stick with the sushi rolls and appetizers, I've gotten the rice bolls but they have never really done it for me.

Nice booze selection too and they have racer 5 on tap!
author: Diana D.

description: This place is legit for their seafood platters. My friends and I ordered fried calamari, peruvian ceviche, sweet potato fries, and platters of hawaiian poke. The dishes are soo fresh! I liked the fried battered lemons and the brown rice on my entree. The service was excellent, the atmosphere was relaxing, and the food is delicious! I would love to come back! A bit pricy but worth it!
author: Allister D.

description:
The goods:

Poke
Macadamia Tuna
Sweet Potato french fries

Those 3 items alone are reason enough to get me to eat here. Coming for happy hour is also a good idea. Finding parking is touch in this area so they get major brownie points for having a lot next door. However, parking across the street in the park isn't such a bad idea either. AFter stuffing your face, a short walk isn't a bad idea. Come here for no muss or fuss happy hour or dinner or if you're just feeling indecisive about what to eat.

Oh, and I really love the pretzal goldfish 'tizers. They were such delicious little buggers that I bought myself a bag of Goldfish pretzels at the grocery store.
author: Erin M.

description:
- nice & clean restaurant
- great location, across the street from the Golden Gate Park (if you can't find parking on Irving, try parking at the park and walk across the street)

Catch of the Day with sweet potato fries. It was good, but not great. The pineapple fried rice is awesome though! Sorry, not much help.
author: Roll N.

description:
Came here for the first time last wednesday for dinner. We ended up sitting in the bar so we could watch the bball game. The bartender was awesome. Let you taste beers if you weren't too sure about what you wanted, and made a damn good top shelf margarita!

We both ordered the 3-taco plate with side of sweet potato fries. Everything was delicious!. It was a bit hard to get waiters attention but only bc it was so busy at the time.
author: Nicole K.

description: Ok, last night we decided to give it another shot. Bad decision. We started off with two beers and an order of fried calamari. We were served a sad looking plate of dried up tasteless crumbs! This was not calamari. This was garbage! Feeling stupid and cheated by this place BF was not going to pay for this disappointment. We paid, got up and left. Really did not feel like ordering more food from a place that starts you off with a plate of nothing but oily crumbs. I hate to write bad reviews about a place I loved so dearly. It's gone down, way down.  Please make some improvements. Till then, I'll steal clear and warn all my friends about it. So sad.
author: Laurie P.

description: Went here with a large group and to the person, the entrées were wonderful. Decent portions, attentive service.
author: Scott F.

description: The calamari looked promising, with its lemon slices and peppers in the mix. But, it was too salty and too oily (yes, I know it's deep fried, but letting some more of the grease drip away before plating it would've been nice). At least the mai tai and the service was awesome.
author: Maximillian M.

description: As you can tell my prior review was mainly based on the customer service experience I had there.  Shortly after having written my review Charmin from their Marketing department actually cared enough to write me and follow up with my recent experience.  I thought that was thoughtful enough for me give them another chance.
author: Mac S.

description: Went there for my first time today for a late birthday lunch for me with a friend for happy hour. Sat at the bar and got promptly waited on. We ordered a steak taco, spicy tuna roll, and salmon poké. Our waitor recommended this seared ahi tuna taco that was sooooo good. He also recommended my friend this spicy margarita drink that had vodka, passionfruit juice & jalapeños in it. It was good but WAY too spicy for us lol. No harm though for happy hour since it was only like $4. I paired my food with the mai thai. *caution* it is very strong so be prepared lol. (I tend to like my drinks strong anyways but it was stronger than I expected. Basically took shots towards the bottom of the drink) The spicy tuna roll was indeed spicy but tolerable if you like spicy food and my poké was pretty good too. I saw some reviews of people getting sick or not liking theirs but so far I'm feeling fine. Overall a very good restaurant. Must try!
author: Andrea M.

description: was seated and served very quickly. ordered the 3 tacos. baja, mahi, and steak. all very good. the baja was my fave. the fish tasted very fresh. also, got the side salad instead of the fries, it was so good!
author: Brian B.

description: A good casual place to dine in the neighborhood. I went with my boyfriend and roommate for dinner on the early side and it was mostly families. They have a varied menu with options for everyone so it wasn't too hard to settle on something we all enjoyed. We just chose drinks from the local beer selection but they have a full bar with signature cocktails on the menu as well.
author: Katrina S.

description:
The miser-li-est combination in the world might be what is happening to me now.  One, I cannot help.  The other, I brought upon myself.

Being Asian (Chinese) and a Student.  Not just a fresh-faced co-ed.  Graduate school.  Professional.  Which means my metabolism can't run on ketchup packets and instant ramen anymore.  Neither can I pull all-nighters and still be coherent enough to be in public the next day.  

The Asian in me loves a good deal.  That's not so bad.  Until you find yourself at home, after a "great" shopping spree with 5 mismatched shoes, none of which are your size.  Just because it was on sale.  And SOMEONE you know must have that size feet.  Then, I look around to make sure that no one is looking.

The Student in me, hates it more and more each day.  Just last week, one of my classmates looked at her loan debt.  HOLY CRAP-O-LA, the amount we have to pay back is like a mortgage!  It's more than a mortgage!  This affirms my current trend of not going on the interwebs for anything productive.

And all this verbal garbage finally brings us to Pacific Catch.  They have a happy hour, which pleases me greatly.  They have food on their happy hour which pleases me even more.  The food includes hawaiian poke (yay raw raw raw fish!), california rolls (real crab, fake sushi), and fried calamari (i just can't get enough of this squiggly stuff).

However, the alcohols are still expensive.  I'm expecting something in the $5 a glass range.  But I think they are more along the $7/glass.  Maybe the rouge rough uncouth uncultured student in me has no idea that what they are really serving is the most delectable wine known to the inner sunset.  And if I can't tell, neither can my wallet.  Or my loan debts.  Oh god.  

To summarize, I would come here for the happy hour, and focus more on the food.  The portions are very generous, there is nothing dainty about it.  Because if you think about it, a roll still uses about 1/2 a cup of rice, which is as much rice as you should be eating in one sitting, you fatty globby sweaty smelly library-hugger.  I like to keep it high in protein with the hawaiian poke.  

Maybe I'll finally learn my lesson and just be content with 2 bar bites.  Do not let the judgmental eye of the waitress guilt you into ordering alcohol.  No, no, no!  You must pass your classes.  

Now, go.  And eat something.
author: Christina C.

description:
I have been to Pacific Catch many times and have enjoyed them very much.  In this particular review, however, I am going to focus on our New Years Eve dinner.

My husband and I opted not to make a big production for dinner the New Years.  Generally, we go downtown somewhere for a fancy-dress pricey prix fixe meal.  This year, that just wasn't our speed.  We wanted something nice but a little more low key and less expensive.

Because we always enjoy our meals there, we checked out Pacific Catch.  They too had a prix fixe choice but it was only $49 a couple.  I was certain I'd misread that but it really was $49 for two people.  We examined the options and decided to make a reservation.

When I told my friend about our plans, she and her beaux wanted to come along too.  So I called on Dec 28th praying I could make the change.  No Problem!  In fact, later that afternoon, I called and added another two to our party.  I was stunned.  No hassle.  No problem with two last minute changes. No "well, we can only fit you in at either 4:15 or 11:45pm" kind of b.s.  No B.S. at all.  

Between the price and the ease of changing reservations, I felt like it must be too good to be true.  What horrors could we expect?  I figured I'd hope for the best and see.

And so, the six of us arrived for our reservation, dressed only slightly better than casual.  We ordered a ton of food, cocktails and wine.  Everything was absolutely delightful from the easy parking, to the outstanding service, to the copious amounts of fresh seafood served with round after round of cocktails.  We had an absolutely great time.  

And then, then the time of reckoning came in the form of the check.  The six of us had ordered far more than allotted by our prix fixe menus.  I slowly opened the cover, afraid of the damage I thought we'd incurred. I was shocked!  It was under $300.  You could have knocked me over with a feather.

Pacific Catch, I am impressed!  A bunch of food snob-hipsters all thoroughly enjoyed our New Years dinner.  Your food and level of service was incredibly competitive and even better than many options that I've had downtown for much more money.  GREAT EXPERIENCE!
author: Amy A.

description:
Came here tonight for my friend's graduation dinner.

I ordered the triple taco mahi mahi platter for $14.50. The tacos were very good. The fish was hot and crispy and the flavors were all around delightful. The sweet potato fries however, unlike Helen V.'s review, were cold. 

The waitress was very friendly, even joking around with some of my friends and I. Although the price for the food was fair, it did not wow me to the point where finding parking was worth being a regular here.

However, they do have a happy hour menu and I probably will come back for that. Till then - Happy Dining!

Oh, and I found out one of the waitresses do not like spicy sauce, and no I was not hitting on her.
author: Dorian T.

description:
Like other reviewers have said, it took me a long while to try this restaurant. It does look like a big ol' chain-style seafood place from the outside and i still miss Canvas, the cafe that used to be in this location but took a deep dive in the dot com bust. The inside is nicely decorated and the layout is good considering how odd the floor plan is. (Canvas always seemed a little... lopsided.)

The bf and i wound up here because we wanted a restaurant that had both decent tequilla and small tapas-like plates. This was the only place that fit our specs and fancy that night in the Inner Sunset. I thought the food was good. Not spectacular but definitely yummy. I like that many cuisines styles are available: noodles, sushi rolls, seafood, Hawaiian, Americana. The sauces are a little heavy but i'd eat there again w/o hesitation. Pricing was reasonable. Probably better if you hit a happy hour.  

I'm giving this review 4 Stars instead of 3 Stars because I liked that the place looked very family friendly; a lot of the groups waiting to be seated had three generations. Also the dining area was roomy enough to space tables appropriately for families with young (= loud) kids. I don't have kids and we sat in the bar area but it's nice to see restaurants in SF that can accommodate families with kids. I guess having chain-style proportions has its pluses.
author: debbie r.

description:
Outdoor space with space heaters = dog-friendly. Yeah!
Service was a bit slow, but he was friendly enough. 
The spicy Pacific Catch Martini was AWESOME. Portions were huge though the salmon fish and chips wasn't as exciting as I hoped it would be. The sushi rolls and calamari were tasty!
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
service was really good, it was speedy!

tried the clam miso soup, not really a fan of miso soup, but this one changed my mind, it had the right amount of flavor and it wasnt like other places way too salty.

had the cabo shrimp tacos those were good, but the spicy chipolte chicken one was a bit on the dry side. the sweet potato fries it came with were so good.

my friend had the hawiian poke dish, the poke was so good here and it was fresh. it came with a tad too much rice though.

overall, i would come back here again, it was good!
author: Stella J.

description:
service is amazing. quick and to the point.. they're also great at recommending food for you to try if you're brave enough to take on the challenge.

HUGE seating area that includes booths, tables, and a bar. I love their "asian fusion" cusine which included hawaiian poke.

so.. Hawaiian poke wasabi bowl with extra nori. need i say more? The pictures got me drooling and when the food came out, i slaughtered it. 

the bf got fish and chips -- eh. fried fish isn't that amazing to begin with, but their spicy fries we're to die for. definitely order some type of fries with your meal because they're crunchy and flavorful.

last but definitely not least, i got 1 scoop of the salted caramel ice cream. it was creamy and deeeeelicious. BF killed it before i could finish savoring my first bite. :) although this was purchased somewhere else, it's great that they support other san francisco based businesses.
author: jennifer f.

description:
For lunch, we had the Ahi Tuna Sandwich ($10), the assorted seafood tacos ($15), and a brownie sundae ($7).  The ahi sandwich was excellent and I would definitely recommend it.  The seafood tacos were fair, but I would only get the shrimp again.  The sweet potato fries make an excellent combo!

The service was average, but we did manage to ask for a couple of refills of iced tea.
author: Rob R.

description: OMG, can't believe its been  5yrs since my last visit.  Wan't a fan 5 years ago, and tried again recently for a friends good bye lunch.  Impression were much better.  I had the assorted sashimi over rice and it tasted pretty good.  I will come back again to give more try.
author: Jasmin Y.

description: Delicious, delicious meal. Had it recommended to me while on a weekend trip and me and my fiancee loved it. The little appetizer of edamame and goldfish was different but a great idea. My bowl was excellent, the beer options were great and affordable, and if you check in on Foursquare you get a free dessert! Hint: get the dulce de leche spring rolls. You won't regret it.
author: Spenser D.

description: Went into the restaurant for some calamari with my aunt. This has been out go to place for the last 5 years because it is usually very good. Today was definitely not their day. The calamari tasted more like rubber bands rather than fresh seafood. My aunt specifically stated that it was the "the worst food ever". Won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Alissa G.

description:
Hawaiian Poke bowls! So good.

I'm over the atmosphere here. Some people may think it's upscale and nice, whatever. I would still eat the food if it were served from a taco truck in front. It's good, I'm just not one of those people that needs to be surrounded by an environment that makes me feel like I am underdressed (because I am.)

They serve Hawaiian beers here, so that is a plus.

The service can be hit or miss.  Sometimes it is great, sometimes avg, and other times (though rarely) it is mediocre.  By this I mean they can seem to just be annoyed with you coming in and bothering them.  Not every time, just once in a while, esp earlier in the day.  The poke and a Longboard make up for it, so until that goes downhill...
author: Tristan D.

description: Let me just start by saying that this used to be my favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset, but over the last few months things have changed. I used to LOVE the Hawaiian Poke. it was always fresh, had cucumber pieces and was simply delicious. The last 4-6 times I ordered it, it was a disappointment. The Tuna was not fresh, and one time the waitress said that "its just a different kind of tuna". I eat a lot of Poke, and  I just got back from Maui a few days ago so I know exactly how fresh tuna looks. Not sure if the chef changed, but the quality of this poke has definitely gone down. Maybe its the days I go when the tuna is not fresh? I dont know, but it doesn't make me want to go back as often and when I do I definitely dont order the poke anymore. the cucumber pieces really added flavor, and now its just plain. would love to see the quality improve so I can enjoy it again!
author: Tati M.

description: the poke was DELICIOUS! they have all kinds but I think my favorite is the macadamia nut poke... service was kind of slow and we got full after our appetizers because we waited too long for the rest of our meal. We told our server to cancel one of the items (fish taco) because we got full while waiting so long for the rest of our food. The manager came out and said that she would take it off of our bill but still brought it out to us for free anyways! Great customer service! and the fish taco was really good! :) will definitely be back to get more poke!!!
author: Karen K.

description:
Appetizer:
Ahi Tuna Poke - OK
Won Ton Chips were tasty, not bland for once

Entree:
Sturgeon with Sweet Potato Fries & Veggies
Nothing really special, a bit disappointed

The one star for our waiter being awesome! (Parker)
Gave us dessert on the house since we didnt really enjoy our food
Dulche De Leche Sping Rolls - The highlight of the whole meal!

I probably wont be coming back here...
author: Yan N.

description:
4 stars instead of 5 because you can't order the happy hour menu from the regular tables--only the bar.
I always get the poke/wasabi bowl with brown rice and salad. 
But last night I ordered the Shiso Fine roll. Delish!! I love shiso and this roll is a little sweet. So it satisfies my sweet tooth. 
All the cocktails are delish. My fave is the Agave Margarita on the rocks with salt.
The booths are large and great for kids. We had a 2-year-old who is wild and we have managed on many occasions to get through and entire meal.
author: Christy F.

description: Service was good and food wasn't too bad. We got seated sooner than we were told, which was nice, but I think the overall atmosphere of the place was a little off. Our group of 5 was seated at a booth for 4 (they were crowded for the night) but they let us move when another table left, which was nice. I had the Fish & Chips, which was solid for the price. The beer I had (which, unfortunately, I cannot remember the name) was fantastic. Overall a good restaurant for the casual eater.
author: Adrian P.

description:
An ahi poke wasabi bowl, tax and tip equals $20.

This is a two part review.  First, at some point two children walked up to my table  without me noticing, and were grabbing at food and water glasses.  While I continued not to notice, their mom walked up, and I looked over and smiled.  The mom said, "Are you guys making friends?  Well, they don't look very friendly," and walked away.  WTF?!  First, the proper thing to say at this juncture is, "I am so sorry for being a negligent parent."  Second, I smiled and said nothing!  One star for her for being a total bitch; out loud at that.

On the other hand, four stars for Pacific Catch.  I'd been meaning to go to the one in the Marina and try the ahi poke bowl on a recommendation from a friend, but this location was too convenient to pass up.  I stopped in with my sisters after spending the morning in the de Young, was promptly seated, and got my food right away.  Everyone was happy with their food and left very full.  I'm ashamed to say that I was just barely unable to finish my food.  It is a generous portion with a generous amount of tuna.  The poke was good, sushi rice excellent, and wakame, daikon, and avocado were all pretty satisfying.  I wasn't a big fan of the amount of soy sauce added to the rice before serving, but I can probably fix that by ordering it without and doing it myself.

Go to the park, get some lunch, go back to the park.  Word.
author: Troy M.

description: I give this place 2 stars. I was charged for surcharge $4.50. I don't want to pay for their employees health benefits. Because of this charge I will not be coming back to this place after just my first visit a week ago. These are not my employee's and I will not pay for their heath benefits. I did like the coconut shrimp they were good. The 3 tacos were just ok. If in the future I get charged for this extra fee again I will be taking it out of the tip!!
author: Geo G.

description:
I want to like you, Pacific Catch....I really do. 

1 Star for the food, because my "sandwich" was soaked. 3 stars for the Sweet Potato friiiiiiies
author: B B.

description:
I think I've held off on reviewing Pacific Catch because it makes me think of the food, and when I think of the food I start salivating, my stomach starts to rumble and the thought of hawaiian poke just fills my mind and my cravings for it go out of whack.  

Always always always start off with the sweet potato fries.  Always.  Then order whatever the hell you want to drink.  Then order a dish that includes  poke.  The rice bowl for a heartier meal, a salad for a light one, but always with the poke!  Whatever else you want to order is up to you =)
author: Heidi L.

description:
It was late in the day and my wife and I were craving a good lunch. We hit up Fresh Catch and like a Irish Brother it was there for us!

My wife had the crab salad. She loves that thing!  While it has the usual suspects in a salad it is generously packed with crab meat and avocados. Today I went with coconut shrimp and they were good. Nothing over the top or different but prepared well for what they were.

It was quite at lunch but then again it is the day before Thanksgiving. Parking is a pain but they do have a side lot that if lucky you can find a spot in. I typically part in the park and walk over. This visit we sat in the bar and had great service by the bartender. 

I grew up in New England (specifically Boston) and this place reminds me of Legal Seafood.
author: Ryan B.

description:
I went here for a first dinner date. As we were waiting for the tables getting turned over my date and I had a drink at a bar. I'm not much of a drinker but got a mojito anyway. I was only done with a 1/4 of my cocktail until I started feeling warm. My date got scared that I was turning red and was allergic to something but it was just because I didn't Pepcid AC for my asian glow (I'm a super lightweight drinker). 

As we got seated, we ordered the calamari as an appetizer. The calamari wasn't the best I've had but it was ok. For our entrees I ordered the salmon teriyaki bowl with brown rice and my date got the poke rice bowl. Both bowls were ok and I'd go back again but not as my first choice to eat.
author: Raquel T.

description:
Best Fish Place in the area

Relax and big dinning space, friendly waitress, has TV but not too noisy.  The Poky Tuna dishes are so fresh, and worth the price, compared I got raw fish from Andronical.  Crossed the street to the park, a best spot on weekend watching people.
author: Jacqueline X.

description:
Service was great.  Atmosphere's good.
Sadly my stomach did not agree with the fried oysters 
(the inside was a bit undercooked but I said what the heck.  
Took a risk and I lost.)
Add to it the copious amounts of sesame oil in the ahi poke rice bowl,
my day in SF was pretty much messed up within 2 hours.
Sorry, but I have to give you one star.
author: avalon e.

description: this location is a little out of the way but perfect if your out in golden gate park.  at night it can get crowded, but the bar is great if you dont mind eating at the bar.  poke is great but the shrimp ceviche is the one to get.  i always get a rice bowl, but everything is great.  i love that they have brown rice and they really do cook it right.  fish tacos and sandwiches are great here too.  fish is always cooked perfectly.  one of my favorite sf restaurants.
author: Robert K.

description: Another subpar visit at Pacific Catch unfortunately.  I visited with colleagues after work and was disappointed with the rare Ahi sandwich.  The cut of fish had a tough and sinewy skin that had to be pulled apart with knife and fork.  Not very tasty when biting into what you are expecting to be a tender cut of meat.  Would not recommend.
author: Kim K.

description:
Sorry friends, while I greatly enjoyed your company, the decision to eat here was not.

Sweet Potato Fries - while I love them, there was nothing impressive here. They came with some Thai chili sauce and this other mayo-based sauce. I preferred them with the mayo-based sauce that came with the calamari.

Calamari - not bad, maybe their specialty is to batter-fry the lemon/peppers with it too...I was like: eeek, this calamari tastes like a lemon! (It was!)

Mixed Catch Basket - deep fried coconut shrimp, fish, oysters with more sweet potato fries. The fish was nice and flaky but maybe they need to work on the batter. For me, aside from good ingredients, if I'm gonna eat something fried, the batter needs to be helllla bomb.

The boy ordered some sort of sushi with salmon on it. And avocado. Both of which I love, but not at this particular place.

Sorry Pacific Catch, maybe I caught you on an off day.
author: Ellis L.

description:
3.5 Pints!  (Trying out a new rating system because I am endlessly frustrated with being limited.)

Yeah.  It's good.  Great Happy Hour choices, although I think they could come up with more than 2 signature cocktails.  The Spicy Pacific Martini ($7) is amazing!  The Agave Margarita ($6) is so-so.  They should come up with something else as I can get an agave margarita in 100 other places.

On two separate occasions I tried two types of HH Rolls ($6 for all types) and they were quite tasty, especially for the price.  A very hearty portion, good flavors and creative.  The California Roll was a little mushy, but they are quite honest to bill it as "fresh crab SALAD" instead of just the meat, but again, for the amount and the price, you can't beat it.  The other roll I tried was the Shiso Fine, and that little hit of Shiso leaf added a great dimension to an already good roll.  Avo was fresh, cold and popped with the sesame seeds and seaweed.

Great atmosphere, although it looks like the beginnings of a corporate dynasty, and very nice natural light in the bar.  (I wouldn't go on a first date if you are trying to hide any blemishes!)  

Bar staff is friendly, but not overly peppy, which makes me happy.  Seems like there are too many back there at times, though, and can seem like they get their wires crossed when it comes to who needs what.

I did notice the managers working, pouring beers, delivering food, answering the phone and greeting people.  The hands-on approach can sometimes make a staff nervous, but it's nice to see that they have a stake in the business and aren't above lending a hand.

I would go back and try other items, although I still have a hard-time paying over $10 for a sandwich.

Overall, the food will bring you back and atmosphere will bring your friends with you.
author: Gina H.

description: Spacious place, plenty  of seating and nice ambiance. We tried the shrimp ceviche, ecstacy roll, and the Hawaiian poke bowl with brown rice. The shrimp ceviche was so delicious! The right amount of spiciness, tons of fresh juicy shrimp served in a little cute cocktail glass with tortilla chips. The ecstacy roll was just okay, kind of bland. More of an Americanized type of roll than what I'm used to eating at Japanese sushi restaurants. The Hawaiian poke was good though, tons of poke and seaweed salad, and you can have the option of splitting it into two bowls to share! Since we did that, I had to get brown rice too cause the boyfriend wanted it, but I would have much preferred white rice. Maybe that's why I didn't like the bowl so much but he at least he did. Could have used a little more spiciness to it though. Parking sucks in the area but usually if you drive down into the park area, there's plenty of parking on the sidewalk along the park and its a short walk to the restaurant.
author: Thao V.

description:
The food here is  blah  BUT i have been back 3 or 4x just for the Fried Dulce de Leche Spring Rolls (with vanilla ice cream & caramel). Once I ordered 2 plates of the Dulce de Leche (shhhhhhh!)

Very kid friendly
author: Chanel M.

description: This place is super cool. I love the decor and the seating outside on a lovely sunny day. The food is great and really fresh. I loved my grilled wild salmon.
author: Marie Lynn M.

description:
This was the place my wife and I chose for our 9-year anniversary last June 24. I had heard of this place from one of my pharmacists at work, and she had mentioned that this place has Poki Tuna, which I will forever have a place in my heart for.

Getting there wasn't hard. It was very close to where I work (and usually try to stay from the neighborhood on my non-work nights). My wife had known beforehand that I would get a UCSF discount of 15%, so she asked me to bring my work badge. Parking could've been a disaster if it wasn't for a tiny space in the tiny parking lot located on the Lincoln Ave. side of the restaurant. And when I say tiny, I MEAN TINY! When we went inside, the seater at the front asked us if we had a reservation or if we wanted to wait for our seats. My wife had already taken care of this, and she reserved us a table for two. Upon showing it to the lady at the front, she acknowledged it.

Our server was very friendly (and a bit too peppy if you ask me, which isn't always bad) and took our orders for our drinks and appetizers. Anyway, we ordered some appetizers (sushi using brown rice and POKI TUNA!!!), which were uncommonly good.

Our main courses were BOMB! My wife got a surf-and-turf combo, and I got a Korean BBQ combo plate. I am going out on a limb and saying that the Poki was definitely on par with Roy's! The meat was very tender (my Korean BBQ) and wasn't hard to swallow at all.

If there was a gripe I had, it would have to be our seating placement. We were right next to the backdoor, which felt kinda awkward when people were leaving or coming on that way. Otherwise, I had no qualms with our choice of restaurant on our anniversary dinner.

P.S. The best part of the experience (food-wise) was the chocolate lava cake we got ON THE HOUSE! It was very chocolatey and gooey, which was a good contrast to the seafood we were having. A+!
author: Geric O.

description:
Came here on a Monday evening to meet up with some friends for happy hour, and I was pleasantly surprised by the reasonable price and the chic decor of this place. 

Four people, 4 drinks, 4 appetizers came out to be $30. Not too shabby! 

While their HH food selection is a little bit limited, it has all the important stuff that will stop those munchies:

-sweet potato fries
-calamari
-california rolls
-shitake asparagus rolls
-ahi poke

Everything tasted good with my Sapporo beer. No complaints!
author: Lynn C.

description:
This place is a great find. Parking is pretty ridiculous here. I seriously thought parking would be cake, since the park is across the street and by evening time all cars would be gone leaving plenty of street parking. WRONG! NO PARKING during evening hours stated clearly on the signs, but many cars were parked. A cop car drove in and I decided not to risk it. They do have a small parking lot next to the restaurant, but it fills up quickly. I suggest biking or walking. What better way to burn off those after dinner calories than riding/taking a stroll in GG park (warning: it gets really dark in there at night)?!

- Salmon Teriyaki Bowl ($14.95): Asparagus, shiitake mushrooms, grilled bok choy, sesame seeds with teriyaki sauce, served over pineapple fried rice (I substituted with brown rice). The brown rice was a little too hard for my liking. Other than that, I really liked the abundance of vegetables and the sweet/flavorful mix of pineapple in the rice was delicious. 

- Sushi Grade Ahi Salad ($12.95): Subsituted with Hawaiian Poke. Avocado, daikon sprouts, ginger, sesame seeds with soy-wasabi vinaigrette. The portion size of this salad is quite generous, great for a meal or for sharing with another dish. The poke accompanied the vegetables well giving me a healthy yet satisfying feeling of fullness. 

- Pineapple-Orange-Guava juice ($2.95): Tasted just how it sounds like; a mixture of all 3 with the guava juice standing out the most. Came in a pretty small glass, so I didn't feel like I got my money's worth. 

No reservations were made and there were plenty of empty tables in the main dining area, but the hostess escorted us and said the only table available was in the bar area. I did not even see the empty tables in the dining area fill up throughout my meal. I don't like the tables at the bar, not much leg room. Other than that, service was quick and efficient. The poke salad and rice bowls are definitely worth coming back for! 

P.S. Opened late until 11PM on Sun-Thurs and 12AM on Fri & Sat, score!
author: Tracy T.

description: We came here for happy hour and it was delicious!! A bit smaller inside but nice atmosphere and really nice wait staff. The salmon and steak tacos were really good and the calamari and sweet potato fries were excellent!
author: Kate A.

description: The food was plentiful and service was great. I ate the rice bowl with Hawaiian Poke and it was delicious a big bowl of sushi delight.  We also tried a meat sandwich it was very flavorful.  I will try again!
author: Sandra M.

description: Stopped in on a recomendation from a friend.  Sat outside with the dogs.  Very accomodating.  The food and service were both excellent.  A lot of great people watching and I will definately go back.
author: Jeanine K.

description:
Dear Foley, 
You suck.  And you were just plain rude. Thanks for that. 

I'll never be coming back here.
author: Molly G.

description:
Came her with my girlfriend before going to Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences.

The happy hour is pretty good, I enjoyed their menu.  I would eat here again and definitely order the Poke :)
author: Alban N.

description: Wanted to go here for a long time, friend loves this place and I am a huge seafood lover so I came along! Our waitress was very nice and helpful so 5 stars for her, but the food was just Okay. I got the ahi tuna salad, which was 15$, pretty expensive for a salad not enough fish or dressing on it, it was very big though but it needed more fish and dressing! also ordered a cocktail,which was delicious. Overall I liked it but it wasn't anything special,and a bit overpriced.
author: Milla K.

description: Despite the fact that I was on vacation and under the weather, I ended up at Pacific Catch on my birthday with my (insert appropriate current pleasantry) and her family and I have to admit - the Poke' on its' own was enough to make the worst of colds feel back o' the bus.  I can't for the life of me remeber which variations we tried, but there were many and they were all delicious and refreshing and absolute worth experiencing again and again on a sunny day.  The restaurant itself looked like a wonderful place to have a fun night out or a cute summer date, but we were fortunate to be able to lock down the comfy couch seats on the patio despite the fact that we battle a bit of a glare from certain seats.  Again, I almost feel bad that I can't be more specific about the menu items we tried, but I have to admit... even with a miserable cold, the fresh fish and lovely citrus flavors that came out of the Poke extravaganza provided by Pacific Catch made my 29th birthday a memorable day.
author: Michael K.

description:
Thank god for this 9th Ave. location - the branch on Chestnut St. is small, perpetually crowded and hard to get a table. 
There is an actual free parking lot on the Lincoln side of the restaurant. Really? Yes. It's only got a handful of spots, but still, a nice amenity, and pretty rare for that neighborhood. If there's no spot available, you can usually get something close by along the Park.
I've never had a bad meal here - LOVE their rice bowls (tip: order them w/ half rice/half greens - easy to get weighed down in rice), sushi rolls, sandwiches, everything really. Their cocktails and drink specials are really good too - strawberry mojito? Yes please! The bar gets backed up - order your drinks before your appetizers or any food - can take a minute. 
Fresh, delicious seafood, tasty drinks, nice service, decent prices, casual but classy. It's in regular restaurant rotation in my house. Have brought many out of towners here who have loved it too.
author: Barbara K.

description: I came here for a birthday party, and all I have to say is that this place offers fresh seafood and is worth trying. I would go here more often if it weren't that pricey, but otherwise I would definitely recommend the Hawaiian poke, one of the wasabi bowls, or the tacos. My girlfriend had the salmon fish and chips. The fish was pretty dry, but the sweet potato fries were pretty nice. I would go here again!
author: Nick L.

description:
I had the most wonderfully pleasant expierence ordering take out from pacific catch.  The staff was friendly and very efficient, I called and first asked if i could have an order ready by a certain time and they told me that I could do that, but there was a small chance it could get lost (I know there is always this risk and I appreciated they were honest) and it typically to about 20 minutes or something to get an order ready.  I decided to call later.  When i did I got the same friendly service and when i mentioned I loved the dipping sauces for the sweet potato fries they were nice enough to give me extra. YUMMY!!!!

When i got there to pick my food up they were quick, helpful and just made me feel like my business, even if it was pick up, was VERY welcome.  

Also, the curry bowls are SOOOOOO GOOD!!!!  I love the Green Thai Curry with Salmon and Brown Rice.  It always lasts more than a day and heats up super well.  Full of fresh veggies I always feel good when i get it.
author: Amy P.

description:
Corkage fee only $10 per bottle. With the mixed basket, fried oysters too 'fishy', shrimps was alright (better with cocktail sauce), fish was somewhat soggy with oils. 

Seating was comfy with pillow cushion. Never rushed us even though we sat there and talked forever. 

Calamari was fluffy and good. Fried lemon slices and peppers was interesting. Salmon salad and Korean beef rice bowl was good.
author: Sam C.

description:
They have a really good happy hour. A lot of different drink and food choices! Most happy hour places only give you a few selections, but they give you a wide variety.

The calamari and sweet potato fries were amazing! LARGE PORTION AND CHEAP! 

I wasn't a big fan of spicy tuna since i can't stand too much wasabi, but if you're a wasabi fan you'll like it.
author: Dorris W.

description: Never had a bad meal here although I mostly order their awesome wasabi bowls... Sushi is good, grilled artichokes are awesome. Very kid friendly and the staff is very accommodating. The bar scene is good and they have great happy hour deals. Ceviches are quite good and all the fish dishes are amazingly fresh... really have nothing bad to say about the place. This place is a solid 4 stars and even more.
author: Lo F.

description:
Can't believe I haven't written a review on this place.  I used to come here all the time when I lived in the Inner Sunset, particularly for the late night happy hour, which I loved.  Their bar bites include the asparagus roll, spicy tuna roll, and spicy calamari, all for about 5-6 bucks each.  Beers are standard and 3 bucks, well drinks are 4.    

I do sometimes come here as a safe dinnertime option, and it's fine, but I have admittedly waited 4 hours to eat dinner just so I can come here after 10 pm for the happy hour deals.

Sometimes they're inconsistent with their late night HH because one time I went at 10 and they were like closing shop already, so don't get mad at me if that happens to you!
author: William S.
