description: Our server Alissa was so on it, thanks! The food was really good. Coming back. We sit outside, under the heat lamps!
author: Parker S.

description:
Just came here for dinner. First off, the food was okay. I have nothing to complain about the food. This review is strictly for their service. 

My server's name was Alyssa. She only came by our table twice. First to take our order and the second to give us our check to sign. When my boyfriend ran out of water, it took forever for someone to come by just so we can ask for more water. When we were done with our food and wanted the check and a to go box, or server was no where to seen. After awhile, we finally got the attention of another server. She kindly gave us our box and a check. When it was time to take the check and the credit card to pay, our server was once again, no where to be seen. Another staff who worked with the dishes took it to the other staffs. Once again, more time wasted. 

When it was time to pay for tips, I really didn't want to leave anything because I didn't think they deserved it. My boyfriend thought we should have left something so I forced him to barely leave anything. I know it may seen wrong but I really don't care if this is the service I got. I never expected anyone to come by often to ask how we were doing but the service I got here was unacceptable. I made sure to leave a comment on the check for future improvements. I was thankful for the other staffs who did what appeared to be outside of their job description. But as for our server, she is being for not even doing her job. 

I refuse to ever come back to this restaurant.
author: Audrey M.

description: The food here is ridiculously good. Great happy hour, nice staff, and fun cocktails. YUM
author: Jeannine R.

description:
We arrived here at 9:30pm on a Thursday night.  All the tables in the bar were full, so we sat in the almost-empty dining room.

We ordered an Ahi Poke appetizer and a few baja tacos with sweet potato fries.

We have always ordered the ahi poke.  Its a definite favorite.  But this time the ahi was a bit too salty.  I think they sprinkled it with sea salt...after it just got doused with soy sauce.  The sweet potato fries were great...this time they didn't come with that great aoili sauce.

Overall...we were able to get a parking space in their 6-car parking lot and were in and out of there in about 30 minutes.
author: Rochelle D.

description:
Unfortunately half of our party's meal came out moderately to entirely wrong-- also, we were charged for one dish that came out which we never ordered, as well as the item we actually ordered. Thankfully we caught the problem- even if it was after our credit card had gone through. The food was good overall- though the chipotle sauce on the mahi salad was more like straight chipotle Tabasco (smothered)- which kept me from  tasting any other flavors in the salad. 
Service left quite a bit to be desired.
author: Ashley L.

description: I just found Cevich tastes pretty good at most places.  The thing is they can give you crappy sashimi and hide it with a lot of sauce!  So it's all about the sauce.  The sauce is is pretty good.  We also had some terriyaki bowl and some appetizers combo platter.  The fishsticks were a little soggy and the sweet fries were really thin and came out lukewarm.  With Scoutmob, our bill came out to be $30.  Good deal with Scoutmob.
author: Byron L.

description:
good food, really bad service.  unfortunately, the food is good enough to keep me coming back, but the service is a friendly reminder to limit my omega fatty acids.

nopalito just moved in a few doors down, which is my new goto!
author: Stephan T.

description: It felt unusally warm inside this place, time to try the tuna poke over sushi rice bowl...LIKE!  ...and filling too, a must have for my next visit, right after the tuna poke appetizer...no such thing as too much tuna poke!
author: Emy B.

description: There food was great and was something different from the norm.  I had the vietnamese sandwhich which was great.  I'd definitely come back again.
author: Leonard G.

description: We came here because we were driving by and decided to try it out. The decor inside is very modern and open spaced. The waitress was extremely nice and all smiles. The food was absolutely delicious. The drinks were very yummy as well. Great service, great food, and great company equals GREAT NIGHT! ^_^
author: Anji W.

description:
I've been looking forward to Happy Hour at Pacific Catch ever since I dined here! Now that I've gone, I can't find many reasons to go back. 

The service was absolutely atrocious! Our waitress was very rude...did not make us feel welcome at all. Even after forgetting about our order, she did not acknowledge us at all. Basically, I want to call her a *itch...but that's not my style. We got her name, but won't name it...don't want her to lose her job. But if she knows who she is, I'd recommend treating customers a little better. 

I love Pacific Catch...but this Happy Hour experience was anything but happy.
author: Allan M.

description:
Food: 3/5
I've been here more than a few times at plenty of different times such as for dinner or lunch or a quick pop-in to have a few drinks from the bar. So far the food and drinks have always been on a consistent level. The thing is that the food, although interesting, never really hits that next level you would expect when you come here. The various sushi plates are ok, the rice bowls are ok, and the specials are recommended in my opinion but still just ok.

Atmosphere: 4/5
This place is very well decorated from "head-to-toe" so to speak. The high ceilings, paintings, various seating sections, and the open kitchen make this place very cosmetically appealing. 

Service: 4/5
The service has always been pretty good, and the servers are always happy to show you around the menu and answer your questions. You may have to wait a bit for your food but it's quicker than you would expect seeing how busy it is. 

Price: 3/5
It's not the most expensive restaurant comparative to most seafood restaurants but it's still about average or just a tad more expensive for comparable food. 

That something special: 4/5
This place is always nice to go to on a casual date or a casual lunch with drinks. You will always be impressed and relaxed by the interior design and the good service will make you leave feeling you had a good time. 

3.6/5
author: Aaron P.

description:
Awesome! Who can eat seafood? Not I. Smelly, salty, slimy. Yuck! Only two places have I tolerated seafood. My friend Ron's house, and a really expensive restaurant in Milan Italy (lets here it for expense accounts). Ron moved and I don't expect to be in Italy again anytime soon. 

I found a third. Pacific Catch. No smelly, slimmy salty yuck. Amazing food. Just food. Don't even think sea food. Just think taste. 

Woohoo, As good as it gets.
author: Danny S.

description:
When this restaurant first opened, it wasn't really that great to me. And I remember the menu being very limited like it was only one page of dishes you could order. 

However, I went back yesterday and the menu has expanded and someone told me the chef changed from when they first opened and I was amazed by how much better it got.

My friend ordered an appetizer, the Hawaiian Poke, and I was just was all over it because it tasted so good!

As for my entree I had the Korean BBQ with steak and salmon which was also good. But I think I could have just had the Hawaiian Poke for a meal because that's much I was over it and kept wanting it.

The service was average between good, but not excellent.
author: Pudgy G.

description: Hawaiian Poke Japanese Wasabi Pan-Asian Bowl and Marinated Beef Skirt Korean Barbecue Pan-Asian Bowl was pretty good. The hawaiian poke was better than the beef skirt. It was not a smart idea to drown the bowls with sauce. The excess amounts of sauce killed the dishes. The Tropical Iced Tea was nothing special.
author: Tony L.

description: The Applebee's of seafood restaurants. Looks interesting from the outside but don't be fooled - it's a big tourist trap. There are many other solid restaurants in the area.
author: Rob C.

description: Went here after Ft. Funston &was craving seafood. I got the wasabi rice bowl &was thoroughly satisfied. I was overwhelmed by the menu because I wanted to try everything! I'll definitely be going back. The waitress was really attentive &nice. Nice clean place, as well!
author: Krystal A.

description: Awkward service, then we had none at the end of our meal. Food was boring and defiantly not worth the money. My guy ordered a steak taco which I tried a bite of and the steak was to say the least a chewy piece of fat.
author: Valerie N.

description: The Pacific Catch location in the Marina may have some minuses because 1. it's in the Marina and 2. because it's smaller, but the service there eclipses the service at this inner sunset location. The staff here are amateurs. Let's see... Seat me in the bar area, then bring me water after a 10 minute wait, then don't return to get my order? Amateurs. It's not my first time with this place. Get rid of the waitstaff, barstaff plus management and start from scratch. I won't be returning here. There's nothing here to convince me that I need to spend money to endure the pretentiousness and incompetence of the people who work here.
author: Jen A.

description:
Dear Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl,

How do I love thee? Let me count the ways.

1. Your bed is a TON (way more than any person should eat in a single sitting) of delicious sushi rice
2. You double team me with nori AND wakame
3. You get me slightly hot and bothered with your spicy daikon sprouts then cool me down with a tickled-pink ginger
4. You come with a soy-wasabi sauce that makes me want to spoon all night long
5. You were my first...a meal of raw fish where I'm actually FULL without spending $60!?  I've never had so much poke in one bowl (esp. for $11)!!!

You are the perfect catch!
author: Krystle S.

description:
After a lot of bad reviews, I'd like to give the highlights of the place.

I have gone multiple times for happy hour, and I think its a great place.. maybe they need more happy hour space because I have had a bit of problem before, but it wasn't that bad. But the drinks are really cheap and there is a GREAT food menu. The best is the Hoki (raw tuna on fried chips) and the fried Veggies. 

Another good thing, is that they have another happy hour from 10-11. Great for late starters.
author: Sirina K.

description: The sweet potato fries were pretty good. The fried oysters and fish n chips were very good. The staff was nice and fairly attentive. I plan on goin back fo sho!
author: Aaron Y.

description:
I was unpleasantly surprised by the food that I got here, I thought that it was going to be so much better than this.

My friends who came with me ordered the tacos, which i actually suggest in this case though it is supposed to be Asian fusion. Their sweet potato fries are good as everyone says. Deliciously fried and tastes sweetly made. There was the Salmon fish taco which was particularly good as the Salmon was seasoned with the perfect amount of spices. My other friend ordered another sort of fish which was less satisfying but overall edible.

I ordered the crab chowder special for this month and was absolutely confused. At the time, I knew that they were leaning towards the Asian fusion as the decor and the menu boasted a modern chic approach to Asian food. Then tell me why oh why was my crab chowder Mexican? There were bell peppers diced into my soup with celery and what looked like green salsa/hot sauce atop of it. The crab was fresh but the overall taste of everything together tasted like they threw it all together to become a soup. To top it all of too, my plate was warmer than my soup. I saw the soup sitting there for awhile, unaware that it could be mine.

My friends and I came at 2:30PM with minimal amounts of people, however that also translated to minimal amounts of service. I couldn't get someone to heat up my soup until it was well cooler than warm and we couldn't get the check for another 20 minutes after our meal was completely over, as in all the utensils have been collected and the dessert menus are put neatly in a stack next to us.

It was a pretty place and I enjoyed the decor and my friend's company there as it is spacious and nice for drinks.
However for the price that we paid and the service I acquired, I am disappointed. The most disappointing thing of all was the food as I was starving and couldn't even like the food.

It would be nice if you were looking for somewhere to chill and had some time on your hands, but we had to keep sending someone off to feed the meter.
author: Winè C.

description:
ACK! That's Marlin, Nemo and Dory you're serving on my plate, you freak!

... just kidding! 

This place is actually not that bad at all. Even months after they reopened, I could not make myself go in for the simple fact that I was an avid fan of the Canvas Gallery that occupied the space before, and to see it close was truly sad... I am in mourning...

... OK. Sob story over... back to me now...

... checked it out on a nice and sunny Sunday (those rare ones in the Inner Sunset when you can wear shorts, a tank and flip flops) and had a great time.

I recommend:
- Warm Edamame (sea salt is umm good!)
- House-made Miso Soup (dunno who'se "house" it was made in but they make it darn good)
- Hawaiian Poke (my FAV dish here! the tuna on the wonton crisp is just something else... this Hawaiian can poke me any ole time!)
- Cabo Calamari (What? Messican Calamari?? Odd name but all the same pretty good thought a wee bit greasy with the deep frying)
- Fish & Chips (Can't go wrong with this one... actually, you can! good but not as good as Woodhouse Fish Company)
- Teriyaki Bowl ((nice especially with bok choy, sprouts and nori!)
- Macadamia Nut Brownie (DROOL! DRIP!... nuf said!)
- Bloody Mary (Sunday and Bloody Mary's?? Ya betcha!)

Nice place, crowd (tourists, neighbors, folks from other hoods), kid friendly, dog friendly (outside), waiter service outdoors can be a bit iffy until you throw in some 'tude.
author: Amit S.

description:
Best Happy Hour in Inner Sunset -- be sure to get the poke.

I wish it were possible to rate a restaurant twice on different types of meals. Like, one for breakfast and one for lunch... because this place would get five stars for the bar and four on dinner. But failing that, I'm breaking out the elusive fifth star on the bar alone.

First up, this place serves Flor de Cana as its house rum. If you've never had Flor de Cana then you are missing out. Made in Nicaragua, I have yet to see it for sale direct to consumers outside of its native country. But in Nicaragua, you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a bottle. States side, it's a rare treat... except not anymore, because I can get it any day I want, especially between the hours of 4-6 M-F and after 10 every day, when well drinks are just four dollars.

But no review is complete without a mention of their poke. In my mind Pacific Catch serves the archetypical poke. Healthy chunks of well marinated tuna with crispy won-ton-eqsue things. Seriously, I could eat it every day. And during happy hour, it's only like $5+ (usually $8-9). Paired with a rum and coke, I can't imagine a better way to relax after work.

Truth is, as much as I love the food and drink, I think what really makes the Pacific Catch bar great is ambiance. From the little group tables, to the high table for two, the whole place is just built for relaxation. Most bars I find to be on either too grungy or too snooty. For me, Pacific Catch is just perfect, and I'm looking forwards to getting to know the bartenders as I develop "regular" status.
author: Sean K.

description:
I should preface this by saying I actually wanted to hate this place because it replaced the Canvass Cafe, a cafe I loved to frequent. It just looked like some big chain fish place. How dare they!

So given that, I really have been surprised at how much I've liked the food here and have been back several times with the g/f. We've liked the salads but better are the fish tacos and most of their fish entrees. I love the sweet potato fries and the free edamame and pretzels to snack on while waiting. And the wait usually isn't that long.  We haven't been here in about 2 months so maybe it's gone downhill (judging by a few reviews below) but for us the food has always been tasty and the experience has always been good. 

I will say I recommend the fish tacos at Underdog's taco shop down the street even more, but if you're here, they're solid. And I also had a very good fish sandwich.  I would stay away from the Sushi here just because there are some great Sushi specialty places right nearby that do it better, not because it was terrible per se.  But the sandwiches, fish entrees, tacos, all that is good. And we also dig the artichoke appetizer. 

All in all, I still miss the cafe but no longer think this place is evil for existing.
author: Craigary P.

description: Went here last night with my boyfriend. We shared the crab soup which was super bomb!! I wish we each got our own. He had the crab sandwich which was really good, too. I got the three poke dinner which is raw fish cut in cubes and marinated/mixed with different stuff. I chose the ahi tuna serrano, california style, and salmon lomi lomi. They were all awesome; I'll definitely be going back.
author: Melissa C.

description: I've eaten here at least 5 times now and I'm long overdue in reviewing. I can honestly say I've never had a bad meal. Fresh fish, nice wait staff, interesting menu. And did I mention...really nice staff. Try it. You won't be disappointed.
author: Samantha Y.

description:
Having been here for lunch, I was looking forward to dinner. I arrived thinking I wanted the seared ahi salad, but that quickly changed as we browsed the menu.  Instead, we opted for a few appetizers and two sushi rolls to share.  The sweet potato fries were irresistible- not too greasy; I kept chomping on them! The Hawaiian Poke and the Shrimp Ceviche starter plates both came with plenty of poke and shrimp pieces. I loved the lime-cilantro-avocado sauce the shrimps were covered in.

Though the starter plates were great, I think the sushi rolls were only ok.  We asked for brown rice for the rising sun and the firecracker salmon rolls.  I was not impressed by the rolls because the brown rice didn't stick too well and the rice fell apart.  I think the next time I'll skip the sushi rolls. 

Surprisingly, there was no wait at all for a Saturday night, and we were able to snag a nice corner window seat.
author: Lisa C.

description: After a nice afternoon at the new California Academy of Sciences we were hunger for seafood and fresh California style cuisine. After searching the internet we found Pacific Catch just minutes from the museum. To my delight, they were featuring their Seafood rice bowls, the perfect meal for three tired souls. I ordered the salmon with brown rice. Yes! With just the right amount of wasabi, it hit the spot. And to top it off, we had the mochi balls dipped in warm chocolate. Decadent, but delicious. Ambiance nice. Service was OK. Could have been a 5 star.
author: Steve U.

description: Have always wanted to eat here and now that I have I wanna go back! The Blood Orange margaritas were especially delicious! Lots of things came to the table that brought smiles and yummy noises to people's faces. The dragon roll was beautiful and tasty. My chicken teriyaki bowl was huge and filled with great flavours of pineapple and edamame. The fish and chips were tender and not greasy. A very nice meal with big portions...too big as it didn't leave room for dessert...although we were very tempted by quite a few!
author: Joaquin G.

description: Big portions, nice service, but price is so not right for what you get. Sorry, the food was just ok nothing exciting, the sushi was big but not flavorful and not rolled right. The only think I can give props to them for is their Tuna Poke, good stuff!
author: Karen T.

description:
Don't get caught up in the hype. 

The entrees are all about $15 but aren't worth more than $10. The salads are unimpressive; the bowls are better but nothing spectacular.  

Happy hour (4-6, 10-11:30) is a good deal, with quality tap beer and small dishes $2-6. Try the poke, sweet potato fries, or spicy tuna roll. That said, happy hour is the only time I'd let the Catch reel me in.
author: Lou S.

description: Food rates a 3.5, but a creative bar menu upped my rating to 4. The lemongrass mojito and pisco sour were standouts for flavor and presentation. Fresh catch (mahi) was actually fresh, not frozen. Menu is what you'd expect from Pacific Rim - Baja fusion served in an airy room with blonde wood.
author: Genevive B.

description: Had to fill my tummy after Bay to Breakers craziness.... We managed to find Pacific Catch after wandering through GG park, and luckily we got a table for 7 of us.. The waitress was pretty nice took our orders in a timely fashion. I got the Pacific catch of the day fish and chips. It was cod, and was fried perfectly. Slightly crunchy on the outside and very soft and flaky on the inside. They included a sweet chili and tartar dip, both were flavored nicely. Sweet potato fries were good, but slightly overfried and dry. All our orders came out about the same time.
author: Thomas L.

description: Finally stopped by this local, green business to try their Salmon fish 'n chips on a slow Monday after riding my bike all over the city. The decor of the place is nice, some nice attention to detail. My waiter was very attentive and personable. However, for $15, their fish 'n chips was a disappointingly meager and not very moist. The Dulce de leche dessert was decadent and might have saved them face, but they took nearly 15 minutes to make my $9 cocktail with only 3 other tables in the whole place and waitstaff lounging in boredom on a slow Monday night. Lame! Lose 1 star!
author: Jake G.

description:
This is the only place I've ever been to which has a late night happy hour. I came here around 11pm last night for some late night happy hour eats after having gone to a private event at the CA Academy of Sciences across the street in Golden Gate Park. 

Prices were very reasonable ranging from $4.95 to $5.95. We ordered the following:

Calamari
Coconut Shrimp
Asparagus and Shitake Mushroom sushi
A mix of seasoned and unseasoned sweet potato fries and seasoned fries

The place is very spacious and has high ceilings. The service is good, but as much as I want to give this place more stars I just can't. Here's why:

The calamari had slices of lemon battered and fried along with the calamari. That would have been fine if the calamari didn't taste soggy.

The coconut covering around the shrimp kept falling off. It was hard to take a bite out of the shrimp without having the the batter completely fall apart off the shrimp. On the bright side the coconut  batter was nice and crunchy, but that could have been because it was overly fried. 

Just a tip, if you see that fried items are not a golden brown, but a dark brown, it could be because the items have been either re-fried or fried for too long.

The seasoned sweet potato fries were so peppery you couldn't taste the sweet potato at all. It comes with two dipping sauces, one is a sweet sauce, the same one you get with the coconut shrimp, and the other is supposed to be a tangy sauce, but tasted too vinegary. 

The unseasoned sweet potato fries tasted a little better, but felt too soggy and soft to me. They are thinly sliced, and I think I would have preferred if it they were more crunchy. 

The only bright spot was the asparagus and shitake mushroom sushi, which was delicious. It would have been nice if it came with a little saucer of soy sauce or something so you could mix the wasabi in it for dipping.

This place might be great for dinner, but for their happy hour eats I didn't think they were that great.
author: Lyn L.

description:
We returned on a Saturday at 1.30 with two friends and the ankle biter.  The food was less awesome than last time (seems to be the case with a lot of our reviews).  The fries were lukewarm!  All of our fries were lukewarm, it was disappointing.  My husband and his friend had the spicy mahi mahi sandwich and both said it was lukewarm.  Our friend said it was better at the Marina location.  

I still like this place though, so I will chalk it up to we went at an off time (but it was tres busy at 1.30 on a Saturday).  Maybe next time will return at prime lunch time and if we get lukewarm food again, we will speak out.
author: Mrs F.

description: I ordered the Wasabi Bowl with Hawaii Poke. I think it's a very successful deconstructed sushi dish. The Ahi was fresh and seasoned with just right amount of heat. Everything worked beautifully together. The cucumber and ginger made it refreshing. The creamy avocado balanced out the wasabi's heat. And the Wakame salad added some sweetness to the dish. It's delicious.
author: Yu Z.

description:
Judged this "book" by it's cover and it didn't disappoint.

From the beginning the service was fantastic, the hostess and servers were patient and attentive to our family party.

The guava cooler was a bit light on shoju but the fish was fresh, the dressings were light and everything was so good. Portions were perfect - left satisfied and not over-stuffed. The espresso and chocolate in the fondue were the perfect ending to our fabulous meal.

Will definitely return.
author: Miharu Y.

description:
I finally ate here and wondered why I hadn't tried this place sooner! After a day at the DeYoung Museum, we were starving and tried many seafood delights. As it was dungeness crab season, there were a number of crab specials. We tried the dungeness crab and corn chowder (not overly creamy, delicious, with lots of lump crab meat) and the dungeness crab dumplings (scrumptious). We also ordered the famous sweet potato fries. So good and served with two tasty dipping sauces - a sweet chili sauce and a wasabi-infused aioli sauce. 

For my entree I had the ahi poke wasabi bowl with brown rice and my husband had the grilled yellowtail special. I am officially addicted to the wasabi bowls. The portion was huge: many hearty chunks of poke tuna, perfectly ripe avocado slices, nori, wakame, daikon radish sprouts, ginger atop nutty brown rice. YUMMMM. My husband loved his yellowtail; I had a bite and it was really good - cooked perfectly with a delicious sauce.

I found the prices to be reasonable for the quality and portion sizes. Commendable service.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Came here for happy hour with my boyfriend and we got the Peruvian ceviche, Let's Get Saucy roll, and Thai Coconut Shrimp...

Food was edible but not the best tasting; the roll tasted like something you'd get at a sushi buffet and the coconut shrimp tasted like shrimp sample you'd get from Costco... 

The ceviche was okay (a bit spicy for my taste buds) but the purple potato chips that came with them were good. To drink, we tried Kona Longboard, a Hawaiian lager which was pretty good.

Service was ok, our server was really attentive in the beginning but it took awhile to flag him down to get the bill.
author: Jess H.

description: Got the special: Oaxacan style Escolar. There were no interesting flavors, but everything tasted fresh. Fish was essentially unseasoned. Beans and rice were plain and boring. Pickled onions were too vinegary. Plantains were good. Not worth the price.
author: Kurt A.

description:
I thought I did a good job by reading Yelp reviews before I came to this place for my future brother in law's surprise birthday lunch. After seeing what everyone else at the table ordered compared to me and my fiance, I was deeply disappointed in myself. I should've read everything more thoroughly, doh!

I did read that the fish tacos were good so I ordered that. They weren't horrible, but comparing my dish to everyone else, it felt like I was a kid who got chicken fingers and fries at a wedding whereas everybody else got the prime rib. Speaking of fries, SWEET POTATO FRIES, yummay!! The Cajun fries weren't bad too, but I love sweet potato fries and these would be rated 9 on my scale of 10 (10 being absolute perfection).

For a casual encounter, I would definitely recommend fish tacos which comes with the choice of fries (choose sweet potato). But everyone at the table (or at least 90% of the people) ordered the Wasabi bowl. Next time I'm back, I will definitely get that. Not only does it look delish, it's also quite healthy as well. From what I noticed with other people, they had a choice of white or brown rice, half salad and half Ahi tuna. Oh my gosh my mouth is watering and my stomach just grumbled a bit while I thought about that.

Next time... Wasabi bowl... get in my belly!!!
author: Ede S.

description:
This place is super cute for a date or a big group of people! We sat outside, where there are heaters, and it was perfect! But if you are allergic to dogs, watch out, people bring there dogs out on the patio and when the wind blows, sometime dog hair starts flying...

I had this raw tuna and chip thing for an app. which was amazing, very fresh and well portioned. My entree wasn't as good, it was the daily catch basket, which came with fried oysters, shrimp, fish, and fries. The oysters and fries were really awesome, but the fish was mediocre, and the shrimp was a bit overcooked.  

The drinks make up for parts of my entree that I didn't particularly care about, I got a tom collins (which I get everywhere, so some would call me an expert) and it was really well made. In addition, I had their signature mai thai drink, that even though I knew there was a ton of alcohol in it, it was still really tasty!
author: Rona Y.

description: This is our favorite gals night out happy hour place!  Never disappoints.  The cerviche is fabulous and the drinks are inventive and yummy.  Service is always spot on.  It's one of my favorite places.  I didn't give it 5 stars only because the dining experience when it's crowded can be noisy with kids.  Go during the day or when it's not crowded and it's a 5 star experience!!!  or go to the bar for happy hour!
author: Roxanne M.

description: I ended up here after a long walk through Golden Gate Park, and at first I must say I wasn't impressed. From the outside and from quickly glancing over the menu I had the impression that this was a touristy place, pricey but average. Boy was I wrong. After being seated I had a closer look at the menu (there's also a daily catch one) and there were lots of really innovative and tasty sounding things on it, from Asian rice bowls to sandwiches and meal sized salads. I went with the grilled salmon salad. Before the food arrives you will get an appetizer, fresh cold lemon green beans and  very cute  fish shaped crackers. I never had these kinds of beans before, very cool. The salad was served quickly after, and was nothing short of amazing (see picture.) The salmon was grilled crispy on the outside but still soft on the inside. The salad consisted of bean sprouts, shitake mushrooms, and various salads, mostly baby leafs making it very crunchy. It also came with what I understand was a yoghurt/lemon/soy sauce dressing. It was blissful, never had anything like it before. Another cool thing: the salmon skin is deep fried and served as a replacement for croutons to make everything a little crunchier, very cool idea. Now this isn't a cheap place by any means, the salad was 14 dollars, but trust me when I say it was worth every penny! Highly recommended.
author: Matthias K.

description:
Loved it!  For some reason I really wanted fish tacos which I NEVER crave but thought we'd check out this restaurant since it had been on my list for a while...and it served fish tacos.

Ceviche, fish tacos, and the mixed catch basket was ordered and though I didn't try anything from the catch basket, I was told it was delish.  The ceviche and fish tacos were to die for and if I ever want some good seafood I'll definitely be back!

I was too full for dessert but suggested the chocolate mochi to the chocolate lover and he absolutely liked it.  I tried a bite and it was incredible.  (I giggle at the description of "mochi" on the menu)

Our waiter was an older gentlemen who looked like he would have been cold and unpleasant but he was surprisingly very welcoming and attentive.

They seem to have a great bar lounge that I would like to come back for at some point.
author: Ninja H.

description:
I've been meaning to try this place for a while.  The beautiful decor always catches my eye when I head to the park, AOS, or just eat in the area.

So today's the day Pacific Catch.  Don't disappointment me after all the build up and recommendations from friends.  Went here on a date and tried to park in the parking lot next door.  No spaces, and around the corner we go.  A little walk never hurt anyone, unless you have a broken leg and no crutches.

We ordered
Sushi Grade Ahi Salad - Large portion, fresh, good
Wasabi Bowls With Hawaiian Poke - Another large portion, fresh, and tasty

This place has no crutch; good food, good service, and good atmosphere, unless you have a broken leg.
author: Po L.

description: I recently came to this location for the first time and was NOT disappointed! Not only was the food delicious (I recommend any of the tacos!) but the space and bar here is beautiful.  I prefer this location over the one in the Marina.  I feel like I have room to breathe here.
author: Tiffany R.

description:
Superkidafriendlyistictastyalodocious!

Right now my number one pick for kid friendly, great eats restaurant in SF!

5 stars.  Food, ambiance, service.
author: Cort T.

description:
Had never been to the Pacific Catch before being invited with a friend. So many things on the menu looked great, but I settled on the coconut prawns and was not disappointed. The lemongrass infused ice-tea was also great. Look forward to returning and trying something else on the menu.

The parking lot right next door made one of the thing I hate most about dining in San Francisco a piece of cake.
author: JEREMY B.

description:
ALL my cravings are always satisfied here. Probably because their menu is so random--Asian-Latin-whatever...it's all about the Benjamins...err, I mean the FISHIES!

First thing's first--FREE edamame and those cute little Goldfish pretzels!

Fish taco platter--mahi mahi and fried shrimp tacos. Squirt those bad boys with some lime and they're ready to go! Comes with a small side salad and black beans. Probably my favorite side salad ever.

Spicy tuna roll. Actually spicy. I'm always a sucker for maguro with daikon sprouts. Oh and it's a honker of a roll.

GINGER WHISKEY MOJITO! Probably one of THE best cocktails I've ever had. Refreshing, yet warm and earthy from the whiskey and mint. MUST TRY!

Service. On par, per usual.

Basically, I LOVE PC! Where else can you get tacos, fries, sushi, and some bomb-ass cocktails (yes, I said "bomb-ass")? It's the total package!
author: Kristine W.

description: For the record, I am marking two stars because MEH, I'VE EXPERIENCED BETTER. Especially here, I've experienced WAY better. The food was great as always, but the customer service was lacking on this particular night, and I know customer service is something you pride yourselves on at PC. It was only 11 on Friday night, but they were already closing up shop. When I asked if I could order some more food, the short-haired female bartender said that last-call for food had already passed. Funny I thought, because people were still receiving their food, and the bar-area didn't seem to have an empty seat in the place! Would have loved to stay around a bit longer and enjoy the company of friends while enjoying the Saucy roll I never got to enjoy, but I guess I'll just come back when Robin is behind the bar. That guy is the man.
author: Alex G.

description: Surprisingly terrible basic appetizers.  Tastless coconut shrimp and almost non-existent calamari.  How can you screw this up?  Service was very good and the atmosphere pretty decent, but man was that appetizer terrible.
author: Joel M.

description: Great Food, service, I'll rate this place 5 star!
author: Ssfnative R.

description: Was expecting a little better for the money.  The salmon special was drenched in sauce, which shouldn't be necessary for a good salmon filet.
author: Adam L.

description: This four-star review is for the impeccable customer service. I came here with family and knew a lot of their food had food allergens I can't consume. But the waiter made sure to personally tell the chefs and customized my order to make sure none of the foods on my plate had any cross continuation. I'm glad to say I enjoyed the meal just as much!
author: Darryl Y.

description:
Halfway through our dinner on Christmas eve with my close group of friends, the waiter asked us if it was a special occasion. We said no, we only wanted to see each other for the holidays. Then he imparted some endearing wisdom about how true friends are hard to find, and that you should hold on to the ones you care about. His words were heartfelt, but too bad they weren't on the menu.

The food was maybe a step above your run-of-the-mill sit down chain restaurant. I had a 3-taco platter which included a mahi mahi taco, a traditional baja taco, and a cabo shrimp taco. All tasty, but unremarkable. And that pretty much sums up the place: decent asian fusion seafood fare, AWESOME life lessons.
author: Derek L.

description:
We have come to this location a couple of times, and have been impressed on each visit. Its not quite as good as the Corte Madera branch, but still a nice, spacious location with its own parking lot (a huge plus for the crowded area).

In terms of the food, its always top notch. The portions are a little on the small side, but the food is good. The sweet potato fries are a great show stopper, while the off menu Vietnamese sandwich is fantastic...but very hot.

The downside of this location is that it's on the pricey side, as it's pretty hard to get out of here without spending around $35 on a party of two.

Overall, a little pricier than we like, but still a nice location and a nice menu to compliment it.
author: Sami R.

description:
Beware the Dark and Stormy.

In other news.. been here a couple of times.  Left happy and satisfied each time.  The most recent time I came w/ a pretty big group (12 people?) and reserved ahead on Open Table.  They were totally cool when I kept calling in and changing the numbers, almost right up to the actual day.

It's been a while so I don't exactly remember what I got.. but I think it was one of the specials of the day w/ salmon.  I do remember that it had a grilled artichoke.  I'm a sucker for some good artichoke.  And it was good.  The fish too, obvy.  Their sweet potato fries are delish.  I've never been disappointed here.
author: Christie C.

description:
I like the quality & convenience of Pacific Catch on Chestnut. But it's always so elbow to elbow. And if you don't live in the neighborhood, good luck trying to park.

When I learned that there was also a Pac Catch on 9th, I thought it would be the same set up. Was I wrong!

They have free parking.
They have a LOT more space.
The food is priced about the same.
The food comes out quickly & well made.

Only feedback I have is that I am usually a big crab fan- and I am not a huge fan of their crab salad- I just don't care for the ground up, mayonaisey-consistency of the crab- I wish they'd consider using lump or whole pieces of crab leg meat.

Overall, it is a very different experience than the Chestnut location. Almost impersonal because of it's massive size- and slightly a little less casual because of the decor/style. But definitely worth another visit the next time I find myself in that neighborhood.
author: John Eric S.

description:
I've been here multiple times - this review is mostly from my most recent visit, Monday after Christmas (was crowded for a weeknight, probably due to people tired of cooking big holiday meals at home the prior few days and not wanting another night of leftovers!).

We got there close to 8 and had to wait a good 20 minutes (the host said longer, maybe 35) and everything seemed fine. We unluckily got the one bad server that night - it wasn't exactly that he screwed up bigtime specific things, he just seemed like he didn't care. I'm guessing he might've had a bad day or something. All of the other workers on the floor seemed happy, enthusiastic, etc.

The food - I always like it a lot. And when I go everyone else usually orders the fish tacos. Yes, they're good. But I'm the type who likes to try different things, even if I know that I like a specific dish at a specific restaurant. If I try other dishes and I don't like them I'll go back to what I like.

So, this time EVERYONE (7 people) besides myself orders fish tacos. I don't like to call my parents, brothers, and 1st cousins lame - but on this night they all were!

I ordered the thai rice bowl with fish (I think salmon). it said that it had green curry (I am a sissy with spicy, and I hate it) - I asked our server about how spicy it was and he said pretty average. Normally for me that means dude, don't order it - but I did. It was spicy - but tolerable, as in I didn't need to drink 4 ounces of water and wait 2 minutes after swallowing before the next bite. And the rest of it was really good - fresh, hot, a good mix of veggies with everything else.

We didn't order dessert - probably because dad was pretty ticked off.

I give it a 4 for this visit, this is ignoring the negatives about the server - he's human and it seemed like he had the potential to be just as nice as all of the other servers. But he should've not been wearing jeans that sagged (other staff weren't).

I give everyone else in my party a 2. For not trying other things on the menu. For getting angrier than they should've at the server and making it even more of an unpleasant time for all of us. For all of them saying i was weird for not ordering fish tacos then asking me to help them finish theirs even before i finished my fantastic rice bowl.
author: Emmet M.

description: I have no idea what their food is like, but it's awesome that they have heated outdoor seating, happy hour from 4-6pm and 10pm-close, and a pretty quiet and low-key atmosphere such that you could have a decent conversation without shouting (this is very important).  I really liked their spicy pacific martini, it's like a girly cocktail with a kick.
author: Jenn C.

description: I recently came back here and enjoyed the food better than the last time.  I had the today's special yellow tail over brown rice.  It was good but nothing to write home about.  I also tried wild salmon and it was overcooked.  Hawaiian Poke appetizer was tasty.  It was a saturday dinner after 6PM and the wait was only 15 mins.  But in an hour the place was packed.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Unfortunately I chose this restaraunt to celebrate my boyfriends 45th Birthday. The service was so slow and the waiter and waitress were bothered by us when we requested water, or to see their selection of teas.  

As far as the food, he ordered grilled salmon/artichoke/jalepeno sauce, I ordered the meal sized salmon salad. Both of which left much to be desired. The oil on the salmon was all I could taste, when I tasted my boyfriends dish, there was virtually no difference from mine. It was like cafeteria food! 

Lastly, our waitress and waiter came by to check on us once only, the 2 or three times we needed anything, we were searching and waiting to flag them down, neither one would look in our direction. The dressing on my salad was absolutely bitter, unpalatable. 
 
I had long awaited trying the food here because it is just a great location with a nice ambiance, and I'm very sad to say, EVERYTHING was extremely disappointing.....

Don't waste your money.
author: Judy A.

description:
I really enjoy this place!  I go about 
every 2 weeks or so.  Sean the manager
is super nice and had helped me order
since I'm gluten-free!  I give this place 4 1/2
stars sometimes different cooks on certain days.
But this place will have a good variety 
for gluten-free  eaters!  Thanks!!
author: Darlene F.

description:
This is by far my favorite rendition of this space.  Ideally located on a corner spot, near Golden Gate Park, Pacific Catch has an expansive and airy feel.  Add to that the double happy hour times (4-6pm & 10-closing), and you have yourselves a very pleasant atmosphere in which to relax and chat over some mighty fine beverages.  (Don't forget to add sweet potato fries!)

Dinners are quite tasty as well, though all dishes are not created equally.  By far the best bang for the buck is the Wasabi bowl (around $16) with your choice of protein (I'm a fiend for the Hawaiian poke).  You get a huge bowl of rice, seaweed salad, sprouts, wasabi, and all sorts of other tasty additions, plus of course, the poke.  This is the dish that, when ordered, everyone at the table sort of eyes ruefully, perhaps wishing they'd ordered it themselves.  Combine this with the spicy martini (vodka, chili peppers, passion fruit juice), and there I am: leaning back, rubbing my belly, convinced I'm on a tropical vacation, with nothing to do except melt into a silky little puddle of happy place.  

Pacific Catch strikes me as more of a chill with friends or colleagues place, rather than a hot date place.  It is good for groups (definitely make reservations).  I've been told that groups have a 2 hour time limit (even on weekdays), though in my experience that has yet to be enforced.

So to recap:
Go spend a sunny day in the park, get here in time for happy hour, eat, rub your belly.  Thank me later.
author: Ravena F.

description:
As the 3 stars suggest, this place is par for the course. I really liked the set up, there was a bar area and a dining section so the restaurant was accommodating to any party. The waiter was friendly but probably put the cheese on a little too heavily, and by that I mean he was corny and tried too hard to crack jokes. The food itself was good but still, nothing to write home about. 

There's really no need for this place to call itself "Asian Fusion" as the only things Asian about it are the names of the dishes and the bowls the food is served it. Don't be fooled, this is about as Americanized as it gets, and not that that's a bad thing, it just ain't Asian, not even a little bit. Just because I threw some cumin into my stew, that doesn't make the meal "Indian Fusion".
author: Anthony C.

description:
I don't know why this place has any less than 5 stars

- Food, insanely tasty and healthy to boot
- Service, prompt and nice - free refills on soda!
- Atmosphere, clean, stylish
- Price, very reasonable 

My new favorite place in the Inner Sunset for sure
author: Lance B.

description: Great Happy Hour deals!  We had sushi rolls and poke, they were delicious and great HH price!  The decor is nice, friendly and attentive staff too.
author: Jen M.

description:
I love this menu, because there are times when i am at a resto, and i think to myself, why didn't i speak up! i wanted to eat this or that.  
i cannot have that excuse because they have mexi, japi, ameri, fryzi,
sure it is not the authentic creme of the milk of any of those cuisines, but everything they have to offer is still tasty and jammin.
yes, their poke is good with those fried bubbly crackly things.  they use lil sprigs of watercress as garnish for everything.  i usually get some sort of fried fish or fries and they don't disappoint.  last time i was there the catch of the day was red snapper, which is a nice light versatile fish for cooking, they were also offering opah and something else that was NOT swordfish or mahi mahi.  
it is spacious, and they have a full bar.  my margarita tasted like honey.  and the service is helpful, efficient and good looking.
thanks for reading.
author: yayoi s.

description:
Ever since the weird appetizers (cubed raw tuna a la cart served in a paper cup to drunk people) at the Christmas Yelp 'Elite' event last year, I have been wanting to pay a visit to Pacific Catch. I have always heard such good things and could not accept that lame appetizer as the true essence of Pacific Catch. After many hours at the Academy of Science, I wanted Seafood, and Pacific Catch was right there on the corner to full fill my needs! It just so happened to be happy hour too. We were welcomed into a spacious and rather 'safely' designed ambiance - nothing special but still comfortable and nice. 

Anyway, onto the food! Unfortunately I have to do that thing where you can only technically review the happy hour but everything I saw come out of the kitchen looked amazing! We got: plenty of beer, sweet potato fries, calamari, spicy tuna roll and a few sides of rice. I know, nothing totally unique but regardless we had a great experience. After all the beer I was too full to order a real entree. Fast service, quality food at a great price, all on a beautiful day in SF. I cant wait to go back and try the wasabi bowls. Also, I am intrigued about the Chestnut location.
author: Holl T.

description:
I didnt think this place was anything special. It is basically just an asian fusion seafood place and has americanized japanese choices as well.

I ordered the Poke Wasabi Bowl which was basically a Japanese Bowl with Poke on top of rice, with seaweed, etc. It was good but nothing extraordinary. We also got some Salmon Roll, sweet potatoe fries, and calamari for appetizers and those were also just normal. The prices I felt were a little on the higher side as well since the place is suppose to look higher end since its near a lot of other fancy and good choices in that area.
author: Alex H.

description: We had a reservation here with me and my girl for her birthday.  I love the daily menu with different choices. I ordered the Mahi Mahi(tiliapia) taco, steak taco, and shrimp taco. My girl ordered the Sole.  The food was amazing.  I would definitely go here again.  Their appetizers are good we had the ribs.  Love the fusion here. Its not your typical fusion place but its good in a different way.  I gave it 4 stars because it has great food and service.  I will definitely go here again for special occasions.
author: Tri N.

description:
I found this place courtesy of you yelpers out there, and because of you all it is now one of my favorites :)

I took my boyfriend out here for a lunch date in the city. When you first walk in, the ambiance is something of it's own. It has a semi-formal feel, and then it has a casual feel and  I like the fusion of different asian decor. It was rather light out in the day so the sun coming in also had a nice feel. 

Our server was one of the most hospitable that I've ever encountered in my dining out life. He was welcoming since we were new to the place and made recommendations accordingly. He even brought out some of the drink samples (non alcoholic haha mind you) so we could figure out what we'd like. 

We had the thai coconut shrimp appetizer which was delicious, but rather on the small side. My bf has the mixed fish basket and I ordered the fried oyster basket. And they both came with the sweet potato fries! It was so tasty & delicious! The jalapeno tartar sauce was also a nice touch. Oh, and the tropical tea + lemongrass tea fused together tastes like an arnold palmer :) jus thought i'd mix both to give it a try.

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone and everyone. Great service, great ambiance. Parking is a little of a pain but hey, it's the city, it's expected. 

Note to self: A million more things to try next time. Hawaiian Poke. Mahi Mahi Bowl. Etc.
author: Liane T.

description:
Faux friendly service from wait people to management.

Very mediocre and dismal food that borders on giving me a rumbling stomach.  No need for a cleanse or a colonic - my food took care of that for me!   Whooooooooooooosh!  Splat!   Baaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaarf!   And it's not happened just one time, but several, and so now I avoid the place like the plague that it is.
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
i m not a big asian fusion fan probably because i think asian food is traditional enough and shouldn't be made any different. i've been here 3 times and the food is OK. nothing great. the location is great if you need a snack from walking the GGP or the museums. (but there are other food to eat around there also).  

the only thing that i recommend is the happy hour here. on a nice sunny day, the bar and outside seating is packed.  happy hour is from 4p-6p so get your orders in before 6p.  

here's their HH menu: 
Hawaiian Poke - sushi-grade ahi tuna in a sesame-soy marinade & spicy seasonings with wonton crisps
Asparagus & Shiitake - asparagus tempura & shiitake mushrooms with miso dressing
Spicy Tuna - ahi tuna with sriracha mayo
Thai Coconut Shrimp - Thai sweet-chili sauce
Spicy Cabo Calamari - crispy chili & lemon with spicy chipotle sauce
Warm Edamame - Hawaiian Alaea sea salt
Basket of Fries - "signature" sweet potato, traditional or spicy 

and yup, we ordered 3 of everything on the HH menu to beat the time! get their sweet potato fries, i like that one the best
author: Kapo T.

description:
My girlfriend and I come here 2-4 times a month minimum. Love it! Katie the manager is a firecracker of a sweetheart, the bartenders make some delicious (read strong and tasty) drinks, they have t.v.'s above the bar, and the service is always friendly and neighborly. Neil is our favorite! 

About the food: all very clean, crisp, fresh and satisfying without breaking the bank. You can often request and substitute your order to fit your dietary needs (i.e. gluten free, brown rice, more salad versus rice in your rice bowl, etc.)

Bonus: Sign up for their monthly email alerts and you'll receive coupons for free starters and the like. 

Double Bonus: AMAZING make you wanna do the happy dance happy hours. 

Necessary: Sunshine roll and sweet potato fries. Eat and Repeat!

Parking: Park in the park.
author: J F.

description:
After a pretty big banquet lunch at Golden Horse, I figured I was done eating for the day. We dropped by my folks place after lunch, and since they haven't seen the kids in a while, they wanted to spend some time with them. They offered to watch the girls and feed them dinner, so the wife and I can go out for dinner. 

What a nice surprise! An unexpected date night with my wife. Yeah, we were still full from lunch, but we took my folk's offer and headed out. Problem was that it was 7PM on a Saturday night, we had no reservations, and most places were pretty crowded already. We struck out on a couple of places either because parking sucked (No Nopa this time), business closed (bye PJ's), or I was wearing the wrong clothes (I had a sweater, and Naan and Curry was steaming inside, unless I wanted a permanent tandoori smell).

We walked into Pacific Catch, and got a table in the bar area. Pretty lively inside the bar area, with the Cal vs. UCLA hoops game going on (too bad Cal). A lot of people in the bar section were dining in, so the waitresses were doing double duty serving drinks and serving food. 

We ordered: 

-House Cured Sake Salmon. This came with 2 crispy nori rice cakes, wasabi creme fraiche, onions, and black tobiko caviar. Salmon had a mildly cured taste, the wasabi creme fraiche had a little, but not overpowering kick. Rice cakes were nice and crispy. OK starter. 

-2 Chipotle BBQ Salmon Tacos. This was a mistake. My wife wanted 1 salmon taco, and one Cabo shrimp taco, but they gave her 2 salmon tacos, but she didn't complain. These taco were topped with cabbage, corn salsa, and lime crema. Nice big chunk of salmon in each taco, and very tasty. 

-5 piece Fish and chips. Fish of the day was rock cod. This came with cole slaw and sweet potato fries. Lightly battered so not to overwhelm the fresh rock cod. Very juicy and moist on the inside, slight crispiness on the outside. Came with a jalapeno tartar sauce and and a Thai sweet chili sauce. I added some more sriracha sauce for more kick. Purple-cabbage cole slaw had a nice light vinaigrette for refreshing taste, instead of a creamy sauce. Sweet potato fries were great. Not overly fried, but crispy enough so I could still taste the sweet potatoes. 

Too full for dessert : ( 

Food came out pretty quickly, and the servers remembered and follow on requests in spite of the bar being elbow to elbow. 

I driven by this place for years while driving along Lincoln Blvd, and glad we finally tried it. Places like this reminded my wife and I of our dating years. Nice memories......
author: Steve L.

description:
What a fabulous concept!  Inexpensive American/Hawaiian/Australian/Peruvian/pan-Asian seafood with full bar, great cocktails, inventive recipes, sushi rolls, sandwiches, fried dishes.  It's like Roy's, but half the price and twice the fun.  

The space is stunning, comfortable, elegant, casual, and grand, all at the same time.   25 foot ceiling throughout, outdoor heated porch, booths, cushions, bar seats, kitchen counter seats, all spaced far enough that you have a little space because it's a huge building and they have room to burn.  It's new, clean, and well-maintained.

One look at the menu, you're salivating, and you think wow, this could be my favorite place, it's gonna put Park Chow down the street out of business: donburi bowls, fish sandwiches, sushi rolls, poke, ceviche, full fish dinners, fried shrimp...

Another look at the menu, a third look at the menu.  I got a lot of looks at the menu because nobody came and the kitchen was closing :(  It was overstaffed and they all seemed so busy...talking on the phone, socializing with customers, wandering around lost.  They work on the group waiter situation, so you can get ignored by ten people instead of just one person.  I flagged three people down and still no waiter for fifteen minutes so I finally ordered from the bartender.

When the food came it was kind of blah.  Overcooked for the most part, not balanced out very well, definitely nothing exciting.  Coconut rice was mushy and had no spark to it.  Even though they use very ingredients.  I don't think they know what they're doing food-wise, and they seem to be cooking by numbers.  Maybe I shouldn't have ordered the specials - one secret of dining out is don't order the specials at a heavily themed restaurant: they've perfected their staples but don't have the kitchen leadership to invent on the spot.

The cocktail list was equally appetizing and they delivered on that.  The "spicy martini" was worth it, fresh lime, mango puree, vodka, a little syrup, and a fresh hot pepper they must have rimmed the glass with.  Just a really tasty thing to be drinking.

I guess I'll withhold judgment and try it a couple more times before I write it off.  It wasn't the staff, they seemed competent and friendly, just adrift.  I so want to like this place, and if they can get the execution to match the concept this could be big, as in food network tourist towns around the world big.

A tip here: prices are already very inexpensive for what it is, and for happy hour (4-6 and 10 to closing) they have $3 beers and the appetizer menu is discounted even more.  You could stuff your gourd silly on calamari and beer for about twelve dollars a person.
author: Gil S.

description: Like. i honestly can't remember what i ordered, but my sister ordered a sushi salad, and it was........ incredible. so tasty! it was a deal. i love the concept, and the food was all really really good.
author: Aletheia W.

description:
I'm upping the star count cuz the Tuna Poke Wasabi Bowl is still incredibly good. And they were able to split the portion into 2 bowls so my friend and I could share so we each had our own bowl of mini poke bowls.

The fact I crave the Tuna Bowl calls for 5 stars.
author: Cindy W.

description: Recently came back here with some friends and was pretty disappointed with my fish tacos (my fault for not going 10 more blocks for delicious fish tacos at Underdog) as well as the overall atmosphere. Sweet potato fries were a little sad and not as good as I remembered. Place was empty for lunch on a Saturday and felt like we were eating at an Islands. In hindsight, I'd prefer eating at Islands - I would have enjoyed a Big Wave burger and fries much more.
author: Kelly R.

description:
You can't go wrong eating here.  This is my regular spot, at least a few times a month.  

Food is great, raw seafood is fresh, cooked seafood is done right and never over cook.

They have special menus for the month and season but you won't get bored of their food.  I have my regular meals but sometimes I adventure into their special monthly menu if I see something I like or interesting.  

All the employees are very pleasant and helpful.  Chelsea is one of their best server and she make sure your meal is exactly what you order/want.  I understand the kitchen can sometime make a mistake, but they never hesitate to get the order fixed to the right way.  

Great service, fresh seafood and changing menus keep us their regular customer.
author: C Y.

description:
This chain restaurant should have stayed in the Marina.  From the name you might think seafood galore, right?  Instead you get Japanese, Korean, and Tacos!  Tacos?  You gotta be kidding me!

They try to staisfy the fish portion by having fish and chips.  Too bad they are about the worst fish and chips ever had!  And for $12 not a good value either!  Greasy and not crispy...horrible!

Stay away chain stores!
author: Sir Paul L.

description: The food is ok, but I would have expected a higher quality fish for the price.  Nothing we had was bad, but nothing was particularly great either.  The restaurant itself is very noisy, so it was difficult to hold a conversation.
author: Jackie P.

description:
Under the sea
Under the sea
Nobody beat us
Fry us and eat us
In fricassee
We what the land folks loves to cook
Under the sea we off the hook
We got no troubles
Life is the bubbles
Under the sea!

I feel really bad for people who don't eat seafood.  I love me some fish! 
 
I know a lot of feathers were ruffled when Pacific Catch took the place of Canvas.  One less hipster coffee shop in SF, boo-freakin-hoo.  I really like what they did with the space here and I think Pacific Catch adds a lot to the Inner Sunset restaurant selection.  
The Hawaiian poke is my personal favorite (that's what SHE said), on top o' rice bowl or a salad.  The Baja Shrimp Ceviche starter is a another highlight, arriving in a classy martini glass with tortilla chips.  Island tacos, fresh sushi rolls, stews and fish and chips (with sweet potato fries!)  are also scrumptious choices and help diversify the menu.  There really is a little something for everyone.  This location next to the park is ideal and the limited outdoor seating is lovely.  

I've had consistently spotty service here, with the place both packed and empty.  But even so, luckily the food itself is consistently delicious and fresh.  If you have the patience to endure being ignored by the waitstaff and a large space CRAWLING with young kids (Hey -I love 'em, but I know some people don't....) Pacific Catch is a solid casual dining spot.
author: Kerry D.

description:
This restaurant has something for everyone! My good friend and I brought our moms here after a visit to the Academy of Sciences on one of those rare, gloriously sunny Sundays. My friend and I wanted sushi and our moms wanted fish and chips or ceviche so we came here.

I was surprised the restaurant wasn't more crowded on such a beautiful day. We got a table outside and sipped beer and pisco sours in the warm sun. My friend's mom did not like her pisco sour martini, she said it tasted like it was made from a mix. Well, in all fairness it was a pisco sour *martini* so it was not going to taste exactly like a pisco sour. She is from Chile and a connoisseur :)

I ordered the shrimp tempura sushi and my friend got the spicy tuna and a vegetarian roll. The rolls are huge and definitely well priced for 8 pieces ($7.00-8.00.) They drizzle a mayo-like sauce on them so if you're a purist I would suggest skipping the sauce.

We got the sweet potato fries and they were just as good as everyone else has commented here. I've never had bad ones so I have nothing to compare them to. I loved the horseradish dipping sauce they served with them. I'd like to come back just for drinks and appetizers sometime.

My friend's mom got the shrimp ceviche which was very good. It was loaded with cilantro and avocado. It came with corn chips for dipping. My mom got the fish and chips and was very happy with hers. Overall, everything was delicious, fresh, flavorful and satisfying. 

The service was great too. Our table was tiny but we had two servers helping us rearrange things to get everything to fit. I couldn't imagine a better way to spend my Sunday, sitting in the sun, sipping a corona with lime, eating sushi and sweet potato fries with my friend and our lovely moms. I can't wait to do this again!
author: L. L.

description: Good fish and interesting menu. Huge place so it's great for groups.  I had the fish and chips (sweet potato fries) and the fish was good and the fries were yummy.
author: Ang F.

description:
I go here because parking is usually convenient and the food is above average. I have never been there when there isn't a child seated near me. 

Edamame and goldfish pretzel crackers? Interesting....
Poke - very good.
Seaweed salad - Excellent, with cucumber and citrus.
Sweet potato fries - crispy and sweet.
Cerviche - eh.
Yellow tail special - had a bit too much seasoning, but was fresh and light.

Would I go again. Yes. They are consistent.
author: A I.

description:
All Aboard!  Get ready to set sail on a FISHY adventure! 
If ever a man wants to get to my heart...let him do it with a POKE! 
Hawaiian Poke that is. Pacific Catch has great fresh seafood, and the best Hawaiian Poke this side of Hawaii.
As compared to the Marina location, this has tons more seating. 
Parking can be hit or miss.  If you go for dinner, it's easier, as you can park across the street at Golden Gate Park.

I am an anti Valentine kinda girl.  In fact, I wish Hallmark would call the holiday what it really is : Happy eat, drink anything you LOVE with those that make you smile Day.  So...going along with this them, I requested my date take me to eat one of my favorite things.

As a starter, the cube and I shared one of the special ceviches on the board. All I remember was big chunks of fish, lime, tomato, and fried plantain chips. At $7.95, I was in heaven. 

For dinner, he had a trio of tacos while I had a Hawaiian Poke ($14.95) wasabi bowl.  Topped with wakame salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, cucumber, ginger, sesame seeds, shredded nori and soy-wasabi sauce served over sushi rice. I asked for brown.

Healthy, delicious, fast, and convenient. Now that's romance!  Forget that they sat us down and told us they needed the table back in an hour and a 1/2...it didn't spoil our efficient LOVE dinner.
author: Flor D.

description:
I came here last night for my birthday dinner with my girls and i thought the food was pretty good. I wanted to order the hawaiian mahi mahi, but it just happens that they were running low on fish that day or something because upon ordering, our waitress announced that they ran out of mahi mahi and a LONG list of other items :*(

So to replace my mahi, i got the mong chong fish. i dont know what that is but it sure ain't the same as mahi. oh well. i'll try back another time. The pineapple fried rice was just okk...it was a bit on the soggy side though, so try to avoid that & their weak skinny onion rings.

It was so hard to choose what I wanted from the menu since everything sounded so good but I have to come back next time to try their fish tacos. I'm craving for some fish tacos & sweet potato fries right now! yum! Oh my friend got the lemongrass iced tea along with added sweeteners & it was so refreshing!

Overall, i thought this place was decent and accommodating to our party of 12 even though we all arrived at different times. damn asians.

i give it a 3.5
author: Rosalynn D.

description:
I'd have sworn that I already wrote a review for this place, and came here to update it.  Nothing here, so I'll write a whole brand-spanking-new review.

The first time I ate here with my Mr. M., it had just opened a few weeks earlier.  We had a lovely time and enjoyed some good, fresh food with some delicious drinks.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  I thought that's what I said in my first review, which I actually hadn't written, at all.

The update is:  we ate there again a few weeks ago.  Bleh!  What happened to you, P.C.?  The waiter was incredibly slow (though, admittedly, very nice when he was actually present).  The seafood tacos were greasy and tasteless.  The previously savory-sweet pineapple rice was just salty and oily.  Did you fire your entire staff and bring on a bunch of ditch diggers to do the work?

Boo.  Parking is nearly impossible.  Not worth the trip nor the expense.  I felt like I'd eaten at Red Lobster for twice the price.
author: Bert M.

description:
Their Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl is very yummy! 
I like their late night happy hour items as well!
author: Jobin C.

description:
After hearing so much praise for the fish tacos at Pacific Catch I finally tried them. They are delicious! A real treat and well made. My only criticism is the steak taco. The meat was good but I think the chef needs to slice the steak into strips rather than just one long piece. Not that easy to swallow. 

Yet the sweet potato fries were great as well the thinly sliced onion rings on top that had just a faint amount of batter on them. So they had a bit of crunch but were not smothered in a heavy greasy batter as typical onion rings are. 

The Ahi was just right and delicious. The sauces were hot but flavorful. Oh and the homemade Miso soup is satisfying. Also try the Lemongrass Ice Tea, very good when eating those really spicy dishes. So refreshing. 

Service is good, even when busy and on a weekend, like Friday or Saturday the place gets busy and fills up fast. 

When I go back I want to try the dessert menu. macadamia nut brownies, sound outstanding as I am a fan of macadamia nut anything.

One of my coworkers Robert Callan praises Pacific Catch and he too enjoys the fish tacos. If you ever want to know more about the City and places to go, eat, etc. Talk to Robert. See his web site at:

http://www.robertcallanjr.com/
author: Jonathan F.

description:
Oh Pacific Catch,
You used to be a 4 but now you're a 0 so you average a 2. I was a reguar (about 3x/week) at the Pacific Catch on 9th because I lived fairly close, because they have a parking garage (although it's packed most of the time), and mainly because they have happy hour from 10-12. I've tried everything on their happy hour menu and among my favorites are the hawaiin poke, spicy fries, calamari, and lemon drop martini. 
Why I haven't been in awhile: On 3/17, the waiter handed us a not so fresh order of Hawaiian poke. Its color was brown with a hint of red. My boyfriend and I did not mention anything because we thought they had a bad batch of fish that day. As we were about to leave, we saw a fresh, bright red batch of Hawaiian poke served to the table behind us. 

Yes, asians don't tend to send their orders back but make sure it does not happen again please. 

And employee discounts should be allowed even for happy hour then I will think about coming back :).
author: Goldie L.

description: Went here last night around 8:30 to celebrate one of my good friends new jobs. We were seated immediatly, our waitress took our drink order and brought some edamame and goldfish pretzels to snack on while we looked over the menu. I had a glass of wine while my friend had some guava drink with mint. She won on the drinks, it was really tasty. We had brown rice sushi as a starter which was good but the rice didn't stick well. For the entree I ordered the Poki Japanese Wasabi Bowl with Brown Rice. First off, they scored major points with me for the brown rice option but secondly, we just came back from Hawaii about two weeks ago and I had a brown rice ahi bowl in Hawaii that this one was 5x's better! The poki was buttery, fresh and had good flavor as did the sauce the use in the bowl. Healthy dinner at a reasonable price. I think I found a new go-to spot!
author: Christina F.

description:
Crispy.  Oysters.  Crispy oysters crispy oysters crispy oysters CRISPYOYSTERS YAY!

I've meant to come here for ages, on the recommendation of one of my foodie friends.  I'm glad I finally did.  I understand this is a local chain, but don't let that deter you: it might be a little sanitized and carefully-put-together, but the food is awesome.

I had the "mixed catch basket" ($13.95) and my friend had a mahi-mahi sandwich ($8-$10, not on the menu - mahi mahi, sprouts, avocado, and other apparently delicious accoutrement).  The mixed catch basket has 3-4 crispy oysters (did I mention how much I loved those?), three big pieces of the catch of the day, a skewer of coconut shrimp, and your choice of fries (sweet potato!).  There were also two sauces - one was a ginger-wasabi cream sauce, and the other was a sweet and spicy sauce.

I don't eat much normally, but I scarfed that basket of goodness down like a thirteen-year-old-boy-undergoing-a-growth-spurt.   It was worth every penny.  

At 5pm on a Thursday it was practically empty, and there seemed to be acres of seating.  The decor is really pretty (I want the graduated hanging-blue-bottle light fixtures, over the bar, for my apartment, please), the service was pleasant, and our food came out quite fast.  

I balk a little at a $6 glass of wine, but I was headed to the Academy of Sciences Nightlife, where wine is $8/glass... so it's all relative, I suppose.

And did I mention the crispy oysters?  I think my only complaint was that there weren't more.  To eat on the epic journey to CAS, and to eat on the way back, and to eat for breakfast, and oh for heaven's sake...why don't I have a personal chef?

EDIT - 03/30/09 --
I took my dad, uncle, and assorted other people here on a Saturday night.  They were pretty good about serving a party of 8, and everyone seemed to enjoy the food.

Two things I wanted to update about: 
1. The spicy pacific martini.  Holy CRAP, that is good.  Mango puree, vodka, and serrano chili - the perfect fruit drink, with a spicy kick.  Goes so well with seafood, and worth the $8 (I don't say that lightly, either).

2. Food mixup.  When I pointed out to the server that my mixed catch basket lacked crispy oysters (ack!) she was going to bring me a side of them, but ended up bringing me another entire entree!  I was really pleased, and it never hurts to bring home leftovers.
author: Jennie K.

description:
Out of the three Pacific Catch locations, I would say this is my overall favorite. Chestnut St. is just way too tiny and crowded, though that might result in the food tasting better because you had to fight so hard to park/get a table. Corte Madera's location is too embedded in the outdoor mall scene and has way too many kiddies running around. But this 9th Ave. location is pretty much perfect with plenty of seating for the bar and regular dining area. It also has its own parking lot so you don't have to compete for the street meters. 

Food is pretty consistent at all locations. You can count on the fact that mostly everything you order from the regular menu will be very good. Some of my favorites are the wasabi bowls (with brown or sushi rice) and any of the fried seafood baskets. I love the Mixed Catch Basket with fish, coconut shrimp and crispy oysters with jalapeño tartar. SO GOOD. Everything comes freshly fried with those awesome sweet potato fries. But eat everything while they are fresh! I don't recommend taking leftover fries home. They really those their flavor after they've cooled down. 

Though their sushi roll selection lacks raw fish, I think they are still made very well with the mostly cooked ingredients. One of my favorites and one that DOES have raw fish is the Rising Sun roll. It has tempura shrimp and avocado wrapped in ahi tuna with a citrus sauce. I don't like that they stuff pickled ginger into the roll but if you're like me, just request that they leave it out. Otherwise it's a very tasty roll. The ahi tuna is always fresh and flavorful.  I love that they give you big pieces of it too. (We got that roll totally F-R-E-E! with the coupon in the Green Zebra book!) I could dine happily on their sushi rolls alone. 

Just recently I ventured off from my regulars and tried one of the their specials: Trout bbq'd baja style so it was spice rubbed and grilled, served with tomatilla avocado sauce, some thin slices of veggies, and fresh grilled corn over sweet potato fries. I could tell the fish was very fresh but for me, it was TOO seasoned and got a little salty since the fish wasn't very thick. And though I had originally wanted the fries, I would now have preferred and wished that the fish was served over rice. I think I'll stick to my regulars next time. 

Big pluses:
-I've talked to the workers and seen for myself that Pacific Catch is environmentally conscious. They use biodegradable materials, from the takeout containers to the straw in your drink. Pacific Catch also practices composting from their kitchen to the leftover food scraps. Smiles all around. =D
-I don't know anywhere else that you can get UNLIMITED refills on Thai iced tea. I could drink three glasses easy. LOVE IT!
author: Julia T.

description:
I love Pacific Catch.  Casual and easygoing environment with decent prices, good food, and fruity cocktails.

I've been here a few times before and I've always had a good time.  Several times I've ordered the fish tacos, poke, and fantastic speciality cocktails who's names I cannot recall.  I've had the coconut shrimp--which were only OK, but since they came with sweet potato fries, I was a happy camper and forgave the overly friend shrimps.  The desserts were HEAVEN.  The Macadamia Nut chocolate cake was to die for.  Very rich, so share with at least one other person.

I recent went there with a few friends for Happy Hour (4-6 weekdays).  I have to say I had a great time.  We sat near the bar on a few couches and ordered a truck-load of food: Poke for half price (instead of $11.95 its only $5.95, and seriously its the regular portion!), Spicy Tuna Rolls, calamari, and sweet potato fries for only $3.  The spicy tuna roll was OK, but everything else was heaven.  It also helps that there's $3 pints and $4 well drinks.  NICE.  

The service is attentive and friendly.  Our waiter got extra points for checking in with us before Happy Hour was over ("Do you want to order anything else before HH ends?"---loved it!).

PC is also a place I want to bring friends who visit from out of town. Its a nice place to grab some fusion Pacific-region food and fancy cocktails that you can't find anywhere else.

Parking off of Irving is always tough, but during happy hour it was easy to find parking on surrounding streets.  By 7pm, the dinner crowd rolled in deep.  I suggest carpooling to save some time and space.
author: Marissa N.
