description: One of my favorite restaurants! Delicious and very fresh seafood! Happy hour is a great deal and the poke appetizer is amazing!
author: Regina S.

description: Ate there last week and it was bad-sweet potato fries were very oily and soggy the coconut shrimp were not well cooked the artichoke was hardly done and we couldn't eat it.Sorry but this is the worst meal I ever ate there and since I live in the Sunset this is sad.
author: Heidi B.

description: Been here a few times and I've always left satisfied. Most favorite item on the menu is the Japanese Wasabi rice bowl with Hawaiian poke. Comes in a big big bowl with nori, ginger, rice, seaweed salad, and your choice of hawaiian poke, grilled salmon, seared tuna or crab. YUM! Also really like their Guava mint cooler. Alcoholic drink..but you don't taste it too much.
author: Rhonda H.

description:
Like most fish restaurants, Pacific Catch doesn't have very much for a vegetarian to eat.  I am very familiar with this particular conundrum, which for some reason seems to affect fish restaurants more than, say, steakhouses, which is odd because you would think people who went to steak restaurants would be less picky about their diets than those who went to fish places.

In any case, Pacific Catch breaks the mold, at least a little bit, because there's a specifically non-fish, vegetarian salad on the menu.  It comes with seared tofu that looks slightly like fish but that is kinda a little bit tasteless.  It's all right, though, and the rest of the salad is pretty delicious.

I wasn't expecting much from this place when I came here, and I pretty much hated Canvas Gallery (this location's former business), so I was pleasantly surprised.  Not four-star-rating surprised, but surprised nonetheless.

It was annoying having to wait even though there were plenty of empty tables.  I got the distinct impression that they didn't have enough servers working, so filling up those tables with that staffing would have been disaster, but it is strange to see so many clean, empty tables when you're waiting outside in the cold for one.

The service is all right, although the lack of servers shows.
author: John S.

description:
Ate there last night (Friday evening, 12/3/10) and don't think I will be going back. Service, menu, and food quality have gone markedly downhill. There were not many people in the place, which made it feel kind of drab. The so-called Korean soup tasted like hot sour soup out of a can.  The vegetable salad was over-dressed with what tasted like bottled ranch. Though food portions are good and prices reasonable, if on the high side, the service was awful. Just the attitude of the wait staff felt surly....like we were bothering them.
$50 is lot of money these days, I wish I had mine back.
author: Jono H.

description:
It takes a lot for me to be content much less impressed with any place serving food and drinks. I come from a restuarant background and am very critical. 

Not only was I content with this place, I was impressed. I grabbed a fee buddies last Friday night and went around the city for some drinks and appotizers. I ordered my usual (manhattan straight up in a tumbler). I have to say it's one of the top three I've had to date. So good that I ordered two more throughout the evening. We all sat at the bar and received our drinks and ordered some apps. Sweet potatoe fries edemame and ceveiche. We ended up ordering a duplicate order, they were that good. The bar staff was friendly and made some great drink recommendations, they even suggested other places around for drinks and apps. 

They did not send us to anyplace that was a "dive". They were all good but not quite the caliber of this place. 

Thanks for the great drinks, appitizers and friendly service. Will definately be back.
author: Ryker B.

description:
I don't know who invented mysitic tans but whoever did, I really dislike you! After a long busy night and then a long busy morning at work, I was starving. Everyone decided to tan and do mytics the last minute and I just wasn't feeling it. I was so happy when I got off that all I wanted to do was stuff my face with food because that is all I was thinking about. I did have a bag of Ruffles on the desk but couldn't eat it since I had clients sitting on the couch staring at me.. I wouldn't want no orange lips, smelly cheesy breath, and pieces of chips all over me... that's just not professional....

After I got off, we headed to Pacific Catch! Finally got the chance to come try this place out! I've heard mixed reviews but more good then bad. I've wanted to try this place out since I saw it on Chestnut but never had the chance. Glad I ended my year with a good meal. 

Everything on the menu and everything on other customers tables looked so good but I came in here knowing what I was going to order. The rice bowls! I knew that I was going to order the Hawaiian Poke Rice bowl since I saw many great looking pictures. We also got a whole basket of sweet potato fries.. Yum!!!!

The basket of sweet potato fries ($4.95) came with two sides of dips, wasabi mayo and chili sweet and sour? Wasabi mayo was delicious. Went great with the sweet potato fries.. Those were amazingly good. Crispy and sweet. Then my big bowl of Hawaiian Poke ($14.95) came. You could choose between sushi rice or brown rice. Me, of course went with the sushi rice! The big bowl came with tons of fresh tuna cubes, topped with wakame salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, cucumber, ginger, sesame seeds, shredded nori and soy-wasabi sauce. I just wanted to dive into the bowl and stuff it all in my mouth. But I am a lady, and I do have manners at the table.. sometimes... Everything in the bowl was yummy besides the avocado.. There were big brown spots everywhere. Ewww... I didn't know if it was suppose to be eaten like a bi bim bap or just pick things out as you go.. So I just mixed everything together and ate it. So good. I think there bowls are a must order because I noticed a lot of the tables ordered those too!

The place itself had a very comfy feel. Service could of been better. I was getting very impatient with the waitress. My water glass was not filled and I was thirsty, and the check took FOREVER to come.... I would definitely come back because everything else on the menu sounded good.
author: Juliane N.

description:
My friends and I came here for appetizers before heading to our work prom, as it was recommended by one in our group.  I was told that the fried oysters are a treat.  They were, and so was the shrimp cocktail, calamari, fries/sweet potato fries, and other items which I'm unable to recall.

We had a reservation waiting for us.  Some of my other coworkers showed up without a reservation and were seated very quickly even though the place was crowded.  That's a positive on their service.  As for the value of the food, well we weren't looking for cheap.  We didn't order any entrees, yet it was enough to last most of us through the night without a full dinner, and only cost $10 per person.  Not bad!

This is a really nice place, we were dressed up in suits, ladies in dresses and didn't feel out of place, nor were others who were dressed more casually.
author: Raymond C.

description:
You guy's ever been to Puerto Alegre - you know in the Mission ... You order a bunch of drinks so by the time you food gets to your table your working on a good buzz so the food is an after thought. 

Well Pacific Catch is just that and after thought. It's more of a T.G.I.F. meets Red Lobster the dinning area has gigantic both that remind me of a Denny's or a Yellow Basket in a suburb some where in southern cal or better yet a restaurant in a Vegas Casino. Ticky- tack if you find your self at P.C. go for the happy hour and stay in the bar area at least you can pretend your at a sports bar in an airport lobby. The service was it's only redeeming quality. The Bartender was funny and made our drink just right, the server was fast and polite and honest about the food. We order most of there apps - not so good and the bill was 125.00 including a large tip for the staff. Would I go back maybe if the beer was really cheaper but it still feels like a suburban restaurant. 

OK,  Pacific Catch is a great place if you have friends from out of town like Orange County and they what to feel like they're  back In H.B.
author: swys -.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 stars. 

I read alot of the reviews prior to coming here tonight and i was pleasantly surprised with the atmosphere, service and food. Atmosphere was beautful, i really enjoyed the high ceilings and cool decorations. Service was good; whenever I wanted to look around to ask someone to refill my water - my waiter was there already doing it. 

Tonight we tried:
-Poke Appetizer
- 3 piece Fish and chips (tonights fish was Talipia)
- Skirt Steak Rice Bowl

We finished ALL the food - and was very full. The rice bowl was huge and the fish and chips hit the spot. I really liked that the fries were sweet potato fries (YUMM!!).. the spicy chili sauce is actually Mai Ploy sauce. You can get it at any asian supermarket (for some yelpers that commented about the sauce).  Overall, we'd come back.
author: Julie F.

description: This place continues to let me down.  I went here a couple months ago and decided to not return after my wasabi bowl was 99% brown rice and 1% sushi, avocado, ginger and seaweed salad.  The portions were just cheap cheap cheap for a pretty expensive price tag for take out.  I decided to try it again tonight. Guh.  Although the portions were spot on, nothing was executed well.  The rice was raw, not the good kind of al dente, but truly too raw to bite through.  Then, the worst part? They forgot the wasabi sauce. Either improve the food or dramatically lower the price tag so my expectation decrease with it.  I walk by this place nearly every day on the way to the park with my dog. I'm rooting for them out of convenience but I think I'm done trying.  One more shot and that's it for me.
author: Amanda L.

description:
Another fun experience at Pacific Catch.  When I first reserved the spot, I didn't get why 6 and 7 mattered that much.  At 6 persons, a table was available for 7:00pm, but with 7, NO!  had to make it 7:15 which turned to 7:25ish to get seated.  Nonetheless, i'm glad the table we got was nice and big and allowed everyone to really enjoy their meal and share embarassing memories.  

And certainly, I'm never going to go to the Marina one since this place is so much bigger and nicer.  Between the 7 of us, a lot of people got the sushi which everyone enjoyed.  Diana K. and I shared the firecracker (I believe) which was really big and tasty with the fresh fish.  

I ordered for myself, the Crab Salad RICE BOWL, which they accidently put in as just the Crab Salad.  I guess its ok to eat a little bit more greens.  I'm cool with that and I really did enjoy it.  The dressing on the veggies was lightly tangy and sweet and the crab meat was plentiful.  I probably would have enjoyed the rice too, but did quite good without it.
author: Vincent K.

description:
"Spooning leads to forking" may be great nocturnal advice for an intimately-challenged couple, but it sure is not a pretty sight for a couple to be eating with their spoon AND fork at the same time. 

It was an eye opening experience to see them shoveling their fried rice with their Ahi Tuna poke (rhymes with hokey-pokey) almost non-stop until their plates were clean.  I almost said to our server:  I wanna have what they are having.  

If you have never tried Pacific Catch, please try some of their best Asian/ Fusion dishes: shrimp ceviche, crab and avocado salad, poke wasabi bowl, ahi bowl, rock cod, and their sweet potato fries.  They have been consistently delicious at this location.  Also opt for the brown rice as a healthy option.  

If you have to get sushi, their spicy tuna roll stands out.

Since Pacific Catch's parking lot fills up quickly, you can park one block away in Golden Gate Park.  You are close to the museums and botanical garden - perfect to stroll after a date.

Drinks are a bit on the weak side, even though the pomegranate mojitos and lemongrass mojitos are tasty before the ice melts.

Decor is nice and roomy inside with a few outdoor tables.
Bathroom is pleasantly clean.  Servers and hostesses are friendly.

Tips:
*  Call ahead for best seating.  Otherwise they will seat you close to the bar and not in the booths.
 
It was the couple's anniversary, and maybe they were in a hurry to move onto their next activity.  Anyway, I wish them happy spooning and happy forking!

                                   S
F   FF   F                 SSS
F   FF   F              SSSSS
F   FF   F              SSSSS
F   FF   F                 SSS
FFFFFF      +             S         =   Pig  Out!
      FF                         S
      FF                         S
      FF                         S
      FF                         S
      FF                         S
author: CT L.

description: The special crab asparagus soup is just ok, both does not have dept.  Salty salty ceviche samplers.  The poke ahi was very heavy and salty in soy sauce. The white fish Peru ceviche was heavy in a salty yellow sauce with so much chopped  tomatoes & not so much fish.  The shrimp avacado was salty too. Overall it was just average.
author: M P.

description: Nice people, but really - the food arrived before the Martini??? Long before the Martini! The prices are a bit high relative to the quality of the food. Big portions, slow drinks and lots of smiles. The smiles are the reason for the third star, otherwise I felt like I was at a seafood version of Chilis.
author: Gary C.

description:
I felt a little let down with the food here. The coconut shrimp was just okay. Honestly the frozen coconut shrimp from Trader Joe's is my favorite. I wasn't a fan of the sweet chili dipping sauce. C'mon, you can buy that stuff in any Asian grocery store (even TJ's has their version). I wish restaurants would be more creative and make their own sauces. The sweet potato fries were good. The california roll was okay.

I like the concept but the food I had wasn't anything special. Since I'm not much of a seafood eater, my only option was the shrimp and coconut shrimp always seems like a good idea. Don't get me wrong, I ate the whole basket (even the slaw, which I'm usually not a fan of) but I didn't feel that it was worth the money. $12.95 for some sweet potato fries and about 8 pretty small shrimps just didn't feel right.

Service was good. We had brought our own dessert for my friend's birthday and they put them on plates and served them to us. Even though it wasn't cake, the waiter put a candle in one and we sang Happy Birthday to my friend.

I wouldn't make the drive from the East Bay just for this place, but if I happened to be in the area, I just might give it a second shot. But don't hold me to it.
author: Joshua C.

description:
The owners and the cooks should fire the wait staff. Well, maybe just the server we had last night. But still.

The point is this: Pacific Catch would've been a shoe-in for four, maybe 4.5, stars were it not for the attitude of our server, which lasted the entire 90-minute duration of our visit.

It wasn't the same person, but the fact that I was brought water (after not having been offered it for the better part of 45 minutes in) in a glass that had a crack that would dwarf the San Andreas fault doesn't help matters.

But, the Hawaiian Poke appetizer and Cabo Shrimp tacos I got were totally delicious, amazing I dare say. A lot of creativity goes into the seasoning and synthesizing of dishes here. The tacos were served with black beans (average) and my choice, sweet potatoes fries (heaven). So, hats off to the chef, cooks, and owners.

But shame on you, server. I mean, was it the fact that me and the love of my life shamed ourselves by sitting on the same side of our spacious booth? That we took an extra 3.2 seconds to order because we weren't sure what we wanted to drink? What was it?

Whatever it was, it should've been overlooked, because you dampened an otherwise awesome dinner.

The clientele should've bothered me, but didn't. I think the seclusion of our booth helped matters.

I'll go back, for sure, because the optimist in me wants to believe this was a one-off.
author: Jeff H.

description:
This space is just fabulous. It's on the corner of 9th and Lincoln. I loved this space when it was Canvas Cafe. It was the best cafe in all of sunset. Sad that it closed. But anyway, enough nostalgia.

The restaurant is very spacious. The way they set up the tables gives you a lot of privacy. Reason we came here was because my friend loved their sweet potato fries. It didn't disappoint. Sushi here is good too. They used to make a roll with mango that was(and I quote) "like orgasm in my mouth". We didn't see it on the menu anymore so ordered sake sake roll (salmon soaked in sake) instead. It wasn't fancy but it was damn good.

Now the entrees, I got the miso salmon and my friends got ahi three way and korean bbq beef. I was already half full at this point so I didn't enjoy my entree as much as I could have had I been famished.  Overall pretty tasty still. The rice is sushi rice (slighty sour), kinda neat.  All 3 ways of the ahi were raw. I had a bite and liked it. But I don't know about eating a whole entree of raw fish and sushi rice. Korean bbq beef was sweet and fatty and juicy and all that good stuff.

Dinner for three=$87 plus tips.

Would come back again, but this time will be mentally prepared to dish out some cash.
author: Xiaoyin W.

description: Food quality is the same as the one on Chestnut. But more seating and small parking lot in the back make it a better choice than Chestnut.
author: Stephen Y.

description: Love coming here when I come back home. Yummy clean food that everyone loves. Good selection for drinks. Recommend highly!
author: Nola P.

description: So fresh. So good. Perfect fusion food when you're craving something healthy, tasty and filling-- I adore their salad bowls, overflowing with fresh greens, seared fish or meat and toppings galore.
author: Tracy L.

description:
One of my favorite Happy Hours in the City by the Bay!

FOOD:  SWEET POTATO FRIES.  Ok so when you offer good fries, I'm pretty easy to please.  It's great that they allow you to mix up the different kinds of fries too.  I also really liked their veggie roll (it's worth the price during HH) and actually I'm not sure why peeps are complaining about their mojitos because I really liked mine.  My favorite drink is the Spicy Pacific... some concotion of passionfruit nectar and jalapenos.  I know it sounds weird and gross, but it's SO GOOD... try it!!!  Oh, and though I don't eat fish, my friend craves the poke specifically from here at least twice a month.

AMBIENCE:  This is actually much nicer and much more spacious than the PC in the Marina district.  A good place for a date.  High ceilings keep the restaurant from getting too stuffy. Lighting is slightly subdued and gives a vaguely sexy feel to everything. The best part?  TWO Happy Hours on weekdays - 4-6 pm, then again from 10 pm to closing.  Boo-yah!

PRICES: Fairly reasonable, especially during HH.  One can easily have good food and two drinks for under $20 and not have to eat dinner afterwards.  And the portions are fairly generous so you definitely get your money's worth.

PARKING: There's actually a lot behind the restaurant, but it fills up rather quickly.  As with most things in SF, it's always better not to drive, but if you must take your car then know that there's usually more parking along the avenues east of the restaurant (try scoping 5th-8th avenues).

See you here for Happy Hour!
author: Catherine C.

description:
you haven't lived until you've had an ahi poke wasabi bowl with a side of sweet potato fries. just do it. 

before you leave to emark on your journey, pray to the parking gods. it'll do you good.
author: Christine P.

description:
Opentable claimed this establishment to be kid-friendly.  They were not kidding!  When we got there, the place screamed of toddlers, 'tweens & strollers.  I was in heaven!  They serve goldfish & edemame while you wait for your order.  The place is nicely decorated that entertained my little one.  

I had the fried oysters
author: Jo B.

description:
Dropped in for an early dinner after visiting the Cartier and America exhibit at the Legion of Honors. 

My friend and I were STARVING. It had been 5 hours since brunch and we decided to grab an early bite before heading back to Russian Hill. 

We shared the "Crab Fest 2010" Crab & Corn Chowder which and both got the Wasabi Ahi sandwich (served on fresh-baked rolls with organic spring greens & sesame slaw on the side). Of course we added sweet potato fries for $1.95 more.

Food was fast, fresh, and tasty. Can't beat it when you're in the mood for seafood!
author: Cecilia L.

description: I came back and had dinner here with a friend a few months ago and had one of their fish specials. Food came out lukewarm and most of the vegetables felt like they were just thawed from the freezer. Next time I go back, I'll probably just stick to their rice bowls.
author: Eric L.

description:
Great, clean establishment with SUPERB customer service.

We had a nice server named James. Sweet,kind, cute.... a lil nervous too, I think he was slammed during our time there. But he still took good care of us.

We started with Mai Tai's -- which I have never done before. May I suggest you start all future meals with a Mai Tai. It makes everything that comes after it taste like heaven.

I had a veggie salad with tofu option. And it was the best dish I have had in a long time.

LOVE THIS PLACE! LOVE THE FOOD! LOVE THE MAI TAI!
author: Brooks S.

description: Favorites: Grilled corn and steak taco with deep fried onions and smoky barbeque steak flavor.
author: Christian E.

description: Very nice place for a Sunday lunch. Their food is always fresh and the service is outstanding.
author: K. D.

description: My son told me Pacific Catch was the best.  I was?  Well, skeptical.  I went to this location as it was close and easy at the time that I was hungry.  Asked the waiter what was best.  He told me the local petralle.  Hmm?  Ok, I tried it. Also tried a cocktail that was a martini with a pepper in it. Skeptical on all this again. But guess what?  I was so pleasantly surprised.  I can say these two things were The Best I have had in so long!  So delicious.  Really!  Must go there and must try for yourself.  You will be blown away. Wahooo!!!
author: Elisa B.

description: The teriyaki and wasabi bowls are SOOOOOOOOOO GOOD!!! You've got to believe me on this people! It's your loss if you don't try it!!!
author: Amiee H.

description:
restaurants like Pacific Catch make living in SF special.
a spicy tuna roll, crispy oysters, and a bottle of dry sake were a nice late night treat.
also worth mentioning were the shrimp ceviche and hawaiian style poke served at the Yelp Holiday party. also got a chance to chat briefly with Chandon the chef at this Pacific Catch. nice guy who manages a kitchen that serves a quality product.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I've been here so many times I've lost count -  Dinner with friends, Lunch with friends, Birthday dinners, drinks on the weekend, drinks after work etc.

The wasabi bowls are filling and extremely tasty, fish tacos are AWESOME and the bartender makes a mean mojito.
author: Stacy Y.

description: I had the macadamian crusted mahi mahi; the outer crust was awesome and the nuts gave it an extra crunch.  I gave 4 stars because they were out of the malasadas so I had to order a substitute dessert like the mochi and then they were out of the vanilla mochi, so I ordered the brownie with ice cream  and it was very decadent. The mochi may have come from Trader Joes freezers and it was okay. Parking had to be in the park.
author: h f.

description:
As with many folks, I was sad to see Canvas Gallery go. When I found out that Pacific Catch was replacing it, I was a little worried about how it would work in the neighborhood. I'm a fan of the Chestnut Street location but that space is much smaller and seems to fit right into its Marina trappings.

So this past Sunday, we went to this new location around 6pm for an early dinner. The place was pretty busy already and we had to wait about 10 minutes for a table (in the sizable bar area). Maybe it was the time of day, but everywhere we turned was some sort of family, be it a clan of six or new parents with their stroller and youngin' in tow, like us.

Our hostess and waitress were both really friendly and attentive. The menu is a mix of Asian and Seafood, so you'll find sushi mixed in with fish tacos and other seafood dishes, with an emphasis on tuna. I went big and tried the Ahi Three Ways - each variation was fresh with enough character to make the meal a culinary adventure. At $18.95, this might have been the most expensive dish on the menu, but it came with rice, seaweed salad and cucumber salad, so full worth it.

Desserts were intriguing enough that we had to try at least one. This time around, it was the passion fruit cheese cake, and next time I'm sure the mochi fondue will be how we finish. 

Being a new Dad, Pacific Catch is a great restaurant to have around. This location is spacious enough to bring little people, and as mentioned above the staff are more than accommodating (although no diaper changing station in the bathroom). 

They have a full bar, too, so might be a curious place to have a happy hour or something. 

Parking tip: they still have the adjacent lot for customer parking, so if you're lucky and/or early you can snag one of the seven spaces.
author: Nish N.

description:
i had forgotten about Pacific Catch, until I ended up going there last night.  first of all, we didn't get there until after 10:00, and the fact that they serve until at least 11:00 is a big plus.  The atmosphere is relaxed, it's not loud, and they have a nice bar with good specialty mojitos.  It's not ridiculously expensive, but it's not super cheap either...i had a teriyaki chicken rice bowl, which came to about 14 bucks...but it's HUGE.  I couldn't finish more than 1/2...heir coconut shrimp are reallly good too.  My friends like the fish tacos, and they tell me the Poke is the bomb (i don't like sushi, so i will take her word for it =).

The only problem i have with this place is that they stopped making the teriyaki bowls with the pineapple fried rice....that was my favorite part!  the pineapple chunks were huge and added a lot to the flavor.  they still put "pineapple salsa" in there, but it's not the same...i don't know why they stopped serving it, but i was pretty bummed when i found out....however, i will continue to go back there.  We've celebrated several birthdays, and they have accomodated our rather large and loud group of friends.  In my opinion, it's a sure thing.
author: Spookee X.

description: If you get anything, get the albacore poke.  Not much else to say, but I would eat that every single day!!
author: Jeffrey Y.

description:
I actually came here just to try their sweet potato fries. I was actually debating with my boyfriend whether to get the traditional or spicy potato fries.  The waiter (he was extremely nice and I forgot his name), actually suggested to me that I should do half/half. I was excited that I could try both at one time. So, I ordered a whole basket of it since I LOVE sweet potato fries!

Aside from the fries, I also ordered the chipotle chicken sandwich because nothing on the menu really appealed to me. But the sandwich turned out really good. The chicken was not dry, which is a plus. I couldn't even finish the whole sandwich by myself, so I was able to pack it to go to eat the next day. 

I was lucky enough to find a parking spot in their mini parking lot, but I am not complaining. I am glad they actually have a parking lot to begin with.
author: Willa L.

description: Great happy hour!!! One of my favorite go-to places when I need a bite to eat and a drink after 10pm. Have tried all 4 sushi offerings on the happy hour menu and frankly you can't go wrong with any of them. Also, don't miss out on their sweet potatoes fries - good size portion, great sauces and frankly freshly delicious!
author: Michelle G.

description:
With my first impression,  I didn't expect this place to be as good as it was.  Asian fusion is the BEST though.  

This place has got to be the solemnly the only place in the city that I know that lets you substitute their things with brown rice!  What a great accommodation for the health conscious.

Ordered the Skirt Steak Teriyaki Bowl, Spicy Ahi Sandwich, and Rock n'  Roll sushi.   

They minorly messed up on my sushi order by using regular rice instead, but it's no biggie.  They were quick to fix it, and it tasted awesome.

I also like their little complimentary appetizer with the pretzel goldfish and edamame beans - yum!

Would definitely come back.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
This place was ok. Maybe because the last seafood restaurant (pappaboux) I went to was simply amazing, but Pacific Catch made me yearning for more. Like Ellis L. said, the sweet potato fries were good but nothing crazy, the Calamari was good but nothing you cant find at some place like cheese cake factory. And I also tried my friend's poke over rice and it was a little too salty for my taste. 

I personally had the swordfish special which was paired with coconut rices blocks which were lightly fried on the outside as well as baby eggplant with a curry seasoning, and a mango salad. The rice was pretty good and had an interesting presentation, the mango salad brought a little acidity to the table which was needed and worked well with the fish. And now to the fish; the swordfish was lightly grilled and had little seasoning. Taste wise, it definitely needed help from the mango salad to bring some zing into the equation. Overall the dish  was so so. I think serving the fish over steamed rice with a mango salsa on top would have worked better.

Pacific Catch is definitely a cool place to be. The location is excellent, with plenty of parking in the park across the street. The decor/atmosphere was nice, open and modern. But the food could be better.

Enjoy..
author: Byron C.

description: Came here for a quick HH & had like 4 margaritas lol. That and the spicy tuna roll, sweet potato fries, and two orders of the let's get saucy roll. Spicy tuna roll wasn't that good, but I really liked the let's get saucy roll. Could've eaten that for days especially since I'm not the type of person that gets fried sushi rolls lol. It's an exception.
author: Diane L.

description:
I have lived in the neighborhood for a while and only recently had the chance to visit Pacific Catch. 

Overall, I think it was only average. Nothing extraordinary. Their sweet potato fries are great but their Japanese food items are not as good as at a real Japanese restaurant and a lot of their other items seem a little overpriced. 

It's a great place to go with large groups though because they have space to accommodate you, which is often tough to find in San Francisco.
author: John K.

description: This place was recommended to me by friend who lives in the area.  and I have to say it was Amazing.  My wife ( picky with seafood )and kids loved it, .  We ordered 4 different plates & everyone of them were  great.  Definitely going back.
author: Simon D.

description: Great food for the price.  Lots of variety in terms of California fusions of Asian and South American meals.  We had sushi, ceviche, a chilean pork appetizer, salmon with a soy sauce glaze, coconut shrimp, and a salad.  Everything was fresh and wonderful.  The cocktails were great too, especially the pomegranate martini.
author: Brian J.

description:
I was highly dissappointed that a fish market/restaurant , which was what I was told, was replacing C.G. (Canvas Gallery) and for the longest time, I would not even give P.C. the time of day...until I tried it out a couple months ago. 

P.C. blew me away. I love it! I had the Ahi Poke bowl (sub. brown rice!) and it was healthy, delicious and the fish was so fresh. The sushi rolls there are huge and everything was priced very, very reasonably. Definitely try their Firecracker Salmon roll - you will not be dissapointed. I don't think I saw any Japanese/Asian chefs there, but hey, with sushi this good, I'm colorblind.

The ginger cooler I had was perfect and refreshing with my Firecracker Salmon roll..it was strong; yet not super sugary.

The service was excellent..no complaints there. Our server was nice, friendly and attentive. 

Pacific Catch "caught" my heart.
author: Vanessa W.

description: This review is specific to takeout for fish and chips - everything was super soggy/wet and the portion wasn't that great. Avoid if you can or check the contents before leaving the resto. Shame, I love some of their other stuff like the tuna rice bowl.
author: james l.

description:
Must...boycott...trendy seafood place that replaced Canvas...

What's that you say?  They have a bar?  With Coconut Porter?  Part of the Microcanning Revolution?  Well, maybe just a quick gander then.

Sure enough, the blond ceiling and red walls have a suburban sheen that's as overly-polished as Tom Scholz' production on the Boston songs coming from their 100% classic-rock speakers.  And the giant plastic bottles of chinese hot sauce on every table sort of belie the trendiness factor.

But the sweet potato fries and calamari that I nicked from my comrades-in-sunset-drinking were impressive, and they even have that sauce, known to me only as "crack sauce" (and which I previously thought endemic to Seattle breweries) that leaves an indelible mark on the buds of all who taste it.  So I'm just saying.

But guys, seriously, turn the lights down after 9, would ya?  You'll save the earth and your potential for booze-friendly ambiance.
author: Wes M.

description:
This place is a pretty good asian fusion place.  I must admit that although I've been here quite a few times, I tend to get the same thing...because it's so damn good and filling.

The Ahi tuna Wasabi bowl, is delicious.  Lots of ahi and enough rice to feed a family.  You won't be able to finish this.  

I also like the Ahi 3 ways, which is served 1) seared, 2) hawaiian poke style and 3) sashimi.  That's pretty tasty as well.

The sweet potato fries are really good too!
author: mike j.

description:
I had some fried stuff and some poke...

who doesnt like fried coconut shrimp and salmon?

ooo which reminds me i had this fried salmon in Dallas, it was from a bento box out of some japanese restaurant i cant remember..but that was really good..um besides that...the salmon fish n chips was pretty good

hmmm no complaints there, coconut shrimp is a typical one that you can find in most places that serve it. Either its good or its bad, and they did it good here so no complaints there either..

Sweet potato fries...lets see, yea it was pretty good too..not soggy or anything and just a good amount of salt..

the poke was good...but it was a bit too spicy..well maybe that or im just a big weenie but then again i do like spicy food so i dont know what happenend there kakaka...o well 

Anyways overall..i only ordered to-go so i cant say much about service except for the fact that the girl that i spoke to had good phone etiquette. The place looks nice and even though i was only in there for like 5 min i guess i should come by and at least have a sit down dinner..

for a to-go order the food wasnt soggy which i was kind of expecting especially with fried fish and shrimp. So that was a plus for me~ 

I think i wrote too much..
author: phillip w.

description:
I eat here all the time. Usually about weekly. I must say my lunch experiences have been much better than dinner.  The menu seems a bit limited, and the family scene was a bit much. 

So, dinner last week. We had reservations for 5 and ordered the short ribs appetizer off the chalk board. They were out. Then why not erase it off the board? 

The waiter was nice, but the drinks took forever. About 25 minutes and way after our appetizers were finished. 

They were also out of some fish entree that was featured as a special. Not the end of the world, but limiting the menu options further. 

After giving my portion of the bill in cash my 2 friends asked the bill to be split 2 ways between their 2 debit cards. On accident it was split like 5 ways and when my friend tried to get the attention of a passing waitress, she was extremely rude. All we were trying to do was pay our bill in full and tip accordingly.   Here is how it went.

MS- "excuse me, our bill is too low can you pl"
waitress- " Do you mean for me to get your server? I am not your server and cannot help you"
MS- " um sure"
waitress- stomps away with an angry expression. 

Fo over 200.00 my friend did not deserve that. I will keep coming here with my lunch date buddy, but dinner was a turn off only because of the rude girl, poor timing and lack of menu items.
author: Amanda L.

description:
It's Asian Fusion, so?

The fish is always really fresh when I come here.

Fish and sweet potato chips? Yes, please.

Wasabi Bowls are to die for. But don't expect them to be really hot.

This location is actually not bad for getting a seat compared to the one in the Marina, but it's still pretty busy in the evening. Parking can be difficult in this area at these times, so take the bus if practical.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Started off with the rare ahi tuna over a small salad: this was really good.  The tuna was fresh and tasty.  The salad was light and not overwhelming with dressing.  It's how a starter should be, it left me wanting more.

I ordered the mahi mahi special.  The mahi mahi was small, and there was a whole lot of grilled onions.  I wasn't a fan of the grilled onions.  What I should have done was substitute it for the sweet potato fries, but I didn't know how popular they were until it was too late.

I was so disappointed in my meal I was tempted to try the vietnamese special sandwich.  It seemed as if everyone had ordered it and  it looked so good!

Our waitress wasn't so nice.  Service was a little slow.
author: Thuy H.

description:
I had dinner at Pacific Catch last night with my girifriend, my roommate/best friend, & his girlfriend/my college friend, so you might say that it was an intimate affair. But holy crap, let me note just for a moment -- how fucking GROWN UP does this dinner sound? A far cry from my usual "grab a quick meal with whomever is around" approach.

Anyway, I should note that Pacific Catch was working against a bit of a disadvantage, since I'd been a pretty big fan of the Canvas Gallery. In all honesty, though? The space works a lot better as a restaurant. Now that I've eaten at Pacific Catch, I can see that fully. It's big, expansive & almost cavernous. All those attributes work in favor of a big dining establishment. The high ceilings & warm lighting made it feel like the kind of place an exec from The Cheesecake Factory might model their next restaurant after (but with more mable columns).

Unintentional backhanded compliments aside, it's the type of place that's appealing on a large scale. The service was friendly & attentive, & we were all very satisfied with our respective meals (I got the Tokyo Salmon w/sweet potato fries, & it was delicious!).

It's a low key place for dinner (what we were looking for), & the kind of restaurant you can go when you feel like eatin' good in the neighborhood.
author: Pete J.

description:
YUCK.

I tried, and tried to like you. I really did. But then I realized something. It's not me, it's you.

I've been 4 times because I think the food there is pretty good, but the crappy service, the gentrification of Asian culture for the masses, and the crappy service (it's really bad service), make me not want to go back.

If their servers were more friendly and on top of their game, I'd probably go back. Lots of my friends also won't go there because of the same reason. Fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me, fool me 3 times, I'm an idiot for even trying, fool me 4 times, and you're dead to me. 

RIP Pacific Catch, it was a nice try.
author: Steph B.

description:
Came back here with Kylie L.!! What brought us in......just the sweet potato fries.

Kylie L. OOo'ed, and I Ahh'd, and we went in.  It seemed busy, but there were a few tables that were free.  The hostess said it will take about 5-10 mins..........wtf? There are tables, so after waiting for about 3mins id say, we got one of the empty tables near the entrance...hmmm

Anyway, I ordered the 3 Ahi something, that came with 3 different kinds of ahi tuna.  Sounded like a small meal, but I got it anyway. Kylie L. got fish and chips that came with sweet potato fries and we got an extra basket of SPF's.  Yummy!! the spf came with sweet and sour sauce, and a sweet horse radish sauce.  The horse radish one is good!  I ate half the basket, theyre just addicting.  

My ahi came, DANG, it was huge, maybe because of the big bowl of rice in the middle.  3 pieces of seared ahi covered with sesame seeds, that one was the best.  Another 3 pieces of seared ahi with some kinda thousand island dressing on it..2nd place. And tuna poke.  Poke ALWAYS sounds good, but it is not so good here...its just drenched in soy sauce.  SO i have 3 different  kinds of ahi in 3 different kinds of sauces, and one the side were shitake mushrooms fried with something also in sauce...hmm..all the sauces mixed together did not go so well with my rice...so i had a lot left over and made chinese porridge the next day.  That was not so good either..

I didnt try the fish and chips, but it looked like a lot.

The goods: food comes fast and SPF's
The bads: didnt i just tell u about them?
author: kim w.

description:
Pacific Catch takes reservations?!?!  They need to advertise that more.  I have to admit that i only eat the poke bowl and sweet potato fries here.  I've had a bite of the unagi bowl which was REALLY fresh, and this is coming from someone who thinks unagi tastes like mold.  Their fish and chips are pretty good.  
I haven't been impressed with any of the specials or other entrees so i just stick to what i like.
author: Susan Z.

description: Great food. I was served by a butch waittress who was very abrupt and didnt seem to care for good service. The calamari was excellent, coconut shrimp was great, and drinks were average. Overall I like this place and its atmosphere and would return. Fwiw at the timd we arrived they were having happy hr pricing on the entire menu.
author: Abdul K.

description:
I freakin' love Pacific Catch, just not this one. Our group of 6 adults and 3 kids figured that the original would not fit all of us, so we decided on the bigger 9th Ave location. Well, sometimes bigger ain't better. The quality of the food overall was lacking. The fish was just not as fresh as the same dishes at the Chestnut location. The service was lacking as well. It's not that they were rude in the least, it was more that the servers looked very confused at times and could not get one of our orders correct after three tries. This place could be a hit, only if it were as good as the original.

MUST HAVE: A map to get to the original (http://www.yelp.com/biz/pacific-catch-san-francisco#hrid:dhLLlLumE3qmnO6xnScwYw).
author: Al L.

description:
Wandering around Golden Gate Park and DeYoung Museum, we realized we were close by the many restaurants in the Inner Sunset.  We walked into Pacific Catch on a beautiful day.

For starters we each got the Signature Miso and Shiitake Miso.  I thought the miso could have had a little bit more flavor in the broth, but it was still good.  The shiitake miso had veggies (mushrooms & asparagus) which made it also good.

Our entrees were the Sesame Crusted Ahi and the Crispy Catch of the Day.  I chose the Ahi as a healthy alternative and it was seared perfectly.  The catch was fresh rock cod served with sweet potato fries.  Although the rock cod was battered, it didn't taste to overly deep fried like what you would expect.  Also we ordered 2 a la carte tacos, the BBQ Salmon and the Tropical Shrimp which were very good.

We noticed there was loud music playing overhead (why?).  We also noticed that Pacific Catch is kid friendly.  This is a plus for parents who are looking for a healthier choice than a diner or greasy spoon.  Pacific Catch is a good midday meal!
author: Janet H.

description:
I was never intending on going, but decided to try something new...  I walked in and couldn't believe this was my beloved Canvas Cafe once... I miss you Canvas!  They changed everything inside... it is decorated in warm colors and the light are really nice... they look like blue bottles... hmm... they could be bottles. They have lots of booths with comfortable cushions.  We were served by Misa who was really nice and very helpful. She made sure we had our fill of tea and was very attentive.  

Here is what we ordered:
- Spicy Cabo Calamari | fried with fresh chilis and crispy lemon, served with a chipotle dipping sauce $8.95. This was delicious. The sauce might be too spicy for some. The calamari rings were cooked to perfection (nothing worse than over cooked ring!)


- Mixed Catch Basket | 2 pieces of fresh fish, 4 coconut shrimp & 3 oysters with traditional fries $13.95. I would probably just order the Shrimp.  I liked the oysters, but it is not all that... I rather not eat my oysters fried.  The tartar sauce was great. I ordered the seasoned fries with this one.  They were very tasty. Next time I will try the sweet potatoes.  

- Teriyaki Bowl - Topped with asparagus, glazed shiitake mushrooms, grilled bok choy, sesame seeds & house-made teriyaki sauce served over pineapple fried rice with Fresh Salmon $13.95. This was ordered by my friends. I had some of the rice with the sauce and it tasted YUMMMY. 

- Mochi Fondu | vanilla, chocolate & coffee mochi ice cream with warm chocolate dipping sauce $5.50 When you get this dessert... eat fast... the hot chocolate makes it a bit difficult to get the mochi out of there before it melts down.  (Suggestion for restaurant owners/chefs - Perhaps if you use spoons or little ladle like utensils it would help save the bites from getting lost in the fondue. The wooden pick slips right off when dipped in the warm chocolate fondue after a few minutes.) I really loved this dessert... YUM! 

Total bill for two was a bit over $50. 

I would go back to try some other dishes.  It turned out to be a nice place to go. It does feel a bit chain like, but either way, I still enjoyed it.  I just don't feel like it fits in with the neighborhood.  I am used to the more wall in the hole feel.  Not a bad thing... it is just an observation. =)
author: Amelia M.

description:
Well, after yelping our unfortunate experience on our first visit to Pacific Catch, the wife and I were contacted by PC's marketing manager, who apologized and offered us a $50 credit if we would give PC another try.

Needless to say, we took him up on the offer, and went back a week after our initial visit. The manager working that night was very apologetic about out previous visit and went to great pains to make sure we were taken care of.

This time, I'm pleased to report that PC lived up to the expectations we'd initially gone in with.  No shards of glass this time. Of course, that's sort of to be expected, but I think our second visit was probably more representative of the typical PC experience and the 4 stars were definitely well-deserved. It was even close to 5 star territory, but again I was hit with a little bout of post-meal queasiness. Not as bad as the first time around but enough that I couldn't in fairness give 5 stars. Still, our meal on this evening was very, very good.

We started with the house cured sake salmon with nori rice cakes, wasabi creme fraiche, and black tobiko ($9.95), which was out-of-this-world delicious. The craime fraiche could have used a bit more of a wasabi kick, but that's a very quibbling critique of what was a very well executed and beautifully presented dish.

For my entree I had the Tokyo salmon fish and chips with ginger-wasabi aioli and lemon ponzu ($13.95). Again my only criticism here was the sauces. The ponzu wasn't as tart as I would have liked and the aioli definitely could have been punched up a couple of notches. The most important part of the dish- the fish- was spot on. Crispy on the inside and moist on the inside, just the way it should be. The sweet potato fries were also very tasty.

Katie had one of the specials- hawaiian opah with pineapple fried rice and bok choy ($20ish?). Aside from the bok choy which was very al dente and very difficult to eat (it should have been pre-cut or served with a steak knife- it was very hard to cut with a butter knife and too large and stringy to just take a bite), her meal was excellent. The fish and rice went together beautifully and he bok choy would have been a nice complement if it had been less cumbersome to eat. Katie also had a couple of pomegranate cocktails of some sort which were yummy.

All in all, an excellent meal and a nice gesture on the part of PC's management to redeem itself and earn back some good will.

We will definitely be back for more!
author: Brian H.

description: I love, love, love this place. Amazing Poke, excellent fish tacos, great french fries. When I didnt live in the area, this was the restaurant I went to everytime on the way to the airport. Although I would go to the location in the North Bay or in the Marina so I cant speak for the 9th Ave location. My mouth waters just thinking about their poke.
author: Patricia P.

description:
I was dissapointed in my most recent visit to Pacific Catch on 9th.
I have been there before and have always enjoyed the food/cocktails and service.
My sister and friends had reservations, although we were seated right away. We did not a see our waiter for a while. We wanted to order an appetizer featured on the specials board, but were told they were out. The waiter recommended the sweet potato  fries as an alternative which was strange because we wanted the meat.  We did order several appetizers and included our drink order. We received and finished all of the appetizers and did not get our drinks until the main courses came.
The food was ok as usual, I did enjoy my oysters. 

When the check came,  we asked to put on 2 credit cards.Our waiter accidently split the bill 5 ways  on 2 cards and undercharged   significantly. 

We tried to resolve this when a waitress passed by she quickly put her hands up and said" I can't help you, I am not your server" the walked off.

Whatever, we could have left paying $70.00 for a meal for 5 people, however thought we would be honest. 

Maybe it was on off-night, but it changed they way I feel about Pacific Catch.
author: Kathy G.

description:
Very easy to make a same day (Sunday) lunch reservation via OpenTable.com.

They started us with a small two-compartment dish of fresh edamame and some little Pepperidge Farm-esque pretzel nuggets. 

Extremely fast service for our "appetizer", Hawaiian Poke. The ahi cubes were very soft and the sesame soy marinade was perfect. This dish was a great value at $8.50...the ahi was piled high alongside and on top of several tasty wonton crisps.

My wife ordered the fried oysters with sweet potato fries subbed in for their traditional fries...both DEE-licious. I ordered the salmon teriyaki bowl with brown rice subbed in for the pineapple fried rice. The latter didn't sound very appealing to me; plus, my wife is always telling me about the healthy benefits of brown rice! Their bowls are HUGE, btw. The size of my bowl reminded me of something I would get at the Cheesecake Factory. The size of the grilled salmon could have certainly been larger, and the quantity of rice could have been far less. Otherwise, it was just okay.

Friendly, speedy service. Nice variety on their menu(s). We'll definitely return to try some more of what they have to offer!
author: B. Earl K.

description:
Stopped by for lunch after the preview of the Academy of Sciences.  We had the Ahi Poke, fish-n-chips and the crab and avocado salad.  The Ahi was chunky and fresh.  The fish was crispy and moist, and the fries were good.  My wife said the salad was okay.  Looks like they add a lot of pickled ginger to some off the salad plates...goes well with sushi but not the salad. 

Service was friendly.  This area is pretty busy so parking may be rough.  We parked inside the park and walked over.
author: Alberto S.

description:
Pluses:
The place is pretty nice, spacious with cool lighting.
Large menu with lots of choices
Big plates
Kids are welcome

Ehs:
The food was okay. The sweet potato fries are nothing special.
Five spice fries taste like bbq chips, not my thing.
The bread on the wasabi ahi tuna sandwich was really chewy and tough. The sandwich also had very little tuna for 9 dollars.
The fried mix fish basket was only ok, again nothing special.
Menu doesn't really have cohesion. I guess that's the price you pay for lots of choices: nothing is exceptional.
The service was not good. I think there were only one or two waitresses working the entire place.

Overall: good for large parties who want a lot of choice but it's nothing special.
author: Jen Y.

description: They have a little bit of every thing on the menu. My aunt and I split the ahi tuna salad, small sweet potato fries and the shiso roll. The salad was alright, they could have given more pieces of ahu, but the dressing was good. Not salty like most restaurants and my salad was drowning in it. I loved the shiso roll!! It went well with the tempura and avocado in it. The sweet potato fries were ok.
author: Lindsay G.

description:
I've only had the fish tacos at the Marina location and that's what gave their review 4 stars and this one only 3.  At this local, I've had the tuna wasabi bowl, the spicy tuna roll (both brown rice), the house salad and the sweet potato fries.  The fries never disappoint but the 2 other dishes and salad weren't that tasty.  They were under-seasoned and the brown rice wasn't as soft as I've made or had in other restaurants.

But the service was up to par, the atmosphere was sweet, and the bartenders were cute.  Hahaha.
author: Susan C.

description: We are regulars at Pacific Catch. This is a perfect restaurant for families and also couples. The food is delicious and there are a lot of options for fish, meat and vegetarians. We ordered delivery from Pacific Catch weekly through the Caviar website. We highly recommend this restaurant.
author: X X.

description:
ambiance was lovely, windows adorn the interior with ample light, and views of golden gate park directly across the street.

the ahi poke is nearly indistinguishable from the Hawaiian original. 

the fish sandwiches are constructed well, but the mahi mahi inside lacked flavor and the texture was a bit dry; sweet potato french fries on the side were good as well.

desert was awesome, caramel something with ice cream and mango passion fruit cheese cake. 

appetizer + 2 sandwiches + 2 deserts = 52 bucks.. not bad at all
author: Peter T.

description:
I just came back from my Valentine's Day dinner and I'm all alone and yelping already.  I was really excited to try this place because the reviews are pretty decent so far.  So we went for the Valentine's Day special for $65.  Everything on there I believe you can order through the chalkboard special menu or regular dinner menu.  

Decor was nice and the place looks a lot bigger than it does from the outside.  I guess I never noticed Canvas was that big inside.  The beech wood on the ceiling brightens up the place while still looking a little romantic, and even the bathroom walls/doors have the little bamboo inside plexiglass look which is nice to look at when you have to pee.

Starter:
Firecracker roll - a spicy tempura salmon roll
Entrees:
1. Ahi Tuna 3 way - poke, sesame seared and another kind of seared with rice, seaweed salad, some terryaki mushroom edamame mix and another mixed salad that could've been one of those japanese mixes with turnip.
2. Grilled Salmon with artichoke and a layer of tomatos
Dessert:
Mochi ice cream fondue with vanilla, coffee and chocolate flavored ice cream
Drinks: Sparkling white wine

The portions were pretty good sized for $65 for 2 people.  The firecracker roll was rather large, but if you look closely, it's a lot of rice wrapped in them.  It still tasted good though and didn't come out looking all sloppy like some restaurants make their sushi.  I really liked the ahi 3-way.  The seared kinds were better and more buttery than the poke, which to me was kind of chewy.  Not exactly the way I pictured poke.  But every other piece was fine.  My husband had the salmon and said he wished he picked something else.  Salmon is salmon - nothing special, but cooked really nicely - not overcooked, just right.  
Dessert was really good.  I love chocolate and I like mochi ice cream on a stick.  This was just right.  
The wine was definitely not the best.  I think with our chosen food, the wine just ended up tasting sour.  But I love sweet white wines and that's just my preference.

The service was really good for such a crowded night.  We had a really upbeat and polite waitress and they served us our food quickly enough.  A nice place to eat overall with a lot more to try.  I love sweet potato fries so that will be part of my next meal there.  They have what, 5 parking spaces there, but there's plenty of parking across the street and in the park.
author: Stacey C.

description:
I've been here several times and I've always left extremely happy and full. How could you go wrong with fried fish and sweet potato fries? Exactly, you can't!

Today, I went here with a good friend after venturing through the Academy of Sciences. We worked up quite the appetite and were ready to chow. 

I tend to get the same thing every time...Catch of the Day. Sometimes I get the Hawaiian Poki Bowl, which is also awesome and super tasty. But I like to change it up with the drink. Today our server, who was awesome as well, suggested I try this spicy yet sweet cocktail. I cannot remember its name, but it was on the second page of the drink menu on the top of the page. Trust me, I will order this again...and again...and again! It was a nice sweetness from passion fruit juice, but had a nice hit of spice and heat with serrano peppers. Amazing! I know, it sounds like a crazy mix, but it was amazing and very different.

My friend got salmon fish tacos (she's such a SoCal girl) and Fat Tire's Mothership. She very much enjoyed her food...and mine as well! She also agreed well with my drink.

So yah, when you're in the area, I'd definitely suggest making a stop at Pacific Catch for a nice meal. There's everything you could want: fried fish, sweet potato fries with jalapeno tartar sauce, sushi, poki, alcohol in crazy concoctions, sandwiches, etc. Just try it out! And even if you're not in the area...Pacific Catch would be a great place to make your way to for a totally worth it meal.
author: stefany f.

description:
I have to say that I am in general a meat-eater. I love meat. Lots and lots of it. So imagine my surprise when I went to Pacific Catch and loooved it. I've been more than a couple of times and was really glad when this location opened up, closer to me in the Sunset! 

I must be a closet salad/healthy-food eater because I can not get enough of the wasabi bowls... Hawailian Poki Wasabi Bowl = jaw-droppingly good. I even like the salads too. Their sushi rolls are also HUGE and delicious. I will always be willing to come back here if I need a dose of good but also fairly healthy food. 

This was really memorable: One time I took a friend here for the first time. She really likes salad. She nearly had happy tears streaming down her face after taking the first bite of her wasabi bowl. And I was just chomping down on a pretty good fish taco. Good times.
author: Nebula H.

description:
[deep breath]

Sigh.  I think that to enjoy this place you have to have proper expectations for it.  For me as a semi-foodie, this place is basically the aquatic-equivalent of a Chevy's Fresh Mex -- bustling environment  with plenty of liquor and mass-appeal foods for the hoi polloi.

You ever have that kinda experience of going to a chain restaurant and get that so-very-engineered taste?  Where they got some guys in a lab trying to distill cooking down to an industrial engineering process, formulate recipes into equations and all, then taste-testing it to a control group to optimize overall appreciation?  Well, I'd say this place is a shining example of that kind of culinary behavior.  In my food snobby words: the food tastes nice and pleasant, but in a very flat and boring way -- it has no personality or soul.

(Grudgingly) went with friends here twice and had good times, but seriously, with that crowd I would have been similarly happy at a McD.  Waiter was totally on "robot autopilot" mode during one of the times and was totally unhelpful.  Food quality is consistent.

Come here: With all your non-foodie friends to get buzzed before a big group outing, before/after a ballgame, or whatever.

Don't come here: expecting gourmet cuisine showcasing the craftsmanship of food-culture-rich SF.

Cost-benefit analysis: Entrees set you back $15-$25, so with some alcohol, appetizers, and/or snacks, expect to be set back around $25-$40.  It's a friendly, casual environment and all... but seriously, if you're gonna spend that money, there are MUCH better options throughout the City.
author: J C.

description:
LOVE IT!

ASSUMPTION: thought this place was over priced with undersized portionsserved by snobby and pretentious staff.

TRUTH: oh how i was sooo wrong... SOOOO WRONG! *slaps* myself wrong.

so after a long ASS day of manuvering through lovefest09 and over crowded muni, it was really nice to sit down at the nicely decor and chill atmosphere of... pacific catch!

the staff is extremely friendly, attentive and knowledgeable! never was i left with a half empty glass.. 

I ordered fish tacos, and boy oh boy, these tacos are bad ass, the fish is moist and seasoned very well! on the side i had some of their sweet potato fries - so damn good with the sauce! *drools* 

my other friends order wasabi bowls, HELLA good!!! 
WHAT ARE THEY? they are pretty much sushi in a bowl... it's a bowl of sushi rice topped with your choice of fish (you have about 5-6 choices), and piles of veges on top of that... very tasty.

perfectly cooked seafood, large menu, fair prices, friendly staff...
i'll definitely be revisiting pacific catch for another dinner rendezvous!
author: Alex C.

description:
Great tip from one of last week's Top Yelpers-Erich D.! 

Went to Pacific Catch on Friday and tried the recommended wasabi ahi tuna bowl.  Wow - lots of food and I liked the garnishes that came with it, especially the ocean seaweed salad.  The ahi was seared perfectly, but the wasabi dressing could have been a little hotter as I could hardly taste any wasabi at all.  Had a bite of their Korean BBQ which was pretty tasty, but there wasn't much BBQ meat for the price.

Good thing I went on 08-08-08 cuz I scored the last parking space in their tiny lot.  Otherwise, looking for street parking around that busy intersection would have been a real downer.  Would have given it a higher rating if parking were better.  Hint: go before 6 p.m. to avoid the crowd.
author: S D.

description: My boyfriend and I frequent this place maybe 5-8 times/month. It's kind of ridiculous...had my 21st Birthday Dinner here...would definitely call it one of my faves in SF, having grown up here. We usually sit at the bar so we can watch whatever game is on at the time...if it's a Niners home game, well, we'll be at the Stick. Anyway, I always order a Sapporo (or cocktail if it was a long day) and the Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl, half white rice, half salad, no sprouts and no ginger. I don't think it could get any better. This is my first review on Yelp, and I knew exactly which restaurant I would write about first :) PS - Ecstasy roll is bomb PPS - You get pretzel goldfish and edamame while you wait!
author: Lauren Q.

description:
I went here on a Friday night sometime a few weeks ago. It was pretty filled up but it didnt look like there was anyone waiting. I had always driven by it and wanted to try it since it was converted from being "The Canvas" For some reason I thought this was strictly an American Fish restaurant - you know, salmon with wild rice and choice of vegetable kinda place, because that is what it looks like on the outside - but it turned out was a Japanese fusion restaurant. 

We started off with some sushi appetizers. If you don't like wasabi, you should ask them to hold it on the sushi, because you wouldn't know it just by looking at the rolls that they a pretty generous amount in there. I myself, love wasabi, but had I known that there was so much in it, I would not have dipped it so much in my super wasabi/soy sauce combo. I admit it, it made me tear. And usually I can handle alot of wasabi.

Then I had the ahi turn wasabi bowl - with tobiko. It came out as a generous portion of rice, ahi tuna, sprouts, teriyaki sauce - or was it sriracha?, and a plethora of different vegetables. Despite how good it was, I could not finish it. It defeated me =(

It was a birthday celebration so they gave us free dessert. It was mochi in a chocolate fondue. YUMMY. I am a sucker for fondue. And fondue and ice cream? What could be better?

I would come back again.
author: Elsa C.

description: Ooh how I wish Canvas was still there! After passing the Pacific Catch which opened in Canvas's place many times we finally decided to try it. Well the food their is weird - neither good or bad, I don't even have anything in particular to say about it. I'm not coming back for sure!
author: Ata N.

description:
The real standout is the basket of sweet potato fries which comes with an out of this world wasabi aoli and a spicy sweet and sour sauce for dipping. Their poke tastes really fresh so if you're looking for something a bit more filling than bar bites, try either the Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl or the Ahi Three Way, both dishes that come with poke.

I love that they have a late night happy hour.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
I cant believe anyone would rate this as less than 5 stars... my guess is that they did not order the ahi tuna 3 way dish that i did.

the dish had plenty of tuna prepared three ways; seared, poke, and raw over a bed of rice with a seaweed salad that was all prepared to perfection.  the tuna amount was so ample i literally did not touch my rice having plenty of fish and sides on the dish.

there is a full bar, though we stuck with beers, but i can see this being a great place to stop in for a meal before or after a visit to Golden Gate Park since its literally across the street from one of the entrances.
author: Edibleocea N.

description:
I came to this place after having such long wait times at the one in the Marina. I love the Marina's fried fish tacos with this really good sauce on it and their fried oysters, so I tried it here as well. Very good, like the ones in Marina. I've only had the oysters once here, so I'm not sure if their freshness at this bigger restaurant is as good as the smaller Marina restaurant. 

I also really like their rice bowls, particularly the poke, which is cubed sashimi tuna tossed in a dressing. Their rice bowls are also topped with lots of goodies like avocado, seaweed salad, and cucumbers. It was really cool because I wanted to split this with a friend and they separated it into two bowls with all the toppings at no charge.

My only complaint is that the grilled corn came out cold. I told my waiter so he brought me another one, but....it really wasn't that much hotter than the first. I wonder if they grill it beforehand. 

I like this place, but if I had the time to wait for a table, I'd go to the Marina one over this one since it has a homier, more attention to detail kind of feel to it. This one does have a wider menu and a full bar though, unlike the the one in Marina.
author: Christine L.

description:
Would you eat Mexican food at a sushi restaurant?  
Would you eat sushi at a Mexican restaurant?  
Would you eat fresh fish fusion at a California concept cafe?

OK.  Fine.  Go to Pac Catch then.

Fish has nooooooooooo flavor.  But, the wasabi bowl (besides being a misnomer) is giant, and tasty.  Fish tacos, not bad.  Sweet potato fries, nice.  Happy hour, happy.  Ambience, contrived but comfy.  Not a bad view, either (GG Park).
author: Jennifer B.

description: I went here with a friend and had a great time! We got free sweet potato fries for checking in on yelp/foursquare, which was an instant bonus, and also had the orange ale, which was a great beer and cheap for a nice restaurant! We also both ordered the seared ahi sandwich and house salad, which comes with edamame and a miso dressing. Both were really good. I was impressed by the amount of ahi on the sandwich and the unique blend of flavors and was able to take a half home after all the other food. The servers were really nice, too. A little pricey but I would go back to try some of the other amazing things on the menu.
author: Courtney A.

description:
Great space! It's HUGE! I love it since it's always a pain to go to the one on Chestnut. There's a bar here too, so it's a great place for cocktails. The menu is also more extended with sushi offerings as well as other specialties such as Korean BBQ beef.

I came here two already and I stuck what I always love at Pacific Catch... the ahi tuna salad bowl and the sweet potato fries! YUM!!!
author: Denise L.

description:
So my boyfriend took me here for Mother's Day because a friend suggested it. And EVERYONE we knew that has been there told us to get the sweet potato fries. 

The first thing that I noticed was that out of all the booths, the hostess sat us at one where I was literally blinded by the sunlight. I ended up sitting next to my boyfriend, which is nice, but I like sitting across from him so we can talk easier. Our waiter (his name totally slipped my mind, sorry!) was nice and attentive. Took our orders and our appetizers came out in like 10 minutes! Kind of threw me off on how fast it came out. 

we ordered: 

- Sweet Potato Fries: My boyfriend is a fries fiend so he totally enjoyed this. I'm not that big on fries, but I must admit that it was pretty delish. 

- Hawaiian Poke: My absolute fave of the night. I always have to try poke if a restaurant has it on their menu and this one totally hit the spot. Not as good as homemade, but close enough! Could do without the won ton chips. Would have been great with a seaweed salad. 

- Cabo Calamari: This is another dish we usually always try if it's on the menu. We were quite disappointed. Usually when you eat a piece of calamari without the sauce, it should still have some flavor from the breading its coated in, but this was just so...BLAND. Then when we dipped it in the sauce, it completely broke apart. No good. 

- Miso Glazed Salmon: Loved the crispy outside and buttery inside. Sauce, mushroom & edamame side, was delicious. The salad on the side was not to my liking. I don't know what it was, but the flavor was horrible and the texture was really tough. 

- Korean BBQ Steak: First of all, the waiter hadn't asked my boyfriend how he wanted it cooked. It came out medium rare which was fine though. Tim loved the flavor, but the meat was TOUGH. Don't think it was the way it was cooked, just that that particular cut of meat was tough. He also didn't like the salad. 

- Lemongrass Mojito: Pretty good. Bartender made it strong, just the way I like it. 

Overall, it was alright. If I were to go back it would be for the sweet potato fries, Hawaiian poke, and maybe to try the Wasabi Bowls and fish tacos.
author: Ashley C.

description:
At first I was really upset that this restaurant had replaced Canvas Gallery, but found myself forgiving since I have fallen in love with their service and great food. I LOVE SEAFOOD and I have to hand it to them-they certainly make excellent dishes and present their dishes in a very crafty fashion. I am a fan! I often order the Sushi Grade Ahi. It's very light and has a really delicate and refreshing taste; enough to want more after every bite! It's a great place to go after working out and to relax. I love sitting near the kitchen so I could watch the chefs create master pieces for us hungry seafood lovers!

GOOD JOB WITH EVERYTHING!!!! HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
author: Janine P.

description: I took my parents who were visiting out of town here on a Tuesday evening. Parking was convenient, and we didn't have to wait at all to be seated right away. I have to say I was really pleasantly surprised by the selection of menu items, service, and the delicious/creative foods they serve! We ordered the salmon rice bowls which were outstanding! I highly recommend this place for gatherings with friends, to take parents to a safe place where they won't question potential health and safety code violations (like so many little holes in the wall in SF), and for families with children.
author: Marina S.

description:
cool that it has a crab special going on.  Went last week and this location is so much better than the one in the Marina... high ceiling, bar, spacious and my order was tastier too!
parking lot only has 6-7 spaces so street parking is the way to go.
author: Emm C.

description:
NUTS!! I was hoping to be the first to review, but 6 other people beat me to it.  Thats ok! :)

My friend and I saw that there were people inside, so we walked in.  Apparently, the restaurant was closed for Friends & Family before the grand opening, but they sat us anyway! 

Full, tasty menu, same great taste as the Chestnut location.  We were more than pleasantly surprised when they told us our meal was free so that the wait staff could practice on us.  (Our waiter seemed to be able to read out minds when he brought us a glass of water perfectly on time.)

We had the fried calamari, which was really good, but also really greasy.  I ate 1/3 of the plate and ended up feeling extremely nauseas afterwards.  Probably my own fault for eating so much of it!!!! :)  That being said though, the calamari was extremely soft.  There was no hard calamari texture that you sometimes get.  hurrah!

Our main course came:  Wasabi Ahi Poke bowl with brown rice.  Always an awesome option on the menu.  Wasabi bowl anything is usually reaaaaaallly good.  We also had the Crispy Catch of the Day which came with the sweet potato fries and 2 dipping sauces.  The Talapia was SO good and the sweet potato fries are always delicious.  It was just hard to eat after feeling too woozy from the calamari.

Anyway--loved it!!!! it's going to be hugely successful.  I do miss Canvas because of the art, but Pacific Catch has some super cool art itself.

Thanks for the free meal Pacific Catch!  It was absolutely delicious!!!!!
author: Steph M.

description: This place was actually really good! They offer many different types of food, so it's hard to decide. I went with the 3 tacos - chicken, shrimp, and fish. The shrimp one was beyond awesome! The kitchen was running behind, so our waitress told us, "Dessert is on me. Go crazy!" So we did. We basically tried every dessert on the menu, and ALL were delicious, but the cheesecake spring rolls were to die for!
author: William S.

description:
How can I write this review without revealing something unflattering about myself...

This place is in crawling distance from my work after a day filled with abuse from the general public and the usual on-the-go lunch of instant oatmeal in my coffee mug.  By the time I arrive at PC, off late again, I am ready to eat the entire children's menu.

We like to sit at the bar, the alcohol comes faster that way. They have Sapporo on tap!
author: Erin G.

description:
OH WE CAUGHT SOMETHING ALL RIGHT! 
Was it the under cooked sushi rice, or the fish tacos made us ill?
perhaps it was the manager (katie) who refused to take responsibility when i called to let her know what we were going through.

We tried it once but will never go back
author: Thomas C.

description: The Japanese Wasabi Bowl with Hawaiian Poke was delicious and very filling.  I finished my leftovers the next day.  I recommended mixing everything in the bowl.  It tastes even better.
author: Jon H.

description:
Still not off the Hawaii tip =p  Wanted something close to the spicy tuna bowl I had at Aloha Sushi in Honolulu....rice, 2 scoops of spicy tuna, and all the fixins in a bowl.  The bf suggested Pacific Catch for the comparable taste.  
Parking was a (%&# as usual around 9th/Irving on a beautiful Sunday afternoon right next to GG park.  All good...beauiful day in the sunset...cant beat those!!  Walked past the cute little tables in their patio and was seated right away and attended to.  The entire menu looked super yum!  I seriously had to narrow it down from sweet potato fries, crispy oysters, teriyaki bowls, macademia crusted seabass, catfish sandwich, sushi....it was rather extensive!!  We finally narrowed it down to....

Spicy Fries:  Normal fries just tossed with a cajun seasoning I think.  I LOVE fries so it was a great version...especially since they were "skinny" fries that were super crispy.  The dipping sauces were a nice touch: sweet chili sauce (the one for lumpia!!...I blended that combo LONG before I came here!!  I like their thinking here) and a creamy miso dip!!  yum!!  Mix them together...its perfect!

Salmon Wasabi Bowl:  I thought it was going to be raw salmon but it turned out to be grilled. Apparently the raw stuff is the Hawaiian Poke?  How the hell was I suppose to know that??!!  I wish there was a description on the menu.  Boooo!!  Even though I was in the mood for raw fish the salmon was a great compliment to the brown rice covered with a wasabi miso sauce, radish sprouts, seaweed salad, cucumber salad, pickled ginger and avocado.  It was all the ingredients to a honkin sushi roll but in a bowl.  For about $15, the portions were huge, fresh, and tastey.  I probably ate a little less than half and was STUFFED!  

Tuna Wasabi Bowl: Same condiments in the bowl just with lighly seared tuna.

I think I was a little disappointed that the salmon was cooked, obviously my fault, but I still enjoyed my meal.  Looking around at the other tables and their selections, the wasabi bowl was probably the best priced dish.  The menu will definitely bring me back to finalize their rating.  I cant wait to try all the other delicious goodies....crispy oysters....mmmm...cant wait!!!
author: Tammy H.

description:
Came here after a drive back from Fresno. If it wasn't for a lucky parking spot within 50 feet, I would've eaten elsewhere, but my kids were hungry and since 1 of my daughter has a food allergy, this was a better place to go. I've heard so much about this place and thru my mom, that I was excited coming here, even after a 4 hour drive.

Dishes that we ordered: California roll / Hawaiian surf and turf / grilled salmon with Gluten-free tortilla chips, artichoke, tomatoes / Tofu teriyaki bowl /  and fixed 3 course meal Costa-Rican (limited time only).
