All the food was delicious! I ordered the Hawaiian Surf & Turf. The skirt steak was very tender and so good. It also came with 2 skewers of shrimps, along with pineapple fried rice and asparagus. The grilled salmon was moist and tasty. My 5 year old daughter polished off the California roll with real crab meat. My mom's Tofu Bowl was very good. I like the firmness of the tofu. My dad's 3 course fixed price meal was very tasty. It looked like a quesadilla with all the fixings, but without the quesadilla. Oh, and the brown rice is a must have, otherwise you'll get the sushi rice, which is still good. 

It was kinda pricey, but was worth it for the delicious meal.
author: Marcus Y.

description: The poke was amazing, only surpassed by the welcoming and attentiveness of our waitress Chelsea. She was very kind and friendly, very attentive to our needs without being intrusive. Our family will be back based solely on the amazing service brought to us by our waitress.
author: Jered H.

description:
I was unsure of how the food would turn out because of it's chainy environment. In fact, it's a unique one because it serves japanese cuisine with an american touch. To summarize what our party ordered

- Wasabi bowl: ahi poki and vegatables over japanese rice
- Fish n chips: salmon strips with crispy sweet potato fries
- Terriyaki beef: with shrimp, rice and thinly sliced crispy onion rings
- Dessert: crispy spring roll with icecream and carmel sauce

All were good except for the salmon. It was tasteless unless drowned in the malt/vinegar sauce or horseradish sauce. 

I definitely want to come back because of their wide range of really healthy meals like their wasabi salads!
author: Oanh N.

description:
I want to give this place more stars but it just really didn't live up to my expectations. The waiter, though very friendly and well-meaning, was a complete bubble brain and seemed confused the whole time. Half of our orders came out 20 minutes before the rest so some of us were done before the others even got their food. The "spicy" fries were wayyy over seasoned (and not spicy at all) and the sweet potato fries (supposedly one of their specialities) weren't very special at all. Also, their sushi was not good and I would not recommend it at all. The tacos were pretty yummy but too dry. 

On the good side, my mahi mahi rice bowl was delicious as was my Kamikaze Bloody Mary (with wasabi,  yummm). I definitely recommend their drinks but most of the food fell way short.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I've passed this place a million times and we finally decided to try it tonight. It was way better than I expected. Good drinks (Pisco Punch!) and really great dishes. We had the Mahi Mahi, which was super fresh, and "Surf & Turf", also delicious!

A lot of people around us were having sushi and I think this would be an excellent place for something light with drinks after a day spent in the park.
author: Lisa W.

description: YUM!!!!!!!! I'm convinced the fried oysters are sprinkled with a lil crack. I couldn't get enough, and kept ordering until I made myself sick. The peruvian ceviche is some of the best I've had - bursting with flavor, light and incredibly refreshing. I usually opt for the special when I come. The last time I visited it was a grilled red-snapper that was seasoned to perfection! Love this place and the price is right!!
author: Shaunte J.

description:
I was hunting for a nice place to eat for one person on Irving and I came across Pacific Catch after seeing that Park Chow was full. In comparison this place was pretty much empty at about 1pm. 

I walked in and was greeted by a friendly waitress, I ordered the fish & chips basked which arrive. The sweet potato fries were faultless and I would probably go here again just to eat these. The coconut prawns were a little odd and so were the oysters. Even so I can't fault it on being a tasty .. basket of food. It was a nice enviroment to sit down and read the paper in, pretty single-friendly although there were also groups around.

Very handy location right by GG Park and on the 44 bus route, the outdoor seating looked nice but it was a bit chilly the day I went.
author: Adam S.

description:
12/1/2007
My friends and I are huge Pacific Catch fans and we attended the complimentary lunch service today.  Pacific Catch on 9th lived up to and exceeded our expectations based on our experiences at the Corte Madera and Marina locations.

We like our poke bowls and didn't stray from our typical ordering.  The poke bowls arrived and were perfectly made.  The poke was fresh, abundant, and authentic (confirmed by the Hawaiian at our table).  It went well with the accompanying seaweed salad, avocado, daikon sprouts, shredded cucumber, and pickled ginger.  The sweet potato fries also hit the spot.  We had some wine and beer but it was too early to have a hard drink from the full bar.  I do look forward to trying their cocktail menu though.

It seems to be a huge staff.  The waiters seemed a tad nervous but the hostesses, general manager, and head chef were pros.  Overall, service was nice, happy, friendly and attentive.  But granted, it's an opening and to be expected.  We hope they can maintain it.

It was nice to see that they made good use of the enormous Canvas Gallery space.  There are plenty of comfy booths and tables all around and many counter seats are also available by the kitchen.  The bar is set off and mostly faces Lincoln and the park, which will help to siphon off the expected noise and buzz.  There is also a section by the 9th Street side, which can probably be closed off and booked for private parties.

The design is warm and inviting, similar to the Corte Madera location.  We liked all the bamboo too.  Good feng shui.

Welcome to the neighborhood, Pacific Catch.

P.S. And to everyone that got annoyed I reviewed this location before it opened, well, hey, tough.  Chalk it up to my rational exuberance.  And c'mon, there are more things in life to have snits about.

6/20/2007
How funny.  I had gone to the Pacific Catch in the Marina earlier this month and whined on Yelp about how they should open one in Inner Sunset  (see review on 6/3/2007).  Lo and behold, tonight I walked past where the Canvas Gallery used to be and there are signs plastered advertising that Pacific Catch will soon be opening it's third outpost here on 9th and Lincoln.  Although the owner planned this months before my Yelp whine, score for me!

And yes, although I haven't tried the food yet since it hasn't opened (expect late summer), I already give it one more star than the review I gave the Marina Pacific Catch because it will be in my beloved hood and it will have a full bar.

You can read more here: 
http://www.pacificcatch.com/press_sunsetbeacon.html
author: Pelle Y.

description:
I don't know.. this place isn't all that and a bag of chips to me-- maybe everyone I know just played it up, and I expected too much from it.  Sorry Pacific Catch, it's not your fault.

The decor is nice and cute.  I really love the outdoor seating area, but let's face it:  It's Sunset.. and it's always gonna be cold n shiz.  The inside is cute too-- perfect little first date place.

The food is.. uhh.. meh?  We ordered the tacos (honestly, I've had better tacos at baja fresh)... and the california salad with the wasabi dressing? (forgot the exact name).  Both were blah... very very blah.  Even my friend, a loyal customer to the other Pacific Catch location, commented on the lack of quality at this particular location.

I heard that the other location is way better, and I probably just came during an off day.  

2 stars anyway cuz of the cute decor and bowl of complimentary snacks.  
FYI: I'm not one to give bad reviews (check my other reviews).. but for the price I'm paying, the food here really sucks !!!
author: S L.

description:
It's always a little on the difficult side for me to review restaurants that serve seafood. It's not that I don't enjoy it, it's that what I order typically seems to be the same across the board. I have a lot of allergies to fish so when I dine out I tend to not be that adventurous.

The one thing I found very cool about this place was that they served SWEET POTATO FRIES. These are hands down one of my favorite treats and this time was no exception. They may even have been better than the  ones I had over at Solstice (which is hard to beat) for no other reason than they served them with this amazing creamy dip. I found myself literally drenching the fries in it (so much for that eating healthier resolution). I found it a little odd that they were serving them at this type of restaurant but hey, I'll take what I can get!

The sushi roll I ordered was average. It was dripping with this sweet  sauce which I found to be a tad overwhelming. It's funny because a year ago I'd probably be all over that sauce but as I've gotten older my sweet tooth has diminished considerably. 

Everything else kinda blended in with the experience leaving me with little to no opinion...the miso soup was well, miso soup - nothing special. The service was fine but not particularly notable. The decor was good but what is really worth mentioning is the bar...FULL bar. It was probably the most appealing part of the inside; even though it was only 3pm when we ate, I found myself mysteriously drawn to it. Damn these alcoholic tendencies of mine.
author: Julia N.

description:
Fried Oysters. Poke Roll.  It's not "to-die-for" food but I'd eat there again none the less.  Service was un-noticeably good (not too bad, nothing spectacular).  They have a mini parking lot in the back, which is good considering the parking in the nearby streets.  

Appetizer: 
"Crispy Oysters" - $9.50: about 10 on the plate.  Fried.  would order it again

My meal:
"Firecracker Salmon" roll - $9.95: not a big fan of the over-induced daikon sprouts.  Didn't know I was ordering cooked-salmon til I got it.  Shouldn't have overlooked the 'tempura-salmon' description.  I'll try something else next time.
"Hawaiian Poke" roll - $8.95:  Giant cubed ahi in a roll (which I like)   I was diggin' the sesame-soy marinade.    

Got a taste of:
"Mixed Catch Basket" - $13.95
2 pieces of fish, 4 coconut shrimp & 3 crispy oysters with jalapeno tartar
No taste of coconut in my coconut shrimp.  The side of sweet potato fries were awesome.  I'd order that on it's own.
author: Diwata B.

description: I have loved Pacific Catch for years.  My experience today was very disappointing.  The food was still pretty good (although my sweet potato fries were cold when they got to me), but the service was what ruined the night.  Our server was slow with EVERYTHING- the water, the apps, the wine, the dishes, the check and then the check pick-up.  It sucks when you go out and you find yourself looking around over and over again for your server.  Disappointment from a former favorite...
author: Tara R.

description:
i'm kind of a forward person.  i say what i need and expect from people right up front.  this eliminates need for assumption (you know, the whole ass out of u and mption or something like that) and i find it useful when people are upfront with me.  when it's valentines day- i tell the old man exactly what i expect.  i don't sit at home hoping he brings me flowers and candy and then get passively aggressively mad when i only get dinner and wine.  

that being said- it's all about the delivery.  i'll be the first to tell you that i need to work on my delivery.  it can be a bit harsh.  a bit too much, especially for sensitive folks from california.  

i walked into pacific catch with 12 other people ready to have a great meal and party it up.  i picked the location, even after the incident with the glass (read previous review) and opted to not tell anyone in my dinner party about it.  the food here is amazing and one mistake should not ruin them for life.  

so i walk in with my 12 peeps.  dinner was being paid for by one in our party- but he wasn't paying for drinks.  it was early (read: no one else in there) and i was hoping that instead of a drink bill and a food bill we could do a food bill and separate drink tabs.  cause i hate having to deal with cash.  so after walking in i went straight to the server, who was with the manager, and asked if she could do it.  if it was that much of a pain in her ass- she could have said no.  and the manger would have backed her up.  and it would have been fine.  but she said no problem.  

so i drank several cocktails and ate a great meal.  and when it was time for everyone to pay our separate drink tabs- i yelled out for everyone to tip wicked extra good.  

asking for what you want upfront is helpful for everybody.  the worst that can happen is you get told no.  because homegirl was flexible and patient with my silly demands...she scored big time that night on tips.

and every year on valentines day...i get exactly what i want.  and everyone is happy.
author: Katie H.

description:
I'm gonna have to give them a thumbs down. I came with a party of 6 for a birthday dinner-- they did seat up promptly but otherwise the service was very slow. Our waitress was flighty and when asked about suggestions pointed out pretty much every item on the menu as her favorite. not helpful in narrowing down my choices! 

We ordered 2 crab apps (special for crab month) which were actually pretty good-- fresh and well spiced and not too expensive. a number of us ordered the Wasabi Bowls which were eh.

the final bill came to over $150 which seems way too high for average food and average service. if you're looking to spend $30+ on fish forget about Pacific Catch and go to a sushi restaurant where you'll find better quality for a better price.
author: Amy S.

description: Great place for business lunches. They have parking in an area that's nearly impossible to find a spot. But more importantly the food is great. I know this is a small chain restaurant, but the fish is fresh and have never had a bad experience here. Happy hour is great too. My favorite is the Ahi/Poke Salad.
author: M R.

description:
Dropped in on Pacific Catch on 9th on New Year's Day following a wander round the Botanical Gardens and had a great late lunch. I had tried Pacific Catch's booth at Outside Lands Festival and really liked the food.

Had the special chowder to start which was great, and then the Island Tacos (Baja, BBQ Salmon and Cajun Shrimp), with sweet potato fries. Was very good. There is a lot of food for not a huge amount of money, I think the chowder was about $6 and the Tacos were $14. Not cheap, but by no means expensive, especially for fresh fish.

The wait staff was very friendly and the place is very clean and has great decor. Definitely a recommended spot if you're over near 9th and Irving....
author: Paul G.

description: I've only had this food through a delivery option and really really love it. Definitely worthwhile - good quality and so delicious!
author: Farzana G.

description:
I was pretty excited to hear Pacific Catch was coming to the Inner Sunset. Prior to their opening, I had only visited the Chestnut location. Pacific Catch offers my favorite salad in the city, Sushi-Grade Ahi. I branched off once, ordering the fish tacos. Alright, but definitely not worthy of replacing my salad, it's why I go here!

It was New Year's Eve. It was cold and dark so I wasn't really in a salad mood so I opted for the Sushi-Grade Ahi rice bowl. Same ingredients as the salad, just warm rice instead. It was good, but it most definitely still didn't compare to my favorite salad IN THE WORLD! 

This place has a lot more to offer as far as seating and ambiance are concerned. I love the ambiance and decor. Seating includes tables, booths, sushi bar and bar/lounge seating. There's also a full bar. It's a great place for dinner or apps with a few drinks. I know I'll be frequenting this place plenty. And I look forward to it.

Oh yeah, service was nice too. Kyle took care of us, good guy!
author: alexa c.

description:
So I finally don't have to schlep it to the marina anymore when I'm craving some Pacific Catch! I'll raise a glass or two of Ozeki nigori sake to that, hell yeah! (which is exactly what I did tonight!) 

Housed in the old Canvas Cafe spot, this Pacific Catch is at least ten times larger than the one on Chestnut. And, dude, get this: you can make reservations on open table!!! How rad is that?!? I got on open table at around 5:30 pm and made a reservation for two for 6:45 pm, same night! It didn't look like there would have been a wait in any case, even if we had just walked in off the street (this was on a tuesday). 

We got the calamari, the spicy salmon roll, and the crab & avocado salad. Both the sushi and the salad we BIG, but we managed to polish everything off! The service was top notch. Our server checked back with us several times during the meal and was way on the ball. Nice. 

The prices are great for the type of food they serve and for the quality and freshness, but stuff adds up. You can drop fifty, no prob, especially if you have a drink or two. Well, I don't get over to the sunset much, but it sure beats the marina! Parking was even easy...there were tons of spots across the way in GG park. Sweet!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Some one year ago, this place used to be the Canvas Gallery - a bar, cafe, art gallery, and live music performance space all in one! I always thought the location and design felt in tune back then.

Welp, fast forward to today and you have Pacific Catch, where they serve infused Japanese-American food, slightly overpriced and unexciting.  The actual space is bigger and more utilized, but it felt noisy during my sitting. The kitchen was exposed, the wall art was uninteresting, the food and service was sub par.  Upon looking at the menu, almost everything is either grilled or fried. The popular sweet potato fries were not bad, but when it came to my Tokyo salmon, it felt like mall food. The rice bowls did not look like anything special either. 

Maybe I need to order something more American and less Japanese here, to go with the fries? I don't know.
author: Fotos C.

description:
Four stars: 
1st star: kid friendly
2nd star: kids menu + adult menu with food that kids would eat
3rd star: tables aren't made of plastic
4th star: full bar
The fact that the service was good and the food was tasty... well, let's just say I don't think we have to go to Chevy's anymore.
author: L. M.

description:
Why did you stick us in the back?  The terrible table close to the kitchen entrance when there are plenty of other tables available.  I grimace at where you placed us.  Your hostess APOLOGIZES, but doesn't re-seat.  What the deus?  Avoid the back table folks, lest you wish your chair get knocked throughout the meal, constantly by waitstaff shuttling in and out of the kitchen.

The poke was so salty, I went home and drank 3, 12 oz. glasses of water after that meal.

Friends swear that they love the chain.  But, my experience here was terrible.
author: K W.

description:
I've now been in here twice for lunch, and both times I've spent far more then I'd intended but left extremely happy. 

It's very hard to resist trying their sushi rolls - oversized and fresh. The Rock and Roll is great, the Rising Sun is decent.

We've had the ceviche which was stellar and the salmon salad. The ahi salad, the mixed catch plate. Overall, everyone has always been happy with their dish. We've had no problems with service or waits, food quality or experience.

The Kamikaze Bloody Mary is fine - the wasabi is a nice way to change it up a bit, but I almost wish there was a bit more bite to the drink. Wasabi shouldn't taste tamed.
author: Max A.

description: Been back about 3 times since my last review and most recently was back this past week.  The food is still just as consistent as the Chestnut location, but the service is still slow.
author: Mare C.

description:
I'm really happy that my hood has attracted a great new restaurants like Pacific Catch. They serve an assortment of seafood in a variety of styles in a very modern setting. 

I had an order of the California Rolls, crab salad and Shrimp Teriyaki bowl. All were over sized portions and delicious. This was way too much food to order. The service was beyond my expectation. A full bar added to overall experience. 

No buts, I recommend going there. Good prompt service, tasty food and great drink options make Pacific Catch the darling of the inter Sunset.
author: J A.

description: Waited forever for the food then both salmon sandwiches were served cold instead of hot. The waitress brought us back "new" sandwiches that were still cold and she neglected to replace the cole slaw she took away the first time. The manager came over to apologize with the lame excuse that they had a big table to serve before ours and it was especially busy that day, but the restaurant was only half full. Won't ever eat here again.
author: Debra J.

description: I'm surprised that this restaurant doesn't have more stars.  The salads are amazing and the tofu is the best I've had... so delicious.  My BF always gets some kind of fish dish and always loves his meal.  Their cocktails and wine are good as well.   My only complaint is that they can be a bit heavy handed with the dressing but I just order it on the side.
author: Smigor r.

description: I love Pacific Catch! They have delicious, fresh and healthy seared ahi tuna (or spicy poki) bowls and salads. They make pretty good cocktails, too. At this location the seating usually isn't a problem and the service is good. It feels a little chain restaurant-ish, but it's not. Good sustainable options, too. Consistent all the way around.
author: Robynne W.

description:
Although like many others, I was sad to see Canvas go, I was also super curious to see what Pacific Catch did with the space.  Since I had a $20 Opentable cheque to use and some friends actually said good things about the new restaurant, I decided to finally give it a try.  Oh and also, nothing seems to be open on Easter Sunday for dinner and we desperately needed to take a friend out for his birthday. 

We had a reservation for 6:30 and one of us was very late, but the hostess and waitress gave us no grief and didn't make us feel guilty at all.  That's a giant plus for me.  It didn't seem like a lot of people made reservations, as our table was the only visible one with the sign "reservation" on it.  

The decor, well, I get it, it's Hawaiian themed.  The color is a bit loud for me and made the space look much smaller than its actual size.  I am glad they retained the high ceiling that I loved when it was Canvas, and we were all in awe that we were sitting where the middle bar used to be.  One thing I really didn't like was the carpet.  It was just ugly.  I don't see why they couldn't do some sort of chic hardwood floor.  And the noise level---it sounded like Happy Hour with a hundred suits packed in some Financial District bar at 5.  

Our waitress was prompt and friendly and efficient.  Our dishes arrived timely.  Among the three of us, we had a basket of sweet potato fries, which was enormous (I mean, it doesn't look like much but sweet potatoes can be dense!)  I don't think anyone can mess up on sweet potato fries, so I was happy.  The sauces were pretty good, but I prefer to eat them without anything.  

I had an unsweetened iced tea, which reminded me of the iced tea from the Grove.  Meaning, it's good---fruity aroma but not actually really sweet.  My boyfriend had a glass of sake.   Our friend had a mojito, which looked really good. 

We wanted to get some grilled corn but apparently they ran out, cuz it was a nice day and therefore everyone ordered corn (our waitress' explanation).  But she came back and told us the kitchen managed to find a piece so they will throw that in our dish.  Free corn?  I was thrilled.  But it was just okay.  I imagined it to be that famous Mexican grilled corn from Cafe Habana in New York, but nope, just your ordinary slightly charred, buttery, hard corn.  Kinda disappointing.

For entree, I had the ahi poke wasabi bowl.  I am not a huge wasabi fan, but I do enjoy wasabi noodles from the House and thought it might be a subtle flavor like that.  It basically came as a giant bowl with every ingredient you can find in a tuna roll, but deconstructed, and enlarged.  I didn't think the rice was flavored enough to be called "sushi rice."  But the ahi poke was delicious and the soy-wasabi sauce was pungent and flavorful.  Did I mention it's giant?  After my indulgence on sweet potato fries and a piece of corn, I could only finish a quarter of my rice bowl.  I think it'll be good as left over. 

The other two had the specials, sturgeon and some other fish---I can't remember!  Both fish dishes looked just alright to me that I didn't even feel tempted to try them, but they both claimed that the dishes were good.  So I will take their word for it.  

We also shared a macadamia nut brownie with ice cream.  It was nice and sweet, and comes in a good portion for sharing.  

The restaurant was packed around 6:30 but by the time we left at 9, it was practically empty.  Sorta surprising to me that people ate so early.  I was glad that no one pressured us to leave long after we ate everything and paid and sat around.  But then again, it wasn't like they needed the table or anything. 

I would go back for the fries.  And possibly go for their Happy Hour special which seems to be a good deal.  $3 beers and little munchies to go along.
author: Candice B.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the Inner Sunset to take friends out to when I want to show them that the Inner Sunset is NOT just a sleepy suburb attached to a major metropolis. 

The food is fantastic, well presented, thoughtful, and just down right tasty. 

The staff is helpful, friendly, and all sorts of adjectives that say that they do their job well. 

Overall, I have to say that this is just a favorite pick on Golden Gate Park and a great spot for seafood lovers (and really, who dosnt love seafood in SF)
author: Jordan Y.

description:
Very nice. With all the restaurants that come and go in San Francisco, how many of them actually specialize in Seafood? I must say that I waited quite a while to check this place out since I thought it was just another new and trendy place. My biannual dinner with Dad day came around and we decided to check this place out. 

Parking, always a bitch in this part of the Sunset wasn't too bad. By that I mean that we got lucky and actually found a spot on 9th. We walked in and were greeted by the hostess and advised that we would have to wait for a table unless we didn't mind eating in the bar. Cool. I don't really care. The hostess lead us to the bar where we were seated at the most awkward table that I have ever sat at. The table doesn't give you room for your legs causing you to sit back and lean forward in an awkward position when eating. It appears that the owner never sat at these tables prior to buying them. 

It then came time to order drinks and I was pleasantly surprised with their beer selection. I had a Tahitian beer that I really enjoyed. 

I can't remember exactly what we ordered bu know that the Ahi Poki was the most memorable. This place is fresh, fresh fresh! The food was truly outstanding and refreshing. I walked out of there thinking that I actually ate pretty healthy. 

Good job guys, just replace those freakin tables!
author: Mike M.

description:
I wasn't that hungry when I came here for dinner - perfect attitude for a critical review.

Started out with a Kamikaze Bloody Mary. Tastes like a Bloody Mary, hits like a Kamikaze.

Ahi poke wasabi bowl with tobiko was delicious - almost like a sashimi bowl, with lots of seaweed. The poke wasn't that seasoned, but the ahi was good enough to make up for the lack of spice.

I had the crispy fried salmon with sweet potato fries. Never had fried salmon before, so it sounded interesting. I've also never liked sweet potato fries. The fried salmon was great (or maybe I liked it more because salmon season was canceled this year), and the sweet potato fries were also great.

All the fried stuff did not taste that greasy.

Had some mochi fondu for dessert. A little thick for mochi (I expect it to be delicate), but tasty all the same.
author: Rob T.

description:
Pacific Catch is a bullshit fish place.  The selection of fish was severely limited, the beer list was nothing special, and the atmosphere is loud and uncomfortable.  I couldn't hear a damned thing over the classic rock blasting throughout.  This place feels corporate.  Kind of like The Olive Garden or something.  

I ordered fish tacos.  They were soggy and small and totally overpriced.  The tomatillo sauce on said tacos was tasty but overpowering and overabundant.  The Thai Iced Tea was too milky and its flavors were unbalanced.  The sweet potato fries, however, were fantastic.  Salty and sweet and fried up right.  So good in fact that I'm gonna give this place another star.

The service was friendly and quick for the most part.  I was seated immediately and brought edamame and pretzels promptly.  I ordered a beer and had to wait awhile before it came.  My server forgot that I ordered it.  I could tell because I saw him walk by my table and look at me, and when he did that this look came over his face like "oh shit!" and he walked quickly to the kitchen.  A minute later I had my Oatmeal Stout.  I didn't really hold that against him though because he was otherwise attentive and nice, and I didn't really have to wait THAT long.  Everybody forgets shit from time to time.  

Another thing that was great:  They brought us the check like a few seconds after we asked for it.  I HATE it when I have to wait forever for the check.  As if it were some kind of pleasure to linger for 15 minutes in a restaurant after the food has been eaten and drinks have been drunk.  Nicely done.  

So...quick and polite service, but lame overpriced food and chain restaurant ambiance.  Bleh...I'm not coming back.
author: Michael H.

description:
My boyfriend HATES fish. As long as I've known him he has refused to eat fish. I, however, am a crafty and creative girl and I SWORE that ONE DAY I would get him to enjoy fish!
So...
One day we both had a sweet potato craving and I casually mentioned that there was a place near the park where we could eat and take a casual stroll. It was a nice day so he agreed. Ah ha! After 4 years, my plan was working..

We came in and sat down but we were sat in these super uncomfortable tall akward wicker chairs. "Surprise Boyfriend! We're at a fish place!"
Then we were served edamame and cute fishy crackers which was awesome because we were starving and made up for the crappy seating. I ordered some kind of ginger-tini and the boyfriend ordered a dark and stormy. Both were fabulous! The drinks were top notch! 
The two of us split a sweet potato basket of fries and loved it. Great dipping sauces!
I ordered the mahi mahi teriyaki bowl with pineapple fried rice and really enjoyed it. The boyfriend ordered the fish and chips. AH? Fish you say?! YES FISH!! And guess what? He LIKED it! 
For dessert, we had the Dulce de leche Spring rolls. MM MM GOOD!! If your thinking of going, make reservations.

***Update: The boyfriend took me here for Valentines day and it was one of the best dates ever! We had a cute corner table with candle light and it was very romantic. Waitress was sweet and attentive while still giving us plenty of time to stare deeply in each others eyes. The tokyo salmon was great but the calamari was not so great. Still love the sweet potato fries and next time I will try the sushi which looks yummy. ****
author: Amy A.

description:
This restaurant is really one of my favorite !

3 top reasons I love going to Pacific Catch:

1. The sweet potato fries.  They are SO delicious! This is pretty embarrassing but I can finish a whole basket of sweet potato fries and still be ready for a second helping :) hehe

2. The Crab/Avocado salad.  Huge portion and super yummy.  This will take care of your vegetable intake for the whole week!

3. They have a GREAT happy hour menu from 4-6pm M-F and after 10pm everyday.  I just found out that they also do happy hour on Sat and Sun after 10pm.  Did I mention that their sweet potato fries during happy hour is ONLY $3 for a whole basket?! And beers are only $3 as well?!
author: Be. N.

description:
Awesome food for a random Saturday night. We had a group of four and were seated immedietly. The place was about half full at about 9:30 PM. Good drink selection (I had a Sierra Nevada). As appetizers we got Edamame (served warm, not cold for a change) and the Ahi Poke. I have to say, the Ahi was about as fresh as it gets. Very flavorful. I ordered the Wasabi Bowl with Ahi Tuna (and brown rice). This food is awesome if you're looking for a healthy meal. As I said before, the Ahi was as fresh and flavorful as it gets, and the bowl included avocadoes, ginger, sprouts, ect. The other three people in our group ordered salads...all healthy portions. 

I live in San Jose and I wish we had a Pacific Catch closer to home. 

My buddy suggested the place as we were walking by (he's been there several times) and I'll agree, this is really good, fresh food.
author: Damon B.

description:
I had a different experience than the first time I went.  I came here last Friday for my 21st birthday.  As I expected, it is really crowded for dinner, but I didn't mind.  We waited about 20 min. for a table, so Garren and I ordered a beer and a mai tai.  The mai tai was small but very strong.  I was buzzed after drinking a third of it.  When we finally got a table, we ordered the salmon tempura roll, the salmon sandwich, and the catch of the day basket.  All of the food was delicious, but I figured out that I don't really like fried musssles (I don't blame the food, just my taste buds).  I also ordered the lime in the coconut drink, but it just kind of tasted like water.  I don't think I'd order it again.  

After we were done eating the waitress told us that that I get a free birthday dessert.  We told her that we were so full, and couldn't eat anymore.  Then she said, "Oh, not even a scoop of ice cream?"  Soooo, we said, "Alright then, thank you."  When we got the bill, she ended up charging us for the "free birthday dessert."  I don't even think that a scoop of ice cream was supposed to be the "free birthday dessert."  There were many other people getting these fancy-looking desserts, with candles, and they were not on the dessert menu.  I am assuming that those were supposed to be the free birthday dessert.  I don't know.  

I like the food from here, but I did not like how we got charged for a "free" not even birthday dessert.  I was also pissed that the people next to us had a different waiter, and they got free mochi balls for no reason.  I think the waiter was hitting on them, but still....  It was my damn birthday.  Overall during the day, I didn't have a very good birthday (lack of sleep, lab from 7 am- 1:30, homework, don't know anyone in this city, spent my birthday basically alone), and by the end of the night, it was topped off with this... Even though a restaurant may have great food, it is really the customer service that can make or break a good experience.
author: Candiace A.

description:
I came with my parents around 7:30 and were told we had to wait 25 minutes.  So we sat down grabbed a menu and decided what we wanted for dinner.  No more than 10 minutes later, our table was ready.  This place we off to a good start.  But it took forever for our food to come!  Tables that were seated after us...got their food before us!  ???  But back to the food.  We ordered...

-Calamari (Not seasoned well enough for me and a little dry)
-Two Taco platter with the Mahi Mahi which comes with Sweet Potato Fries.  (The fries were amazing!  Definitely my favorite part of my meal.  The tacos were also pretty flavorful)
-Skirt Steak Teriyaki bowl (Felt like we could get this as part of a Bento box at any Japanese restaurant.) 
-Spicy Mahi Mahi sandwhich (This was also superb.  It came with avocados which added so much flavor.)
-Skinny Dip ON TAP!!! *And the chorus begins to sing...*

Overall a decent dinner at Pacific Catch.  The food was good for the price we paid; however, nothing really "caught" my attention.  I did notice that they have Happy Hour daily and will probably come back to try that!
author: Helen V.

description:
I once stayed at a cinder block, rat-hole motel near Lake Tahoe because we were stranded due to a blizzard. I'm pretty sure I didn't sleep that night waiting for Jason from Friday the 13th. 

Best hotel I ever stayed in! What? Why? You confuse me... 

OK here's the rub. It's all about perspective. We awoke to 3 feet of powder and were virtually all alone on the mountain giggling down each and every run. I'd do it again and pay double. 

That is how I feel about Pacific Catch. 
I went with my two daughters and lovely wife. You see...my girls are at the "we shouldn't go to a public restaurant" age for fear of being banned and never allowed to return again. 
The wife and I have dined at many a fine seafood restaurant (pre kids)...that would blow this guppy out of the pond. But since our two little "angels" arrived...we keep these experiences to a minimum. 
You can thank us now. 
Pacific Catch rocked for us on all levels. Waiter great. Brought crayons, coloring pages, kids' menus and lot's of wine....immediately. 
He treated our daughters like royalty and kept me and the misses well hydrated (if you know what I mean). The food was surprisingly great. Wasabi bowl is a keeper and my kid barely got to try her fish-n-chips. (must have been the wine...sorry honey). 
We'll be back. And on a bright note...I think they'll let us come back. 
We'll be there about 5 p.m. with the senior citizens and other families with rug rats. Come say hi.
author: Mark C.

description: I come here all the time and I am never disappointed. Lunch or dinner, the waiters are always great, the food is always fresh and delicious with way too much to even come close to finishing. I have had huge groups of 20 and just two people, and no matter what, everyone leaves satisfied. Love this place. I really appreciate the sustainable interior design as well!
author: Breanne B.

description:
Came here on a whim after a trip to the Academy of Science.  The menu looked good (lots of seafood, which we love) and reasonable prices.  We decided to sit out on the patio and enjoy the rare sun.

Started with the shrimp ceviche - YUM! Not too spicy, and tons of shrimp.  We ran out of chips, thank goodness - I would have gotten full off that alone.
I ordered the Ahi Poki Wasabi bowl, with brown rice, half rice half salad.  Complicated, huh?!  Wasabi/soy over rice was... different.  Had a little wasabi kick, but not too bad.  Though next time I'll order that sauce on the side.  Careful of the salad too - they drown it with dressing, though the dressing was pretty good.  Poke was ok - huge cuts of tuna, but lots of chewy parts (are those tendons??)  I think if they were cut properly, it would have tasted much better.  
Husband ordered the 2 taco plate - one salmon and one mahi.  I didn't try the mahi - I guess it was good cause he ate the whole thing!  The salmon I tried and was yummy.  Not too much sauce, just right.  

Have to admit, eating my asian dish, followed by a taste of his spanish dish was kinda weird.  But both were very tasty.  Just not at the same time...

Love the variety of dishes on the menu.  We wouldn't mind coming back to try new dishes.
author: Paulette L.

description:
I've been to the other one in the Marina a few times but have always been hesitant to go back because of the crazy parking and the over crowded place. You are literally sitting elbow to elbow with the table next to you. Anyway, I was pretty excited when this location opened because it's so much closer to where I live and not to mention spacious. The atmosphere is different than the one in the marina, it's more elegant and has a 'higher class" look to it if that makes sense. The food is slightly different and a little bit more expensive than the other but great non the less. I will be coming back soon.

BTW...I had the taco platter and it was yummy. Minus one star for not offering the same sandwiches as the one in the marina and for raising the prices on some of the same things offered at the other location.
author: Diane M.

description:
First off, how awesome is it that they give you little fish pretzels and edamame to start off your lunch?  I have this bad habit of getting busy at work and putting off my lunch break until 1:00 or later, so by the time I get to a restaurant, I'm starving.  Having a little snack while I'm waiting for my food is exactly what I need to put me in a good mood again. 

I'm in love with their Ahi Tuna bowl with brown rice.  The tuna is always PERFECTLY seared... except for the one time I ordered it to go.  By the time I got back to the office, it had cooked itself in the box, unfortunately.  
But at the restaurant, it's always cooked on the outside, and still pink and juicy in the middle.  You also get little bits of seaweed salad, sprouts, and pickled vegetables.  Tasty!

They also have fun, sugary martini drinks, which I always enjoy (after work, of course).  I wish they'd have a happy hour discount on them, though, because it's a little cost prohibitive to have more than one.  

Speaking of cost-prohibitive, I would come here more often if their entrees were also a little less expensive.  Minus one star for that.  I don't normally like to spend more than $10 on lunch, so it feels like a waste to spend $15-20 at Pacific Catch, when there are lots of delicious and cheap restaurants in the neighborhood.   As it is, I still manage to go to Pacific Catch about once a month, so apparently it's occasionally worth it for the perfect tuna.  :-)
author: Jane A.

description:
My sweetie wanted to give this place 5 stars. No,  he is not a Yelper but he vicariously Yelps through me.  His Yelp is as valid as mine since we are in this together.  

So, we had a nice delicious date night at Pacific Catch on 9th Street. Initially I planned on taking a nice walk at the Botanical Garden at Golden Gate Park to induce some nature in sweetie's system but it closes at 5 pm which meant it will be too early for dinner at Pacific Catch. So, we slept in anyway on that day and didn't make it to the City until almost 7 PM.  

Found parking at GG Park as soon as we entered the park. Crossed Lincoln holding hands and informed the hostess that we had a 7:30 reservation at 6:50 PM. Got seated right away.  I felt sad!!!! This used to be Canvas Cafe where my very, very dear friend Russell used to perform.  I remembered the good old days when he used to bring down the house!!!!! 

Anyway, sweetie and I got a welcome appetizer of Asian pretzel and edamame. We barely had time to eat it when our appetizer of fried oysters arrived. It was actually very good!!! The oysters were fresh and light.  (Our waiter was very prompt and attentive.)  I really wanted to order the famous rice bowls but I opted for ahi tuna 3 ways!!!! And 3 ways I was pleased.  Sweetie got the beef with prawns.  I don't know what it was called because I was busy concentrating on my tuna.  He said his was delicious except it was not enough. (Disclaimer:  my sweetie is a hefty eater. Pacific Catch's portions are adequate for normal human eaters like me who is Asian, petite but can pack  it in once in a while if the food is yummy!)  

Then we shared the mochi fondue which was nice contrast between the hot and the cold. Cold ice cream wrapped in the soft skin of rice flour dipped in hot smooth chocolate. The flavor just burst in my mouth.   

Overall, the experience was great.  I still could not give it 5 stars, though, even though the venue was hip and welcoming. Maybe because it should have stayed as Canvas Cafe where my dear, dear friend could have been still playing and bringing down the house. Maybe someday.... I will learn to forgive Pacific Catch eventhough I know it was not his fault. But I will definitely go back to his arms again......

We finished the evening with me showing sweetie my old hangout places like Tart to Tart   (that's for another Yelp review) and staying up until 2 PM watching "Eyes Wide Shut."  Yup, I was right all along. Nicole Kidman said the "F" word at the end of the movie.
author: Leah E.

description:
Without a blink, 4 stars. 

I seriously love this place. I love the menu, the ambiance, the wicked happy hour deals. 

Sign up for the Pacfic Catch newsletters...there is always a monthly "deal." In October, it was 'buy one entree, get the 2nd free!' 

My faves: salmon or ahi tuna wasabi bowl with brown rice, or the taco combo with sweet potato fries.

I love coming here with girlfriends, esp because you can get opentable.com reservation points--win-win baby!
author: Misha F.

description:
First off I must say this is one beautiful building for a restaurant.  For any of you guys who remember the lame art gallery that was here before, thank god this place is here now.  I really loved walking in and seeing the spacious ceilings, great warm looking color scheme and pretty diverse wait staff and customers.

The service was pretty good from the get go.  We made reservations so there was no wait on a crowded Sunday night.  They had sooooo many servers there.  I think at any time there were at least 6 waiters standing around because really there is only so many times I need my water filled.  

Now as far as fusion cooking I have some mixed emotions.  Most of the time I rather just have the pure breed, Asian or simply the Hitler blond hair, blue eyes Aryan super food.   This really just kind of tasted Hawaiian.  I really thought the food was superb.  I had the Ahi menage trois aka, ahi 3 ways.  I have to start with the Poke, which unlike most places make it really small.  The poke here was HUGE chunks nicely seasoned and spiced!  The sesame grilled Ahi was good too, but I guess I rather wish I had more.  The other grilled Ahi was similar, but a little more raw with no sesame seeds and some sauce.  

I also had a taste of the Teriyaki bowl, which was kind of boring.  A little Pineapple, some veggies and chicken.  

Overall I guess you should just stick to the seafood, make reservations and ignore the fusion aspect and you'll be ok.   

  Fusion food is usually pretty hit and miss, with most places tasting like mall food.
author: patrick o.

description:
How piggy are we...only 4 of us girls and we polished off TWO large baskets of the addicting sweet potato fries...as apps...for lunch!  That's how good they are...and fairly priced at $5 for a large basket.  I liked the menu but my House Special Salad w/ grilled tofu was meh @ $12.  Others ordered Fish & Chips and Asparagus & Shiitake Rolls (asparagus tempura) and said it was good.  Plenty of good drink choices. 

Space is cool...very open, high ceilings w/ lots of booths in the main room w/ a huge sky light and open kitchen.  Off to the right of the entrance is another room where we sat.  This room could easily accommodate a large semi-private party.   

I really appreciate that they serve sustainably-sourced seafood and consult the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch "green light" list.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
Service was fantastic.  We had reservations and were seated promptly and the server was friendly and refilled our drinks promptly and often.

Unfortunately, I thought the food was just okay.  Started with the sweet potato fries and the poki as our apps.  Potato Fries were good, although it would've been nice if they were crispier.  Poki was just average.

My friend had the scallops and I had the combination fish and chips.  The fish was very good.  Fresh, but a little on the small side.  The shrimp and oysters were average although they were deep fried...  Forget fusion, just deep fry everything and I'd be happy.  Wrap it in bacon and I'd be in heaven (probably figuratively and literally).

Dessert was excellent.  Fried Dulce de Leche "Spring Rolls"   Yum.

Parking is a bit yuck like normal around the Irving area.  You can find it, but you have to do the parking crawl.

All in all, it was decent.  I'd go back, but probably not as my first choice.
author: H C.

description:
Hubby and I came here for a date night a few weeks ago. We started with a bottle of wine and...it had a twist off top.  Yikes.

I had miso soup and one of the daily specials- I know it was trout. It was fine but certainly didn't blow my mind. Hubby had fish and chips and thoroughly loved it. He loves any and all battered and fried foods, however!

I'll come back to Pacific Catch but I'll only expect mediocrity.  Eh.
author: Kayla N.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night.  It was pretty busy and we had to wait.  The cool part is that you can leave your cell phone number with them and they would call you when your table is ready.  This let us wander around the neighborhood. 

The food is definitely good.  The wasabi bowl is pretty good.  We had it with brown rice.  The rice is flavored with a touch of wasabi so it was pretty tasty.  I had the sturgeon.  It was ok but I think I liked the wasabi bowl better.

I would definitely come back.

One thing that was a little weird was that every other table had cloth napkins but we didn't.  We had a paper napkin.  Kinda weird.

*Update* - came back again last night.  had the mixed catch basket (fried shrimp, oysters and fish) and it was just so so.  it was good but nothing to write home about.  i definitely think i'll stick to the wasabi bowls when i come back
author: Patrick L.

description: Nice looking place with friendly and efficient service.  But the kitchen is indifferent and weak.  If you want a good meal, this definitely is not the place to go.
author: Allan S.

description:
I'm a bit obsessive.  When I know that I'll be going to a restaurant, I like to study the menu and plan out what I'll order as well as what my husband needs to order. 

I finally narrowed it down to the tacos, and I got uber happy to know that I could mix up the tacos.  Sadly, when I finally bit into all three of them (shrimp, mahi-mahi, regular fish), they all tasted the same to me.  The sauces in those tacos overpowered everything else inside those tortillas.  The sweet potato fries were okay.  I got tired of them after a while.

My husband ordered the wasabi bowl, and that was pretty tasty.  

Overall, the restaurant was okay.  My stomach couldn't have possibly expanded any more from all the food I was piling into it.
author: Maricar M.

description:
I took my friends here as a late Christmas dinner, subsitute present after my other friend told me how delicious this place was. After confirming the fact on Yelp, I decided to make a reservation. As my friend and I sat and waited for our other friends to arrive, the waiter was kind and attentive. He asked us if we wanted anything to eat as we waited, filled our water cups, and gave us our complentary plate of edamame and pretzel gold fishes. 

To start we ordered Rock & Roll and also sweet potatoe fries. The sweet potatoe fries were really good and the sauce was delicious. Rock & Roll, not so much - it's not that it was bad, rolls are just not a good choice for this restaurant. Anywho, my friend and I ordered the wasabi bowl with ahi tuna and crab salad to share. The bowl was really good and had huge portions. The salad had a lot of crab, but not much flavor. The Thai salad on the other hand I liked. My other friend ordered the salmon sashimi. It wasn't good and unlike the heaping portions of salad and wasabi bowl - it was lacking. She ended up eating from our plates. The meal came out to $80 with tax and tips. A little pricey, but considering what we ate and the occasion, it was pretty good. I would come back, when my wallet permits it. 

The interior design and the high ceiling of the restaurant felt warm and cozy, and definitely made me feel like I was out of the Sunset. This is definitely a romantic restaurant and would be a great place to take a girl on a date. Maybe not a first date though, cause the noise level kills that.
author: Adrianna C.

description:
i got the mixed basket of fish, coconut shrimp, and oysters, with sweet potato french fries.  It was delicious.  Bubs got the hawaiian mahi mahi which was a bit too grilled and smokey for our taste.  But it came with pineapple rice which was yum.  

for desert we had the macadamia nut brownie sundae, with toasted almonds and fudge.  that was incredibly delicious and worth the trip alone!  

the atmosphere is laid back but trendy-ish.  the waiter looked like ellen degeneris and was super nice!
author: Jo M.

description:
1 star for their accommodating parking spaces in the back of restaurant. Although limited, still very convenient, especially in the sunset district.

1 star for their prime customer service. The entire staff was very friendly. From the start of our experience with the host, to the end of the meal when the manager approached our table for comments.

1 star for their food. What an array of interesting selections. I enjoyed the sweet potato fries with the flavorful aioli. The fish tacos were also yummy.
A few other items that were a hit for my party were the california rolls, spiced cajun fries and wasabii chicken bowl.

Last star for the spacious floor plan. The tables and chairs weren't so crowded around each other and the place was very family friendly. 

The only reason they were shy of 5 stars were the prices. Some items were a bit overpriced for the quantity of food given.
author: Anne K.

description: The cocktails are inventive and very tasty. The environment is bright, clean, but not sterile.  It does feel like a chain, and when you get you're food you'll see it tastes like one too.  The menu needs a boost. The whole Asian Fusion thing is not working for them at all because the quality of the food gets lost in the middle.  My partner had fish that was very bland. I had the ahi 3 way which sounds a lot more erotic than it was. Service was good. Our waitress was a friendly college girl. I would go back for the cocktails and appetizers, not the entrees.
author: Mark S.

description:
When I saw Ono on the chalk board, I knew I had to walk in...
The moment I opened the doors though, I was buffeted by something I learned a long time ago to identify...

The smell of old, dirty fryer oil. Seriously, I don't care how new or old a place may be... if they serve anything fried, and don't have the respect for their product to change bad oil, then I'm pretty much boycotting the place.

Come here only if you have reservations. When we walked in, the hostess first looked disdainfully at my hat (a nice shiny, new ushanka, bite me.), then asked if we had reservations. 1 hour wait? Are you kidding me? For a place with bad oil? Yeah lady, I have reservations... about your oil, can you dig it?

(I really am a sucker for Ono though, I'll sit through a place reeking of bad oil just to eat it.)

Totally didn't dig the crowd either, think a healthy mix between what seemed to be tourists in tshirts, old affluent couples, and hipsters swilling martinis at the bar. What can I say, I was being a little picky thanks to all the friggin' rain that night. (saturday... the day of the deluge part 2.)

Not quite my crowd, not a decent tattoo, hooligan or body piercing in sight. ;)

I'll be back when they fix that oil problem, and then I can add critique of their service and food.
author: Dave M.

description:
Originally, I was looking for their location in the Marina, but we were near Golden Gate Park and the tiny but small parking lot had a few open spots so I figured why not.  With multiple locations, the differences in ratings didn't really seem logical.

My family enjoyed the quick service as we were hungry.  The waiter recommended the coconut shrimp for an appetizer and I'll pass that recommendation along.  The fish tacos and sweet potato fries were the common entrees that got praise.  

The only universal entree that got high marks was the dessert.  The fried Dulce de Leche spring rolls at first didn't sound appealing to everyone, but we devoured two orders without an effort.  

4 out of 5 stars, and next time I am hungry and nearby, I'll definitely stop in even if the parking lot is full.
author: Ian C.

description:
3.5 stars!!

Parking absolutely sucks around this neighborhood, but if you are lucky enough to get in to there lot that holds about 5-6 cars you are lucky. If not then you will be driving around the block a couple of times and having to feed meters. But hey, cant help that, it is San Francisco!

I tried the taco plate.  And i asked if it was spicy and they said no. I got it and it was pretty hot. I was able to eat one of the 2 tacos.  The sweet potatoe fries are pretty good. I like the free edamame and pretzal gold fish they put on the table when you are seated! The service was good. We had about 7 people. It was my grandpa's birthday. We brought our own cake. They did charge us a cake cutting fee, which i thought was kinda tacky, but we paid it. $2.00 a piece.  

All in all the food, service and place was good. I would go back!
author: Shelley N.

description: Came here for a late lunch yesterday. I had the fish n chips and my friend had the tacos. Zero complaints but could've used a heads up for how spicy the chicken taco was. Only docked a star for the host who gave us a wobbly table when there was hardly anyone there. Our server was an older guy; super sweet and attentive. Loved this place and hear they have a good happy hour. Great ambience as well.  Will absolutely be back.
author: Siobhan T.

description:
I'm so glad that they opened up a Pacific Catch in Inner Sunset... the Marina one is just WAY WAY WAY too small and difficult to get to with parking issues too.  

Pacific Catch is in no way supposed to be close to being authentic japanese food.  Instead of serving you bread, they give you a small plate of fish pretzels and edamame beans.  

They have a large variety of dishes to try.  I like their wasabi bowls.  It comes with seaweed, fish (depending on what kind, I get the Ahi Tuna or Poke Tuna), guacamole, and some other ingredients I don't remember.  The bowl itself is pretty big, and will definitely fill you up!  It costs about $15 for this bowl.  Their sweet potato fries are also very delicious, served with sweet and sour sauce.  Their sushi rolls are average, and nothing spectacular...

I tried their soup special one day... I forget the actual name of it, but it was similar to a ciopinno.  It was a tomato based soup with seafood.  The broth was very flavorful!  There was plenty of content in the soup too.  I was actually surprised by how much I enjoyed it!!  The soup cost about $12 though.  But very delicious.  It's something not always on their menu.

Their fish and chips were very good, comes with about 3-4 pieces depending on what combo you get...  The fish was fresh.  I also got a fish special of the day.  The fish was cooked nicely, and not overcooked.  I don't remember what was in it, but it was reallygood over all.

Overall, if you go here, get their fish dishes.  It's not as cheap as the other restaurants on Irving, but it's worth it for what they give you.  They also can take large groups with reservations... we had a group of 14 or so and the service wasn't bad or lagging at all.
author: Diane L.

description: I've always gone to the Pacific Catch on Chestnut and love it there! The only thing is that parking is impossibleee to find and its a very small place. Decided to come to the one here on 9th to let some out of towners try the food. This Pacific Catch restaurant is sooooo big! They have more stuff on the menu and it came with small dishes of peeled edamami and pretzel fish. I did want to try the 3 way ahi (on the dinner menu but our waitress said they can make it for lunch as well) but I stayed faithful to my beloved ahi tuna wasabi bowl. I love it... if I could, I would eat it at least once a week! I'm coming here from now on to get my ahi fix.
author: Katherine C.

description:
The location is great and it looks nice on the inside, they put a lot of effort into it and the menu looks fantastic. I just wish that they put the same effort into the service and food. The bar seemed pricey for what it was and didn't seem to have a great selection. My friend definitely ordered the wrong thing, salmon fish and chips which stated "lightly breaded and fried" and it showed up over breaded, over fried and room temperature. Not even close to being edible. I had the wasabi sandwich and it was just ok, pretty bland. By the time the staff came back to see how our food was going so much time had passed that we didn't want to send the salmon back and wait for something else, we just wanted the check.

Menu looks great but maybe be more adventurous than I was, I am sorry I didn't try more here before deciding not to come back. The location is nice and convenient.
author: William R.

description: Very kid friendly!! They brought my 16 month old a dish of pretzel fish and edamame when we first arrived which she loved. The service was very good, waitresses very friendly. The food and drinks were just okay however. It was also a tad loud.
author: Lacee D.

description:
My last  find of 2009 and one of my new favorites in 2010 in San Francisco. This place is great (at least so far for happy hour). I will definitely return again and look forward to doing dinner there soon.

The well-priced happy hour (M-F 4-6 & again from 10-closing) serves daily-featured) house wines at $6. The bar menu is interesting. I have had on both visits, the Hawaiian Poke (sushi-grade ahi tuna in a delicious sesame-soy marinade with spicy seasonings with fresh wonton crisps (not ordinary wontons found in Chinese places). It's a hefty serving at $6.

It's a bit noisy in the bar between 5 & 6 due to the USC students so I suggest before 5 if you prefer a smoother atmosphere.

In Patrick (bartender & server) the establishment could not hope for a better ambassador...thoroughly knowledgeable regarding all the restaurant's programs and very cordial in explaining them as they seem a little complicated at first.

Once again, all in all, a very pleasurable experience.
author: Lee S.

description: I was pretty underwhelmed by everything everyone ordered, but we may not have made the best choices either. I thought the fish tacos were pretty goofy - none of the seasoning/sauces really did anything, but maybe it's my fault because I should have had fish tacos elsewhere. But the fish and chips weren't good either - too dry and also flavorless. So, if you go, try something other than those dishes. I also attempted to drink the strongest mai tai I've ever had but gave up after a few sips. This would be bordering between 2 and 3 stars, but overall I can't see going there again, which I wouldn't say of a place I'd give 3 stars to.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Maybe it was because it was kinda late for a Monday night supper, but I had the fish tacos and they were pretty bland.  

Was disappointed they didn't have hot sake (only cold), to thaw out from the especially bitter Sunset chill.

However, their yam fries were hot + crispy, with scrumptious inner ~ most excellent :)

The service + space are also fantastic.  I'd go back to try some of their other dishes.  For now, 3.5.
author: Cathy K.

description: The Japanese Wasabi bowl with brown rice and seared ahi is delicious! Very fresh vegetables and fish. Also, the Kiwi Flash, an unlikely pairing of kiwi and cucumber, offers a refreshing beverage.
author: Chaz G.

description:
It's amazing someone didn't think of this type of restaurant sooner - a more upscale Hawaiian restaurant, focusing on serving quality fish. 

I've always had good experiences here. I prefer this location to the Marina, because it has a LOT more space. They usually serve up great lunch specials, and a little known fact is that they have a late night happy hour! After 10PM til close, they serve up $3 beers and cheap appetizers, which are all quality.
author: Rod M.

description:
In a nutshell: Yummy! Good service, great location, nice & casual ambiance.

Having had an AWFUL experience at their ugly stepsister restaurant on Chestnut, I was a bit apprehensive to try out the new place in the Sunset. Given that it's a new location & the staff is still fairly new, I had a fabulous lunch here today!

The location can't be beat, across the street from GG park. Much closer for me to get to, living in the Richmond. They did a great job with the space. This location is far more comfortable than the Chestnut PC. Lots of space and casual dining means parents with babies. LOTS of them. However, this actually wasn't too bad at all since the acoustics of this PC just makes everyone's noises blend in to the overall sound of dining.

I ordered my usual, the crab salad wasabi rice bowl. It came out promptly and was delicious!!! Lots of crab salad and toppings. 

Our server was obviously new but did a great job nonetheless. Our waters and soda didn't ever stay empty for long and he came by regularly to check how we were doing. 

Overall, this location is FAR better than the one on Chestnut. Pac Catch has finally redeemed itself, I'll be back for sure.
author: Jen P.

description:
Minus one star for the price.  I thought it was a little pricey for what it is.  Besides that, I was pleasantly surprised.  I had been to the one on Chestnut, and it is so cramped and uncomfortable.  This one is opposite. Spacious, and well decorated.  Good food and Great drinks.  I highly recommend the lemon grass mojito.  It was so yummmy.

UPDATE: I went there again tonight, and i was great again!  I have to add that we went without reservations both times, and were seated within 5 minutes.  Also, the food comes really quickly.  We shared a Dulce de Leche dessert, and it was FANTASTIC!
author: Erica S.

description:
This location is pretty closeby. I like the 10PM-closing happy hour. 

Yes, parking sucks, but it's usually not a problem after 9:30PM, and it's really nice to have the little parking lot on the side for customers.

The bartenders are attentive and helpful.

The Food:

- SWEET POTATO FRIES. MMM...they're crispy and salted just right. I wish I had some right now.

- Poke bowl. - has always been a good choice for me.

- Sushi rolls. - nothing to write home about, but they taste good.

- Marinated steak bowl. - marinated, grilled meat, need I say more? 

- Fish and Chips, Coconut Shrimp, other fried items - good, fried, no complaints. 

- Ceviche. - wasn't particularly impressed. Sauce seemed a little overpowering.
author: Kay N.

description:
Pacific Catch was okay. It was good but not especially good. I ordered two sushi rolls, the spicy tuna roll and the sake sake roll (salmon, avocado, sprouts, and lemon zest). The rolls tasted good, but the tuna roll felt a little rubbery to me. Also, I wasn't expecting the center of the sake sake roll to be just avocado, as opposed having some sort of meat in the middle, but I like avocado, so it was alright.

The service, however, was good. My server was friendly, and I got my food quickly even though the restaurant was crowded. If you are willing to spend about $22 on two average-tasting sushi rolls, you can go. If you're like me, though, and find that to be a lot of money to spend on food that isn't that great, I'd pass.
author: Storm T.

description:
I was invited for the complimentary lunch today. When we walked in, there was like 4 employees who greeted us at the door. They all had a sincere smile on their face. 

I brought my husband and daughter. The invite was for "me and a friend". My daughter was just going to share with us since she doesn't eat a lot. Our waitress said that if my daughter wanted something, they'd accommodate us. How cool is that?

They brought out a small dish with edamame beans and salted goldfish crackers. 

For appetizers, we ordered the fried oysters which came with a jalapeno tartar sauce. MMMMM!!!!

For my entree, I ordered the teriyaki bowl with Grilled Skirt Steak. The beef was tender and very tasty. Sitting on top of the pineapple fried rice was slices of mushrooms and bok choy. I LOVED the fried rice!!!

My husband ordered the Crispy Oyster & Chips Basket. It came with crispy battered Oregon Coast oysters with traditional fries, sesame slaw & jalapeno tarter. That was good too.

My daughter got the salmon teriyaki bowl. 

I loved everything about this place. Prices aren't bad at all. The staff was super friendly and very attentive. They have one staff assigned to each table. Who can ask for more? I don't have even one single complaint or disappointment about this place. I suggest you go eat here yourselves and see what I'm raving about. Check out their website too!

I really didn't want to go to this restaurant because from the outside it just seemed like some wanna-be trendy fish spot. At the behest of my mom and cousin....I was forced to partake. Walking inside it definitely has that trendy feel, so I sat my frown down not at all in the mood for some crazy fish concoctions. 

The menu is mostly Asian with a twist of Mexican on some dishes. We had 3 dishes and shared them all around the table. Sturgeon with sweet potato fries with a spicy guac sauce, scallops with shitake mushrooms and seaweed salad, and the sushi grade ahi salad. THE BOMB!!! It doesn't sound like any of that would go together well, but it did. We were all very impressed.

None of us had any cocktails but the wine we had was wonderful and our server paired it with our meal nicely. Mikey (our server) was very attentive without being irritating. He hooked us up with a comp dessert which was crazy good! Ice cream fondue...which translates into fried ice cream wrapped in rice paper and dipped in chocolate sauce. It was a great finish to a great meal. 

We stayed for a pretty long time converstating and enjoying ourselves. When we were leaving I did notice there were a few families with kids so it seems like a good place for all ages. 

One of the managing partners came by our table to check on us and gave us the rundown of the restaurant....I'm sure his presence contributed to how great everything was, but I can't imagine anything truly suffering in his absence.
Most definitely will go again and again and again.
author: Jocelyn J.

description: Service was horrible. It was barely packed and it took the waiter 10 minutes just to introduce himself and give us waters. The food took forever and was mediocre.  Maybe it was a fluke night but this was my experience. The restaurant itself was very nice and modern however.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I am so sold on this place. I came in with a clean slate, having never tried Pacific Catch anywhere. First impressed by how clean, fresh everything was. The high ceilings make the place feel even more spacious. The wait staff and hostesses were all very friendly. HUGE bonus points for the fact that they're super kid friendly and even have "stroller parking" back by the restrooms. I ordered the special - organic chinook salmon, tomatillo salsa, grilled veggies and sweet potato fries. The fish was perfectly cooked, not underdone but not dry or tough. The spice rub on it was AHMAZING! The salsa was pretty good, not my favorite part of the dish, but was nice. The grilled veggies were fully cooked, maybe even a little overcooked, but since I was feeding them to my toddler, I didn't mind. The sweet potato fries, totally awesome. Toddler LOVED them. I loved them!

The only thing was that I was a bit disappointed by the portions, which felt on the small side. But, I don't need any encouragement to overeat so I don't feel too bad about the portions. 

I definitely recommend if you get a salad, ask for the miso dressing. My mother-in-law tried it and we were dipping everything in it. Totally delicious.
author: Laura G.

description:
Went for happy hour last Friday.  We got there early enough to snag seats at the bar, but the bar area filled up pretty quickly after we arrived.  The dining room is huge (and was pretty empty), but happy hour deals are only good if you sit in the bar area. Why?? This rule made it difficult for groups larger than 3 or 4 to sit together.

Ordered almost all of the happy hour appetizers: sweet potato fries, calamari, spicy tuna roll, and poke.  I'm not sure how discounted the happy hour pricing was, but they all seemed pretty cheap for the serving size.  Both the fries and the calamari were fried crispy and light, not at all greasy.  Poke was good, but not the best cuts of tuna, and it seemed a little heavy on the sauce.  Spicy tuna roll was good, and I'm not usually a fan of "spicy" rolls.  

Nice alcohol selection at the bar, and decent variety of beer on tap.  Also tried a kumquat mojito and a lemongrass mojito - yummm.  Not too sweet.  Service was ok, although it was hard to figure out who our server/bartender actually was.
author: marissa a.

description:
I really liked Canvass, but this seafood place is a surprisingly tasty replacement.  Great cocktails.  I had a wonderful pisco sour, with the egg whites so, so mild.  My friend had the yuzo drop, with Hangar One vodka, the Japanes citrus fruit and a sugared rim--mmmmm.  

Food portions are huge, so expect to take something home at the end of meal.  Loved the crispy oysters appetizer--very crisp and batter-fried with tender oyster meat on the inside.  The firecracker salmon roll, filed with  tempura salmon, chili sauce, avocado, cucumber, daikon sprouts and crispy shallots, was another winner.  There are eight pieces, so definitely a plate to split.  For the entree, I had one of the "chalkboard specials," which was a simple grilled opah served with a halved artichoke, brown rice, and a chunky tomato and lemon sauce.  It was very flavorful, and I had enough for lunch the next day.  Really liked the cold edamame and fish-shapped crackers they serve instead of boring, table bread and butter.  

No room for dessert, so I dont know how good they are.  Wouldnt mind coming back to find out.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
I like this location more than the one on Chestnut.  

This location is roomy and the decor is quite nice.  I always get the hawaiian poke wasabi bowl!  SOOOOO GOOD! I usually get it with sushi rice but I got it with brown rice recently and it was just as good! and healthier too might I add.   the mahi and tuna sandwiches are also quite tasty.  Their fish is fresh and always cooked perfectly in the sandwiches.  
The sweet potato fries are a must!!!  They are so thin, sweet and delicious!  

A plus:  I love the complimentary edamame and pretzel fishes.  YES! FREE FOOD!

I'll be back!
author: LiveToEat F.

description: I am addicted to this place!  Amazing food, I've enjoyed everything I've had (though I'm partial to the wasabi bowl).  The staff are SO nice and they are extremely kid friendly.  Perfect end to a morning in GG Park.
author: sf f.

description:
If you ever have a chance to purchase the oatmeal stout at this restaurant I would highly recommend it. The oatmeal stout is a very sophisticated beverage that really defines what's possible if you get creative with your brewing processes. 

The location of this place (on the lively corner of Lincoln and 9th Ave) makes Pacific Catch an excellent venue for happy hour meet ups or one on one dates.

I personally prefer the outside patio sitting but those are usually fairly busy during peak hours.

Also I would recommend the sweet potato fries and shimp ceviche.

I think this place will continue to be an important part of the inner sunset scene for years to come because it reeks of good vibes.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
One of my favorite stops for casual dining, both the quality of cuisine and service has been consistently pleasing over the years. My out of town guests love dining here. It's next to Golden Gate Park & convenient for events or visiting museums.

There are also a few tables outside where dining with your well behaved dog at your side is possible, water bowls provided. -- It was a bit hit with my chihuahua.

The fried calamari has a twist & is worth trying. I often get BBQ fish tacos & they are just fab. Even if you are not starved, this is a great place to stop & have a beer or cocktail on a leisurely day or after work.
author: Juliette C.

description:
You know, I have to say that I'm a little shocked at the low score of this place.  I'm not going to go off the hook and give them 5 stars and a kiss on the cheek, but I thoroughly enjoy myself here.

Usually my girlfriend and I go in and sit in the bar area and have a wasabi or teriyaki bowl and a drink.  The "Dark and Stormy" drink is really great, the food's not too expensive and the help's good.  Plain and simple.  I don't spend a lot, the place is clean, the food's good, the drinks are good.

Sitting in the main area isn't bad either, I recommend the smoked artichoke appetizer.  Great flavor.
author: Craig F.

description:
Well, to be honest, I'm not even sure that I should be writing this review, because I'm very content with my little 'find' of a Happy Hour and exposing it here just might jinx it.  But, what good is something great if you can't share it?

I was pretty skeptical of the whole restaurant when it 1st moved in.  I really loved The Canvas (the previous business in this location), and the new restaurant looked big, scary, and corporate.

Turns out that they have a really great Happy Hour!

Well drinks (well made!) and pints (good beers, like Longboard!) for $3-$4.  Several of the appetizers are also discounted between $5-$8 and they're really nice quality and a handsome portion.  

We've been sticking to the Hawaiian Poke because it's a great bang for your buck, but we've also tried 2 different sushi rolls which were great and well worth the cost.  And if you time it right, you can catch an outside seat with the sun going down and a gentle breeze through the bamboo.
author: Heather W.

description:
This truly is a "catch." Checked this place out Sat. night. Went to the 9th Street location due to the fact that it seemed larger than the Chesnut location. 9th Street has parking in the rear. I do have to say the ambiance was real nice. Very unexpected. I chose this place due to the yelper reviews. Checked out the menu - It's kid friendly which is a total plus. Food was excellent. They had a variety (fish tacos, ahi poke, fish & chips etc...Hawaiian Fusion).  My sister thought this place would cost us an arm and a leg due to the ambiance but it just cost us part of an arm which wasn't bad for seafood. Hey... I'm all about cheap in this state of the economy. I will definitely return. 
Overall: Nice, clean, food is good, kid friend, those single -great bar...what more can you ask for. Loved it.
author: Yvette R.

description:
First and foremost, I am not a big seafood fan. After years of my boyfriend trying to get me to go, I finally decided to give them a shot. I started off small, I got their 3 tacos; two chicken and one mahi mahi. All I have to say is that the mahi mahi is far better than the chicken! But what made me an immediate fan was their fried dulce de leche spring rolls. I drool at the thought of them, they are that delicious. The springrolls are crunchy on the outside, warm and gooey on the inside and here's the kicker, a really yummy scoop of ice cream with a caramel drizzle.
