This thing is a heart attack on a plate, but a heart attack that I'm willing to suffer. 

My second visit I decided that since I had a great experience with their seafood the first time, that I would try experimenting something new. I ordered the seared ahi macadamia, the best ahi I've ever had. For those of you who don't like ahi because of it's aftertaste or "fishy" taste, this dish does not have anything like that. The ahi has a yummy mango thai citrus salad that really compliments the ahi and is delicious!

The bar scene can be really fun, it's nice to stop by, have an appetizer and beer and watch the local games. 

As far of prices, for a party of 2 with 2-3 drinks total, one appetizer, 2 entrees, dessert and coffee with run you close to $80, so for a full course meal it's not that pricey!
author: Hedieh G.

description:
I wanted to try this place to see if it was worth closing the Canvas Gallery for and I'm so sad and disappointed because now, I miss the Canvas Gallery even more!

Wasn't too impressed with the food. I love sweet potato fries, but the ones here were dry and oily. Pricing for the food isn't worth what you get. Service was decent as well as decor.

Giving this place 2 stars since I'm biased...I LOVED the Canvas Gallery and am disappointed with what replaced it.
author: Janel Y.

description:
What I like that this place does is give you a stamp card. For every 8 lunches you have you get a free lunch. I don't know of any other seafood place that does this in SF. I am a sucker for the Ahi stuff. I enjoy the sandwich there. I like this location more than sunset since there's lots and lots of parking everywhere. Plus after going here you can always go a block away and go to Arizmendi. 
The fried Oyster and other Fried dishes I tasted there I didn't really care for much. Some alcohol would help make it taste better.
I also didn't really like their alcoholic drinks much.
author: Nir B.

description:
Wow.. after reading all the glowing reviews for Pacific Catch on 9th, we dashed on over there to see what all the hubbub was about..

Sorry to say, we were a bit disappointed.  

Nutshell Review: Anything we experienced that was good tonight (food, service, etc), also had an unexpected mild downside to it.

The Good stuff: The sweet potato fries were pretty good, and yeah.. for dessert, we split the mango cheesecake - now.. this WAS good.  I'd order this again.  OK.. all good on the dessert.

The three tacos I ordered up as the main dish were decent.  I ordered one each of (1) a Grilled Mahi-Mahi taco,  (2) a traditional Baja-style fried fish taco, and (3) one shrimp taco.  As for Taco #2, I think I've had better at Rubios.. Um. wait.. I have..  The others were okay. The best was probably the shrimp taco.  

Grilled Corn - this little side dish was complemented beautifully with a flavorful chili-lime butter - AWESOME butter. but hey.. they didn't grill the corn the whole way - either that, or it was just sitting around too long after leaving the grill.  Parts of the kernels were clearly COLD upon biting em.. 

The Mahi-Mahi Teriyaki Bowl my significant other had was overseasoned and covered in a heavy sweet sauce that completely drowned out any other flavors or texture that once were part of the pineapple fried rice which became almost mush.   The Mahi itself was perfectly prepared.  What a bummer.  Maybe the better way to go here is to go instead with the brown rice they also offer as an option.

Service: So-so.  Our greeter and waitress were very friendly and greeted us with HUGE smiles and a wonderful attitude, but once we ordered up our food, our server was very hard to find, even though we were seated near the front of the restaurant where all of the OTHER servers congregated.  It seemed as if I was invisible there tonight, as I was pretty thirsty, but well,  we only got refills twice over the hour we were there.    Our waitress did a great job and was probably swamped. It's just that the other help that we tried to flag down seemed as if we didn't exist.

 I'll probably give them another try, but there's plenty of competition from other cuisines all over this neighborhood.  

I was expecting much better, and to place this restaurant into our normal "rotation" of places to eat. Oh well.  Blame it on my expectations being sky-high..
author: Harry W.

description:
With the original Chestnut Street location only a couple blocks from my apartment I can't say I'll be frequenting this location very often, but after running some errands on Irving Street I was hungry.  I looked around at the taquerias and other eateries, and then remembered I was close to Pacific Catch!  Having been craving a wasabi bowl for a few days, I braved the cold wind and walked the few blocks to P.C.  

First of all, the place is HUGE!  There is actually a bar area (where I sat) as well as a restaurant area, and even some covered outdoor seating too!  Why can't the Marina location be like this?  When I walked in about 1:30 the place was not very crowded, but by the time I left it was packed.

Being by myself, I chose to sit in the bar, where I alternated between reading a book and watching the soccer game.  In true comparative fashion, I ordered my usual: Ahi Poke Wasabi Bowl with Brown Rice.  I was pleased to discover that it tasted just like what I am used to in the Marina.  Staff was pleasant and accommodating, and if I lived in the area I'd make use of their bar, their drink menu looked yummy and they're fully stocked.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Outrageous fish tacos and chicken chopotle salad.  Colorful friendly atmosphere and service.  We spent the whole week in San Francisco and came here the first night.  We loved it so much every night after, when trying to decide where to eat, we'd say, "We could go back to Pacific Catch!" It's really a great place.
author: Newyorkwalk D.

description:
Ok, I came her again last night.  Despite what my earlier review said.  Some friends from out of town were visiting and wanted seafood.  Since I live in Inner Sunset, Pacific Catch is really the only option.  So, what the hell, give it another try.

OMG, SUCH a better experience.

We had a very friendly waiter who was very helpful with suggestions and attentive but not obtrusive.  The food the second time around was MUCH better as well.  The seafood was fresh, cooked just right and served very quickly.  I had the Salmon Teriyaki bowl and it was huge, nice to bring home leftovers for lunch!  My friend had the thai salmon and really enjoyed her dish as well.  Her two kids had the salmon sandwhich and mahi mahi and both were very happy with their dishes as well.  We hadn't seen each other in years and we were left to sit and talk and catch up after dinner, not rushed out at all (it was a slow night, plenty of open tables).  I'm glad I gave this place another shot.  After my last review I doubt I would, and the manager messaged me to help try and rectify the situation, which I appreciated (although I couldn't help her with any more info to pinpoint my lousy server).  She was eager to not have it happen again, so hopefully everyone got a reminder on how to be a great server.  All I know is that I certainly enjoyed ours last night, so thanks!
author: Jen K.

description:
I like this place. Finally checked it out with an outing with my friends a couple of weeks ago. My gf kept raving about this place. Chill dude. . . .its only seafood. We live in SF, great seafood 24/7. I'll go catch and dice a fresh fish for you if you like.

Ordered my food with beer, forgot what I had, just the usual over-priced seafood I see in alot of restaurants. I'm very picky, why pay $20 for seafood when you can do it yourself? 

Pacific Catch, love the decor, and the setting. Nice location. Just park in GGP, but remember to leave after 10pm, they will tow you.
author: David L.

description:
We came here with our 2 kids, ages 4 1/2 and 3. GREAT place for families, I'm happy to say. The kids each got a little chalkboard with colored chalk, which kept them busy til the food came. (management should consider providing erasers though...when we asked for some, we were told to use napkins)

The restaurant has been remodeled with high ceilings, funky casual decor, overall a warm and welcoming feel.

The food is basically seafood with Asian and Latino accents. Inventive menu items, and stuff that even my picky preschoolers will eat. The chicken tenders off the kids' menu was so good that I ate most of my daughter's. I had the shrimp/mango tacos, which were light and flavorful. 

Service was friendly, efficient. Parking lot in back of the restaurant but room for only around 6 cars. Maybe you'll be one of the lucky ones. We'll definitely come back.
author: SfMom O.

description: We were seated promptly on a Saturday at  6pm. The interior is lovely, the food well-prepared and moderately ($$) priced, and the staff was attentive. There is a small on-site parking lot, but another option is to park across the street in GG Park.
author: Josie E.

description:
I had the worst experience last night at Pacific Catch that I have ever had at a restaurant in this neighborhood.   By way of background, Pacific Catch used to be somewhere that we enjoyed going from time to time -- twice a month or so. Suffice it to say that none of my friends will ever be back.  I don't really want to go into detail about the experience, because it was really weird, and I'm still kind of angry about it, but the hostesses -- especially a girl named Anastasia -- were bizarrely rude.  We waited at the bar for 15 minutes past the time of our reservation, and when we went up to inquire whether we would be seated within the next 15 minutes or so, this girl Anastasia literally stormed off like a five-year-old. I then had to reassure the other hostess that we really weren't mad at them, we just really needed to know, so that we could make plans.   I don't really know what possibly could have triggered the kind of genuinely odd behavior we encountered, but it was enough to make me feel like something really bad is going on there.  It was like dealing with a bunch of angry teenagers.  And then they kept asking us to move at the bar, after we bought drinks.  It was a huge mistake to go here -- I don't need to pay that kind of money to reassure people who are doing a terrible job that I'm not mad that they are.  

Churlish people, mediocre food. Avoid.  Go to Bistro 9. Good food, and much, much better people.
author: Danielle G.

description:
The decor of this place is far above the Chestnut Street location or the Corte Madera one too. The main dining area seems to have like 3 areas. The center of the floor is split between tables and booths. I generally don't like booths, or is the designer term banquette? Whatever it is I don't care much for them as you have to scoot in and out of it and that's not a feat that can be accomplished by many with much grace. There is an area that is off to the side, on 9th Avenue that is just tables, I believe. There is also a bar area that looks nice and you can be seated there too. And there is also seating right in front of the open kitchen but I would advise against that unless you're that desparate because it's also where the pick up area is. So the wait staff is constantly marching back and forth or just waiting right there.

Have been in for lunch and for dinner. The lunch service was good, it wasn't too crowded or anything. Had a fantastic ahi sandwich that came with sweet potato fries.

The dinner service was not great. Place was packed. Very glad I had a reservation. I'll give them a little leeway because any place that has been open for under a couple months (heck even 6 months) is going to need to work out it's pacing/service issues. We ordered dessert and it took them 20 minutes to bring out mochi ice cream that was pretty much coming out of a freezer. And that was after the waiter asked if we had gotten it yet. I'll still go here but more so for lunch than dinner.

**4.29.08 came back for dinner and the service is much, much better. Had the escolar (fish) and that was yummy. What was also on the plate was pineapple fried rice and grilled baby bok choy. Eh. The baby bok choy needed seasoning stat. Salt, pepper, something. I can see how the pineapple fried rice can appeal to some people. I am not one of those people. Maybe if the pineapple chunks were not so huge. The grilled calamari that we had as a starter was excellent. Stuffed with sausage and it wasn't too chewy, just the right texture.
author: cyndi L.

description:
Arrived here expecting just sushi. Their menu only consisted of about 5-7(?) plain-nothing-out-of-the-original sushi rolls. Then me and my friend realized Pacific Catch was a Japanese-Mexican fusion restaurant, but we decided to give it a try anyways since we were drooling over the food on the table next to us. 

We started off with the Spicy Cabo Calamari, which was really soft in texture, definitely not crispy because the breaded exterior would fall off whenever we tried to pick at one; not spicy at all, it lacked much taste until i doused the heck out of it with the dipping sauce. Then we also figured out they also added a few other concocsions that should have just been left outta the fryer.....like the fried lemon I accidently ate.....twice. 

My friend ordered the Mixed Catch Basket. There wasn't anything special about this, except the fact that her side of Sweet Potato Fries were YUMMY!!

I ordered the Ahi Tuna Wasabi Bowl, topped with (of course) ahi tuna, wakame salad, avocado, ginger and cucumber. The sushi rice was flavored with a wasabi sauce, which was somewhat mild, but SO GOOD!! It's basically like sushi, but bigger and broken down into all its components. 

We also ordered two drinks, a Mai Tai & forgot the name of the other one, but both were pretty strong!! I like! I like!

Gotta come back to try their Mojito & Mochi Fondue!!

4 stars for their strong drinks, my Ahi Tuna Wasabi bowl and my friend's sweet potato fries!


[UPDATED: 4.26.2008]

Came here again with another friend around 8ish. Considering it was a Friday, there was a 30 min. wait for the tables inside, so we decided to dine outside, which turned out really nice...although it was butt-freezing cold at first. Thank god they had the protective sheet to block off most of the wind. 

Tried the Ahi Poke Wasabi bowl this time and it was delicious! Although I did like my Ahi Tuna from my last dining here, I would recommend the Ahi Poke over that. My Lemon Grass Mojito was refreshing as well. My friend's Gin & Tonic was pretty stiff.

Service was still attentive, friendly, consistent and quick. The bar was open till 1AM that day, but too bad we couldn't stay for another round of  drinks considering my friend had the Asian glow by the time he finished his Gin & Tonic. -sigh-
author: Serena W.

description:
I had high hopes for this place. I heard so many great things about their original restaurant down at Marina so always wanted to try this place.

I was surprised it felt very corporate, I had been by the Marina location and it looked more homey. But my biggest complaint was about the food of course. I think a salt monkey made our food. We got the White Tuna Tataki | seared white tuna served with crab & daikon salad $9.95. It was REALLY bad. Both the tuna & the crab were incredibly salty. I also ordered a lemongrass mojito, it was not an easy drink so I switched to my friend's papaya cooler. Not great but okay. Service was okay. The mochi fondue was a little bit different than we envisioned. We thought there will actually be a "fondue" instead of just a container of hot fudge that we dip the mochi in. I guess it's a more economical version of fondue... The hot fudge was warm by the time it got to our table, it was a little bit hard to dip.

I am surprised to see so many great reviews on yelp, we must've gotten the b team that day. We all wished we had went to park chow or hotei instead. Much cheaper and much more fulfilling. 

Damn you iPhone commercial, you lied to me!!!
author: Cindy L.

description:
We had an amazing early dinner on the small outdoor patio with Sadie.  As we basked in the warm summer breeze, I gobbled up the shrimp ceviche.  It was perfectly tangy tart with a satisfyingly large quantity of plump, sweet shrimp with lime juice, cilantro, onions, and avocado.  I tossed the tortilla chips aside and just started forking it up.  The ahi tuna sandwich was lightly seared with spring greens, tomato, wasabi mayonaise, fresh ginger and avocado on chewy ciabatta bread.  It was like a sushi sandwich aka the best sandwich I have had in a long time.  

One star down for the sides.  The sweet potato fries were just ok (didn't get any dip) and the cole slaw was bland - both could use some heavier seasoning.  Skip the lemongrass tea.  It was like slightly flavored water for $2.25.  

Service was average.

This is a great stop before or after visiting GG Park.  I'll be back.
author: Esther R.

description: This is where I love to come for my Bday :) Have been coming for the past 3 years. Amazing Poke, great sashimi, and their drink's aren't to bad either! A great place to come with friends, family, and loved ones.
author: Stephanie H.

description: Nice and fresh! The service was great and the food wasn't overly priced, and the portions are pretty large,  I'll definitely come back.
author: Allie D.

description:
This is kind of tricky place to write a review for because there are some very cool things about it, but also some pretty mediocre aspects. The first time I came for happy and sat at the bar watching the giants in a spacious room with a good selection of beer and great appetizers. (I like the ahi poke). The food is very reasonably priced in my opinion, the sushi rolls are good and the wine corkage is only ten dollars if thats your cup of tea. 

The downs. The service was not very good. Several times we felt like our waiter was going out of his way to avoid eye contact with our table. Perhaps this would have been more understandable if he was slammed, but we were visiting at 9:30 and the place was empty. Also, while the fish is very good, and some of the appetizers on the menu are very tasty, there isn't any food that will blow your mind and make you a regular. Thus, the three stars. (3.5-4 for happy hour)
author: Clayton V.

description: Good food.  Love the booths, esp to bookend the toddlers so they don't run wild.  The wait staff is excellent.  One waiter in particular is just fantastic.  We've got him a couple times and I will get his name next time.  They are understanding of young families and really do backflips to make it great.
author: John S.

description:
Went here for a friends birthday. The venue is excellent if you have a big group and they take reservations. I really like the inside of the restaurant because the kitchen was in plain sight, and I was able watch them cook, which gives me some sort of entertainment.

So it should be noted that I am really not a big fan of seafood. It is actually something I have very recently got into so I am still a little shy when it comes to trying fish that isn't in sushi (don't question, I'm just weird). So when I looked at the menu online I figured I would take small step forward in my food trying experience and go for the fish and chips. When I got to the restaurant and placed my order, I stayed along that line, except I got the oyster basket with sweet potato fries. The waiter also mentioned that it was light in terms of fried food. For me, it was delicious, but really heavy like all other fried food (don't ask me why I was expecting fried food to be light). The sweet potato fries were awesome. I threw some hot sauce on the oysters as well to give it a kick.

The group also had various appetizers ordered in the beginning that included edamame, poke, and the basket of fries. All tasty.

The executive chef came out and visited with us for a moment to check on our experience, as well as how we liked the food. I was really impressed with that.

The service was decent, however in the earlier part of our dining experience, the waiter gave the wrong drink to someone at our table. When we told him this, he corrected it, but also freaked out a bit and started playing "musical drinks," and attempted to take my drink, which was correct. It was a bit funny but annoying because usually you just take the drink back and correct it.
author: Diana R.

description:
1. They should call it TGIFishys or Fishybees or Fishlies or something like that.   I was hoping for something.. yummier.
2. I  like that it's all sustainable and everything but I still won't eat tilapia.  
3. The lemon drop was good.
4. But even the lemon drop wasn't any consolation for not having the Canvas around anymore.
author: jette s.

description:
3.5 stars really.

Great happy hour options (one in the evening and one from 10pm to closing), very nice and accomodating staff and the food is good too.

This is where I was first introduced to sweet potato fries! The menu said that one could choose between traditional or spicy fries.... so I asked the waiter if we could have spicy sweet potato fries. The waiter thought I was strange but he did it anyway! And they were delish!

Also have tried the coconut shrimp (nice and crispy) and the firecracker salmon roll (it was only ok). Fish tacos are pretty tasty, too(several options of fish). 

The lemongrass mojitio is a delightfully interesting combination. 

All in all, a good place to have a small bite to eat. It gets busy during dinner time.
author: Christine C.

description:
Pros: ALWAYS reliably tasty food (especially the bowls, appetizers, and fish specials), reasonably priced, lively atmosphere, some great servers

Cons: Sometimes slow service, especially when eating in the bar
author: Jacob M.

description: I've tried some specials here and have been very satisfied, but nothing beats those bowls!  The best combination of ingredients thrown into a bowl, seasoned/sauced perfectly with quality fish (or tofu) and it's simple and healthy.  And they're great the next day, because I can never eat a whole one.  Never tried a dish here and said "meh".
author: Ian S.

description:
came here for a post valentines day dinner. place was packed and supposedly had reservations booked until 10pm. THIS PLACE MUST BE REALLY GOOD THEN. Well....it was OK. Looking it seems to fused japanese and american dishes, and judging by the name of the restaurant,  it is a seafood place.

 i ordered the catch of the day fish and chips because it included sweet potato fries and i knew my friend was finding for those. after receiving my plate, the price of it seemed to outweigh the overall quantity of it, even though the fish of the night was talapia from costa rica...(the best kind of talapia there is). the sweet potato fries but "not the greatest fries ever". my friend got some wasabi bowl and she dint seem to really have a taste for it much as she seemd to only pick out the fish leaving a a bowl full of rice that can feed a hungry family in vietnam with ..haha jk

food was average at best. there are so many restaurant in the surrounding area, as i observed as we took a stroll around the block to kill time before out table was ready. But who really goes out on a vday dinner or in, this case post vday, primarily for the food....its really  about who your having the meal with.
author: Rex P.

description:
Good tasting, reasonably priced seafood is hard to find.  Variety in terms of the different ways it is prepared is often pretty limited in most places.

What I love about Pacific Catch is that when I am feeling taco-y, the salmon tacos are the bomb. When I am hunkering for a fish sandwich, the spicy ahi is just killer.  Feeling like a rice bowl, the ahi wasabi rice bowl is sushi-grade goodness.  Heck, my wife and kids even eat there enthusiastically.

We have been long time customers at Chestnut location and were thrilled when 9th avenue opened.  Why?  Bigger menu (try the crab salad with yellowtail appetizer, yum to the vietnamese beef sandwich, crispy calamari, grrr!), nice, warm space and drink-worthy bar (tasty strong drinks).

Highly recommended.  Family friendly too.
author: Mark S.

description:
Tasty, Fresh and Affordable. 

We have been here several times for brunch/lunch. Good food for sure. Nice salads, fish, tacos, fried dishes, deserts, full bar. Coconut Shrimp and sweet potato fries are cant miss items. Nice touches like lemon grass in my mojito. ;-)

Good place for dates, large groups (long tables allow for parties of 12 or more), quick bites, casual and friendly. And I did mention it has a full bar? Because you know it's those "little" things that can make a place worth returning to.

Parking is horrendous in this area. I either walk or pay for parking. But we are all used to that.  It's tight with strollers, but kid friendly. 

Right across from the park, a wonderful location, with a lot of competition on the block, I expect this place to do well. We shall return.

updated to 4 stars: we went back and it was still really delicious and tasty and for tolerating children so well, the best sweet potato fries, and the lemongrass mojito, I grant thee one more star.
author: Matthew C.

description:
One word: disappointing. 

Also poor service, wannabe Asian food, great decor.

I love the decor and the way the place is designed, but the food is lacking. The atmosphere wasn't too bad. There were people of all ages there and even a few crying babies.

We started with the crispy oysters and they were great. I'm not a fan of them but I enjoyed. You also can't go wrong with deep frying stuff.

After the oysters we had the shrimp teriyaki bowl and the 3 pieces of the fresh catch of the day with the sweet potato fries.

The teriyaki bowl was horrible. Who drenches sauce all over the rice? It was so SWEET!  The Pineapple fried rice was not even fried like it said on the menu. The sweet sauce ruined it. The veggies were okay though. The bok choy and mushrooms were nice. This was basically wet rice with sauce and a bunch of veggies and grilled shrimp. I could have made a better bowl at home.

The fish and chips were fine because you cannot seriously mess up on fried foods.  The pieces of fish were decent sized, but for around $15 I expected more. The sweet potato fries were the highlight.

Oh wait, let me talk about service. It was non-existant. Johanna our server was nowhere to be seen. We had to tell the hostess that we were ready to order. After ordering our food, she did not acknowledge us at all until we asked for the check. She didn't even bring out the food. What was she doing???? No refills on water, no how are you guys doing, and no eye contact. Worst server ever.

This place is a nice date place, but you can get better food elsewhere. It seems to me that something is wrong with the fusion. The food tasted like it was made by someone who thinks they know Asian food but really doesnt. I guess thats where the "fusion" comes in. I won't get over how they drench teriyaki sauce all over rice. Eww.
author: SF N.

description: Have been to the new Campbell location a couple times now and LOVE this place. I have had the Wasabi Ahi sandwich and the Salmon Sandwich, both were amazing! I have tried all three fries and the original are my fav but my husband likes the sweet potato. The wait staff has been very helpful and there when you need them, but not overbearing. They even had a chalk board and chalk for my son to play with while we waited. It is a little messy but a great way to pass the time until his food arrives. A new favorite place!
author: Maureen R.

description: Food was delicious, My Server was sub par (absent, unattentive, slow, and forgetful) however her support staff was great. The manager escorted us to the table, and discussed the menu at length and made a few helpful suggestions. I had the rice bowl with grilled Ono, which reminds me of the texture of swordfish. We started with Raw Tuna Poke, which was top notch. Thank goodness the food was good to great, becasue on another night i may have been turned off by our server leaving us parched on several occassions.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Another place to eat their delicious sweet potato fries!  Yikes!  Am I gonna od on them. . I think not!  I have always enjoyed Pacific Catch on Chestnut street, but was anxious to see the new location.  
Gorgeous - wall treatment an amazing terra cotta color, artwork awesome ,use of space was excellent with a full bar on one side and eating area that is children friendly on the other. Open kitchen with counter service. Saw generous bowls of salads and chicken teriyaki over rice passing by.  Poke wasabi salad here I come......recently ordered the fried oysters with sweet potato fries and they were just the right crunchness. everything is fresh and perfectly prepared - what more could you ask for.
author: Kea C.

description:
I had lunch here not too long ago - I had one of the teriyaki bowls and my friend had the hawaiian poke wasabi bowl. The teriyaki bowl had a little too much teriyaki sauce mixed into the bowl. However, the steak that I got with it was very good - the rest of the bowl was just too much; too much sweet-taste. The poke wasabi bowl was very tasty. The fish was done just right. But, it was just too much of the same thing with the same flavor. It was slightly on the salty side (wasabi + soy sauce was mixed into the rice). The fried yam fries were cooked well and reminded me of my southern roots. 

Overall, not bad, (~mid $30ish for 2 people) with reasonable portions. However, the food is flavorful and good for the first 1/3 of the meal and then it's simply too much of the (very) sweet or salty flavor. If you're craving fried yam fries, definitely come here but if you're craving some type of japanese rice bowl, go to an authentic japanese place - you'll be more satisfied and happier with yourself!
author: Brian L.

description:
We also stopped in before our member preview at the Academy of Sciences. Was quiet in the bar with half the tables empty and most diners served. We sat at a two top and waited for a greeting and perhaps a menu. So we waited...
and waited..
several bar staffers passed by as we tried to get their attention.

and we waited..

waited some more...
20 minutes and we were outta there.

I'm not the kind to shout out for a menu.
Maybe the food is OK...prolly not. We'll never know.

We wandered up to Bistro 9 which was GREAT! 
Friendly, attentive staff. The seafood pasta was fabulous.
I'll leave the details at Bistro 9 Yelp.
author: Karlton L.

description: PLEASE, pacific catch really doesn't deserve 3.5 stars. The food is devastatingly mediocre and overpriced for what you get. Can you really expect sushi rolls to taste good when they are offered next to tacos? First time I ate here, I realized that this was clearly not the place to go for seafood. On top of that, the service and staff is horrid with attitude. One time, I was forced to endure this place again for a birthday and even though our group brought our own cake, they charged us to cut it...$3 per slice for 15 people. This place is way too mediocre to be setting that fee...
author: Justine C.

description:
I had both their shrimp ceviche and tuna tartare at the PLEY holiday party and was VERY impressed... probably my favorite bites of the whole night! 
MUCH better than what I've ordered in the past and pretty damn delicious. Can't wait to go to PC now that I know what to order. I am still thinking about them a day later! Yum, yum
author: Amanda C.

description:
I used to come here whenever I had disposable 20 and wanted to treat myself to some qual-it- A food. I've had fun happy hour times with some friends and even quick one drink hang outs. I had not eaten here in over a year and was excited when the opportunity came to indulge in a yummy lunch. After Bay to Breakers, my friends went to Gordos (YUM) and I chose to order take out from Pacific Catch. I requested the seared ahi rice bowl.  Excited to chow down, I ran to Gordos and proceeded to stuff my face. However, one thing felt wrong. The fish did not taste the same. Again, here is another place that overloads on the sodium to masque the taste of their food. Not only was the fish too salty, but there was something fishy about the fish. After a while, I decided to cease my "chow down" and wrapped the food back into the bag. There is a huge problem if I order food and do not devour the entire thing. This means I either am not hungry or the food does not taste good. Thinking that I must not have been hungry, I decided to eat the bowl later that day. From the moment I went to my bfs house to later that afternoon, my stomach was hurting. I assumed it was due to the hangover from B2B, but it did not make sense. I went to go finish the bowl and figured out my stomach was hurting from the food. Pretty sad. The bowls used to be enjoyable.

What I have eaten here: 
Baja Shrimp Ceviche
Sweet Potato Fries (Get them!)
Cabo Calamari
Seared Ahi Bowl
Hawaiian Poke Bowl

I'll keep the rating 3/5 because this could have been the one bad experience. I was always a fan of Pacific Catch, but I may need to take a permanent break from them. SORRY!
author: Jessica B.

description: Just finished an excellent meal here! Used a complimentary calamari coupon for checking in with foursquare to start as an appetizer. I ordered the three tacos, one shrimp, one steak, and one mahi mahi. I would say the fish taco was the best and the Tangerine wheat bear was great! Love the unlimited edamame! Definitely recommend to all if your hungry! Just a little full right now!
author: Eric H.

description:
My friend kept recommending this place to me, so I finally went and tried their Hawaiian Poke Wasabi bowl with brown rice. It was great.  It reminded me of the Korean dish bibimbap but this in a Japanese/ Hawaiian fusion version. You have a choice of white rice, sushi rice or brown rice.  And you can also have it with half salad half rice instead of full rice.  It is a big bowl for its price and can definitely be split into at least 2 servings.   The tuna was well seasoned and the rice had a great wasabi soysauce all over it.  We also order a small side order of sweet potato fries.  It's sweet potato fries. It's great. haha

My friend said this location has a larger sitting area than the marina/cow hollow location and is easier to find parking.  There is a small parking lot available, but mainly street parking.
author: Crystal L.

description: Great cocktails here and a wonderful spot to grab a post-museum and park bite.
author: Claire M.

description: Had the Hawaiian Poke Wasabe Bowl and it was gooooooood.  The wasabi sauce had bite but it wasn't overpowering.  The portion size was pretty big.  You'll definitely get your money's worth on this one.
author: Arnold M.

description:
I am kind of obsessed with this place. The food is delicious, very fresh and interesting seafood dishes. My favorite part though, is it's close proximity to CA Academy of Sciences. For some reason, every time I go to CA Academy of Sciences, I have a mad craving to eat seafood. That may seem a little perverse, but at least I don't crave animals after the zoo.  Anyways, I am writing this review after my last visit there on a Thursday night (after my mouth watered from staring at the fish in CA Academy)....I went around 9 pm and Pacific Catch was pretty packed. Luckily, without reservations, the super sweet and amazing Anastasia was so helpful. She walked me and my date directly to a table. I'm not sure why Anastasia got a  bad review before, she was so nice and prompt to accommodate my hunger pangs. 
Must orders for Pacific Catch: One of their refreshing cocktails, Sweet potato fries, and Hawaiian Poke. Yummmmm!
author: Nat S.

description:
I'd really give this place 3 1/2 stars...4 stars for food, 3 stars for the service. I actually really like this restaurant. The place is pretty casual, but fun. A good spot to get together with a small group of friends for a reasonably priced dinner. The food was delicious, but the service was mediocre. I think our server was new to the job so I felt bad for him. . We ordered the hawaiian poke to start off but didn't end up actually getting it till a little bit after our server came out with our entrees. But better late than never because it was ooh so good. Very fresh and flavorful. After contemplating about the many enticing choices on the menu, I opted for the island tacos for my main entree. One grilled mahi mahi and one cabo shrimp with a side of sweet potato fries. Definite thumbs up! 

I do need to mention a strange but funny incident we had while dining here. As we were all finishing up our food, one of my friends was drinking waster out of his glass...when all of a sudden I see a big splash. At first I thought he dropped his glass of water but it turned out that the bottom of his glass broke and all the ice and water spilled out! And let me just tell you...it broke just on the bottom of the glass in almost a perfect, complete circle! How weird is that!?! Luckily he already finished his meal. We, of course, complained to our server and he was able to get his meal for free. He mentioned that it probably happened because the glass was hot when they poured in cold water.

Now for dessert...always my favorite part! The four of us shared 2 different plates....the mochi fondue and the fried dulce de leche spring rolls. Both were scrumptious! I never thought of dipping mochi ice cream balls in hot chocolate sauce but it is dee-lish!

YES, I'd come back to this place and YES, I recommend it!
author: BrElla4eva H.

description:
I heart the sweet potato fries from this place! Seriously, I will come here just for that, but more my usual addition is the Hawaiian Poke which is really tasty. The Poke is really something I recommend as the appetizer version b/c then it comes with yummy fried won tons to eat it on. 

The drinks are usually solid standards with a slight twist that have never done me wrong and dessert is always fun if I have room after consuming mass quantities of sweet potato fries!
author: Stephanie W.

description: The fish tacos here were really good, you can choose from different flavors and fishes and create a combo plate.  The poke here is also really good and really fresh and flavorful.  They also have a great happy hour menu.
author: Gordon C.

description:
oh.my.god. I am considering flying back to San Fran JUST for the Ahi Tuna Wasabi bowl. 

Sushi was fresh and amazing and exactly what I was hoping for.

LOVED the sweet potato fries as well. 

Wish I had had room for dessert!
author: Shoshana g.

description:
One would think that going to the bigger Pacific Catch, one would be seated in timely manner but this is not the case. People definitely tend to linger around this one a lot longer than at the Chestnut St. location. Again, sweet potato fries can do no wrong but the service here can definitely do with some speeding up. 

Pretty good sushi rolls and ceviche. Not a big fan of the tacos because they all seem to taste the same, i.e. drenched in the same avocado sauce. I still love the salmon sandwich.
author: Maggie L.

description: This is a great place, I had a tilapia with tomatillo/avocado sauce that was really really tasty. excellent sweet potato fries and grilled zucchini to go with it. appetizer was the baja shrimp ceviche with chips that was really good too. The service was very fast, and the manager even comped our desert (egg nog ice cream-it was ok.) Overall a great atmosphere, tasty food, great service. I'd definitely recommend Pacific Catch
author: Kyle D.

description: I came here with a few friends for no special occasion. We were seated pretty quickly. The tables were a little sticky so I didn't want to put my bare forearms on it. I ordered the crab salad wasabi bowl. The avocado, crab, and wakame salad was not that tasty; the majority of the taste came from the wasabi sauce. Also, the texture of the rice was supposedly "sushi rice" but it turned out to be a little more watery than I had expected; the sushi roll we ordered was good though. The meal all together was decent but I think the price is a bit steep. I usually like asian fusion but I didn't find this place particularly outstanding.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Better than I thought. =P I must admit that I walked in w/ mediocre expectations -- just another Japanese fusion place. And in reality, it pretty much is that, but its also surprisingly tasty! I had a wasabi bowl, which, oddly enough, doesn't include wasabi. (go figure). It was described to me as all the ingredients that go into a sushi roll...but in a bowl. So you have your unagi or ahi tuna w/ the sushi rice, strips of nori, cucumber, etc...I got it w/ the sushi rice and it was very yum. 

If you like sweet drinks, the kumquat mojito is uuuber yums, even if you're not a fan of mojitos. Its just sweet, but you will have to deal w/ all the mint leave and over-excessive foliage in your drink. =P I'd def go again as a standard in the inner sunset.
author: Grace G.

description:
My boyfriend and I went to Pacific Catch last night to celebrate his birthday.  He's been interested in going for a while, so last night (although Father's Day) was the perfect opportunity.  The place was PACKED.  We didn't make a reservation (although it is possible, and perhaps recommended on, say, Father's Day), and were offered a table by the door, a seat at the counter, or a seat at the bar.  We took the table by the door--perhaps a tactical error, because they're high tables BUT there's no room for your legs underneath, so you have to sit fairly far from the table.  Kinda sucky, but the food was great.

He had one of the specials, the ohah (ohai?), nicely grilled and served with grilled baby bok choi, pineapple fried rice and Maui onion rings.  I had the unagi wasabi bowl (but there was no wasabi in it?), a big ol' bowl filled with sushi rice and topped with unagi and a bunch of sushi-type ingredients, like a deconstructed roll.

Overall, the food was REALLY good, and we were both completely stuffed.  

I am minus one star because it's incredibly, incredibly loud.
author: diana s.

description:
This is truly the best restaurant for kids! The kids menu is great, the soy bean/fish pretzel tray when you arrive is great, great , great. The Adult food is great, did I say great!

Tell your friends!
author: Scott D.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to eat in my hood. You can pretty much please anywhere here since there's a wide array of healthy and not so healthy, a bar, a restaurant area, fishy stuff and not so fishy, ethnic, American, etc... plus, there's even parking (a small lot behind and easier street parking close by in the park). 

I love their sushi bowls and salads since they're flavorful and healthy. The salmon bowl and thai steak salads are particularly good. Prices are, well, pricey (for a fairly casual place at least), but portions are huge. Share, or if it's not raw and you can take a second portion home, you've got yourself a deal. Plus, if you sign up for their newsletter they run monthly promos. I'm not surprised they're doing well and now have multiple locations. 

(Don't read past this if you want to stick to eating healthy) 
Unfortunately, I've also tried their dulce de leche spring roll dessert and it's now one of my favorite desserts (maybe in a three way tie with Bellanico's cheesecake and BiRite creamery ice cream). Soooo good.
author: Shoshana D.

description:
The place has only been open for a few weeks so I URGE people not to condemn the place until they've had a chance to work out the kinks. 

Though the food at the Canvas was awful, I know the neighborhood sorely misses it as a great place to hang out. However, the Pac Catch people did an amazing job transforming the cavernous location into a cozy and almost sexy full-service restaurant. I've only had lunch, which was decent, so far, and as I've said, I'm going to give them a couple more months to hit their stride before passing judgment.
author: Brandon B.

description:
Delicious!!! 

We came here  wanting fresh salads and fish and we got it. The salads are huge and a meal in and of themselves. I indulged in the sweet potato fries with the wasabi and chili dipping sauces..... oh my gawd yum!!!

they have a takeout menu so you can call it in since it's at the corner of 9th and Lincoln so parking can suck. 

now that the mr. and i have started our pre-wedding 'fight the fat' starvation diet, we will be dining here quite a bit.
author: K B.

description:
I've been here over a good seven times and I must say, I am pleased each time I visit Pacific Catch. The lunch specials menu is pretty affordable ranging from 7-15 dollars. I usually order the Ahi Tuna Wasabi Bowl with the white rice (the brown rice tastes disgusting to me!) and it is delicious! The portions are very filling as well. This place is good for groups but make sure you make a reservation! It gets filled up quick for dinner but not so much for lunch. The ambiance of the restaurant is nice at night with the hanging blue bottles on the ceiling.

Two tips though! Parking is definitely challenging but they have a private parking lot next to the restaurant! And if the tables are full, the bar tables are up for grabs!
author: Vikki K.

description:
I came here to eat with my family for my birthday.  Why did I pick it?  I was bored of all the other food I had eaten in the past week and hadn't been here for about a year.  I just wanted a change of taste plus a restaurant that wasn't anything too fancy or expensive.  And that's exactly what we got.  

There's nothing too special or particularly awesome about their seafood and Asian/Hawaiian inspired dishes.  Pacific Catch has become a mainstream chain that lacks uniqueness.  There's nothing that will WOW you here.

I usually order the sweet potato fries and the Hawaiian poke (pronouced po-kee, not like "poke" in the eye) wasabi bowl.  The rice in the last wasabi bowl I had was poorly cooked and still hard.  I hope they can refocus on serving quality...  It's A-OK.
author: Randall L.

description:
My sister comes here a lot when she's in the avenues to hang out with her friends.  She insisted that I try it.  I was reluctant, because I hate driving out to the avenues ad I abhor street parking in San Francisco, but I trust my sister's instincts when it comes to food, because she's as particular as I am.

It's places like this that makes me trust her.  This place was pretty good.  I'd give it 4 stars, but I hate crowded places and this place is crowded.  People love this place and the wait to get in is trying.  We must have missed the height of the dinner rush, because we were seated after 20 minutes.  

I had the Thai Coconut Shrimp with sweet potato fries.  People rave about the sweet potato fries and they are good, but I've had better.  You can't go wrong with the Shrimp.  My sister is addicted to the Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl with brown rice.  It looked like health food.  Yuck!  Then I tasted it.  It's tasty.  Taking one bite made me feel healthier.  We also had some of the Dulce de leche spring rolls a la mode, which was not greasy and very good.  Can't wait to try this place again.
author: Babette C.

description:
Sweet potato fries are soooo good!
Everything tastes good, and the service is fine, it isn't too expensive, but it feels a little impersonal and kind of chain-y.
author: Aunt B.

description:
I gave you a shot, Pacific Catch, i wanted to like you-- i really did.

But god dammit, why is your take-out so sloppy!!??  Did you just throw it in the box and shake that shit up like a martini before you gave it to me?? Did you box this in a washing machine?! You're fired. (the sweet potato fries were nice...)
author: bm b.

description:
We resisted this place for a long time, on account of its seeming too chain-like, too touristy...  And one day, after a certain Yelp Holiday Party, one during which we had the opportunity to sample their tuna poke, we decided to stop by.  And realized the value of their outdoor puppy-friendly space, well protected by plastic on the colder days, and well-served by heat lamps.

The food is fine -- I enjoyed their crab salad over garden greens -- you're provided with a very generous portion of pure crabmeat, serverd over very lightly-dressed salad greens, served with slices of avocado and pickled ginger.  The sushi rolls are also good -- the Sake Sake and Rising Sun are as fresh well-executed as one might find at Moki's or Blowfish.  On another night we sampled their Tuna Poke again -- and overall it's a good appetizer -- the large chunks of fresh tuna are admirable, but they might benefit from a slightly smaller cut and just a tad more dressing. The fried wonton chips are plentiful and the perfect accompaniment.  Take caution when ordering their grill items -- the fish I ordered turned out to be overcooked and a smidge dry...

Overall, PacCatch is a good alternative when the lines at Park Chow seem to be interminable, and you're looking for a nice outdoor space to sit with your puppy.
author: Claudine C.

description:
Sweet Jesus this place is awesome. 

We started with calarmari, and it was easily among the most delicious I've had. The aoili that came with it was great, and complemented the calamari well. 

I had shrimp tacos, which again were delicious. I got the three taco plate which was a little too much, but I was starving. The two taco plate is plenty though. I subbed in pineapple fried rice for the sweet potato fries, even though I've heard those are amazing. The rice was really delicious too. I can't remember what my fiancee got, probably because I was face down in my plate.  

We split a mochi fondue for dessert and I almost died because it was INSANE. I would not hesitate to kill any of you for some more of that stuff. Holy crap. 

Add in a pretty nice bottle of wine, and we were still out of there for around a hundred bucks, including the tip. 

My fiancee really, REALLY misses Hawaii often, and this is one of the places I can take her in San Francisco that makes it hurt a little less. The food is really fresh and the fish is amazing, and it's similar to what you would get on the islands. The staff are all very friendly and knowledgeable, and according to our waitress, a lot of them are from Hawaii as well. 

We made a reservation about an hour in advance (Friday night), but when we arrived twenty minutes early, we found an open table in the bar area, so we just grabbed that.
author: Steve C.

description:
I will give three stars because since my visit back in january. I had a head office rep reply back to my complaint and I think thats very very professional. 

thanks
author: Kyle W.

description:
meh.

i made online reservations and they called to confirm the very next day, which was great. Got there on time and was seated right away. 

con:
-parking is horrible since its near Irving
-ambiance was meh
-a good portion of food, but it wasn't something to cheer about

pro:
-fast food
-strong drinks
author: Ruby R.

description: Awesome food and awesome service. Great location near Golden Gate Park too. We had dinner here after spending the afternoon at the Cal Academy of Sciences and were extremely pleased. The rice bowl with ahi and wasabi is amazing and I can't wait to have it again.
author: Mark W.

description: Very fresh fish and pretty hopping Friday night crowd. The wife and I split the inside-out California roll and poke sandwich. Beat the walk-in dinner crowd after 7pm on a Friday by making your reservation online.
author: Joshua W.

description:
My rationale for getting the mixed seafood basket at Pacific Catch was indeed predictable, but the food was grood. It's somewhat expensive, I think it was about 15 bucks for the frood, maybe 25 all together with drinks and whatnot. I got two pieces of fried fish, several big coconut shrimp, and what I think was described at crunchy oysters. It was all good, the ambiance was very nice (with an amazing ceiling), very relaxing.

A big plus for me is that you can make reservations on their website! Yay for being anti-social! I believe their site is (surprisingly) www.pacificcatch.com.
author: Chris S.

description: Its a very "flashy" place for a small neighborhood. Anyways, its good for big parties and seem like it could be a family style restaurant (Sharing food and passing it around the table).I went there with a party of 13 tho we had to make a reservation. The waiter was very nice and waited even tho we were really slow. I order the 3 taco platter and a roll on the side. The roll I ordered was a Shiso Fine Roll. The rolls are overpriced but that's how most places are.. It was ok, nothing special and if your sushi lover like me, you'll see there are way better places. The tacos I ordered were the steak and the two fish ones. I feel that the steak taco was good but the fish tacos were from a fast food joint. I think they could do better but I think I won't come back  when I visit SF
author: Ryan V.

description: First experience was at Late Lunch time, slow they helped me first although the guest that were with me got a mixed order with errors and no extras on a burger. Anyways overall the lunch special was great, service kinda slow but good location and staff was nice besides the boss which insisted that he was right and the cooks didn't make an error or two.  How hard is it to know the customer is always right!  Nothing is needed but a sorry sir, can I do anything else for you.  Although after the meal they did credit one meal.  My second visit for an artichoke grilled, a beer and a break..nice visit place was dead.   Good Bar service !
author: Brian M.

description: This place was good- tasty seafood salads, and yummy sweet potato fries!
author: Lisa M.

description:
I've always wanted to try Pacific Catch from every moment that I have driving on 9th from Golden Gate Park! Well, I got my chance when I wanted Fish and Chips and this was the place my girlfriend and I decided to go to!

First thing's first, it was awesome how they could call you when your seat is ready. It was a twenty minute wait for us, so we opt for them to call us and took a stroll along Irving for the duration of the time. 

After being seating, I was taken away from the comfortable booth seats! I could lean back a little for a more relax sitting position, but note that it works for someone my height (at about 5'10''). Either way, it's very comfortable. 

We ordered a set of Mahi Mahi tacos containing two tacos with sweet potato fries, a four piece Fish and Chip set with regular fries and the Hawaiian Poke as an appetizer. 

The Hawaiian Poke was a first for me. It's essentially tuna sashimi that is drowned in soy sauce and sesame seed oil. It comes with this wonton strip-like crackers that are light and crunchy, which you eat with the tuna just like chips to salsa. At first try, it's very flavorful with the soft, creamy texture of the tuna mixed with the crunchy...chip? The soy sauce and sesame seed oil work well together, but only on the top most portion of the tuna. Most of the sauce stayed at the bottom, which made the tuna at the bottom too salty. It would be better if the tuna were equally marinated instead of having a special few that literally drowned in its own sauce. Recommended dish, but eat in moderate for its sodium content.

The entrees were both great and it was pleasant of the waiting staff to separate the taco and fish for the both of us since we wanted to share. So each of us had a basket with one Mahi Mahi Taco and a basket with Fish and Chips. 

I love the sweet potato fries! Sweet and soft goodness in a crispy outer crust! It's definitely a good alternative to the regular potato fries, but good thing it's an option. I still prefer the ol' fashioned potato fries. Still sweet potato fries...good alternative.

The Mahi Mahi Tacos were good. The Mahi Mahi was grilled, of course, instead of the usual beer battered filet. Everything on the taco was well-balanced and the fish was light. There's a picture with a couple of tacos dressed with a generous portion of guacamole. Looks just like that, but with grilled white fish filet instead. 

Fish and Chips are like any other Fish and Chips. The only problem I had with it was the thickness of the batter. A little too thin for me. I drizzled some lemon over the fish and the batter couldn't hold the fish together, so it became a messy basket of fish meat and batter. The good part about it: the freshness of the fish, which was Tilapia that night (I think). 

Overall, I thought it was a delightful experience eating at Pacific Catch. There are sushi and rolls on the menu, but I learn to have sushi elsewhere for now. The tacos and fish and chips are something to try out and there are many other options to choose from. The price is reasonable with the more expensive choice under the special catch of the day. I would come back again for another try.
author: Jeremy L.

description: This place was just OK. Nothing special --  The food was bland and our server was pretty terrible. She forgot about us after bringing the food out and we waited for about 20 minutes to get our check. Another server ended up bringing the check. Save your money -- There are so many other great seafood restaurants in the city.
author: Ashley B.

description: We have eaten at Pacific Catch (Lincoln & Irving, SF) many times and enjoyed.  Yesterday we did enjoy in particular!  The swordfish was terrific and the vegetable salad was so good as well.  To add to that we had Adriana as our waitress and she was outstanding!  Great waitress, great personality and just a pleasure!
author: JJ L.

description:
This fusion Asian/seafood restaurant is great for the following reasons:

- They have their own (tiny) parking lot. In SF, free & convenient parking definitely deserves a star in and of itself.

- It had vegetarian options. Whaaaaaaaat! Hollerrr!

- Our waitress put up with my friends' (and myself's) high maintanence restaurant behavior. Extra hot sauce, 3 rounds of water, extra soy sauce, more ice, more whatever other sauce, another cup of coffee. And she did it all with a smile.

- We spent over 2 hours sitting and being obnoxiously loud, but they tolerated it anyway.

The only bad thing: they didn't card us for our alcohol. DO WE LOOK OLD NOW?!?!
author: Peggy T.

description:
Don't be fooled by their "fancy-dancy" name, NOTHING special about this place and this was what we ordered:

Spicy Tuna roll - very fresh and the ONLY satisfying dish
Sweet potato fries - decent and had better
Calamari - the WORST I ever had. HUGE batter covered these  diminutive shellfish & BLAND like there was no tomorrow!!!!!!!!
Spicy Ahi sandwich - mediocre
And there was one more entree yet I can't remembered, guess it tells how you how much I adore this place :P LOL
author: Katy N.

description:
My bf and I split the ahi poke wasabi bowl and fish and chips.  The wasabi bowl was a little bland.  There wasn't enough ahi and too much rice.  The fish and chips were good.  But tasted like fish and chips from any other place.  Although I was quit fond of the sweet potato fries.  

A great place to dine if you're passing by, but not anything to make your way out to.
author: Joanne H.

description: Food was pretty good aside from the massive amount of sauce on my fish tacos. Made it hard to judge the quality of the fish.
author: Aeon G.

description:
I am a big fan of this place, especially if I'm in the neighborhood, but wouldn't make a trip there. The food is great, especially the wasabi bowls (like Poke in mine). Unfortunately, this particular location is REALLY expensive compared to the Chestnut street location. I'm talking $4 or $5 more for a given entree. I'm sure this has to do with the fact that they are in a prime spot, especially given that the Academy of Sciences is now open, and they have lots of space, but $5 more?!?! Really?!? If I were at this location, I'd almost consider driving to the Marina just on principle alone.

Don't be mistaken -- the food is great. I'm just not crazy about the way they do business.

*edit: I received a prompt response from Chamin, the marketing manager at Pacific Catch, who assured me that the price different for the dish I ordered was $2. That's probably correct, and my perceived price difference was greater than the actual difference because the Chestnut st. prices were high to begin with. Let me correct my earlier statement "this particular location is REALLY expensive compared to the Chestnut street location" to "this particular location is just expensive. period." If it came down to it, I'd be happy with less food (the bowls are enormous) for less money.
author: Derek S.

description: This place is yummy and reasonably priced.  So far I have tried the fish tacos, sweet potato fries, and the trout.  All were very good.  Their drinks are good too!  Try the pomegranate ginger martini or the mai tai.  Yes, incase you haven't noticed I'm a drinker!
author: anne m.

description:
We were looking for inexpensive seafood and that's what we got.
The place was clean and the service was friendly and attentive.
We started with the miso soup which was nice and a little fishy (in a good way), the Hawaiian Poke which was fresh enough but really not very well cut - it had unchewable bits, which is a big no-no in raw fish. The Mahi Mahi was overly seasoned and the fish got lost in the dish. The grilled salmon salad was nice except that the fish was lacking in flavor, but we were pleasantly surprised by the California Crab & Avocado salad which was just right! Everybody LOVED the sweet potato fries - yum!
All in all, a decent value for your money in the seafood scene.
author: OfLit G.

description: Great place for a quick and relatively healthy dinner.  Food is unpretentious and delicious.
author: Juan R.

description: Treated our party of 10 well:  pleasant service and overall tasty, fresh food. Hits:  the specials rainbow trout and yellowtail (cooked just right), Baja tacos, Korean Bowl, Mixed fish and chips, of course the great sweet potato fries. Only miss was the "Peruvian Ceviche". Not like any seen before...small pieces of fish in a cup of very spicy ahi; served with good purple potato chips, like a dip, but not what was expected and maybe need a better description on the menu? Overall a great place for a get-together.
author: Gale H.

description: this review is for happy hour only. sat by the bar for some delicious and cheap food. kind of hard to flag down the waiter at certain times..that was sort of annoying. but we tried all the food items from the happy hour menu (i believe they're $6 each) and the portions were generous and they were all really good. the drinks were good as well. we also ordered a poke bowl which isn't on the happy hour menu but is definitely worth trying! a perfect place to go with a group of friends and pig out on a budget
author: Allison Y.

description:
The first time that I experienced Pacific Catch was at the original location on Chestnut... but on a busy and blustery Thursday night, we tried for Irving location because we were starved and figured that we had a better chance of getting served and fed more quickly.  

We were told that the wait was 15-20 minutes, which was definitely reasonable...but even better than that, we found a comfortable table in the bar area and was able to plop ourselves down almost immediately.  

I was craving the Ahi Poke Rice Bowl, and it didn't disappoint.  There were piles of spicy poke, with seaweed salad, and heaps of rice to keep me very satiated.  My friend ordered a salmon sandwich, which came with their awesome sweet potato fries.  I think the fries are better as an appetizer because then you get a larger serving and yummy sauces to boot!

I'm tempted to rate PC 5 stars, but I think I need to experience it a few more times and try some more dishes to qualify the rating.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
I have to admit, when Pacific Catch took over the Canvas Cafe, I was pretty irritated.  The Canvas Cafe was awesome!  It was the hip place to go to for a drink, to listen to live music and to check out artwork.  Also, there were tons of people playing chess, checkers and other card games I have never seen before.  The Canvas Cafe was a great place for all types of people with different interests to hang out and enjoy a nice evening.  Unfortunately, the Canvas Cafe has shut its doors and Pacific Catch has taken over.  Arg!

Here's my review for Pacific Catch.  Pacific Catch is a trendy place to eat with an Asian Fusion menu.  The prices are reasonable, actually very reasonable.  They have a bar on the left and the main dining room is on the right.  The bathrooms are clean and the service is great.  I had their rice bowls, which was highly recommended by each waiter/waitress I had.  They were very sweet tasting and very Americanized.  I'm not sure what type of "fusion" they are going for.  I'm assuming American?  The food is ok, the seafood was definitely fresh and the service was good.  

In conclusion, I guess I would go here again, but I am still bitter about our loss of the Canvas Cafe.  If you decide to try Pacific Catch, be aware that parking is difficult but here's a tip . . . park on the Golden Gate Park side (on the other side of Lincoln).  There are tons of parking.
author: Manton R.

description:
Fabulous meal; we came here tonight for the 1st time. We definitely wanted warm, yummy food... love the fog but hate the cold! 
Lani is a great server, and Robin gave us great recommendations-- the salmon on cedar , grilled asparagus, mashed red potatoes and corn on the cob are utterly perfect. The macadamia nut borwnie with ice cream and fudge sauce is about as decadent as desserts get. 

Courteous, friendly people. We definitely plan to come back.

We'll bring friends too.  A bit loud, but it helped to be in a booth.
author: Joan O.

description: I am reviewing one item on the menu, the Sunset Rolls.  Such a simple name BUT this roll is perfection in texture and taste and freshness.  Beautiful presentation on top of everything else that will bring me back for more, and more.  Thank you, Pacific Catch, for doing something SO right!
author: Rona M.

description: I like this place, but I don't understand people's love of their sweet potato fries. I've always found them soggy and undercooked. Similarly, their fried fish could use a bit more crunch. That said, they have tasty and inventive preparations for their fresh fish. The rice bowls are particularly tasty, and big enough for a meal.
author: D V.

description: So my friend informed me that there are cake-cutting fees at a lot of expensive restaurants! I've been to Pacific Catch twice, and the restaurant was really cute, but the food was just alright :/ Maybe I just didn't order the right items on the menu. My favorite part is the free parking behind the restaurant.
author: Cindy S.

description: Good ambience.  Great for dates and birthday.  Food was pretty tasty.
author: Danny N.

description:
I love what they did with the space.  The decor and vibe was comfortable.  The staff and service were professional and attentive, although you can tell they're still learning on the job.  The food was tasty and reasonably price.  Try the sweet potato fries.  The fish from the fresh catch and fries could've been fried harder.  The dessert didn't impress.  Worth a revisit.

p.s.  Corkage fee is only $10.  A good place to bring those white wines you've been saving.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
I had heard so much great stuff about this place that I was really excited to try it.  When we walked in at about 1:30pm on a Sunday, the hostess asked us for our phone number.   She said she would give us a call when our table is ready.  We looked around and half the restaurant is empty.  I can't believe they pulled this crap on us when their restaurant isn't even full.  

When we finally got seated, we ordered their chicken sandwich and it was ok.  I would love to give them another chance, but it'll be awhile before I go back.
author: AhLin C.

description:
I thought this would be a good place. Seafood in San Francisco? Sounds like a sure bet.

Not so.  Scallops, while fresh and big, were tasteless and merely lightly grilled.  The grilled salmon was dried up and burnt.  The waitress seemed quite proud of them being organic salmon, though.  They did have some big rice bowls, but you might as well go to the Serramonte Mall's food court if you want to eat rice bowls.

The only saving grace is the sweet potato fries.  And only because not a lot of restaurants have sweet potato fries.  

Two stars because I'm not coming back here and won't recommend anyone else to.
author: Robert L.

description:
Yeah, yeah, I miss Canvas too, but considering I loved the Marina Pacific Catch location and gave it a great review here, this did not taint my last night's dining experience here. And here is the basic problem, I guess regardless of location, invariably tested over the last couple of visits: besides their few signature dishes, which ARE truly great - the rice bowls and meal-sized salads with seared ahi (prices for which rose some time recently), sweet fries and, as we found out this time, the poke starter - the rest of the specials and entries pretty much SUCK. The fish and preparation is very mediocre: for example, last night "Japanese-style trout" had very little Japanese about it (and I've eaten in Japan), and trout itself was totally average. It wasn't worth the price.

Don't like the decor much - given the size of the space and the treatment it was getting from Canvas, they could've put more imagination into it! The bar area was empty before midnight on Friday...
2.5 stars, really, but given high marks I already gave the Marina location (where I sometimes go for lunch, for which those bowls are perfect), I round it down.
author: Sasha M.

description:
Me heart sweet potato fries.  I was a little heart broken when they closed Canvas.  Like alot of my past relationships, I picked up the pieces of my broken heart and went in search for a new love.

I found it, and fell immediately in love with their sweet potato fries with wasabi aioli and sweet-chili dipping sauce.  I could eat the whole basket as a meal.  We had the grill mahi and Hawaiian BBQ surf and turf.  The mahi was a little bland to start.  Since I add hot sauce to everything, it was good after a little spice.  The steak was better than the mahi, very tasty and tender.

The place is much bigger than the marina location.  You don't have to worry about elbowing the person next to you when you are fumbling around with chopsticks.   I was the victim.  I know how to use chopsticks.
author: Muncia S.

description:
Pacific Catch just recently opened on 9t Street and we decided to go try it for a mellow weekend lunch.  We weren't sure what to expect because it was new, but the online menu sure looked great.

The decor is modern and clean, providing a rather trendy atmosphere.  The place wasn't crowded when we came so we didn't have to wait for a table, which is always nice.  We saw one table had ordered the Baja Shrimp Ceviche so we decided to start with that.   The presentation was really cool.  The ceviche, stuffed full of shrimp and avocado, was served in a tall martini glass with a pile of tortilla chips sprawled around the base.  The best thing about this dish was how much shrimp they gave us!  It's always annoying when you pay a premium for a shrimp entre and get 3 shrimp.  We counted each shrimp as we were going through the ceviche, they were good sized shrimp mind you, and ended up with almost 20! The chef was overly generous with the shrimp for the price we payed.

For my entre, I went with 3 tacos; 1 BBQ salmon with corn salsa and lime crema, 1 tropical grilled shrimp with mango salsa, and 1 spice-rubbed grilled mahi mahi with avocado tomatilla salsa.  Now let me first say that I am a little biased when it comes to fish tacos.  I've been a long time advocate for Wahoo's fish tacos and nothing has ever compared to their tacos.  Pacific catch however served me some really tasty fish tacos, which can definitely compete with Wahoo's.  I really appreciated the nice quality of salsas and toppings that went into the tacos.  They worked well and tasted great with the various fish and shrimp pairings.  I took down these bad boys so fast and had to restrain myself from ordering more!

We also ordered sweet potato fries which were good.  I tend to find any type of french fry that offers a spin off the traditional French fry (different potatoes, etc) very satisfying.

Pacific Catch is definitely a decent restaurant and we will for sure go there again.  They had other dishes, such as sushi and fancy deserts that I would also like to try.  I also noticed they had a pretty nice full bar with comfy seats and a decent happy hour.  This would be a good place to come have some drinks and a nice dinner with some friends or even a date.
author: Timothy C.

description:
I can see how some reviewers think that this place is trying too hard, with it's hodge-podge all over the place menu, but it definitely works for me.  5 reasons why I like it:

1.  drinks - Guava Mint Cooler was delicious and refreshing
2.  happy hour at 10pm - need I say more?
3.  meal for 3 people including drinks was $51
4.  sweet potato fries with sweet chili sauce - SWEET!
5.  discount for cocktails sans alcohol
author: Em C.

description:
My boyfriend introduced me to this place about 6 months back, and I've been back at least 3 or 4 times since. 

The ingredients are fresh and clean and delicious, and the interior design is beautiful. The food is definately fusion, but every plate is relatively simple. It's not trying too hard. Interesting and bright flavor combinations. We have mexican, japanese, chinese, thai, hawaiian and californian influences. 

It's a laid back casual atmosphere, with friendly efficient service, and the prices are just right for what their offering. Nothing completely blows me away, which is why it doesn't get 5 stars in my book. But everything I've ordered has been good, if not completely yummy.

I've seen way to many places open and close at this location, but I think Pacific Catch has found a permanent home here. I'll be back again many a time, I'm sure.
author: Mindy L.

description: The food here is very good. I got some sort of of hawaii bbq mix with shrimp and beef and it was very good. I also got a miso soup, and it was good but I prefer the more simple one. My friend that I was with got the rock n roll and california roll, and was pleased with it, because the pieces were large and filling. It was a bit pricey we paid 60 for the 2 of us. The decor of the place is very modern and the service is very good. Definetly a place i want to go again, and a place i would recommend to anyone who loves fish.
author: Nikita K.

description: Food is tasty and menu offers great Asian and Latino flair.  Service not so great as minor botches just seem to add up.  A Chevy's waiter class could make all the difference in this place.  Some minor fixes would make this a great place.
author: Dean F.

description: Went here for a catch-up dinner date with one of my girlfriends and had a great time! I love the complimentary pretzel goldfish and edamame. Our waiter was great and the food came fast. I had the traditional baja and pacific steak tacos and my friend got the baja and chicken tacos. We had sweet potato fries of course as well. Everything was delicious fresh and flavorful. I also had a 50% off deal from Scoutmob which the waiter graciously accepted. I always make it a point to tip the waiter/waitress generously when I come with a coupon, especially if the service was good. Will definitely be coming back!
author: An-Nhien L.

description: Amazing service. My friends and I finished eating ard 8pm and they didn't complain at all that we stayed talking till closing at 10:30pm. Waiter was amazing. So attentive! Food is good. Reasonably priced. Just remember that they have free parking on Lincoln Ave! Oh and free edamame and pretzels when you sit down...yum!
author: Connie S.

description:
Update:
Welp, I've given it almost a month since my first try & review and the food was still a let down -the quality not on par with the prices. The entrees we had were in striking distance from the $20 mark but were not nearly of the quality a dish should be in that price range. Portions of the dishes were either drowning in heavily applied, prepackaged tasting sauces or they were over marinated, the texture and taste degraded by the ingredients being premixed and sitting vs being combined fresh as needed. 

I am sorry to discover this and am disappointed to find that apparently Pacific Catch really amounts to chain restaurant like quality for real restaurant prices. In the future I'll stick with the lesser priced offerings, although, come to think of it, I can get authentic donburi bowls,  poke or sushi for less.  Guess I'll wait again and see how things go.
------------------------------------------------------
My first experience with Pacific Catch did not catch my attention in a good way.   

It was simply food prep and content that was disappointing - fried items were all literally still dripping in oil, the salad part of the ahi salad I had was really not much more then generic organic type mix with a couple of add-ons sprinkled on top (it could have used additional veggie elements, perhaps some edamame, jicama, almonds, to add texture and enough to integrate into the mix), and the artichoke was soggy at the heart but its leaves were dry and tough.

I was anticipating that Pacific Catch would be a place I'd frequent in my neighborhood (especially for all those lazy nights I pick up dinner to-go) and will certainly try them again  - I hope that when I do I will be able to update this review and add stars.
author: GIR ..

description:
This place is supposed to be FUSION of Asian and American cuisine.

Basically it's Asian food for white people as my friend said over dinner.  The American food with an Asian twist wins.  The Asian food with American flavor is somewhat bland and uninspired.

Waitresses are very friendly, and service was great.  There is this Asian guy that stands at the counter, but is not dressed in a uniform.  He looked like a customer, but don't be fooled he works there =T 

Fried Fish (n Chips)= WIN (Not greasy, well fried, mostly good chunks)
Sweet potato fries = WIN (They need to cut these bigger! So GOOD)
Any Ice Tea= LOSE (water with lemon tastes better than lemon grass)
WASABI BOWLS= LOSE (4 tiny pieces of not fresh tuna, and rice $14)
Sanwich= WIN

Sweet potato fries are great, and I only wish they came in bigger cuts.  I liked the sweet dipping sauce.  The ahi tuna wasabi bowl came in a large bowl, but the tuna did not taste too fresh.  I did appreciate that they offered brown rice as a substitute for white rice.  I will go back for those fries!
author: Joe O.

description:
These guys did a great job with the new space. The basic layout is the same as when it was the Canvas, but they removed the center counter.

Their Japanese rice bowls are awesome. I prefer the udon. Most recently I tried the chinook salmon, which was very fresh and tasty, but the presentation did not warrant its $19.95 price.

I'd go again, but get some of the more budget items. Read: fish and chips.
author: Blake E.

description:
