When I first found out i was going here to celebrate my girlfriend's sister's  birthday, I just had to look it up on yelp. The pictures here didn't look to good, decor wise. But to be honest, the decor was really nice. Very modern and the place was pretty spacious. 

The food is moderately priced, but I somehow wound up spending $40. The group ordered two rolls of sushi and I wasn't paying attention at the time, so I didn't know what either was called. One of them was very tasty, while the other was completely bland. 

Personally I ordered the Thai Coconut Shrimp. There was nothing Thai about it, and there was too much coconut. I really like coconut shrimp, if balanced correctly. It was not. It was overwhelming and I was barely able to finish it. The sweet potato fries were nothing special. They were sweet potato fries that could be made at home with no extra seasoning and taste the same. 

The service was good. Our waitress was on top of everything and the food came out pretty fast considering how crowded it was. And if you plan on celebrating a birthday here, it's a $10 fee if you bring a cake and have them bring it out and sing happy birthday. (To me, for them to sing happy birthday was nice, but makes the restaurant all the more generic). 

This place gets the 3 stars because of the good service, the decor, price and just below average food. My expectations weren't huge of this place, and the food matched what I thought it'd be. 
Would i come back? Sure, I'll give other menu items a try, but coconut shrimp will never be an option here.
author: Calvin L.

description:
I was excited to try the Pacific Catch on 9th because I've heard great things about the space and it's kind of a hassle to go all the way to Chestnut. The look of the restaurant is beautifully casual and comfortable with plenty of seating. For that, I give this restaurant big ups. 

Our waitress on the other hand was just blah. It looked like she cared more about socializing and dancing with her co-worker friends more than earning her tip from us. The whole time she seemed insincere from the moment she brought us our drinks to handing us the check. 

I always liked Pacific Catch's food, even though it's slightly over-priced.  The food is the same in terms of taste and the sweet potato fries (which I love w/ the wasabi aeoli) were consistantly yummy. Even though we ordered the Firecracker Salmon Roll and Spicy Tuna Roll, I don't recommend trying the sushi here. It lacks flavor, authenticity, and freshness..but I didn't expect it to be good so I wasn't surprised. The fish tacos are always delicious; especially the Mahi Mahi Fish Taco which is one of my favorites. 

The atmosphere, location, and food is great. However, the waitress we had and the sushi are not. Something else was just lacking as a whole but I can't put my finger on it. But, I will be back to this location..

Service: 2
Food: 4
Atmosphere: 4
Overall: 3.5
author: Jen Y.

description:
The parking may drop this to an average three star rating, but that would be deceiving.  This place is simply tasty!

The food is just as fresh and scrumptious as the Marina staple and the wait staff is great.   It's much larger than the Marina stop-- almost vacuous on slow days.  The high-vaulted ceiling makes the room seem cavernous, but the clientle typically fills it up with joy and vigor.   

Try the wasabi bowls with brown rice.  It's great! 

It's slightly pricey, but the unique fusion of Japanese and California seafood makes this place worth of a visit.
author: Kel S.

description:
I went to Pacific Catch this evening for dinner and while I like the concept of the menu I wasn't overly impressed with my salmon teriyaki bowl. Yes it was fresh, but the rice had a bit too much sauce on it for my taste. I'm not sure if this was the reason, but I was extremely thirsty after having a few bites of my entree. Even when I got home I was thirsty. My friend had the grilled mahi mahi which I tasted and thought it was good. We got the sweet potato fries as an appetizer. While they were good I've had them elsewhere so it wasn't that exciting. The sweet potato fries don't hold their temperature long so you need to enjoy them fast.

The decor of the restaurant is eco-friendly and asian themed. They used quite a bit of bamboo throughout the restaurant and use environmentally friendly products per the insert in the menu. Overall I liked the decor and the openess of the restaurant which is a result of the high ceilings. Regardless it's nice to be able to have room when you're dining. 

Service was decent but nothing really spectacular. A manager did come by and greet us and thank us for making a reservation on OpenTable. I'm not too sure if this has anything to do with being an OpenTable VIP member. For those wondering I haven't noticed anything different when dining since being designated a VIP user.
author: Kevin L.

description:
The name itself makes me want to go eat here wondering what I'm going to catch =)   I had lunch here with my favorite guy and we ordered the following:
1.  Tempura shrimp sushi - whole shrimps, fresh, delish
2.  Fish and chips (sweet potatoes fries) - fish is tender, fries are yummy and not so mushy considering its type
3.  Spicy ahi sandwich - medium raw ... on ciabatta bread ... has a nice spiciness that really compliments the fish ... I like it a lot =)

The chair's comfortable, lighting is just right (not too dark nor bright), may be a bit overstaffed during lunch time because we sort of had 3 different waiters, and very attentive service ...

Just a bit cold where we sat ... and I had my beanie on heheh
author: Chau L.

description:
My reaction to my experience here = meh.  My friend had hyped it up a bit for me so that was part of the reason.  Anyway there were 4 of us that went on a Friday night around 8pm after having a few very cheap yummy beers at Mucky Duck up the street.  When we walked in there were maybe 4 people in front of us and a few open tables in the dining room but for some odd reason the airhead of a hostess told us it would be 30 - 40 min wait.  My friends were hungry and we almost didn't wait but I decided to put our name in while we figured where we would go.  She then told me it would be a 35-45 min wait...ridiculous.  We stood contemplating getting take out when after barely 5 min had passed we were seated!!! huh??

Anyway food wise was alright. I'm a very picky sushi eater so I wasn't that impressed but I wouldn't say it was bad.  The sweet potato fries were definitely the most amazing part.  Price was as to be expected for a chain like that, definitely not cheap but not outrageous for what we got...I think for two of us sharing two 8 piece sushi rolls (fancier ones), a basket of sweet potato fries (they do hook you up there) and 2 Sapporo beers it was something like $38.  

I would go back for drinks and sweet potato fries, that's probably it.
author: Ariana K.

description:
Tacos, sweet potatoe fries, sandwiches, most of their good is pretty good. HOWEVER, I just think it's overpriced for small portions. I understand that it's fresh fish, etc. and etc., but why would you have to pay extra for fries when you order a $10 sandwich? 

I guarantee the bill will be expensive..but hey, i guess it's fish. i came out still hungry with an  empty wallet. I guess it's good to try for the first time. Service was great by the way. Hostess could have waited until we were seated, placed the menus, and mention "enjoy your meal." none of that there.
author: Yelp-alholic T.

description:
I have been to this place a couple of times. Their bartenders seem at least knowledgeable - best madras I have ever had. Their sweet potatoe french fries have been a guilty pleasure of mine - but those are easy to make at home.

Ok atmosphere - the bar seating is just a little too squished for me.

4 stars because they replaced Canvas and because they are a chain but they are also pretty good.
author: Kayla H.

description:
I like their sweet potato fries and the wasabi bowls. :)

But I think they are pricey. Pricey price pricey! For what the food is...

I didn't like the poke too much. I thought they should had cut the cubes smaller and marinated them w/ a light yummier sauce.

They should get some pointers from hawaii :) Places in hawaii serve DELICIOUS poke. I can still remember the taste... every morsel of it.... :9

I hear the Pacific Catch in the Marian District is better -- in taste and price. :)

P.S. Ahi Tuna has high levels of Mercury. I'm trying not to eat tuna too much!! eep! (See article in NYTimes).
author: J T.

description:
Pacific Catch is a great place to go for lunch and dinner. It serves very tasty food at a decent price. Few drawbacks, but not much to affect it.

Service: Service is decent, they come around to give u water/coffee/w/e else u want refilled and they get the orders put in quick. Nothing wrong w/ it, but nothing spectacular. 

Food: The food tastes great. The Sweet potato fries, calamari, sushi, and wide variety of fish are delicious. The price is decent for the food and it comes out pretty fast compared to most places. 

The restaurant is decently sized, can accommodate a good amount of people, but parking sucks. I'd recommend this place if u decide to go early in hope of finding a parking space or if u live around there.
author: Dylan T.

description:
If Pac Catch wasn't highlighted as kid-friendly resto, I probably would not have discovered this place.

Service was quick to accommodate our party of 7 (3 kids!) and to handout appetizers - pretzel goldfish and edamame. Lucky for us, my daughter LOVES goldfish, so that was able to tide her over until her meal came.

Food was good - not outstanding, but good. I had the Thai coconut shrimp skewers with sweet potato fries. The shrimp was nothing special to write home about, but the sweet potato fries were excellent! My husband had the unagi wasabi bowl and he seemed pretty satisfied after finishing off 3/4 of it. I had a bite of my daughter's fish & chips - tasty, not too greasy.

We were all too stuffed for dessert - perhaps on the next visit.

Definitely kid friendly, but they do not provide coloring materials as other restos would.

Didn't try the sushi, but with Ebisu up the street, why would you?
author: Kelly R.

description:
There's always a charm in being able to visit a restaurant in their not-so-busy time of the day.  There's no worries about getting frustrated about waiting for a table, getting mediocre service while the waiters battle multiple tables, and having to deal with a high noise level.

I dropped by on a Saturday for lunch around 11:30ish as the neighborhood was slowly waking up.  I liked sitting around the bar area surrounded by dining tables.  It was well lit with tall big windows.  The service was OK and I was left alone for the most part.  I tried their ahi sandwich and it was definitely worth coming back for.  I read lots of reviews before heading over and of course, the yam fries were ordered.  A couple of guys sitting next to me were chowing down on the wasabi bowls this place was known for.  I guess I'll try that next time.

Definitely a place worthy of a revisit!
author: Ginni S.

description:
I miss the Canvas but I think Pacific Catch is doing a good job with the space.  It still feels open and fun---obviously the decor got a facelift. The food...pretty darned good. I've had various fish lightly seared, cooked through, appetizers, salads.... the blends of flavors are good and it feels fresh and fun. I can't remember trying cocktails but they look decent.

Times visited: 3
author: Amy L.

description:
Here's the conversation after our meal...

S.O.: So you gonna write about this on yelp?

Me: I'm trying to be nicer and eat at a place more than once before I write a review.

S.O.: So that means you'd have to come back here again...

Me: Hmm...good point. Okay, I'll just give it 3 stars. [and skip the return trip!]

The food was just okay -- didn't quite like the "baja bbq style" for the fish. The mixed fried basket was okay. The sweet potato fries were good, but it didn't necessarily win a new fanatic (like other reviewers).

The Good: Very quick service (on an active Sunday night), nice waiter (sorta looked like a young Will Ferrell), and nice ambiance.

A little pricey given the quality of food -- we would've paid $25-30 for something that cost more like $50. Oh well. That's what we get for trying a new place!
author: Gray C.

description:
I have been a fan of Pacific Catch for years now!  Def am relieved that the Irving location has opened - its so much bigger...

Ok down to the food - ahi tuna/poke wasabi bowl with brown rice!  You cannot go wrong..sweet potato fries are seriously the best...their tacos (big portions) are filled with freshest fish...granted I only go for my favorites - but I've nibbled off a few of my friends' plate, and have yet to be disappointed by the food.

The new location beats waiting in line - def try this place out if you're looking for a fresh alternative!
author: Julie H.

description:
I really, really didn't want to like this place having replaced the Canvas Cafe.  I wasn't a huge Canvas enthusiast--it was always a little scenestery--but I'm a fan of small business.

A series of most unfortunate events lead a large group of friends and me here for dinner.  They seated a group of 8 with no reservation quickly and without snarkiness.  

The food was good (portions are crazy-big here) and have a pretty decent beer list.  Oh, and the desserts are INSANE.  The dulce de leche spring rolls?  Thank god we shared them (our group ordered a couple of desserts & passed them around)--I think they might have killed me.

Service was attentive and very cool--our waiter made great suggestions about menu choices.

Would go back again.
author: Jen D.

description:
Ahi poke wasabi bowl and sweet potato fries.... 
It's the same kind of dementia that makes me ALWAYS order a 15 or a 17 at Tu Lan (http://tinyurl.com/5trmyz). 
I don't even look at the menu anymore. 
I do but I just do it to kill some time while other people order. 
You can't go wrong. 
Well, you can if you order it with brown rice. 
Why you wanna go fancy?! 
Plain, good ol' rice vinegar seasoned sushi rice.
The only spiffage allowed is'a touch' of sriracha...but don't overdo it.
We can still be friend, Pacific Catch, for a long time.
author: Dario B.

description:
Much bigger spot than the one in my hood but Marko and I love coming here after playing tennis at GG park. Unlike the one in the marina, tables are plenty, but becuase it is bigger, the service is a bit slower than we are use to. 

We went there earlier this week and because it was such a warm night, we sat at the outside tables and it was the perfect spot to enjoy the food and enjoy the evening...

Still love the poke wasabi bowls with extra nori...
author: Bernadette L.

description:
I love this place! Randomly decided to try Pacific Catch on a Saturday night (no reservation) and we got a table outside for 5 in less than 10 minutes. Even though it was really cold outside their heat lamps were superb and kept us toasty throughout dinner.

I actually pass by this restaurant every day on my bus ride to work and had no idea that it was an Asian fusion restaurant. The menu took me by surprise but in a good way. 

For appetizers we ordered sweet potato fries (very yummy) and artichokes (good but could have done without). I ordered the white tuna poki with crab salad (very good) and surf & turf (steak w/shrimp, pineapple fried rice, onion shoe strings, and asparagus) to share with my friend. I was very satisfied with my entrees and was completely stuffed afterwards.

The prices are reasonable. For a group of 5 we spent about $107 (pre tax and tip) so it's not bad at all. Service is very friendly as well. Definitely will go back!
author: Terry D.

description: The Wasabi bowls are great if you're hungry. Add some sweet potato fries and you're good!
author: Ryan M.

description: Our meal was just short of devine... I had the tasting menu: calamari salad, wild barramundi, and persimmon cake. It was invigorating! Fresh fish,& crispy calamari. We were in heaven.
author: Nikki S.

description: Came in here for the first time for lunch. Service was very slow and rude. I ask for soy sauce for my sushi the waitress said, " you don't need sauce there's already sauce in the sushi". Worst service ever. Our order took a good 5-8 minutes to come out. We order lobster sandwich which didn't have taste, fish and chips were all burnt. The only decent food that had taste was the sushi roll we order. I would not recommend this place it also doesn't have much variety to choice from.
author: Jaden L.

description: Favorite place! I've only ever gotten one thing here - ahi tuna wasabi bowl - and it's delicious! Unfortunately it's a little pricey so I can't go that often (that's why the 4 stars and not 5 - otherwise it would get 5 stars all the way!). Their margaritas are also great. My mouth is watering thinking about it!
author: Simona M.

description:
Pacific Catch is a fusion Japanese/seafood place that I've had my eye on for a while.  It sure is gaudy and lures you with the baubles and trinkets however, fails to live up to the expectations.  It is like a beautiful yet underwhelming performer of a car.  Walking in, it is very ample in size.  The ambiance is very cozy and there is a nautical theme.  Our hostess led us to our table and accommodated us when we wanted to sit in the booth.  The back support of soft cushions beats those of hard wooden backings any day.  Our waiter was a very nice chap, a water sprite of some sort...calm and collected on the surface but a giggler I am sure underneath.  

We were given goldfish/unsalted beans to start of the night.  Never was served goldfish as a starter but I can't complain.  I love goldfish.  Alas, it was the nasty pretzel flavored ones.  I ordered the Hawaiian poke bowl while my female counterpart ordered the miso salmon.  We also ordered sweet potato fries.  This was the first time I have ever tried sweet potato fries and I became a believer.  I always thought it was for females for some reason....excuse my ignorant rationale.  It was so good that I hogged the whole basket.  The only thing I was not fond of was the wasabi sauce.  They give you this asian dipping sauce also which is the secret to King of Thai #31...wadDUUUP.  I eat my fries with 2 things...ranch or ketchup.  I grabbed the ketchup bottle, squirted a gob and was good.  While sweet potatoe fries were good, regular french fries still capture the majority of my thump thump.  My poke bowl came out and it looked very good.  They were not scrouges on the poke.  Everything was neatly proportioned...a couple slivers of avacado, wakame salad, radish, a lotta poke, etc.  When I took my first bite, I nearly grimaced.  I forgot to request no wasabe sauce.  While the taste wasn't overly strong, it was still lingering enough to make me quite sad.  My girlfriend's miso salmon was good however, nothing of the taste made it stand out as a Pacific Catch dish.  It tasted like something I could get at any Jap restaurant.  

Pacific Catch is very generous in portions and the price is not too bad.  However, the food, while nice in presentation, was only that...superficial...the way I like my girls...jk jk.  You will leave this place full, no doubt about that, but it is the type of full that leaves you hungering for more tasteful experience.
author: Brian V.

description: We finally ate at Pacific Catch, took our 6 kids ages 27-6. Wasn't sure if bringing all of them was going to be worth it since there were a lot of really great reviews and bad ones. Well it was totally worth the hassle of finding an available parking spot and having a $200 bill. Loved the three Korean Sticky Rib bowls, three orders of 3 Island Tacos (shrimp, Baja and Mahi), Fresh Catch was fresh, one sweet potato fries, one spicy fries, fried Calamari went fast and the Ceviche was perfect. I highly recommend the Pomegranate Ginger Martini. It was worth every penny and the staff was friendly, thanks Alysssa.
author: Girl L.

description: The days before, the day of, and those following my birthday have been filled with nothing but fun. That, and a ridiculous amount of food. I have been so well fed this week it's not even funny. One of my best friends took me here for dinner last night. PC was fairly busy in spite of the rain. She said I could order anything I want. (No, you didn't just say that!) I wasn't planning on stuffing my face, but surely I was in the mood for some tacos. I chose the double platter with one traditional baja and one cabo shrimp taco. Before our orders were up, we had their crispy oysters and spicy tuna roll. The oysters weren't greasy and the roll had a good kick. As for the tacos, I liked the shrimp one better than the baja. Cod (which was the daily catch featured in the baja taco) is a pretty bland fish unless you pair it with a flavorful partner. In this case, it was the tomatillo salsa. Good thing I ate that one first before the shrimp or else I probably would have been a bit disappointed. The shrimp taco was much better. Even more so with the avocado and pico de gallo. My friend and I could have ended our mission right there, but I managed to set aside some room for dessert. Normally I would skip it, but I heard some good things about the dulce de leche spring rolls. The concoction came drizzled with a generous amount of caramel sauce and a scoop of vanilla ice cream. Yum! I think the filling inside of the roll was cheesecake, not sure. It tends to get pretty rich after a while. Once again, I'm stuffed. I'll have to put in a few rigorous workouts next week to compensate for all this eating.
author: Rhia R.

description: Had dinner last night, wasn't their best performance as i've been there a few times beofre.  I love their menu, good diversity and decent portions. Service was a bit slow, had to repeatedly ask for refills on soda and water, and took a while to get our food.  Maybe it was because it was Easter and they were shorthanded.
author: Kris H.

description:
I've been here before and liked it, so I took 2 of my friends for their birthday, but we were all VERY disappointed.  

They also did not acknowledge my open table reservations because the server that sat us didn't seem to care to note it. Won't recommend it, won't ever come back.
author: Ms B.

description:
Gorgeous! The interior is really nice and the food is excellent (I got the seared ahi wasabi bowl with half greens and half brown rice) the staff has been super friendly and not overbearing both times I came here and the mixed drinks are awesome! I've had ( at the risk of exposing my alcoholic tendencies) the agave margarita, the guava cooler (or something) the lemongrass mojito, and the black and white drink (don't remember the exact name) they were all really girly and yummy but I still felt the alcohol...and no, it's not because I drank all of that at once- remember I've been here twiiiice

I'd recommend this place for birthdays, dates or nice dinners to catch up with friends...pacific catch 'caught' me!! Harhar...
author: Amy L.

description:
i've had the poki many times at various venues but have never actually sat in at the restaurant to eat. i came with a friend after we'd gone to Hukilau to try and attend their poki festival only to find a bunch of drunk people and no poki. as giant heifers, we got the poki, sweet potato fries, shrimp ceviche, and sides of artichoke and corn. all of it was good and i wasn't disappointed with anything. 

....and their description of mochi said something like "pulverized rice," which i thought was hilarious.
author: Regina C.

description:
I've always wanted to try this place as I've heard about it.  Finally my hubbie and I were able to eat here for a late lunch.  It was quiet and mellow past 2 p.m.  I found the restaurant to be clean and spacious and had nice decor.  Even the ladies' restroom was clean and I liked the bamboo motif on the stall's walls and door.
I ordered the Mixed Catch Basket.  Thumbs up and two snaps up!  The fish was thick, super duper soft, and flaky.  The oysters were warm and just the right softness and moistness.  The coconut shrimp were big and yummy.  I had also ordered a Nojito, a mojito w/out the rum.  Totally refreshing, flavorful, and perfect.
My husband had the Thai rice bowl with the crab salad; he was pleased with it esp. the crab salad and was full.  Lemme tell you, it takes a lot for my husband to get full.  The rice bowl could fit at least four, Chinese rice bowls of rice in it.  He had also ordered the Aguave Lemonade.  That was awesome to drink as I got to try it.
Our server was friendly, efficient, and checked up on us.  We received good service from him.
I would love to come here again and oh, there were families here so it's child friendly for sure.
author: Kekumukula N.

description: Great lunch specials and quick service makes this place perfect for a quick healthy lunch.  The food always tastes fresh and there are interesting food combinations that you don't find at other places.
author: Joe S.

description: This place has bottomless Thai ice tea.  If that doesn't sell you on Pacific Catch, I don't know what will - but their fish salads are pretty awesome, too, Their sushi-grade raw salad is amazing, and the salmon salad with the skin "croutons" is one of the best meals I've ever had.  I'm not really a fan of their appetizers, though, and while the servers are REALLY great, it seems like they're a little understaffed so sometimes things are slow.
author: Sydney A.

description: I always cringe at the thought of a $15 salad, but by the time i am eating my very generous portion of greens and poke tuna, it all makes sense.  I most often get my order to go.  Great 10 min parking spot makes all the difference on a busy night.  Only wish I could make it over here more often.
author: e w.

description:
I would love to give Pacific Catch 5 stars for their food and friendly staff. I'm going to leave off two stars because of a problem I have experienced here on several occasions. I often call in to pick up my food. All of the other hostesses who have taken my call are very friendly and sound more than happy to help, however, on a FEW occasions I have been greeted by one who sounds thoroughly irritated that she has to help someone. It's no better when I arrive to pick up the food as she greets me and the other diners I see arrive with NO smile as she looks pained to be there. On one occasion I found myself hanging up when she answered and mentioned her name. The waiters and bartenders are always very nice and helpful when I sit to eat. Since I usually order my food to go though I often deal with only the host and a bartender.

Other than that it's good food(sweet potato fries, ecstacy roll), good people, good location!
author: Kate J.

description:
The food is great (the table shared sweet potato fries, and I had the wasabi bowl with ahi). The menu is inspired. The portions are generous (as in way too big, I ate my meal for dinner and lunch the next day). 

So why the three stars? This place feels a chain restaurant. When trying to explain the chain feel to my boyfriend I couldn't put my finger on it-- but something about the menu, platings, tables, atmosphere, lighting made me feel like I was in Applebees or Fridays. I know they only have 3 locations but seriously, go there and tell me you don't feel like you're in Tony Romas.  

P.S. the bloody mary was marginal and overpriced (around $10).
author: christi m.

description:
I absolutely love Pacific Catch's Poke Wasabi Bowl & Sweet Potato Fries-- my friends must think that I'm crazy b/c I rave about that so much!  

...anyhow...FYI... the Pacific Catch on 9th does not have Cricket Cola. :(

Oh...they have Happy Hour from 10pm to closing....how great is that?!
author: Lise T.

description:
The decor of this place is really nice, but its like going into a really nice spa with waterfalls and zen gardens, but you get the worst massage ever, in the end you paid for an atmosphere. Their prices is medium ranged, but the food quality is really below average. 

The service is really really slow. I don't know if it is because I came when they first opened or if it is because of the figure eight they make their servers make. I don't know what genius M.B.A. did the trade study on this one, but making a server serve tables on each corner of a restaurant isn't a great move. Makes service slower, and the server annoyed when you ask for more tea.
author: Ray H.

description:
I can finally take this place happily out from my bookmarks. The three of us rushed-in in the midst of San Francisco's heaviest rain on Sunday evening. Stepping into this place feels like arriving at a warm sanctuary. We were a bit discouraged by the 20-minute wait we were told. Thankfully, in not even 5 minutes the waitress came and said that our table was ready. 

Looking at the menu, the three hungry creatures start drooling. We ordered three wasabi rice bowls (2 ahi and 1 poke) in addition to one fish+chips for sharing, and 2 bottles of Cooper's Beer from Aussie. OMG, it was a real feast! Overall experience was great. We were even impressed by the decor in the bathroom. 

Enuff abt the poz side. The fish on the fish+chips were fresh, but the batter was kind of soggy. I love the edamame as the starter, but the fish-shaped pretzel remind me of the sodium-infused cheap airline snacks. The service was just okay, could have been more friendly.

I guess that's it! =)

Oh wait, I haven't mentioned about the sweet potato fries. It was HEAVENLY, as always.
author: Andy W.

description:
I've declined this place on several previous occassions due to atrocious parking... I get utterly frustrated in that part of town!  Anyway, I wasn't impressed by the seating arrangements and the cheap looking tables. Overall, it kind of looked like a diner trying to be more upscale than it is, and it gets overpacked at lunch and dinner time.

However, the cheap prices, the variety, and the food is a good sell.  I got the Tuna-kyu roll as an appertizer, and it was just right.  Also, the Wasabi bowl with Unagi is HUGE!  I was very full and satiated.  

However, waitress, please stop asking how our table is EVERY FREAKING 52 SECONDS!  I get it, you want us to leave, so you can serve more tables for the people waiting and get some tips, but seriously annoying.
author: Vicky B.

description:
I've had mixed experiences

I generally like the rice bowls-- theyre cheap-ish and good-ish-- not the best quality fish, but commensurate with what you would expect at a place that looks like wahoo's fish tacos.

The sandwiches are not very good -- ahi sandwich was particularly bland and uninteresting.  Fried oysters were also mehh-- definitely not worth 10 dollars.

Also, the architect who designed the place should be shot-- its a very cramped space to begin with, and whoever designed it exaggerated the worst spatial aspects of the joint.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Tasty Drinks! Their Guava Mint drink was a bit too grainy for me, but I guess that's what you expect out of 100% Guava Puree. However, the Citrus Ginger drink was reallllly good. I will go back for that.

Wasabi Bowls are great as are the sweet potato fries with different dipping sauces. 

For dessert, we had the Mochi Fondue -- not worth it.

The bartender was a sweetheart but our waiter had an "i'm a jerk" attitude. 

I'll definitely go back for the drinks and the poke wasabi bowl with Brown Rice.
author: Alyson C.

description:
Couple friends took us here to dinner on a Tuesday night.

I really like the decor of this place.  Love the modern look and they have nice outdoor seating with heat lamps.  

Service was great.  The guy was super friendly and attentive.  Once we sat down we got a nice little muchies of edamame and pretzels (I guess a little fusion there too).

We ordered the sake salmon sashimi, spicy tuna roll, grilled ahi tuna salad and ahi poke wasabi bowl.  The spicy tuna roll had plump pieces of tuna and rolled into a pretty good size roll.  The sake salmon sashimi however was a flop.  When the dish came, it was razor thin.  It tasted like kirkland smoked salmon from costco and the sauce was like watered down cream cheese, we had no clue where the sake infused part was.   Totally not worth the $9.  The salad and the rice bowl were delicious and a lot of food.  The ahi poke was flavorful with a wasabi-ginger sauce over warm rice, wakame and pickled veggies.  I will definitely order that again.

This place is a good sit down place with friends and we will come back here next time.
author: Yun W.

description: Arrived here for dinner.  Service was great, atmosphere was nice and the food was finger lickin good. Price is somewhat decent.  I ordered one of the wasabi bowls.  wasnt wasabi spicy, but they did have siracha on the table so a few squeeze of that will work.  The bowl came with a massive amount of rice.  I only ate half, too much rice is bad for the belly.  Overall i would come here again to try the other food on the menu.  The type of food they serve is a mixture of Japanese and Hawaiian.  Thumbs up Pacific Catch!
author: Mimi S.

description: I love usually get the Sushi Grade Ahi salad substituted with Hawaiian Poke with sweet potatoe fries, edamame, and Peruvian ceviche. The service is usually really fast and I never have to wait that long, esp if we have lunch around 2-3 instead of noon. I've never had any complaints for this place!
author: Tiffany P.

description:
I like that they have a list of fresh fish of the day which is always good when you go to a fish place expecting a big filet as your main dish, but not so good when most of the selection is more sushi-like and served as such. They do get much kudos for their sauce it was very good and I feel like if I swabbed anything in it I could eat it but alas I had to ask for extra sauce because there was not enough of it even to finish my serving.
It's definitely a family place although be weary a few will also bring their canine sons and daughters. After a long Bay to Breakers there's no better thinking than I want a good plate of seafood in my belly, but dont come here for that, lest you order at least half their menu to feel full. 
I also feel like the seating was designed for stick skinnies in mind because we couldn't sit comfortably on any of the high chair tables. Or maybe they just wanted us to sit at the bar. 
And thanks Pacific for the chex mix and green peas, that's exactly what I wanted right before dinner.
author: Jim L.

description: Definitely my favorite happy hour in the area -every Monday through Friday from 4-6 and after 10. The drinks are good, especailly  the margaritas, but the happy hour appetizers are what make it worth it. Try the sweet potato fries and raw tuna.
author: Amy T.

description:
WOW!!

When I walked into this place, didn't have very high expectations. Although there were a lot of people, the place was a little tacky. We sat down at the table lead by a host who wasn't friendly nor rude. But, when they served us their substitute for bread and butter, my expectations went way further down: their substitute was edamame beans and pretzel goldfish!! Although it's a cute idea to have goldfish at a place called pacific catch, it's a little cheap considering there are $8.95 sushi rolls!

I order the spicy tuna roll and this wasabi salmon salad thing, and I was IMPRESSED! The fish was unbelievably fresh, tasty and flavorful, and overall one of the best fishes I had in a while (both the spicy tuna and the salmon). Have already gone back a second time and I love it! But, beware of waitresses that won't come to your table for a whiiillleee.
author: Lauren G.

description: ever since they turned this place into pacific catch i promised myself i would never step foot here.  this place used to be The Canvas Gallery and it was my fav hang out. however, after looking for an hour for parking around this area and realizing that this was the only place that i have yet to try i finally gave in. plus i was hungry. i ordered their fish and chip which came with their sweet potato fries.  their fries were pretty good, but i guess it was a bad idea for me to concentrate too much on the fries and not the fish.  you can tell that their fish was fresh and not the frozen type. i was surprise that i didnt have to wait for a table being that it was a saturday.  however, i think the grease got to me, and i had to down some tea before my tummy goes the wrong direction. ifyou are not a seafood fan this is not the place for you.  if you are,  the prices are pretty reasonable and you should give this place a try.
author: Belinda C.

description: Pacific Catch is a trendy place to dine, the interior gets very noisy when the place is busy.  The food, service was good but the atmosphere is too noisy for a decent conversation for my comfort and the pricing high.
author: George L.

description:
PC=Plan C. 
My buddy had offered to treat me to din last weekend.
I was excited, but unfortunately had not planned ahead or settled on a place (yikes-I wondered where my refined palate could get in on a sat night). 
My 1st choice was too out of the way, my 2nd choice was booked up, but then as we drove past PC, we both perked up (as neither one of us had tried it and my friend raved bout the marina PC's sweet p fries).

It was strange to walk into what had formerly housed Canvas gallery and not see peeps lounging on couches or playing board games. 

We decided on one of the "catch of the day" along w/the three-way tuna. 
Our entrees arrived as we'd barely started on our appetizer and before our cocktails.  They offered to hold our entrees and we said "yes please!"
When our food came back,  our "jumbo" scallops,  were more on the petite size and our tuna was just ok. 
I think these folks may have too many items on the menu and should focus on fewer options. 
On a better note, my friend surprised me with brownie a la mode for dessert. 
That was the best part.
author: Sandrita R.

description:
I came to this place upon a recommendation for great fried sweet potatoes.  You know how it is, they are hard to find.  And so I ordered the fries, along with coconut shrimp and the kick ass seabass.  Must wash it all down with a Sierra Nevada.  

The food was great.  They came out super fast.  I mean minutes in the single digits.  And it was good.  Pretty good.  Shrimp was a little hard on the coconut shell.  

I must comment on the excellent service.  The guy was friendly and attentive.  

It was a good experience but nevertheless, I reserve 5 stars for the best.
author: L L.

description:
So a friend of mine says that only extreme views show up in ratings.  Well this is not an extreme view, just a recap of a decent (actually good) but not outstanding meal.

This space is very nice, and I was surprised that something so open was not too loud.  I felt very comfortable and conversation was easy.

The food was good.  No complaints, nothing really stood out, but I will be back.  My fried oysters were just right, the fries were nothing special.

The service was very prompt and efficient.

So I guess the net, net is pretty good, not great but fine and dandy.  I will go back.
author: David R.

description:
I have had two really good experiences here.  The first was during their happy hour.  The poke was delicious and they did not skimp.  

A few nights ago, our (well, my) lazy ass decided on take-out.  We had the spicy tuna sandwich and 3 tacos.  The bbq salmon taco was amazing.  Same with the crispy shrimp one.  Sandwich was what I expected- very yum.  

And what was really cool was the care they took in getting the order together.  Sides of two sauces- sweet chili and aioli- for the sweet potato fries.  

I guess they had my boyfriend waiting pretty long for the order, so the bartender bought him a beer.  V cool of them- especially since the bf is not the bitching type and was prob sweetly surprised by the freebie.  THAT'S the stuff people remember.
author: Staci M.

description:
A good friend of mine had his birthday celebration here about 2 weeks ago and it was my first time. I ain't gonna lie, money was kinda tight so I Yelped it (yeeh!) to find out what they had and how much it was gonna break me off. As I read reviews, I figured, not too bad.

I must say that the ambience is dope. Nice place to take a date because it don't get too loud, although they do have music (80's when I was there) playing on the p.a. system. It wasn't bothersome though.

I had the Pacific Fish & Chips which wasn't too shabby. It wasn't all that but it didn't suck. The sweet potatoe fries really broke it through the otherside for me. These wasn't your ordinary, run-of-the-mill sweet potato fries, they were crispy! The fish was alright. I wasn't feeling the little wire plate they served my meal on. So it was like a wire/mesh plate type deal which they covered with a piece of parchment paper that when I put malt vinegar on my fish, it made the paper all soggy. Boo.

Big up for the decor of the spot. Real nice like and original. The bathroom was clean. Not to mention that the place is baby friendly. My homies' daughter was there and she's 2 yrs. old and just started walking so she was up and about mingling with everybody. 

I'd probably come back...but not on the regular.
author: Ivan F.

description:
Lots of big bonus points for being so family friendly!  My husband and I prior to having a baby, would love to dine out and enjoyed a great meal in the neighborhood restaurants.  Now with a 16 month old toddler in tow, we still love to dine out, but have to be careful which restaurants we go to.  

Most SF restaurants are too small/cramped or do not have enough healthy variety for the kids menu.  Besides a great variety of delicious and healthy seafood items for adults, I was really happy with the Kid's menu selections.  Our son has a severe dairy and egg allergy, so most restaurants only have mac and cheese or things he can't eat.  I was thrilled to see a terriyaki rice bowl with chicken and steamed brocolli for him.  I know it doesn't sound exciting, but try being a parent with a poor child with allergies and you'd be excited too!

Other pluses is the size of the restaurant which translates into dining tables that are actually not smooshed so close together that you hit the other diner in the head with your butt.  Very friendly staff to parents.  Some places you feel out of place coming to with a toddler, here they help you open the front door for us with our stroller and the wait staff knew to bring out the kid's meal during appetizers so he could eat first.

Loved it!  Highly recommend to anyone with kid's.
author: Pam P.

description:
Can't say I've been to the original location so I can't compare but I thought Pacific Catch was pretty good nonetheless. 
I had the fish and chips with the catch of the day. Quite good, extremely fresh fish (would be scared if it wasn't!). The dipping sauces added something special to the fish, which was fresh but not overwhelmingly tasty on its own, so I do recommend giving them a try (the Thai one especially). Sweet potato fries were fantastic, definitely the standout original of my meal. Probably the one thing that would get me coming back to Pacific Catch again!

I also tried a bit of the sushi, just California Roll and Spicy Tuna. Nothing special, so I can't speak for the quality of the specialty pieces, but if I was looking for quality basics or specialties... I'd just go out for some sushi! So decent sushi but not worth the price when there are much better options within walking distance. Also had a good beer from the rotating selection but it was almost $6!

So all in all, good food. Very good choice if you want a broad selection of choices on the menu, all with very fresh fish. The place seemed pretty popular on a Friday night, very trendy and nice setting. Service wasn't fantastic: very friendly, but took a while just to get water. Busy night though. For the negatives, can't recommend the sushi as a standout and the food wasn't special enough to be paying more than a 10-er for each dish (even the salads). Still. Great sweet potato fries. And sauces.
author: Taylor M.

description:
Their original location is a bit better in terms of quality and preparation, IMHO.

Shame their prices went up because this was one of my 'tried & true' spots....Still, Wasabi bowl is great...Seasoned fries trump the sweet potato ones, for me.

Word to the wise, eating in always is better than carry out
author: Barca F.

description: Wow the service was bad.  Food was ok - not great... I would have given a probably 3 stars for food and proximity but the absolute lack of service... wow.  if this was a play it'd be les miz.  heavy on the miz.
author: Bradford H.

description:
the sweet potato fries ARE really good!  i liked the sweet and sour sauce that comes with it.  california rolls are excellent, my crab salad wasabi bowl was excellent, and my friends poke bowl was excellent!  
bartender was a really nice guy as well!  oh! and the spring roll for dessert is excellent toooo!!!
author: Soph I.

description:
Just came from  another nice dinner at Pacific Catch
I hate sweet potato   even  do not put it TG table , but Sweet potato fries there are soo tasty!Also had grilled snapper - that was 8 out of 10 (still pretty good )
I love this place . not saying that is superb - but very very good
And great place to go with kids too. 
B+ for all .
author: Lena M.

description:
the restaurant is pretty big and you have your choices to sit in the main area, bar, or al fresco.

i absolutely love their poke wasabi bowl.  i don't think i would veer off to any other option on the menu.
author: Sheri N.

description:
I like this place. the prices are good; there's a full bar, the tacos are good, so are the rice bowls, the sushi, the brown rice option, the mochi ball dessert for $1.5 is awesome! Their salads are really good! 

Their sandwiches are really good

I always end up regretting getting their dinner plates, but I am always satisfied with their tacos, sandwiches or salads! 

I HATE their fish & chips! Their fried oysters are OK though... 

The service is usually friendly and fast! (they get 4 stars, because they take reservations and the service is better than the other one!)
author: Maddy S.

description: It was my first time here tonight and everything was superb!  While my husband, brother, my son (sleeping in his stroller) and I were waiting for our table the manager was so kind to offer us a table by the bar to wait and enjoy our cocktail.  I ordered the Hawaiian Poki ric bowl, my husband and brother ordered the mix catch we were all very satisfied!  The waitresses were all so attentive wish other restaurants have employees like the ones here at Pacific Catch.  I highly recommend coming here they are super family friendly.  Can't wait to go back and try other items on their menu.  Thank you to the team at Pacific Catch for an amazing first time experience!
author: Mrs. F.

description: Awesome food!!! Great service!!! Try the Hawaiian poke and the Pacific Punch :)
author: B M.

description: Simply put, good seafood at a reasonable price.  Everything from the spicy mahi mahi sandwich to the tuna tekka don is good.  The new location on 9th can handle large groups but tends to get blogged down around dinner time.  You can thank the hoards of tourists scrambling for grub before tackling the City's exit points.
author: MTBer I.

description:
Went here for the first time a few days ago and was pretty satisfied. I had the salmon sandwich with a side of sweet potato fries and my pals had 2 salads. Salmon was just right for my sandwich and the roll it came on was pretty good as well, definitely makes the sandwich better than just any ordinary bread. The sweet potato fries were great as well, and they came with some sort of tasty honey mustard dipping sauce.

The salads my friends had looked pretty tasty as well, I will probably have one myself next time I return here. Another great point is the bottomless Thai Iced tea they serve here, I drank so much of it I was sweating thai iced tea later that day.
author: Vilen G.

description: Food was delicious.  Poke trio dish was a twist on familiar hawaiian style poke that I grew up with in Hawaii.  Service was friendly and timely, which was important because we had to be at an event on time.  Tween kids ordered from the kids menu and our party of 5 all said our food was very tasty.
author: R L.

description:
Went for a nice dinner out with the hubby. He had the Surf & Turf with asparagus. Nicely cooked & flavored. I had shrimp & fish tacos with black beans. I didn't enjoy it much, but did like the pretzel goldfishes & edamame served at the start of the meal. And then was dessert...we chose the brownie a la mode & uh...won't have it again.

I really miss The Canvas...but a nice turnout & change for the Sunset. I'll try Pacific Catch again since my friend was raving about the rice bowls & Japanese dishes. I guess the good tip here is stay away from the Mexican style dishes from here...too Americanized. The prices a little too high for the food, but presentation counts?!?

I'll visit again. Nice environment & vibe. Cool a$$ servers.
author: L S.

description:
I will definitely be going back for the happy hour! 

We sat in the bar/lounge area and all three adorable bartenders waited on us. We had the delicious Hawaiian Poke (so good we ordered another one). My friend had a mai tai, I had gin & tonics. All the drinks were really stiff. Felt like we were getting our moneys worth. 

The prices during happy hour were great! Fresh fish for $4.50!? I was skeptical about the $4 well drinks (sounded pricey for a happy hour), but their 'well' alcohol is way decent. We also ate the sweet potato fries which were great and come with tasty dips, and the edamame, which was yawn. I guess you can't win 'em all.
author: Leslie S.

description:
Hell yeah, this food was delicious!  The wasabi bowl comes with sushi rice, avocado, wakame salad, fresh ginger and wasabi, all kinds of other stuff...and beautiful salmon and tobiko.  It was sooo good i stuffed myself to the brim. And the Island Mint cocktail had fresh guava juice, so so refreshing!

The price is fair, appropriate for the food.  I only gave it four stars because it is a bit of a family style place trying to be trendy.  I don't got family out here so wasn't necessarily my cuppa tea...but all in all I loved it and am definitely going back soon!
author: Hella M.

description:
Had dinner here last night with some old friends. It's a good place to catch up with people, have some drinks, and/or take the family for a casual dinner. 

Food:
You MUST order the sweet potato fries. Yes, sounds so simple, but they are crisp, slightly sweet, and not greasy at all. The fried oysters are good as well, batter is light and crisp and the oyster is still plump and juicy. You can still taste the oyster...
The Poke was ok. It was fresh but lacked a bit of seasoning. also, they threw in a couple of chunks that had a lot of sinew in it, and if you've read my previous review, i LOATHE sinew in raw fish.
For dessert we got the mochi with ice cream dipped in hot chocolate sauce, can you say YUM-O?!?!

They have a small parking lot on Lincoln. Make reservations.
author: Kat T.

description: Over the years, I have seen this location transform from an empty building to a coffee shop/bar, to this current seafood restaurant. After a quick bite to eat across the street, we walked over here for happy hour. It seems to cater to the after work crowd and they deliver on the cheap foods. After the wonderful smell of fried calamari on the roof of the Academy of Sciences, I craved the fried appetizer here. They make it decent here with an aioli dip. Don't be food by the fried lemon, it doesn't taste great. We also tried the sweet potato fries, which is served with an interest sweet and sour sauce. Never had sweet potato fries with that before, but it was pretty good. At $3 for a huge basket, it's hard to beat. The Hawaiian poke was also decent. I tried the Alaskan Oatmeal Stout just because it sounded interesting. At first glance, it was a dark beer, but didn't taste dark at all, which was good for me. Overall, it was good, but I didn't get much of a chance to taste much of the Asian fusion seafood, which makes up much of their menu. Happy hour prices are decent, but it doesn't really showcase fish much other than the tuna.
author: Bailey Z.

description: My boyfriend and I have been coming in here at least once a week for the past couple of months.  We choose to sit in the bar where it seems to be a cozier atmosphere than in the main restaurant.  We are always given menus and order is taken right away.  The bartenders are very friendly and the service is spot on.  The Hawaiian Poke appetizer and the mixed catch basket with sweet potato fries are definitely our favorites.  When it comes to drinks, the Dark and Stormy is delicious and has quite a kick!   They have happy hour after 10pm with good deals off the bar menu.  Parking in the area is sometimes difficult but I'd definitely consider it worth it.
author: Dominique K.

description: The perfect meal for me when coming to Pacific Catch is as follows. A starter of Calamari, which is my favorite starter anywhere, meaning I get  picky and Pacific Catch makes them well. If I am with company I will usually add the Hawaiian Poke; both to share of course. Now for the main course I will almost always go for the Crispy Oysters. I can say honestly that I have tried everything on their menu and I continue going back to the Oysters. Now I am a big Oyster fan and I love how they prepare them. The fish and chips are a signature goodie and there are great things to explore on the menu. They have something for everyone. Now for dessert and I'm not joking when I say this, they have the best dessert I have ever tasted. I will go there just for their dulce de leche spring rolls, they are out of this world. They are the reason Pacific Catch goes from 4 to 5 stars for me. The service is great and they are super attentive to the customers needs. Just a great semi-casual place. Good for kids and adults alike. Just some more good eats on Ninth Ave.
author: Anna B.

description:
I have been here on a number of occasions (i.e. the bigger restaurant in the Sunset -- I have never been to the original hole-in-the-wall place in the Marina) and I remain unconvinced & on-the-fence about the place.

The location is in a well-trafficked area near a main entrance to Golden Gate Park and in the busy 9th & Irving area of the Sunset. It's a big, comfortable-looking restaurant with a large-ish bar area facing the Park. The menu has a large selection of seafood dishes (as the restaurant name would suggest) done in a variety of fusion-ish ways. Some of these are predictable, and in my experience, not that exciting. I have had the Fish & Chips and the Fish Tacos in the past, and I wasnt very impressed by either. (Big portions... though on the flip-side, the prices are on the high side.) However, I was very impressed by some of the more unusual and interesting dishes. In particular, the different Rice Bowl options are very good. I have become addicted to the  Hawaiian Poke Rice Bowl & Brown Rice. VERY tasty, and it feels healthy, with its variety of veggies and carbs (though it probably isnt!)

The place itself feels a bit impersonal - especially, the large restaurant area. It has the feel (just a bit...) of a suburban Red Lobster or TGI Friday's. (Not anything like as cheezy -- but there's a sense of it - not a good thing in an area where there are so many other places that do have personality & character.) The bar feels a bit better - tho the quality of the wait-staff & bartenders is hit-and-miss. 

So - definitely ambivalent about the place, and typically, the price-tab for a meal is a bit on the high side  - but Pacific Catch has its upsides. I remain hopeful, but unconvinced about it.
author: donal c.

description: Came here to celebrate my bday. Service was ok though we got sat in the back corner and it smelled like dirty mop water. Server was nice but very busy. Asked for water several times never got it. I will not be going back to this location.
author: Giovanni L.

description: I love this place. The fish is awesome, and the decor is beautiful. It's located not far from the Academy of Sciences building, so I've had fun with friends visiting the sciences museum then coming to Pacific Catch for lunch or dinner. I've always had good service, and the food has been excellent.
author: Jim T.

description:
+ Mahi Mahi fish tacos
+ Grilled Asparagus w/ wasabi mayo dip
+ Sweet Potato Fries
+ Lemongrass Mojitos
author: Tulip F.

description: Hawaiian Poke Wasabi Bowl and the Fish Tacos are AMAZING! The service is also great. The only downfall is that we brought a cake and their charged us $2 per person for a cutting fee, which  we weren't told of prior to and we were shocked when we saw the bill. The cuttings fees ended up costing more than the cake. Luckily, I love their service and food.
author: Joe d.

description:
Two words: wasabi bowl.  I'm pretty sure they're lacing the rice with something, let's just say...it's delicious.

This new location boasts some huge advantages over the marina locale: 1) it's not in the marina 2) it is MUCH more spacious, no more waiting for one of 4 tables at which point you are sitting on top of your neighbor 3) you can walk off that huge wasabi bowl across the street in golden gate park

Prices are reasonable, portions are large, and the staff is friendly.  They're still new, so give it a little time to work it all out, but definitely a place to check out!
author: Liz Y.

description:
Eh, tasted like a TGIF's if it dealt with fish.  Service was fantastic - but very chain-esque.

Will not go again.
author: Sofia M.

description: Can we say stellar cocktail, and Thank Goodness for Parking!!!  Well, that is what I would say if I were to go back.  Their cocktails are absolutely delicious and strong!  Strong in the way that it doesnt taste like you are doing a shot, but that when you are done you are so glad for once you got a drink that at least had some of the alcohol you paid for it to have in it!  The food is ok...not something I would rush out and get as their prices a tad high for what you get.  I would love to go back for Happy Hour and get some apps.
author: Adrienne B.

description: This place was designed to be tourist trap.  First restaurant you see walking over from GG Park.  Reminds me of a Midwest seafood chain, Red Lobster fused with Panda Express maybe.  Or at best, Joe's Crab Shack meets PF Chang.  Highlight is the bar with good cocktails and nice atmosphere.  The beer selection could be better.  Worth a stop in for a drink on the patio on a warm day.  The bar tenders are cool.  The servers are not very welcoming.
author: Ryan S.

description: Good food. Good service. Nuff said.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
i finally get to visit this location of pacific catch.  it is much roomier and less claustrophobic than the marina location but service is still a bit shotty and slow.

we opted to sit in the "bar area" to the left of the entrance upon walking in.  the tables are smaller but beats waiting 20 minutes.  there were a lot of tables open when we walked in but i guess they were reserved.

they said they would give us menus but we had to ask and the table next to us who got seated afterwards got their menus before us.  then they told us they ran out of menus. 

they have a full bar.  i had a guava drink which was delicious.  they also have additional items on their menu that dont appear on the marina menu.

we had a basket of sweet potato fries, fried calamari, shrimp ceviche to share.  the shrimp should have been cut up for easier scooping with provided chips.  i then had the ahi poke wasabi bowl which was very good.  but i was so full from our appetizers that i had to take it home.

our waiter was also a bartender so we had to wait to get his attention. o well.
author: claudia y.

description:
the drinks here pack a punch. 

there was this bar in thailand, where tables are gathered around a boxing ring and you can go in and fight other patrons for a bucket drink on the house (around $10 in value. a plastic bucket filled with red bull, coke and whisky).  don't quite know if it's worth it, when you're handed that drink at the end and all you really wanted was to get that busted lip looked at and the piece of scraped skin back on your shoulder.  

but this place is the opposite.  you get knocked out by the drink.  not get knocked out, then have the drink poured on you.  i dig that.
author: Andrew P.

description:
This tops the list as one of the worst restaurants I have ever been to. My boyfriend and I came on a Friday afternoon for lunch. The inside was cute, but it was freezing (not really a big deal). I ordered the grilled mahi mahi tacos and my boyfriend ordered the coconut shrimp and fish & chips. Our waitress came out with a mahi mahi sandwich, but she quickly brought it back in because I wanted the tacos. When I finally received the tacos, I took a bite, and immediately discovered that the rub on the mahi mahi was kind of yucky... Oh well... I just continued eating, but then I noticed that they left out the avocado and instead of chipotle Crema, they gave me a little drizzle of sour cream AND they never gave me a side of black beans. At this point, I was annoyed and I didn't want it anymore, so I told my boyfriend to try it. He took a couple bites and hated it. So I told her what had been left out and that I didn't like the taco, so she asked me if I wanted a side of avocado.... NO I DON'T!!! ( I didn't yell, I was nice). So she tried giving me the old mahi mahi sandwich ( oh yeah! I want an old soggy sandwich... what a smart girl!) I obviously said no. She asked me if I wanted something else, so I ordered the fried calamari. She asked if my boyfriend wanted the other taco I had left, but he din't, so she took it back with my new order. Then out came the calamari and it was okay ( you can't really mess that up). It would have been better if wasn't swimming in oil, though! EW! 

After we had finished eating, she came over with the check and didn't say a word..... she had the nerve to charge me for half of my other meal when it didn't even come to me complete!! Instead of complaining, we figured her tip could cover the sneaky little half charge she added on to our check.

All was not bad... I tried my boyfriends coconut shrimp and hey were delicious, but not enough to come back to this crappy place.
author: Lauren D.

description:
Just had dinner here. Have been here on more than one occasion but find that the service and the food quality is going down hill. 

First, we ordered the sweet potato fries which are usually pretty good, but they were soggy and not particularly hot. 

Second, we ordered hot tea and waited about 10 minutes before the waiter came back to tell us that it was being brewed and would we mind drinking a different tea "to tide us over until it was ready"? We were ok with that but he never offered us the regular tea after that.

Third, we waited a VERY long time (close to 40 min) for our meal. We ordered about 5 minutes after the couple on one side of us and they were done before we even got our meals. The couple on the other side of us came about 20 minutes after us and got their meal at the same time.

Very disappointed at the poor organization and food service.
author: Mz S.

description:
this place is good if you want something fast and light.

the oysters are good dipped in their special sauce hmm oh so good..

their sweet potatoe fries yummo can't say no to that one. if you're going to be eating at pacific catch you should get the sweet potatoe fries and the oysters so good.

i tried the fish tacos its good but too messy lol...
author: Junel L.

description:
After people get off the N Judah at Irving and 9th, they walk down 9th looking for a good meal before they head into the park. The wait at Ebisu is too long, they're not in the mood for ramen or Indian Food and Park Chow is too crowded. So they end up at Pacific Catch. That is the ONLY reason anyone goes to this place.

Blech!
author: Jenny J.

description: very small inside but i decided to eat outside. The price is are very cheap in my opinion. I had the ahi tuna rice bowl. AMAZING. The service was outstanding aswell. Very friendly staff.
author: Samantha W.

description: Plenty of seating, quick waitstaff, and tasty food. What isn't to like about Pacific Catch? This restaurant gets the job done when it comes to seafood. My go-to items are the mahi mahi terriyaki rice bowl or the mahi mahi sandwich. The same dishes are available with salmon, but I prefer mahi mahi. Nice grilled vegetables go with the plates to ease your health consciousness.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
Alas, the much-anticipated Pacific Catch has finally reached the Inner Sunset!  Though The Canvas served up delicious lemon bars and ambiance conducive for a late afternoon catch-up with a close friend, Pacific Catch seems to round off the 9th Ave area perfectly by joining the ranks of cheap eats like Park Chow, Hotei and Pluto's.

Desiring for a guilt-free meal at times, my husband and I used to trek to the Chestnut location to treat ourselves to their ahi-tuna or hawaiian poke salads.  Now, ask anyone close to me, and they will affirm that my palette is adamantly of the anti-salad mode, but Pacific Catch's hawaiian poke salad has converted me.  The salads are HUGE, comprised of a generous helping of rare hawaiian poke atop a bed of mixed greens garnished generously with slices of avocado, a handful of baby tomatoes, a healthy sprig of daikon sprouts, shredded carrots in a joyous, unassuming soy-wasabi vinaigrette.

If you're doubtful that the salad won't quench your appetite, order a side order of their sweet potato fries to push you just over the edge.  These crispy, subtly sweet fries score big on their own, but what knocks them out of the ballpark for me is the sweet chili dipping sauce.  For those who enjoy variety (as my hubby and I do!), they also have a wasabi-aioli dipping sauce too.

Just when we thought Pacific Catch couldn't impress us anymore, today we tried their fried dulce de leche 'spring rolls' for a sweet finish to our already yummy meal.  W-O-W!!  That's all I have to say.  It was a sweet perfection of texture and flavor that honestly, you won't comprehend unless you experience it yourself.  The warmth of the deep fried outside and the contrast with the vanilla ice cream that it's served with is an absolute wonder in the mouth.  And that's not even taking note of the dulce de leche and mascarpone in the middle of the deep fried bliss.  

Don't miss out on this place!  It offers a ton of variety so you're never bored and there's always something new to tempt your tastebuds.
author: Jana H.

description:
i think this place got into its groove, because we loved everything we ordered. it began with the irony of  a cute lil' lezzie hostess (at a fish joint, get it?)...and ended with delish miso bowls and fish tacos.  I'm definitely going back.  
minus one star for the waitress describing the chenin blanc we ordered as 'fruity and crisp.' I mean, duh.  My summa-cum-sommelier friend wasn't impressed.
author: Rachel D.

description:
I usually come to Pacific Catch for the happy hour. They have two, one at 4-6pm, and one from 10pm til late. The happy hour menu is pretty nice. I usually order the Hawaiian Poke and Spicey Tuna roll. The calamari and Sweet Potato fries aren't bad either.

I wouldn't recommend coming for a regular meal as they get more pricey for the amount you get.
author: Daria M.

description:
I've been to this restaurant 4 times and usually have a good time.  But I had a horrible experience this last time - Sept. 21, 2008.  We called ahead to make reservations & told the hostess that it was my mom's birthday.  When we arrived, the hostess sat us at the table near the bathrooms.  There were 4 adults in our party so we then asked for the corner table so we could have more privacy.  They told us the corner table was reserved for a larger party.  On our way out after lunch, we passed the "reserved table" and saw 2 adults and 2 little kids at the table.  We were pissed!
Anyway, the unagi wasabi bowl, which I usually liked, was not good.  Too much vinegar on the unagi and sauce! Ugh!  My BFF had the oysters, which were small - not worth the money!  He said he'll never go to this restaurant again!
author: Chilly W.

description: nothing wrong with the service or the atmosphere but i wouldn't come back here for the food. it was all a little wrong. the sushi rice was crunchy. crab soup too salty and lukewarm. sweet spare ribs quite fatty. and lastly, the poke is served on rice (really? after living in hawaii for most of my life, this is something i have yet to see).  we had other dishes but they were so underwhelming i can't even remember them.  the only redeeming factor about the food was the drinks (because alcohol is liquid sustenance). so props to the bar tender for saving the day. and to our waitress who did the best she could to serve our rowdy party bunch.
author: Catherine A.

description: This place is near where I work so I've been here several times. Some items I have tried here: the Hawaiian Poke, Wasabi Rice Bowls (which is a freaking large portion), side of Pineapple rice, the Mixed Catch Basket, the calamari, the sweet potato fries, etc etc. Everything is great. I would highly recommend any of these items!
author: Jennifer H.

description: I've been dining here, for a few years, and have never ordered anything but the Poke Wasabi Bowl!  Ridiculous I know, but it is so f-ing gooood - I can't bring myself to order anything else!  Sushi rice, topped with perfectly marinated tuna morsels, avocado, wakame salad, daikon sprouts, ginger and their tasty soy-wasabi sauce.  The deliciousness is completely unfair, because they always have great specials, which I ignore.  The dinner salad is fantastic - love the shitakes, edamame, and that miso dressing!  PC provides a nicely designed dining room, plus attentive and friendly service, along with a magical view of the park?!  Yeah, pretty damn great, and the prices are tres reasonable!
author: Loretta G.

description: The fish is very good. But the price is a high. For example, I would have given 5 stars if the daily fish special was like $12, but it was around $15.
author: Miguel T.

description:
Came here without a reservation for Mother's Day dinner. Only a 20 minute wait! Not bad.

Food:
-California Crab & Avocado salad: Pretty good. It tastes like it sounds -- a salad version of a california roll. I probably wouldn't eat the WHOLE thing as a meal though because it's too much of the same thing.
-Korean BBQ Steak: YUM I love beef! This was my choice, so I liked it. If you're looking for the real deal when it comes to Korean BBQ, then obviously it doesn't size up, but the beef was perfection.
-Alaskan 3-course meal w/ halibut skewers, salmon entree, and merengue & berries: They have a special 3-course meal highlighting the cuisine of places around the Pacific, so when I went, it was Alaska. I liked the skewers, especially the sauce. Even though it was battered & fried, it felt really light. The salmon was just ok -- nothing special. Didn't like the liquor-soaked ligonberries. The dessert was PERFECTION! Great balance of textures & flavors.
-Alaskan Stout: I hate dark beers, so of course, I wasn't too fond of this. My parents liked it though.

One of the nicer, bigger places to eat at in the Sunset but if you're looking for a date place, I wouldn't go here. It gets really loud! That could be due to the number of families w/ young kids dining there on Mother's Day though.
author: Miss H.

description:
Oh, Pacific Catch, how did I go so long without you in my life? This is now my current favorite restaurant in the Inner Sunset.  Despite being right under my nose, it took me something like 2 years before I tried this gem, and now I'm hooked.

The normal menu is brilliant.  I love how they have similar fish/flavor combinations available in different forms depending on if you are in the mood for a salad, a sandwich, or a 'bowl'. The "Wasabi Ahi" sandwich or salad are my usual faves.

The daily specials are really nice too.  Ask about the different "side styles" since they will let you change the "style" if you'd prefer something different.  Periodically, they have a special "regional" 3 course menu.  For example, currently it's Chilean-inspired for Restaurant Week, but I've tried the Vietnamese ones as well.

The service here is amazingly wonderful.  For awhile we kept getting the same waiter who remembered us after our first visit.  We thought it was just him, but as we got other servers we received similarly great service.

The space has a nice modern yet inviting decor.  The main dining room has lots of seating alongside the kitchen, so reservations aren't really needed.  If you make reservations (or if it's slow), you can get slightly nicer and roomier table/booth near the windows.  If they are busy or want a more casual vibe, you can usually grab a table in the bar area.  The bar area is also open later with a bar bites menu and late night happy hour everyday.

Only complainant is that when they opened they painted over the sweet street art that used to cover the entire wall alongside their parking lot! ;)
author: Jared D.

description:
i used to go to the location in the marina a lot, and i always liked it.  i came to this location for the first time yesterday and was surprised by how big the place was and how it's actually like a real restaurant as opposed to a hole in the wall!  

i had the ahi poke sushi bowl, which was yummy of course.  it's great that they give you the choice of brown rice, since they give you a bowl of the rice big enuf to feed a family of 4.  

i came w/ my fiance, who is veg, so there weren't many options for him, but he had the sweet potato fries, corn on the cob, and edamame.  they should have more veg options here other than side orders and one veg sushi roll.
author: Helen T.

description: This was our first time at Pacific Catch. We decided to try it based on the great reviews. We were seated at a small table, stuffed in the corner, in the bar. The tables are very small in the bar. So small, we had a tough time juggling dishes for our appetizer and also our entrees. Also, the shape of the tables are not comfortable to sit. They have an awkward base/leg to them, which force you to straddle the table, sit side-ways, or hit your knees. Overall, the experience was average. We aren't planning to rush out and try the restaurant again, any time soon.
author: Cster x.

description: good good food and service! the hawaiian poke salad was sooo good!!!
author: Maria S.

description: This place is good. You should believe me because I love food immensely. You should believe that because food makes me immense. I have ordered the sushi with great results and you cannot go wrong with the teriyaki bowls. Of course, as everyone says, the sweet potato fries are the best- nice and thin and crisp and yummy. My fellow dining companions on multiple occasions have always gone for the fish and chips/taco combos and rave about them. The miso soup tastes homemade and hearty. You can order it with shitake mushrooms and asparagus added to it. Their pisco sour is rivaled only by NOPA's. Friendly waitstaff who don't look like they hate their job, and even act as though they might like it. Good vibes, nice atmosphere.
author: Anna S.

description: I ordered the fish tacos and they were pretty good but not great.  The sweet potato fries were a nice option.  The kids did not seem to be fond of their kid meals but it is always hit or miss with them anyway.  The service was good and there was ample seating.  I would definitely give this place another chance since some of their other menu items looked pretty good.  Other pluses include a small parking lot and conveniently located within walking distnace of the main attractions at Golden Gate Park.
author: Julie D.

description: Why do i keep going back?  6 months ago i went back...it took an hour from the time we placed our order to get our food.  Since the food was pretty good at that time, i ventured back recently.  This time it took about 30 minutes to get our food and when we did my wasabi bowl was full of overcooked rice.  It was SO overcooked that the grains were no longer individual and it was just a solid lump of rice goo. Not sexy.
author: Freedy H.

description: the breakdown of the 4 stars: 3 for the korean sticky ribs and 5 for the hawaiian poke half-half bowl for an average of 4. let's start with the bad...the "ribs" were tough, not melting off the bone like i had envisioned. they looked and tasted more like pork chops than ribs. the best part of the appetizer was the sweet sticky sauce. not too salty with lots of flavor. now to the gooooood...and it's pretty damn good. the hawaiian poke over half brown rice and half greens has become my go-to healthy meal now. like a japanese style bibimbap, it's loaded with seaweed salad, pickled ginger, avocado slices, and big chunks of yummy poke. are you salivating yet??
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Simply put, my favorite place to eat in the city. Everything tastes great!  They have a rotating menu and emphasize different ethnic foods at different times of the year.  Have I mentioned how fantastic the food is?  Anybody can find something to eat here, even if you're not a big seafood person. 

The atmosphere is a little confusing to the senses, because on the one hand it has definite Asian influences, yet it has a contemporary American feel to it as well.  Due to the rotating seasonal menus, you can find anything from edamame to burritos to sweet potato fries on the menu.  However, it doesn't really matter what you pick to eat, or how confusing the menu feels, because it all tastes fantastic, and they pull it all together very well.
author: Anthony D.

description: Love this place. Definitely my go to place in the sunset for happy hour and a quick bite. Their ceviche is excellent!  Nice and spicy. Wish they didn't serve it with the yam chips, adds a little too much grease but that's a picky point.  Happy Hour deals are very good.  Less impressed with their kids meals as far as flavor goes but my kid is a foodie, if your child likes bland mildly flavored foods, then you're good.  Their poke is very good and probably my favorite meal here.
author: Halima T.

description:
i would like to start off by pointing out that pacific catch is not the big bad wolf responsible for the closing of canvas gallery.  this is an untruth, and in fact, canvas gallery originally opened to showcase the artwork of the owner's wife.  guess whose paintings now hang on the walls of this renovated space?  that's right.  the wife of the owner of canvas gallery.  interesting, hmmn?  yeah, i thought so too.

the space here is incredible.  from the pretty long bar with original and unique cocktails (lemongrass mojito, anyone?) to the vaulted celings with beautiful fixtures, this place has a truly modern and sassy yet comforting feel to it. beware that if you are coming in on a friday or saturday night, you might want to make a reservation or be prepared to wait for 45-1 hour at the bar if you don't.
