there are additions to the menu here different from the chestnut street and corte madera locations, and all of them looked wonderful, but my friend and i decided to stick with the basics as we have been to the other locations countless times and have our favorites.  these are as follows: poke appetizer - if you have not had this dish you are seriously missing out on some wonderful flavor / fish tacos - i usually get a 'catch of the day', a mahi-mahi and one chicken taco to mix it up, all with the famous sweet potato fries / dulche de leche spring rolls - i have no words for how addictive and delicious this little dessert is... you MUST TRY IT:/

service ran smooth, our wine pours were generous, and in all i was really impressed that PC  has managed to make a nice changeover from the fast sit down/take-out marina locale to a more traditional style of dining.  i definitely want to come back with a larger party and try some more of the new cocktails and maybe even be adventurous enough to order something new...
author: Karen K.

description:
My immediate thought upon receiving a call from the manager telling me I didn't get the job: "F#*& I didn't get the job!". 

My immediate thought upon walking out of this place after actually coming in here and trying out the food: "F#*& I didn't get the job!".

I'll be going back ^_^
author: Mike A.

description: How bad can it get, but a bad first impression.  Went for dinner, they were not to busy, asked to sit by a table by the window, hostess said that station was closed even though there were seated tables next to it.  Next we are seated and did not see our waitress for 10 mins.  Did not offer any of the daily specials, had to read them on the board ourselves.  Took another 10 minutes for our drinks, which were very good.  Dinner order 20 minutes.  The food was delivered by the food runner who was excellent, sorry did not get his name.  The food was ok but not outstanding.  The waitress never checked to see how we were doing or ask if we needed another drink.  Had to order from the food runner.  Did not see the waitres again till she brought the check after the runner cleared the table, she did not even offer dessert.  It was very annoying watching her and the other servers play around when they should have been paying attention to their customers.  Bottom line no tip to the waitress, $ 20.00 tip to the runner.  Can be sure we will not be returning.
author: Steve R.

description:
hmmm, i do love their pomegranate martinis...

the mood is open and casual.  it's unassuming and friendly to families and big groups with choices of seating at the bar, tables and chairs or comfy booths.  

well, since i was not on a liquid diet yet, i had to sample their menu.

thanks to yelpers, i did read up a bit on what to order.

the grilled artichoke was good but yes, do order the sweet potato fries.  i couldn't choose between the two dipping sauces so i compromised on dipping into both.  
the hawaiian poke sashimi was a close second to the fries.

for entrees, i do recommend the korean bbq skirt steak and  the unagi wasabi bowl - we added grilled fresh salmon to it.
i had the giant scallops which had a jerk chicken like seasoning.  so if you aren't into kicky spices, then this is not the dish for you.  the menu is pretty extensive so there is something for everyone.

we ended the evening with the fried dulce de leche spring rolls which were delish.  next time, i'll have to come back and order the passion mango cheesecake.

parking is tough in the neighborhood but there is a lot a block away.  frankly, i rather pony up for the parking and be sipping on their yummy martinis than circling the block.
author: Anh V.

description:
Strictly gringo.
Good friends, good company, but not for good people who know good food.
It's a great location, so I can't imagine it can fail, especially with the "Happy Hour" 1/2-offs on some of their appetizers, and I would eat here again, possibly, if I were at the De Young or CAS and in a hurry, but it is palatable and little more.
We had Ahi Poke, which I always love for its memories of Kauai, but it was sloppily cut, with quite a bit of stringy "tuna floss" to chew through.  That appeared again in the Spicy Tuna Rolls.  Both the latter and the Rock n Roll were crude creations I could easily have made better at home.  Our Warm Edamame were covered in what looked to be Hawaiian salt, WAY too much of it, even for my salt-loving son, and even the Thai Iced Tea was just not right.
I think if people haven't enjoyed much good quality Pacific Rim cuisine they could enjoy the Coconut Shrimp and other selections, and the portions are fairly large (remember that word "crude" in the last paragraph?).  Probably a better idea is to come here for a couple of beers during Happy Hour and call it a day.
author: Kimberly V.

description:
so many memories of studying over beers, hanging out with hawt law and medical students, attending cool as hell art and music shows...i am sorry.  when i accepted an invitation to the place that took away my precious canvas, well- let's just say i was not all nice and happy to the staff.

all the servers were bubbly and attentive, the space was renovated only in minor ways as the original,open shell design didn't need much to accommodate a dining spot.

lets talk food...the fish tacos were mediocre, over-seasoned and dry.. BUT the POKE(sounds out like "po-keh," you're welcome round-eye!) bowl was amazingly delicious.  i was flat-out stunned that they actually used limu kohou, which is the utmost vital ingredient for real local kine taste- along with just the right amount of sesame oil. 

close your eyes, think of the ocean, take a bite...and i bet you will feel you are at a local spot in hawaii. 

2 stars for the poke bowl- which is a value for the quality ahi and is actually enough to share for two.  1 star for the smart, pragmatic placement of the bar area right in the front, left side of the space for passerby to peep.

don't be mad pacific catch, i almost didn't review you at all for taking away what was a choice, go-to spot in the 'set.
author: omar b.

description:
I took a friend to there for his birthday.  We got seated right away, but of course it was mid-week.  Nonetheless, the waiter was very friendly and attentive.  The place was cozy.  I had the baja tacos and it was tasty.  For dessert, you got to try the mochi ( chocolate, cofffee and vanilla) dipped into a warm chocolate sauce.

Thumbs up.
author: Dan G.

description: Went here last night and this place has it going on. When you walk in the staff greets you with a very friendly hello. We did not have reservations but they seated us in quick order. Appetizers were good, but the fish is off the hook (sorry) very fresh and prepared to perfection.
author: Larry R.

description: I LOVE Pacific Catch!  I come down to the Bay area every few weeks to sell wine for my winery and usually stop into Pacific Catch for an amazing lunch.  I have been here a minimum of five times and every single time it has been great!  I am thoroughly addicted to their Ceviche Trio.  Some people do crack I do their Ceviche.  I also love their bowls and sandwiches.  The service is always super fast and extremely friendly.  There seafood is pristine and their Mai Tais rock!
author: Francois d.

description: I passed by this place almost every day, and been thinking to visit for quite sometime now. Tonight, I finally did, and was pretty disappointed. Maybe it was my wrong choice that made my visit un-worthwhile. I had the Thai coconut prawn, very dry, overcooked and doesn't taste fresh at all. I also had the Teriyaki Bowl with Mahi-mahi. For $13.95, they should give more mahi-mahi.. this is just mahiiiiiiiiiiii. $32 for two, tummy not happy.
author: Marlis T.

description:
Very nice place to go, especially with kids.

The fish-n-chips was really  nice - flaky fish with a light batter.

I had two fish tacos, also very nice.   I got the spicy sweet potato fries with it - not too spicy but very nice nonetheless.

We also ordered the daily escolar special, which was coated with a chilli-based rub.  Excellent.  Will go there again.
author: Nick K.

description: Came here for dinner last night because my husband keeps talking how great their Wasabi bowls are. I got the salmon wasabi bowl (be warned the salmon is cooked). My husband got the tuna wasabi bowl (that was raw). I didn't particularly like mine, I guess I should have gotten the tuna. However, since the meal was called wasabi bowl, I expected wasabi up the ying yang. I didn't get much of any wasabi kick so I was disappointed. The only thing I would come back here for are the sweet potato fries. But I would only come during the happy hour times.
author: Lang T.

description: It's good. It's safe. It's kinda like a chain but a little better. The space is funky and has a really hip vibe. I like the pomegranate mojito I had. The sweet potato fries, spicy tuna roll and Hawaiian poke with won ton chips were all satisfying as a matter of fact it was too much food. I've never been to a restaurant where I left 1/2 of the sushi..I did that here. You get alot of food and the happy hour prices are outstanding. Great for families and groups.
author: Sherie R.

description: Awesome food.  Fish and Chips are perfectly cooked every time!  Sweet potato fries are amazing!  Happy hour here kicks ass.  Mother Ship on tap, cool bartenders, beautiful women working here and Spicy Tuna Rolls are 5 bucks and they actually put TUNA in it!  instead of half assing it.  place constantly amazes me.
author: Brandon H.

description: Some of this may not apply once the crab specials are done, so your experience might differ.  Both the crab dumplings and the crab-corn chowder were amazing... so very delicious I could have made a meal out of them alone.  The Tokyo Salmon fish and chips were excellent.... they may have ruined regular fish and chips for me.  The Baja fish tacos were also very good.  Service was also very good and prices are very reasonable.  All in all, a very nice place to get an early dinner when in the Inner Sunset.
author: Alured P.

description: Great sweet potato fries, nice menu, interesting selection of beers, friendly atmosphere.  Why 2 stars?  Last visit with a crowd of 10 for a birthday; found a gnarly-looking tomato in my otherwise tasty salad.  Waitress said, hmm, can't wait to show this to my manager!  Then we got the check - no "so sorry about that,"  no happy birthday, not 50 cents off the bill.  We've had worse experiences in much fancier places  (the worst: a used paper towel mid-entree at a high-end restaurant - they comp'd us a half glass of wine!) but probably won't breeze by again in a hurry.
author: Ellen S.

description: one word for this place "GROSS!!!"  I went there for a first date to show a good impression to my soon to be girlfriend, and since she likes seafood, I thought I can take here there. Server was cool, but the food was gross. How embarassing. Luckily, there is a "tart to tart" up the street on irving, so I took her out for a nice good tasting cheesecake. She was happy!
author: Poison I.

description: I think the space is really great and the next time I am in town, I will be sure to return. I had the Fish-N-Chips and the Crab and Avocado Salad, it was amazing! My girlfriend had the Ahi Poke Wasabi Bowl, she loved it and practically licked the bowl! The service was really good as well. I recommend this place for a great meal.
author: john n.

description: Good, but not very exciting food and drinks. Go there for Happy Hour!
author: Jan H.

description:
Same concept as the other location on Chestnut Street except in real restaurant format, ie. you sit down and order with a waitress. 

My favorite things about this location I must say are the service which I find fast and friendly, and the atmosphere which is warm and inviting. 
The food, I honestly felt was better at the original location, yet I keep coming back to this location since it's alot closer to me. 

Anyway, onto the food.......the sweet potato fries are yummy and once you start you can't stop eating them. They are a bit addicting, I think they are perfect as is, but my fiance likes to add salt to them but then again he adds salt to everything and takes blood pressure meds............the sushi is good and consistent, and the menu is extensive enough where if you have any seafood fan they most likely will find something they will like here. Most of the food is healthy, but if you want something fried there are plenty of options for that also. My personal favorite for years and years was the Hawaiian poke yet here I find it to be really salty every time I order even though I keep order it again and again thinking the last time was hopefully a fluke. It wasn't. My other let down was possibly the pineapple fried rice, which I usually tend to think, there is no way to mess up, which they diddn't, but they also didn't do anything with to make me even want to finish eating it! Let down! If it sounds like I am complaining I don't mean to because I usually do like what I order here, just the last two times the fried rice and poke have been letting me down. Usually though my experience here though does leave me satisfied, and as mentioned earlier, the atmosphere and service always stay consistent.
author: Denise B.

description: Best dessert ever! Main course? Not so much. The only reason I'm giving it a 4 star is because I believe there might have been other courses on the menu that were better than what I ordered. But get the mochi ice cream and the chocolate fondue, it'll be the best dessert you've ever had! So yummy.
author: Sarah A.

description:
my sister and i shared the hawaiian surf&turf and the fried oysters with sweet potato fries, and boy, were we stuffed! friendly servers, great ambiance, it's a nice place to go for something other than the usual inner sunset food. 

they have late night happy hour every night from 10pm till closing. i passed by on saturday night and the place was packed with people. gotta try their happy hour sometime...

the food was really flavorful and their menu is extensive, ranging from sushi to salads to seafood. 

a bit pricey, but what isn't in san francisco?
author: Sharon O.

description: We were close to the Chestnut location but it was totally packed, and TINY... so we decided to drive over to this location... We were starving and our eyes were hungrier than are stomachs... we ordered a lot of appetizers.. hawaiian poke, sweet potato fries, and calamari... and we were stuffed before entrees came.  I WISH I had room because from the few bites that I did have... it was so tasty!  I had the Wasabi Bowl with Hawaiian Poke.  The wasabi bowls come with all the things I love and they all are so great together.  The hubby got the 3 taco platter with 3 different tacos, and they looked delicious as well.  Our friends had also got meals that looked DELICIOUS... a miso salmon and the salmon wasabi bowl... mmm....  This location is a lot bigger with its own parking lot and the service is very friendly and attentive as well.
author: Kymberli C.

description:
I LOVE this restaurant! And I cannot understand why more people don't give it a 5 star rating. Okay, the parking is difficult. Well, you can say that about anywhere in SF. And yes, it can get noisy, but so is every other place in town, besides noise lends atmosphere. The space may not be for everyone, because it is large. But when was the last time you could walk into a good restaurant in the city, on a Saturday night, in a popular neighborhood, no reservation, and get a table, with no waiting?!

And the food is fantastic! I have eaten here more often than just about anywhere else (except maybe my favorite taqueria). I have tried a lot of the items, and every single thing, every single time, has been delicious. The fish is always fresh, the menu has lots of variety, from Asian style to Asian twists on Mexican. Their fried calamari and coconut shrimp skewers are the best anywhere! Amazing fish tacos, superb salmon entree, the absolute best rice plates.

And I love the decor, especially the creative use of resin panels (made by 3-Form - check out the bathroom stalls. Brilliant to use two panels back to back instead of the boring formica you see everywhere else). But the best is looking at the bar, from the restaurant, at night. The way the blue pendant lights glow through 3-Form ring panels is a really nice effect. 

I have turned lots and lots of my friends onto this place and everyone agrees that it is great. So I don't know what everyone is whining about - don't listen to all the negativity, check it out. (and PJ's was sooooo not better - why do you think they closed down?)
author: Susan T.

description: Great place (thanks tamz!) I highly recommend their Hawaiin Poke bowl....so much food, great pricing...strawberry mojito was a little weak...but the food is superb!
author: Nancy M.

description:
once upon a time, there were two girls named rhea and shirley who were training for the nike women's half marathon. one morning, during an 8 mile training run, shirley told rhea, "i'm sad; my work had a hawaiian-themed party and there was no "hawaiian" food. all they had was hawaiian pizza and maui onion-flavored chips, and i wanted poke!"

rhea replied, "ooh, some poke and kalua pig sound REALLY good". they continued on with their run and a couple of miles later, rhea asked shirley how she was doing (with the run). shirley responded, "i can't stop thinking about poke!"

so, after they finished their run, they visited their friend, lizette, to find out where they could find some of this much sought after poke. she saved the day when she told rhea and shirley about pacific catch, where they immediately found parking in the restaurant's lot (on a saturday afternoon, no less!) and enjoyed a delicious lunch.

the poke appetizer was perfectly seasoned with just the right amount of soy sauce, onions, and ginger; both the spicy mahi mahi and spicy ahi tuna sandwiches were equally satisfying!

...and they lived happily ever after (well, except for the no kalua pig part). the end.
author: arpee q.

description: Night date my wife first time here. We lucky found a parking on the side parking of the restaurant. It was noisy when we got in the table, we had to talk out loud to hear ourself. I ordered Ahi 3 way, the fish was very fresh and tasty, I guessed there is some Sake favor inthe rice.  Yellowtail Baja Grilled was for my wife. It comes with sweet potato fried and half corn. She liked it and first time ever she finished her dish. We really like the food here, our waiter was very nice. The price is good. We will come back again soon.
author: Tommy T.

description: This place was ok. The food was good, but not worth the price. When we ordered the oyster appetizer, we got really excited because we thought we were ordering raw oysters, but didn't realize the word "crispy" was in front of the description. No wonder the oysters seemed inexpensive. We went in a big group and it ended up being about $50 per person, but for such a casual place w/so-so food, it really wasn't all that worth it.
author: Emy s.

description: Huge enticing menu, something for everyone.  Light and healthy or fried and smothered- whatever's your pleasure.  Sushi or fish and non-fish options for the seafood foe, vegetarian or picky kid.  What more can you ask for?  They also had tasty cocktails and the service was pretty quick and friendly.  I will definitely be back.
author: J L.

description: Pacific Catch has been a great addition to the Inner Sunset neighborhood.  The food here is consistently very good---favs are the Pacific Salmon (battered fried salmon and sweet potato fries) and the wasabi bowls (any combo).  Servers are efficient and friendly.  A unique  feature of this Pacific Catch is the size of the building (built on an old x-mas tree lot, d'ya remember?).  It's not often to find an SF restaurant that is not a bit cramped so this place is a treat.  Finally, the martinis are well priced and good sized (have you noticed maritini glasses seem to be shrinking in SF?).
author: Michael W.

description: A personal favorite spot for the reliable late night happy hour.  I have been here many times at all different times of the day.  Service is great, decor is very nice, and overall the restaurant is very clean!  Nothing but good times at this place among both family and good friends!
author: Carter Y.

description:
Went back today with my family for birthday dinners. My sister and I wanted to have and try several things, so we shared A LOT of food. (In our defense, we were going to share with the others in our family, too.)

My sister and I chose:

-Sake Sake Sushi (still very very good. tastes so fresh and yummy. not overdone. had avocado inside with salmon and roe on the outside)
-Rising Sun Sushi (this was okay for me. just may not be a huge fan of the tempura inside. this one had tempura inside with tuna on the outside)
-Mixed Catch Basket with SWEET POTATO FRIES (the fries came with diff sauce, but it tasted good dipped in this other seafood sauce from another dish we had, and also good dipped in this sweet sauce that came with our mixed catch basket. Mixed Catch Basket came with 2 pieces of fish, 4 coconut shrimp, and 3 oyster. My sister and I agreed the oysters were the best. Breaded on the outside and when you bite into, it's soft, not quite slimy, and very good!! We could have done without the so-so fish, and the coconut shrimp)
Last but not least, we also had:
-today's special appetizer - seafood in sauce(i love sauce) with a piece of very crispy bread that was grilled and tasted excellent dipped in the seafoody sauce, and it was topped with some spicy mustard that gave some surprising zing)

Our family also shared:
-Hawaiian Poke (very good. many pieces of poke with little chips to eat with it, though the poke was a little salty)
-Baja Shrimp Ceviche (this was great. tortilla chips with the sour sauce tasted good. and there were many large shrimp we kept discovering beneath the sauce too)

Other family members had:
-Pineapple fried rice - apparently not very good
-Shrimp taco - tasted ok
-sweet tea - basically just sweetened tea
-spicy fries - not too special
-shrimp tempura roll - nothing special. the tempura just didn't do much for me

AND, because my family had 3 birthdays, they comped 3 desserts for us! We got two Mochi Fondues, that come with the ice cream mochis in chocolate, vanilla, and coffee flavors to be dipped in warm chocolate sauce. I had the vanilla and that tasted pretty good. We also had the Macadamia Nut Brownie Sundae. I had a bite, and it was good, but just too sweet for my taste.

Also, the service was interesting. They kept collecting our chopsticks, and once even collected plates they gave my sister and I to use to share our food. We hadn't even used our chopsticks (2nd set) and plates yet! So our food came, and we're like...where are our plates AND our chopsticks! So I was onto my 3rd pair of chopsticks. After that, every time they came by, I held onto my chopsticks. Can you be overserviced?

But I like the appetizers and the sushi and sweet potato fries, so indeed I would return. Oh, and those oysters, too!! So that helps me forget about some of the negatives and give Pacific Catch another 4 stars!

Maybe sometime I can just come for happy hour between 4-6pm, and get the things I like, and not make it a full on meal. :-)
author: Anita C.

description:
Had a lunch time birthday party there with friends.  Food was decent, if a bit on the boring side.  However they do serve some very good sweet potato fries.  

What was disappointing was the service.  They seemed disorganized, couldn't remember who ordered what, and drinks took a long time to come out.  I had brought a large party with me (around 15), but for some reason they chose to ring it up as two bills.  They forgot to run the charges through for one of the bills when we settled.  About 20 minute later, after I walked all the way to the California Academy of Sciences, the manager called and said we stiffed him on the bill.  We hiked all the way back, missing a planetarium show we were standing in line for.  I wasn't so keen on the forgetful service, and mismanaged bill, and being accused by the manager of stiffing him.
author: Greg C.

description: Wanna eat healthy? This is the place. I had some wasabi tuna salad and it was so fresh and delicious. In fact I've been back and have tried almost all their salad's. Good, healthy and delicious. Kinda Asian Fusion with lots of fresh fish dishes. i like this place. They have a full bar and depending on who you get for service, it has been fairly good. The place in Marin is good too.
author: Moby L.

description:
Oh wow, look at that, I'm the first person to actually have eaten here that is writing a review (despite being the 3rd review).  Disclaimer: This review was written on a preview service meal (first ever served) so please take it with a grain of salt!    

I just had lunch today for the preview service of the newest location of Pacific Catch (Corta Madera and Marina are the other two).  They're doing a preview lunch today and tomorrow before hopefully opening on Tuesday (as per inspectors approving them).  They did an amazing job with all the space of the old Canvas Cafe which I frequented weekly.  The red really pops and the decor is great.  There's a full bar and PLENTY of seats all around.  The vibe is really good and the food is well...it's Pacific Catch!  I love the one in the Marina and frequented it regularly for the salad bowl with Ahi Tuna Poke and sweet potato fries.  I tried something new today and we split a coconut shrimp appetizer which was really good.  I had fish tacos this time around which were all pretty decent but the sweet potato fries were a bit tasteless.  The ones at the Marina location have also changed from how delicious they used to be.  Not sure if they're using different sweet potatoes but they're definitely brighter orange and less sweet than they used to be.  Anyway, there was a bit of a glitch in the computer so our order took a while, but this was all a trial run, so I'm sure it'll be worked out by opening time.  

They have an expanded menu at this location (same as Corta Madera) with sushi and sashimi bar.  The prices are slightly higher than the Chestnut location though.  This place is awesome and I highly recommend it.  Easy parking across the street in Golden Gate Park.  The space is gorgeous (high ceilings with skylight).  The management and staff were really nice and friendly.  The place is huge so you shouldn't have a problem getting seated.  I highly recommend checking it out!
author: Dave L.

description: Commenting just on the bar, they have some excellent drinks, even if the list is a bit short. I definitely recommend the Mai Tais.
author: Jan Michael K.

description: Giving this place 3.5 stars.  Had the poke appetizer and the steak teriyaki rice bowl.  The poke was just ok.  A little too much ginger for my tastes.  I actually prefer the Shoyu poke they sometimes carry at Costco.  The teriyaki bowl was real flavorful and the steak was cooked and seasoned perfectly.   The rice seemed to get a bit mushy in the gooey sauce halfway through the meal.  Though the food didn't taste too salty for some reason I drank 4-5 glasses of water throughout the meal.  Not sure what it was.  Overall this place didn't knock my socks off but I'd come again if I get a hankering for some seafood with an Asian/Pacific twist.
author: Karl L.

description: Ordered takeout from this place. Food was late and then soggy when it arrived. Sushi was runny and unpalatable. Coconut shrimp was overcooked. Fish was barely above fast food quality. Calamari was not bad, though. Would never order from this place again.
author: Evan and Christine J.

description:
Tuna Poke and wasabi bowl, only two words you need to know coming to this place.  skip the ceviche, comes in a martini glass and looks cool but last time i had wasn't that impressive.  shrimp app and calamari are real nice though.  

oh and they make a fine dark and stormy (rum and ginger beer) that you want to try
author: Robin R.

description: I really like this restuarant. All of the cocktails I've had from here were really good..esp. the Ginger Pomegranate Martini..sooo good.  Plus they have a 10pm happy hour!! How cool is that? The bar food during the happy hour is cheap and yummy. For example, the spicy tuna roll is really good and the sweet potato fries!
author: Sonya D.

description:
When I first came in, the hostess was really friendly. The waiter was ok. I think he tried to be friendly but was overwhelmed. He was quick to get us the sweet potato fries for the appetizer but after that he completely forgot our main courses. We waited for 1 1/2 hours. He said the kitchen was backed up. That pretty much ruined our mood. 

The 3 course dinner menu was also misleading. Cocktail was listed together with appetizer, main course, and dessert. When we asked the waiter he mocked us by saying oh..i would've loved to get the cocktail too. Wtf? Only after we talked to the manager we got it for free. She said many people questioned the menu as well. Hello...? I was gonna give 2 stars but I give one more because of her.

I had the poke wasabi bowl which was very good. i'd come back just for that.
author: Novi O.

description: I'm not usually big on chain restaurants, but I have to admit, I have a soft spot for Pacific catch. Perhaps it's because Ryan, the bartender, mixes such fantastic lemongrass mojitos.... or perhaps it's because the sashimi creations are so darn tasty. Whatever the reason, I find myself eating and drinking at the bar at least twice a month.... and I definitely recommend that you try it, too.
author: Leslie F.

description: Oh joy, Pacific Catch finally opens at this location. Double joy, I got the free meal this past Monday when they were having the mock "opening day." Ordered the calamari as appetizer, which was good but not superb. I'd stick with sweet potatoes next time. As usual, ordered the ahi tuna wasabi bowl. It's the best wasabi bowl I've had in Pac Catch. Tuna was not overcooked; sometimes they overcooked it in the Chestnut location. Not so keen on the lemongrass iced tea though. Service was wonderful. Nice ambiance. Will definitely be a frequent customer here.
author: Poof S.

description:
i came back here after going to the academy of science.  we had the salmon teriyaki bowl and mahi mahi special which were totally edible. we also decided to get the rock and roll (unagi roll) with brown rice. what a way to ruin a meal. the brown rice was super hard (cold and perhaps undercooked?) and the unagi was disgusting. it was cold (like they had taken it out of the fridge) and they used the hard crusty pieces (hard skin attached, the fish was just hard in general). SERIOUSLY???  what a disappointment for an $8 roll

of course the sweet potato fries were good. don't get the sushi with brown rice or eel if you go!!!

the service was still good but i just had to downgrade them based on the sushi experience.
author: joyce l.

description:
this is a lunch review.
the bestie and i heard good things about this place since it opened so we decided to come by for lunch one day. it was about 12:30pm  when we got there and we were both pretty hungry. we were seated pretty quick, and sadly that was the last thing speedy about this place. 

our server came by to introduce herself and drop off menus... it took her a while to get back to us to take our orders, then gave us our drinks and the house appetizers - edamame and pretzel goldfish. thinking back on it now, i should have realized if it took her that long to get our order, i should have realized it would have taken just as long to get our food... in which case, i should have just ordered a real drink rather than soda. anyways, since i had the time to look around. from what i can tell there were two, maybe three servers in the restaurant and a couple more kitchen/wait staff to bring food to the tables. the restaurant wasn't even busy. it was at most half full.

the bestie had a wasabi bowl and it was tasty. the sweet potato fries were yummy as well but i honestly don't remember how my tacos tasted because i wolfed them down the moment the plate hit the table. 

by the time we left the restaurant it was a bit past 3pm. we were not happy and it definitely didn't feel like it was worth our time or money. never going back.
author: sasa w.

description: Really good, Sushi and Fish Tacos and Ahi apps and Sweet Potato Fries and more... go here all the time.
author: Andy C.

description:
My girlfriend and i wandered into this place after realizing Hotei was closed down the street. About halfway through dinner we learned that it was the first night serving dinner at the new Pacific Catch. We were very happy with the food - shared a few sushi rolls and a seared ahi dish with a mango salad. The sushi iitself was pretty standard but we especially enjoyed the brown rice option for the rolls. The service was excellent, and our server Ben even obliged when we asked him his opinion on some juicy relationship gossip. 
The urban - chic atmosphere was also pleasing, but seems a little out of place in this neighborhood which is full of low-key but amazing restaurants. But what do i know, maybe it's just what the area needs. We would definitely go again, although if you're just looking for good sushi I would still prefer Hotei.
author: Izzy S.

description: This location has a full bar, and god bless it. I usually try the special for lunch, but there are great appetizers and roll options to choose from. I had a party here a year ago, and they were a pleasure to work with. good prices too. An appetizer and fish taco are a great meal
author: Paigey B.

description:
This is a new restaurant in what was Canvas Cafe. (With it's live music night, relatively good food and nice booths/tables to park yourself with your laptop, Canvas was one of my fav spots in the Sunset.  But I remiss...) Anyway, so I'm headed to Pacific Catch because my SO is part of an acronym friends and family group (aka AF&F) and most of them are devout meat worshipers.  I mean they really, really like their meats and fish.  And don't suggest to me that fish is vegetarian.  Hello!  If it's got a face, moves and /or you keep it as a pet, it's not vegetarian.  So Pacific Catch has an upscale look and feel to the place. Nice decor, lighting and a friendly wait staff.  But the menu is not vegetarian friendly.  Lot of choices (sake salmon, calamari, thai coconut shrimp, tuna tataki etc etc...) if you like your meats and fish but not if you're vegetarian.  Most places in SF by now have a section on their menu for vegetarians. Not here. (Btw, I asked the waiter and she didn't have a suggestion off the menu for me as well)  Frustrated, I asked for peanut butter & jelly sandwich and they didn't have that. So I ended up with some starters and sides: wakame seaweed salad (kindda fishy), pineapple fried rice (kindda bland) and sweet potato fries (ok...the fries were good especially with their special dips).  Not very satisfying for $25 (w/ tips) per person bill.

Tip for Pacfic Catch.  Have something vegetarian. Something noodly on your menu. And if you can't do that, at least have peanut butter and jelly sandwich.  Is that asking for too much?
author: ITesh J.

description: Very good chance of having a super meal here. We are 5 for 5. Really good. It can be very busy and the staff can get lost in the crowd.  I thought it was easy to relax.  At least the food comes pretty quick once you get going. The Crispy Salmon Taco was great.
author: Richard S.

description:
its really not all that I had hoped it would be...
You know that there are those times when you're craving something light, and for the life of you you can't think of where to go to get some nice fish that isn't too pricey, isn't deep fried, or isn't sashmi?

...this could have been that place, but it didn't turn our that way. The fish is okay, the prices are also okay - considering that they do keep to seasonal fishes - but overall? not so great. 
1.Low marks for envrionment - waaaaayyyy too noisy - its great for small kids - of which there were many the night we dined there, but it makes for near impossible discusssion of any kind under a yell
2. Low marks for presentation. the food was slopped onto my plate, I had order the fish of the day - an australian whitefish in a lemon & butter sauce, and the dish looked as if it hadn't even really been cleaned. 
3. Low marks for the service.  Our hostess that night was all up into her self - to te point where we had to literally flag her down to get her attention. (being under 20-something...) she could barely keep from admiring herself in the reflective surfaces of anything nearby
4. low marks for the food itself... bleh... that's all I can say. 

I'll pass unless I'm starving.
author: Kira G.

description:
Two thumbs up! Everything I had was excellent (fried calamari, salmon special with the hawaiian fried rice & bok choy). It was all cooked nicely and tasted great. There was even more on the menu I wanted to try, which means I will have to come back. We sat at the counter by the kitchen because the wait was 1.5 hours on a Friday night (yikes!) but I didn't mind sitting there at all as the service was attentive and prompt.

P.S. We (two of us) had a bottle of  Sauvignon Blanc over this dinner and it made the experience even better.
author: S. S.

description: Go to the one on Irving and Lincoln--HUUUUGE!  Not as many marina folks too--yay!!!  You can sit down and eat your lunch pleasantly without cheese being thrown at you (oh wait, do I still sound bitter?!).  They even have their own parking space for ya!  Wow!  The place used to be the old Canvas Gallery and although there were many a times that I've stumbled out of that place in a drunken stupor,  I think my aching heart will manage..when I stumble out of Pacific Catch satisfyingly full from the sweet potatoes fries and ahi sandwiches.
author: Abby E.

description: This place was suggested to me to be a good lunch choice for a birthday celebration.  I took an elderly relative who enjoys Hawaiian Poke and that was his choice and  what he ordered.  Myself, I choose the Salmon Sashimi and was not only disappointed by my choice but suffered a violent food-poisoning an hour later from it.  Needless to say, it put me off ever going back.  Lunch was fairly pricey and to get sick from it added insult to injury.  It also put me off raw fish for a good long time to come.
author: Fleur R.

description: My fat belly says the Marina location has better tasing food eventhough its the exact same menu.  But this location is much beter for groups and is easier to get a reservation/table.  I had the Maui Brewing company big wave IPA.  It was freakin awesome.  Its $5 for a can but if I see it at Trader Joes I am going to beat some fatty ass.
author: Fatty A.

description:
I don't turn down food so when I was invited to attend the opening Friday night, I was more than happy to attend with an empty stomach.

I agree with Dave, the ambiance is well done in this location.  The male servers, though most very young, are great eye-candy.  Everyone working was attentive.  My glass was empty and no less than 5 people asked if they could bring me another drink.

The apps are out of this world. The Hawaiian Poke with those chrispy things are well received by the table.  the sushi was fresh and fried calamari even came with fried sliced lemons.  Never tried friend sliced lemons before this night and it was better I expected, though I couldn't eat a whole one.

The main entree wasn't as stellar as the apps.  I had the grilled shrimp over rice with mushrooms and other veggies. The portion of the rice was big but the shrimp felt like they weren't marinated but just grilled plain.  My DH got a seafood basket. I did enjoy the fried oysters but not so much the coconut shrimp.

Mochi-Mochi-Mochi. The server called it Mo-ki so I corrected him.  It came with warm chocolate dipping sauce. Perfection.  They served three flavors, chocolate, mocha, and vanilla. It was so soft, YUMMY!

If I wasn't so full, I would have ordered more entress to try out but I think this place will do well and so I'll be back.
author: Mona B.

description:
maybe i hold a grudge against this place for taking over the space where the canvas gallery used to be.  it was weird going to the bathroom and finding that it was actually clean!  that aside, i thought our evening at pacific catch was pretty mediocre.  not horrible but not great.  

we started with the sweet potato fries.  average but good.  the wsabi dipping sauce was interesting but the sweet chili dipping sauce did not go with the fries at all.  as an entree, i had a special.  hawaiian style opah fish with pineapple fried rice and fried onions.  the fish, which is supposed to be a more oily fish, was dry, dry ,dry.  the "hawaiian glaze" tasted like something you could get at TGIF.  the fried onion rings just oozed with oil.  each bite just squirted oil into my mouth.  the pineapple fried rice was pretty good.  

my friend had the poke wasabi bowl which was good but, like he said, was "nothing special".  i think i'll revisit this place in a month or two to try it out again.  maybe after settling down, they'll fine tune their cooking techniques.  but until then, i'll still be missing my canvas gallery.
author: Thom Y.

description: This place isn't terrible, but it kinda sucks.  The hostess should be fired, she's rude and unprofessional.  Our waitress was okay, but not really on top of her game.  I felt bad for the manager that had to bring out all the orders that were left out for long periods of time.  We had the fish and chips which were pretty decent, but my lemonade tasted like water.  I would certainly not return, but the fish and sweet potato chips were not bad at all.
author: Nate W.

description: This place is all sorts of wrong.  The food is overpriced, the service was mediocre, and the food was unsavory.  Their lemonade was horrible too.  They definitely use the dumb powdered stuff to make it.  Even their pretzel-flavored Pepperidge Farms Goldfish crackers failed to cheer me up (it's all about cheddar, guys).  Glad I didn't pay for my first and last meal at this lame spot.
author: Christine S.

description: This place was great- a perfect spot for a nice dinner that wasn't super expensive. I had the wassabi bowl, which was delicious, really flavorful, filling and healthy. It was a bowl filled with veggies, brown rice, sesame seeds and I had the ahi tuna - yum yum yum. I've never been to the location on Chestnut, but I'd like to check it out.
author: meagan m.

description: This is one of my favorite places in the hood for a quick, easy no frills bite.  The salads and wasabi bowls are great, as is the fish and chips with sweet potato fries.  It's perfect on a warm sunny day after a walk in the GG park.
author: Eric C.

description: I am definitely a fan. I usually go for the eel bowl with brown rice (LOVE that sauce they use) and never miss the opportunity to get the grilled artichoke and the sweet potato fries (I wish they had places in NYC that served both of those!!!). The atmosphere is nice and the service is generally pretty quick and friendly.
author: Marina G.

description: Love the fish tacos. You can order 3 different versions. The sweet potatoe fries are yummy.
author: Tom L.

description:
service was outstanding

food was just ok. too much sauce in the salmon dish and the seafood just didn't taste that fresh. sweet potato fries were tasty however.  good selection of beer

prices are out of whack..6.95 for a california roll? 

parking is tough
author: Bobby B.

description: Came to try this place out with my boyfriend since he loves poke bowls. We got free calamari for checking in and the calamari was mediocre and not even hot. The waitress even forgot to take it off our tab so I had to remind her when she gave us the bill. We ordered the wasabi hawaiian poke bowl and the two taco platter (grilled steak & mahi mahi) with sweet potato fries. Also, I ordered one of the house made drinks that consisted of mint leaves & lime that the waitress recommended. The poke bowl was a big disappointment. It felt like there was not a consistency with everything going together and there was very little poke. The mahi mahi taco was not good, but the grilled steak taco was pretty tasty. The best thing about this place? Their sweet potato fries. The drink I ordered was way too pricey for what it really was too. Disappointment there also. I don't think I'd come back anytime soon.
author: Syd T.

description: So when my friends from out of town came to visit, I took them to one of my favorite places to eat, the INNER SUNSET.  So when they closed one of my favorite coffee shops down (Canvas) I already wanted to hate the restaurant that was taking over that space.  Enter Pacific Catch.  My friends love seafood so I reluctantly came in.  Had my usual soda pop, and friend oysters with rice......Not Bad.  I was disapointedly impressed.  So with my inner issues resolved with Pacific Catch I felt free to attack everyone else's food.  Poke, fish and chips, it was all good.  Best hidden secret of this place is that there is a parking lot.....Luvs it!
author: Rossi C.

description: The decor was fantastic, but I wish I could say the same about the fish.  The waiter needs to pay attention better; our drink orders were fulfilled.  The sweet potato fries and the spicy fries are definitely worth a try.  I'd stray against the catch of the day, the ahi tuna, and the poke all together.
author: Jenny L.

description: Came here with a friend for the first time and was blown away at how fresh their fish was. I had the HAWAIIAN POKE WASABI BOWL. This was amazing! the ahi tuna was so fresh that the soft and tender fish melted in my mouth. it was a mouthful of flavor...thesoy sauce that they put with the tuna had wasabi mixed into it so it added the perfect kick to the dish. I substituted the sushi rice with brown rice...tasted just as good and was healthier :) The bowl included shredded veggie salad (daikon, cucumber, carrot), sliced avocado, sesame seeds, and shredded seaweed on top. This was an excellent and filling meal and I would definitely come back!
author: Ivy L.

description: Yes, I'm a fan! I've always passed this restaurant in the car or walking by, but never went in. But, I'm very glad I finally did! First, the mixed drinks were great.  For an appetizer we had some sushi and poke. The sushi was ok (nothing special) but the poke was sooo good! My sister (who spent a few years in Hawaii) agreed as well. The fish was fresh, and the marinade was flavorful, which made for some great poke!! My dinner was a bunch of fried seafood, which was a mistake on my part.  Next time I will try something else for dinner (fresh fish maybe), but overall it was a great meal!
author: Erin V.

description:
hot on yelp his month..Lime tree. so thru the park we go...Lime tree lime tree lime....OOO Pacific catch...lemon whatnow???

I haven't been to the wharf in years but PC took me back.
come here for lunch when it's roomy so you can really notice the clean and elegant, yet casual, decor. Plus quicker service!

I was with my bff and like always we over ordered but it was well worth it bcus we actually took home the left over this time. 
we had the... 
-calamari (w/great spicy dip)
-mix basket (took 5 mins for us to figure out that one of the item was like some sort of huge oyster that looks nasty but taste just fine)
-tempura rolls and Hawaii poke rolls
 
i think the waitress was thinking...wow what  pigs!  she was trying to time out our order so it didnt come out all at once...nope that didnt help.. nice try tho. we had the same amount of food that tables with four people had!
author: Lynn T.

description:
i'm torn.  on the one hand it was nothing spectacular, but on the other hand there wasn't really anything bad about this place.  start it off by saying that the waiter was very friendly and informed us that the kitchen was really good about substitutions/preparing items that weren't on the menu, so that was a plus...but the options on the menu all seemed so good that it wasn't really necessary to ask for something different.  

i absolutely adore raw fish.  all seafood really.  but raw fish is great.  so we started with the hawaiian poke (raw ahi marinated in soy sauce etc.), huge chunks of ahi, a little heavy on the sauce, but still delish.  the calamari was also not too chewy, so props for that.  and the seaweed salad was actually pretty good.  

but then i ordered the tacos, which i've heard great things about.  i ordered the cabo shrimp and a special ahi taco that's not on the menu but the waiter recommended.  well, i wish he hadn't.  the ahi was overcooked for my taste (obvi raw would've been great, but i was expecting a slight seared edge...this was almost completely cooked through), and there was no moisture in this thing.  i need me some sauce on my tacos!  the shrimp was better, thanks to the large portion and ample sauce.  i even resorted to pouring leftover sauce from my seaweed salad on the ahi taco.  

so suffice it to say, i've had better fish tacos...but the quality and freshness of the fish actually seemed pretty great, so i'll likely go back and order a salmon sandwich, or an ahi bowl or something else.  heck maybe even a steak taco, though that wouldn't really be keeping up with the theme of the restaurant very well.
author: Anne Marie B.

description: I was just here the other day for a friend's birthday, and it was the perfect place to have it - loud, colorful environment. It was pretty busy but they do take reservations. Their menu is rather unique - they have an interesting variety ranging from sushi rolls to tacos. I ordered the Spicy Ahi Tuna Sandwich with sweet potato fries (which were so delicious). I liked the sandwich but I have to say the tuna wasn't very flavorful. I also mooched off my friends' Teriyaki Bowls and Wasabi Bowls..pretty good! We shared the Mochi Fondue and some kind of brownie a la mode which was really delicious. The service was good, and there was a really cute bus boy. :)
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I finally had a chance to go here for an early dinner on a beautiful, warm, sunny Monday evening. Getting there around 5 and on a Monday (my parents' favorite time of the day/week to dine out and now I see why) means absolutely no wait. We sat in a window seat in the bar which was great for people-watching, Golden Gate Park-watching and Irving St. traffic-watching. The food and drinks were tasty and filling. I got some sort of mojito (special drink of the day) and the mahi-mahi sandwich which came with the sweet potato fries. Loved the sweet potato fries. The sandwich was just okay. We also ordered shrimp ceviche as an appetizer which was probably my favorite part of the meal. Served with tortilla chips, it was fresh, light and citrus-y. The service was friendly, although it did take awhile to get the bill. All in all, I thought it was a good meal and a great new addition to my neighborhood restaurants.

Extra tip: You can sign up to receive monthly newsletter emails from Pacific Catch. So far the email always has a "special offer of the month" which is typically a free appetizer that the restaurant chooses(i.e. the shrimp ceviche) if you order entree(s) -- sometimes they require you buy 2 entrees, but with the latest email you only had to buy one.
author: Anne Q.

description: I only came here because I like the food at Pacific Catch in the marina.  the prices here seem steeper and the portions smaller.  that' sprobabl b/c the space is huge compared to the marina location.  the place feels like a gutted starbucks.  very generic feel.  with so many other neighborhood establishments, i'd probably pass on coming here again.  but i do like their poke bowls and their sweet potato fries, both of which were much smaller portioned than at the marina.  and a couple bucks more...
author: Caroline I.

description:
with the appetizer coupons we scored at the yelp party in hand, we headed over to the sunset pacific catch for some consistently delicious grub and, as usual, we weren't disappointed. we tried both the hawaiian poke (a must eat) and the baja shrimp ceviche, which came out in a cool martini glass with tortilla chips... so refreshing and good! i'm usually wary about getting salmon, but the salmon wasabi bowl here was perfect! and you can never go wrong with the rock cod fish and chips...

chef chandon and chef (eek! forgot your name!) even came out to greet us and shoot the breeze about the yelp party the night before... can't believe they actually DONATED all that food that, well, i didn't get to eat (cuz i'm not elite... pshh).

i had actually come to this location earlier this year, and enjoyed one of their lunch-time sandwiches... which were super good as well. only wish i lived closer... i'd probably eat here at least 1x a week if that were the case!
author: Andrey C.

description:
I love this place and now its a short bike ride across the park!  The food is just amazing (if you like seafood & stuff) and I can only suggest the entire menu since I've already eaten everything on it. 
Being a Hawaii girl, my favorite is the Ahi Poke Wasabi bowl since they make it like home along with yummy avacado and wakame salad. And I shouldn't be able to finish the whole thing but I do.  The sweet potato fries are great - I've eaten two boxes in one sitting before our holiday party- along with the fish tacos, which are not too greasy or batter-y. Who cares about service when the food is so good - I still have no complaints about the staff.  They are all accomodating and nice.
This newest location does have limited parking available and a pretty posh bar but I do miss the Cricket Cola from the Marina location.  It gets pretty busy & noisy on the weekends (typical SF dining scene) so call ahead for reservations.  It is definitely worth the wait!
author: Trish K.

description: Went there last Friday for dinner with a couple of friends. The service was good, and the wait wasn't too bad. I had the ahi tuna salad with Hawaiian Poke...what huge portions they serve you...totally worth adding $1.
author: Jenny W.

description: Food was sub-par at best. Had the king salmon which was hardly "king." It was shady and disappointing. I was not full at all and it was one of the most expensive things on the menu. The only reason why I'm giving it 3 stars is because the customer service was very good. The waitress was very friendly and the food came promptly. Overall a good place to hangout and chill, but I wouldn't go there for the food.
author: Tommy B.

description:
Some friends and I stopped in here for lunch during a bike ride across the city. Decor was great, staff was friendly, service was prompt, bathrooms were very clean, and the food was quite good. When one of my fellow bike riders dropped his glass of water, we were blown away by the response time of three separate members of the staff showing up in a split second to deal with the crisis. They handled this situation incredibly well and even apologized to surrounding tables for the disruption. 

The appetizer of sweet potato fries was very delicious.
author: Russell P.

description: Excellent selection of seafood and sushi-fusion. Service is good and the scene is a great treat for the area.
author: Johnny L.

description: I love this place! Lots of Good Healthy food and good sevice for a reasonable price. All the same stuff as the chestnut location but much bigger for everyone.  Well Done and a great deal
author: David G.

description: I have to say I have been to all 3 locations and love them all equally. I went to their newer location after taking my infant son to the zoo for the whole day, so needless to say my husband and I were very hungry. Our server Justin was very pleasant and knew a lot about the menu. My husband had one of their great margaritas and I had a arnold palmer made with their awesome tropical tea. It must have been my lucky day because they had ecsolar which is my favorite fish as a chalkboard special options, I ordered it baja bbq style. Yummy!!! I can't wait to go back. I heard in their email that they are starting a new 3 course regional menu starting with Mexico !!! Viva Pacific Catch!!!
author: Crystal V.

description:
First pro of eating at Pacific Catch is that reservations can be made online at opentable.com! The interior is much roomier than the marina location and the decor is trendy and comfortable. Our server was friendly and even showed me the box package of the tea that they brew when I asked what type of green tea they used as it has some fruity floral notes unlike other traditional green teas. 

We started with the spicy fries, which were perfectly crispy and had a cajun spice sprinkled on top. It was served hot and the side sized order was a perfectly adequate amount to avoid overfilling on starches before our meal. My boyfriend had the fish and chips with the "catch of the day" which was cod. It was flaky and soft and the batter was light and airy. The sweet potato fries were crispy and tasted really good with the tar tar sauce and sweet/sour sauce that accompanied the dish. I had the seared ahi tuna salad that came with 6 pieces of perfectly cooked tuna that was still raw on the inside. Instead of the wasabi soy dressing, I opted for the miso dressing and was happy with my change as the dressing was creamy and tangy, which matched perfectly with the fish. 

Pacific Catch is a great place to indulge in seafood and enjoy a nice night out in a trendy joint, which i must mention also has a bar area.
author: Florence T.

description: there are these guava mojito things that are amazing! everything else is typical seafood place, asian style.  the food was good, moderately priced.  parking is like all things in sf.
author: rosalinda f.

description: Sweet potato fries, crab & avocado salad, & oversized California rolls. What more can you ask for? They also give you Goldfish pretzels & edamame to munch on before your food arrives. Yum! 9th & Irving is always busy, so looking for parking can be a pain.
author: Stephanie W.

description: This was my first time dining at "Pac Catch" and I loved it. My friend and I started with a sushi roll... DELICIOUS!!! Next I had the Tokyo Salmon. I am not always a big fan of the fried fish but I made an exception and it worth it! The sweet potato fries were also a nice treat! The service here was great and I loved the dining experience
author: Miguel V.

description: Pacific Catch is my healthy standby. I don't leave feeling guilty. So that's always a plus. They have good, fresh fish. I really like this location, so much better than the marina. You can always get a table, the menu is bigger and it's not so cramped. (Plus you get to avoid the yuppies) I like their poke wasabi bowl and of course their sweet potatoe fries are to die for! (When I eat these, I leave feeling a bit more guilty than previously mentioned)
author: Jessica W.

description:
Update: 5/17/08

Came here for dinner last night with a friend and my fiancee.  We ordered the sweet potato fries (of course) and one ahi poke salad and 2 ahi poke wasabi bowls.  The portions are HUGE and the food always tastes good.  When we got there, the hostess said the wait was 45 min but that she could call us right before a table was ready.  I really liked that service so we walked around and shopped a bit.  The call came sooner than we expected so we doubled back.

The food is great like everyone says but what I want to talk about is the service.  We had an awful waitress.  She didn't give us nearly enough attention.  She barely served our table.  In the beginning, we asked for water and she completely forgot about them.  We had to ask another server to bring it for us.  The waitress only took our order then another server basically brought us our food and waited on us.  She only came back to check on us once and refill water.  Afterwards, we got our bill and we were casually talking.  She dropped by twice to see if we had paid yet and it made us feel rushed.  

I don't mind being rushed our nicely if the place is packed.  I'm not a jerk and I'll give up a table but there wasn't a wait at all so we had time to sit around.  I thought it was very rude to be ushered out when we weren't done talking yet.  It turned the atmosphere sour so we headed out quickly.  I knew we were being rushed when she realized we hadn't paid the bill so she asked if we wanted a dessert menu.  It sounded like we either buy something else or pay up and leave.  

I understand that this is a one time deal with the waitress and hopefully we won't nearly be as unlucky next time.  But it was very disappointing from a place that I expected solid service from.  

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Original Post:

This new Pacific Catch is much more spacious and a much friendlier date place than the original in the Marina.  However, I found that I was very much disappointed by several things, which are enough to deter me from coming back here.  

1.  The prices are higher (possibly for the ambiance)
2.  Menu is different from the Marina 

The Marina location isn't exactly a hole in the wall cheapo place to eat but it's decently priced at least.  Here on 9th ave., everything is at least $3 more.  They were also missing my favorite sandwiches here as well.  Lastly, we ordered a basket full of fries and were heartily disappointed that it wasn't a very full basket.  

Verdict:  Overpriced.  I'll make the longer drive out to the Marina location.
author: Scott L.

description:
This is the second time we've dined here and I hate giving bad reviews to places with good food. The food, indeed is good. Their Tuna Bowl and Tuna sandwich is delicious. Of course, their sweet potato fries are the best fries around. Now the bad. Their service. Our server, Rochelle, ruined our image and experience of this place. Not only did she hardly check up on us, near the end of the meal, when our drink glass were completely empty we tried in vain for over 10 minutes to get her to bring us a refill. It was not a very busy day nor did they seem short staff. What made it worse was that she made eye contact with myself and my friend MULTIPLE times from a far, acknowledged us and still did not come over.  As far as I could tell, she was only putting away napkins or putting straws away from the counter. Finally, my friend raised his hand like a child in a classroom for over 2 minutes before she finally came over. 
I hope this is a rare occurrence and we just got unlucky. Well, good food tho.
author: sammy z.

description: Came here with my high school teacher and a friend. food was fine. but there were several flies going around to all the food and around everyones head. that was annoying. the prices are a little bit much but what can you expect from a place so close to the museums. gotta up the price for the tourists! and the yuppies who love this place.
author: just k.

description:
After reading several reviews on YELP, decided to try Pacific Catch on 9th Ave. There were a few unfavorable remarks, so we had hopeful trepidation. A plus was that they take reservations. 
 From the start service was great. We were greeted and seated immediately. The restaurant was full, but service was prompt and plesant. There was much to read on the menu and our wait person was always patient and her  return timing to check if we were ready was perfect. Our waitress gave us good suggestions, The ceviche sampler was tasty! Two in our party  tried the best selling Asian Wasabi Bowl topped with different proteins, I had the Corvina Peruvian and it was delicious. We were all happy with our selections.
Two minor drawbacks: The margaritas are a bit pricey at $9.00 and they only have 2 flavors of ice cream for dessert (vanilla and a cappucino crunch, though maybe a coconut or Mango would fit the taste theme better?), no other dessert options.
We ate half our entrees got them boxed and then walked over to Tart to Tart fon Irving for dessert. It all worked.
Well absolutely return to Pacific Catch again!
author: Sarita E.

description: Well where can I start. The sweet potato fries. Yes we'll start there. Good but not great. If you have been to Poleng Lounge, you will not be impressed by this signature side dish. Not to disagree with everyone that has reviewed this place because they were still satisfactory. Adding to the okayness, we had the calamari. Good but could use a little more flavor. Finally we had a trio of seafood tacos. Mahi mahi and salmon tacos were okay. Their best is definitely the shrimp tacos. However a good El Tonayense taco truck can totally wip that. Okay server was slow but it was a Friday. A bit pricey for what it is. However on a good final note, it does have atmosphere. You'll love that! Overall, just stroking a par.
author: Eugenel E.

description: came here for a late lunch on sunday after a weekend of camping/rafting in oakdale and it was nice! i ordered the fresh pick of the day, true cod (as opposed to false ones) which came with sweet potato fries, cole slaw and two dipping sauces. one was a jalapeño tartar and the other was a sweet chili sauce, the kind you dip filipino lumpia into. the fish was fried nicely and you can tell it was fresh. i also had a taste of my friend's ahi tuna sandwich and my cousin's salmon sandwich, both of which were delish! i love the ciabatta bread they were on too! also shared one of their special sushi rolls, which had a catchy name that i am blanking on right now. but it had a nice bite, which came form the spicy mayo, and a nice crunch from the tempura batter, mmm!!! i'm craving some right now...
author: Pamela s.

description: I'm not even a seafood fan, but love the idea of this place: take whatever's fresh for the day, and serve it up a couple different ways, in addition to a fresh menu of standards. Plus, the space inside is amazing, and we were treated very well on opening day (to a free lunch!). We'll be stopping by again, soon.
author: Sunset G.

description: Try the wasabi bowls. they are BOMB!  the poke is my favorite... get it with the japanese rice and you will not regret it. it also comes in brown rice but the japanese rice will not disappoint.  sweet potato fries are good and the fried oysters are a great way to start your meal so be sure to try it.  prices are not that bad, and you're geting real quality food.  parking sucks but it's a small price to pay for good food.
author: Glenn M.

description: I would describe my views of this place as somewhere near obsession. The cuisine is a fusion of fresh, citrus flavors + great seafood. I honestly feel refreshed when I leave this place. The flavors follow that of the countries bordering the pacific rim, which allows for great fusion cuisine. You'll find anything from South American to Asian flavors. However the genius behind the menu is their ability to put a trendy, modern, city-like, lunch style spin on seafood. And that's just the food...the ambience definitely matches its location very well. It's relatively upbeat, and the decor is pieced together in such a funky yet unique and semi-elegant way. I love love love any dish with hawaiin poke, especially their japanese wasabi bowl. Yum yum yum!!! Unfortunately, I moved to Orange County and can only dream of Pacific Catch at this point =(. If anyone with some authority is reading this, please open a location in oc!!!!!
author: Dina K.

description: I read the mixed reviews on this restaurant and decided to go and check it out myself.  Service was good and fast. I have to agree with everyone that wrote about the Ahi Poke - it was delicious!  The spicy calamari was OK, spicy (which I enjoyed) but not very crispy.  I also had the 3 different types of Taco: the Baja, Shrimp and Mahi Mahi.  I thought the Baja taco was good but the Shrimp and Mahi Mahi was average. I recommend the Mango cheesecake for desert though.  It was very refreshing.  Overall, Pacific Catch was OK. I would go back for the Ahi Poke and the Mango cheesecake but that's it.
author: Natalie S.

description: Multiple my 5 star rating by infinity, this is by far my most favorite restaurant in SF. Our waitress was cheery, helpful and efficient. The food was fresh, decently priced, and amazing. There is so much on the menu, I have to go back 10 more times to figure out my favorite item.  The only negative, which is drowned out by all the positives, is that it's loud. But it's because of the building structure - high ceilings and wood floors. I cannot wait to go back!
author: Iliana T.

description: Went here for lunch and got the Hawaii Poke Wasabi Bowl with brown rice. It took a while but was worth the wait. The edamame and the little fish crackers helped! The sweet potato fries that came with my friend's entree were also very special.
author: Angela K.

description: Went back for a second visit and was seated in the main dining room. The food was just as good as the first time, but the service was much-improved. I believe in second chances and Pacific Catch has earned a spot in my list of my recommended restaurants!
author: Ray C.

description: I dont know what all the fuss is about.  I had the sweet potato fries that everyone mentioned, and the ahi tuna 3 way which included the tuna poke that was also mentioned.  The food is ok and prices are reasonable. Very mediocre chain seafood. but at least there was a small parking lot to the side.
author: Yen C.

description:
the ahi salad is definitely worth a try!

it has a great variety of veg and quite a lot of tuna. i dig the dressing too. it is light and not too overpowering for the fish.
author: SF U.

description:
I love the mixed basket with oysters, shrimp and fish!  They are crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.  They are not too greasy and taste fresh.  Only once were the shrimp overdone.  It comes with the sweet potato fries which I have come to like with fish.  This is good with either a glass of Chardonay or a mixed drink.
When I am headed for the museum, I plan it so that I go here first.  The food here is much much better than the museum and is not as hectic.  Service here is much better.
I tell myself I should try other things on the menu, however, I love this basket!  Enjoy
author: L H.

description: Not sure how to rate this. Maybe I should give it three stars, but I've been there  twice and don't really need to go back. The fish is fresh and good, the prices pretty reasonable, and energy in the place is excellent, but the menu tries a bit too hard. Offer some of the choices without the spicy accoutrement for those of us who have a bit more genteel constitution. The service was also a bit  snotty as though someone who prefers less spicy is somehow not good enough. Place is good, could be better.
author: Shelly C.

description:
Always in the mood to find good seafood, I was excited to eat a full meal at a restaurant that I only sampled at a recent event in San Francisco.

This place has all the ingredients of a great dining experience for me.  Great interior design and a nice, casual atmosphere without sacrificing service.  The sweet potato fries are a great consistency,  not too greasy or soft, and come with two dipping sauces - even though they would be great on their own too.  The sweet chili sauce and wasabi aioli were so delicious that I had a hard time deciding which one to use with each fry.  

I had the ahi poke bowl.  Fair warning, this bowl could feed a small nation.  The poke was a little spicier than I would have liked, and I'll echo requests to cut the cubes into smaller pieces. 

Our waiter was great with wine service, the food was delicious, and I'm already looking forward to coming back for another great meal.
author: Luisa M.

description:
This place is a staple in my life. 

Loves: poke, wasabi bowls, and pisco sours

Hates: the music

Please change the music!!!
author: Sheri E.

description:
ohmigoooood!  This place is so unbelievably good I can't stop thinking about it!  We finally got into the Marina location about a year ago and really enjoyed both our meal and our server - friendly, funny and muy helpful!  The only thing we didn't like was how chummy you needed to be with your neighbor.  Definitely elbow to elbow situation.

Last night we wandered over to the 9th street location after a major hot hike in Marin.  While we really liked the coffee shop which occupied this space previously - I have to say welcome to the neighborhood PC!  The space has a very zen-like feel - great color scheme - awesome bar area - even the bathroom is nice with the bamboo stalks pressed between smoked glass.   

Great little starter vittles (sesame? goldfish and edamame).  We shared an ahi tuna wasabi bowl with brown rice and a mahi mahi taco platter.  The fish in both dishes was incredibly well prepared.  Amazing how good (and simple) fresh fish can be!  The sweet potato fries were delish.  The sesame salad in the bowl was refreshing.  The only thing that wasn't absolutely fabulous were the black beans which weren't bad - just merely came across as an afterthought.   Washing everything down with a cold beer - we were two very happy campers!

Service was friendly and attentive - seems like a good place for families and larger groups - definitely one of our new faves along the Irving corridor!
author: L F.

description:
okay, before i go into the restaurant, i just have one question about parking...when the hell did it become okay for someone to stand in a parking spot to save it for their friends?  wtf?!?!?!?  if you are not a vehicle, you have no business taking up a parking spot.  people like you deserve to have a million bird poopies land of you AND your stinking car...so there!

....now on to the food.  i have to admit, the calamari was pretty dang good!  i would go there for that alone.  i'm not totally sure why some of the slices of lemon were fried up...was i supposed to eat that?  i wasn't sure, so i decided not to take the risk.

the sweet potato fries were okay, although i wasn't sure why they served it with the sweet/spicy sauce....i actually dipped it in the spicy aioli that came with the calamari, and that worked well...while the calamari was good with the sweet/spicy sauce....go figure....maybe it's their ploy to make you order both....

the entree is where they lost me.  the mahi mahi almost didn't look real....and the grill marks were just a bit too perfect....almost like burger king is behind this restaurant or something.  it was also a bit overdone.  the pineapple fried rice was way too mushy.  the the vegetable side was overdone also.

bottom line, i would come here for the calamari, and then go have dinner elsewhere....
author: Miss P.

description: My family and I have been regulars at Pacific Catch for years, and we just realized I had never "yelped" about it! What we love about coming here is the consistency of the menu as well as the nice surprise specials and emphasis on sustainable items. Nothing beats having a delicious meal and not needing to feel guilty about where the food came from! Our favorites are the shrimp ceviche and assortment of sushi rolls, hearty salads, rice bowls and sweet potato fries. They also have a nice selection of kids choices that are simple versions of the adult items, not the sub-standard "kids food" you're likely to find at some trendy restaurants. During shrimp season they feature an amazing soup appetizer called the seafood "chupe" - every time I insist it should be an entree size it's so tasty. Another reason we love going to Pacific Catch is Chelsea - she always makes us feel welcome and treats us like family. Ask to be seated at her station when you go - she's a sweetheart!
author: Rebeca M.

description: Came here after my friends and I got back fcrom caacademy of sciences and there wasn't that much people around 3pm. Sat at the bar and our waiter was reallly nice. It took him a while to get our drinks rdered but we were in no rush or anything. I ordered the vietnamese sammich cooke med. Rare and it was more of a "upscale" viet sammichc that u would get at lees.good flavcor but boy was it hot that I had to take the other half home. If I would havce nknown their jalapeno aioli was flaming hot I would have got it on the nside.their sweet potato fcries and cajun fries were also yummy.
author: Iba N.

description: This is easily one of my favorite go-to places and I order the same thing every time (cause it's that darn good): BBQ salmon sandwich and sweet potato fries with a side of that awesome Thai chili sauce. The ingredients are fresh and simple and I always leave satisfied. I've brought several friends here and sparked their addictions to this place as well.
author: Novi M.

description: Ahi tuna sandwich was excellent and so were the sweet potato fries. The calamari was bland and only edible because of the good sauce it came with.
author: Jason W.

description:
3 stars for:

- The nice decor with comfortable seats. I like their plastic walls things with twigs in them.
- Very friendly staff, polite and helpful. The host graciously answered my questions (more on this below) and the waitress gave good recomendations.
- Super quick! Appetizers came even before the drinks, which didn't take that much to come anyways... main course was there shortly after appetizers were done, which was nice considering how busy the place was.
- Reasonable prices

Not a better rating because of:

- The food. Sadly (?), this is still the main thing about rating a restaurant! Although not horrible, it was not really good either. Fried calamari was ok , but the Ahi Poke and the Salmon were waaaay too salty... I mean everything was: the fish, the sauce, the guacamole, the vegetables, etc...
- The atmosphere: VERY loud. I know, not much the can do there, more to do with the acoustic of the place. But once in a while you could hear the music, and it seems like it was some random radio station playing stupid pop music... considering the decor, you'd expect some more elaborate music, whatever theme they might choose (house, blues, etc...).
- The fact that they had us wait for 10 minutes when they had plenty of 2 tops empty... I understand there might have been organizational concerns like whose section is filled up and such (which was confirmed by the host when I asked about that, even though he found it weird a customer would ask such a thing) so I didn't care, really, but more impatient people might not be so understanding and get annoyed by it.

I would love to try again to see if the oversaltiness was just a one time mistake, but I didn't really enjoy my meal so I probably won't.
I do see good reviews from other Yelpers which help me decide on a 3 stars instead of 2... just giving them the benefit of the doubt!
author: Vithiet L.

description: I went to Pacific Catch for my birthday last night with about 12 of my friends and I enjoyed it. I ordered their daily special which included steak which were nicely cut, asparagus, pineapple fried rice, and onion fries. The orange guava drink was pretty cracking as well. I highly suggest people to try this place, it is not a big chain, for there is only 3 restaurants in the city, with this one being the newest. Some may be upset that it has replaced the Canvas, but I am loving this place as if the Canvas was never here.
author: Edgar G.
